title: Rome Total War
review: Rome Total War is a very good game. The building mechanics of the game are enjoyable. I think its a lot of fun to watch your settlements grow from small villages to massive cities. Although, many of the buildings don't feel useful to me. Not because they weren't useful, but because I didn't feel their effects. The buildings that actually did feel like they give an effect were the walls, military buildings, the roads, and the governor's houses. The politics in the game are exclusive to the Roman factions. The political systems of the game are lackluster. It boils down to just getting more popular and than marching on Rome. The way you raise popularity is by conquering regions. The political system is mostly useless. The other part of the game, and probably the reason you would want it, is the fighting. And I will say, that doesn't disappoint either! Battles in the game are very fun. And watching your faction grow is very satisfying. If you like the total war franchise or grand strategy games, and you haven't played this game, I would suggest trying it out.

title: Rome Total War
review:
It was a great game (I have many, many more hours on the CD version which I bought at launch), and still would be if not for a couple of bugs with the way it interacts with steam.  You can play it just fine, the problem is when you quit out the launcher gets stuck running, and there is no way to exit out of it.  Even going into task manager and ending process will not resolve this, the launcher continues to run (There is no process related to the launcher in task manager).  Thus steam will report the game is running, which prevents you from: restarting the game, verifying files, uninstalling/reinstalling, or logging out of steam.  You can exit and restart steam but the game will still be running.  You can play other games (the launcher doesn't really seem to interfere with anything) but can't relaunch the game.  The only solution is to restart your pc.

The above doesn't trigger immediately so you may think you're in the clear after exiting the game (also if the game crashes, possibly because you alt-tabbed out, you will be able to restart the game), but this bug will trigger after a while and you may have no idea it's still running till hours or even a day later.

title: Rome Total War
review: I first bought this game in 2006 and fell in love with it immediately. It was and still is a perfect blend of turn-based strategy and real-time battles. It takes awhile to get used to the interface, but once you get the hang of it, the game flows like a gentle breeze. Don't make the mistake of auto-resolving the battles, because you'll miss the best half of the Total War experience. The combat is as gritty, in your face, and nail-biting as any historical game you've ever played, and if you win you'll want to drink vino with your winning general. If not, be sure to order the Senate to give him a hero's burial with all the gods and people of Rome weeping as he's laid to rest.

title: Rome Total War
review:
"Gods...I hate Gauls. My grandfather hated them too, even before they put out his eyes. Did you think I'd be out here on the frontier without good reason? Yes, Rome needs a strong frontier. No, Rome doesn't need unwashed barbarians at her gates! So, that's why I'm here, the leader of the Julii: to bring Roman order to stinking Gauls. Revenge? That'd be good too. This war against the Gauls won't last long, and when it's done, I've got plans. This is all about power, power in Rome. Going down that road means dealing with all my rivals: the Senate, the Greeks, those Carthaginian elephant-riders, the Scipii and the Brutii families too. After all, the man who controls Rome rules the world...and one day, I will be Emperor."

My favorite TW game to date.
Good and fun unit diversity for different play styles making all factions feel unique when playing, an amazing and memorable soundtrack, and amazing battles.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is one of the best games I have ever played. After countless hours of game play it still offers a unique experience on each playthrough. There are several different campaigns that can play out in any number of ways, all of which are completely up to you. There are a multitude of units that are specific to each faction, from the elephants of Carthage to the Praetorians of Rome. If you are looking for a start in the Total War franchise; THIS IS IT. 

Short campaigns or long campaigns, easy or legendary; there is no end to the amount of fun a person can have on this game. I have been playing this game since it came out in 2004 and can say that i still enjoy it today.

This game is a MUST for any steam library. I hope, that if you do purchase this game, that you enjoy it as much as I have.

- Cretin

title: Rome Total War
review:
[i]Rome: Total War[/i] is my favorite Total War game. It has the best campaign mechanics of the series, and one of the best modding communities. 

This game is the only Total War where you have to deal with problems such as culture, population, and distance from the capitol while expanding your empire. Buildings from different cultures give negative public order penalties that must be compensated for. Expansion means slowly integrating new cities by building and demolishing buildings. Recruiting units draws from a pool of manpower that is influenced by climate and buildings. On higher difficulties and huge unit sizes this means relying on a populous core to defend the fringes of an empire. Cities further from the capitol have higher corruption, and a public order penalty. This must be compensated for with administrative buildings, religion, and garrisons. All of these factors limit expansion in a realistic way that prevents steam rolling. They also promote playing the game in a more historically accurate way. 

[i]Rome: Total War[/i] lacks the detail and accuracy of [i]Medieval 2: Total War[/i], but that issue is resolved with mods. Mods such as Roma Surrectum II, and Europa Barbarorum correct issues like bronze age Egypt existing during the time of Rome and add an insane amount of detail to the game. They slow down combat, balance the game, and expand on the base games brilliant campaign mechanics. Europa Barbarorum adds a provincial system that represents citizenship, integration, and the effects of slavery, and wealth inequality on the Roman Republic. Roma Surrectum II starts the player off with challenging historical scenarios such as Hannibal being at the gates of Rome.

title: Rome Total War
review:
It blew my mind back in 2003 and now its 2020 and it keeps bringing me back for more. The graphics may be a wee bit dated, but it still shines!

You want to form the Roman Empire? Curb stomp Carthage and usher in Pax Romana? Well this is your game.
Want to re-write history by defeating Rome as Hannibal Barca? This is your game.
Want to restore Alexander the Great's empire as one of the Successor States? This is your game!
Want to be an unwashed barbarian and keep everyone in the dark ages by burning civilization to the ground... This is your game!

Go forth and CONQUER!

p.s. The there is a mod out for this that covers the Bronze Age and by god is it AMAZING!

title: Rome Total War
review: Perhaps the best strategy game of its time. Plays well today, even though it is dated, largely because of the effectiveness of AI, the general gameplay -- the combination of Risk-esque battle map mechanics plus local battlefield control -- and the ingenious scalability of the graphics, the later which takes advantage of the minimal need for model detail when zoomed out from your battlefield army. In other words: plays well and looks good, even today! Worth the $$$

title: Rome Total War
review:
Not sure which I have more hours on, this or TES IV: Oblivion, but 15 years later I still come back to it. Nothing for me is as rewarding as following one soldier in a battle of thousands, so I can see how his story ends. 

At the same time I love being able to completely destroy an army, something much harder to do in later games.

City got a plague going? Better start recruiting some spies so  you can go infect your enemies : p

One of your big cities is rioting? Take your garrison out of it, let it riot, then sweep back in and kill 3/4 of the population. Now everybody is happy and you get shit tons of money :D

It's not a perfect game in that regard, but it is the perfect strategy game.

review:
Reviewing games I played a long time ago:

I can't emphasize enough how many hour I played this when I was a teenager. It's quite simply one of the best games ever made and the transition to full 3D, at the time, was a tremendous success. I still remember, during the Shogun and Medieval games thinking it would be impossible to have this scale with all models in 3D. I was naively wrong of course. This version also has the expansions which are also quite good. Mods are also a must.

title: Rome Total War
review:
The first Total War game I ever played. I didn't play it on release, but I did have a Mac, and games where super limited. Luckily, Feral Interactive ported Rome Total War to mac. Thus began my love of military history, and Total War. Frankly.... this game is amazing. If you have a potato and want to throw away hundreds (thousands if like me you jumped over to wikipedia to research each faction's real life history.) of hours of your life, this is the game for you.

I have a new computer now, and I own most of the total war games, including the sequels... but lets be honest with ourselves. Rome Total War 1 is damn near perfect as a strategy game.

review:
played as house of Julia and owned a settelent called corduba in hispania. Ever since I took it from carthage, they have always been a problem. Constant low public order and riots. I had the entire city garrisoned like 70% peasents and 25% townsgaurd with 1 samnite gladiator.

I sent a governer over there to see if that was the problem, but no the best i could get was 70-75% public order. I had enough so i removed all the garrison and let it become a rebel settlement. The settlement was later known as the gladiator uprising. about 8 unit of veliti gladiators. 

Point is, this story is the retarded version of spartcus. They would send out wave after wave of gladiators while i had my untrained and dumbass peasents in the 1000s fight the gladiators. It was equivlent of like 80 mma fighters vs  240 average blokes per unit. I remember on the right side I had aboaut 1440 peasents and simply just charging them at the gladiator units made them break. My favorite battle in rome total war.

title: Rome Total War
review: Gods...I hate Gauls. My grandfather hated them too, even before they put out his eyes. Did you think I'd be out here on the frontier without good reason? Yes, Rome needs a strong frontier. No, Rome doesn't need unwashed barbarians at her gates! So, that's why I'm here, the leader of the Julii: to bring Roman order to stinking Gauls. Revenge? That'd be good too. This war against the Gauls won't last long, and when it's done, I've got plans. This is all about power, power in Rome. Going down that road means dealing with all my rivals: the Senate, the Greeks, those Carthaginian elephant-riders, the Scipii and the Brutii families too. After all, the man who controls Rome rules the world...and one day, I will be Emperor.

title: Rome Total War
review:
The Rome: Total War Collection includes the base game of Rome: Total War, and its two expansion packs; Barbarian Invasion and Alexander. 

Rome: Total War was the first 3-D game of the now incredibly popular and critically acclaimed grand strategy series, Total War. As the first 3-D game in the series, it set precedents. Ones that are still felt in the series today. Many claim that this is one of, if not the best in the series, and it isn't hard to see why. The main selling point of Total War has always been its unique combination of turn based empire manager, and real time battles. This core game play is nicely exemplified by Rome. It may be a bit clunky and poorly optimized, but a little help from the steam forums, and a few hours of practice, will make you an expert at it. Controlling units of an army, utilizing real strategy and tactics, such as the importance of the High Ground, calvary charges, and phalanx formations, are all impactful and fun features. Sieges are a personal favorite of mine. The empire management is pretty solid, even considering its age. The juggling of culture, public order, and public health in your cities adds a challenge that isn't too difficult. Still, its not as flushed out as the combat, where he position of the enemy's shields affect your arrow effectiveness, for example. All in all, Rome: Total War is a great start for people who want to get into the series, and is a very solid and deeply enjoyable experience that'll hold your attention for hours on end (provided you can get it to run).

Now on to the Expansion Packs

Rome: Total War - Barbarian Invasion may be one of, if not the, greatest Total War expansions/DLC. It provides an entirely different campaign and experience to the base game. It adds in features that are still in Total War games, such as religion or hordes. It is a noticeable difficulty spike/challenge compared to the base game as well. Play as either one of the two halves of the Roman Empire during its (well, the West's at least) Twilight years, or as one of the Barbarian factions. Essentially, Barbarian Invasion is a fantastic addition to the series, and could be counted as its own game, seeing how good it is.

Finally, Rome: Total War - Alexander, is the weaker of the two expansions. I know, ending the review on a high note, aren't I. I hold no real ill will towards Rome - Alexander, it is just that its uninteresting compared to BI. No real new features or mechanics are added. Its just Rome: Total War, but instead you play as Alexander the Great's Macedonia, and have to conquer all that he did in the allotted time. Perfectly serviceable on its own, but compared to BI, bland.

In conclusion, Rome: Total War is a great game that you should consider picking up if you are into empire management and/or RTS games.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This has to be one of, if not the greatest TBS/RTS games ever created. It also has a fantastic BGM that will get your adrenaline pumping as your soldiers either march or start laying into your foes!

The best part I think is that it the game play never gets old because no 2 play through are the exactly the same and even 16 years on, I'm still learning new things about this game!

The game is also very easy to mod if you want to unlock the unplayable factions, change the stats of units or give additional effects to buildings. you can find plenty of youtube videos on how to do this.

If this game isn't in your library. your'e really missing out on something special!

title: Rome Total War

title: Rome Total War
review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#238 out of 558)... it's time for Rome Total War.

Rome has long been lauded as the premier entry in the venerable Total War series. Personally I don't quite agree with that assessment, but when it comes to ancient era warfare, I have zero qualms about declaring Rome: Total War to represent the best Creative Assembly has yet managed to produce.

Which is another way of saying that the long-anticipated sequel, Rome 2: Total War, is absolute garbage. But I digress.

Rome Total War represents the best RTS take on the ancient world, but be aware that this game has not aged particularly well. When it comes to the factions, Rome is a mess--almost entirely ahistorical. It often feels as though the campaign was crafted by someone who had never so much as read an encyclopedia entry on the Roman Empire, and is utterly nonsensical: the vast and dynamic empire of yore is instead depicted as a loose alliance of three, largely autonomous noble houses, constantly vying for supremacy. Don't think about it too much: it's rubbish. Thankfully there are a great many excellent mods that correct this... bizarre creative interpretation, and I strongly advise that you ignore the vanilla game altogether, and only ever deal with the mods. Personally I would recommend the Europa Barbarorum mod.

Beyond that, several aspects of the game feel a bit clumsy by modern standards: diplomacy is largely an afterthought, unit balance is all over the place, camera controls are unnecessarily clumsy, etc., etc. But even so, Rome Total War manages to provide an epic spectacle -- all the more impressive for the fact that it can render enormous battles, comprising tens of thousands of soldiers, on even the most modest of today's hardware. If you're looking for an excellent historical RTS, or are fond of the Roman era in general, Rome: Total War should most definitely be your first stop.

Note: Also played on PC, sans-Steam.

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of many of the best war strategy games I've ever played. It's like age of empires and civilization. You have to act very carefully, You can even go into the actual battle and control your troops if you really wanted to but there are things wrong with this game as well. 

1. The Romans are responsible for the killing of christians.

2. They crucified Jesus on the cross. (Because of what we did to Jesus through our Sin)

3. They were cold blooded killers that showed no mercy to their enemies.

4. Sent people into the arena to be slain for sport and entertainment, mostly christians!

There is more that I can point out but overall the game is really good, just don't like that they serve false gods. But I can recommend this game, just blot out or your ears all of the dodgy stuff if you buy and play this game. The best part about this game that there are console commands to make factions christian, otherwise just remove the shrines and replace it with christian ones. Most Roman (eastern empire) citizens/leaders ect are christian but some are pagan, you can choose to make every city and every leader christian, just look up my thread "Christianity Factions?" This will show all suitable traits for Christians. As much as I didn't like the Romans, I love that this game also supports Christianity so thumbs up from me. One last thing, DO NOT BUY Rome Total War 2, too expensive as well as an extremely dodgy story plot. There's also a blood and gore DLC in the second one!? Violence that is overpowering in gaming dulls the conscience not being able to know what is right and what is wrong. Don't get the second one, waste of money.

5/5

Game Rating: M (Violence)

Genre: Strategy

RELEASE DATE: 22 Sep, 2004

title: Rome Total War
review:
Great Total War game. Battles are pretty great for its age, and require some thinking. Campaign map feels large, but not to the point where your grinding to conquer everything fast enough. Just make sure you betray the Senate and seize power before the other factions get to large! I made that mistake and had to reconquer all of the Balkans, Anatolia, and Crimea. Not a good time.
Only thing I disliked about the game was the "Squalor" town modifier. Super stupid and annoying, and was just utterly bothersome to deal with. It'd decrease by towns happiness slowly, and never stop. Only way to deal with it was to recruit a bunch of peasant units in the town, walk them out to the middle of nowhere, and disband them. Was that what the developers intended? I have no clue but it was pretty unprofessional. Regardless, no other issues, and its a great game.

7/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is awesome! It has simple mechanics and provides a great experience. This game is a classic 

but..

it runs terrible on some modern laptops.

In my case, the GPU I have is nvdia geforce 940mx, I get a higher FPS from Medieval 2 than in Rome.

If you experience lag especially in the campaign map you'll have to download a dll file in order to remove the lag, you can download it from here: https://steamcommunity.com/app/4760/discussions/0/412448792372318074/

The downside in using the dll file is that it'll visually remove fire effects from arrows, artillery projectiles will be invisible, the shadows will also look very pixelated.

The game crashes when I finish large battles but this was resolved once I fixed the resolutions of both the battle map and the campaign map to be the same.

Overall other than the hardware and performance issues, this is a good game, I do recommend buying it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Fantastic classic old game, but you CANNOT RUN IT on windows 10!
When I saw this game in Steam store, I was really thrilled and excited - this is a classical best off total war game ever! YOu can imagine my disapointment, when I bought the game and it simply did not run!
After 5 hours of searching, trying and discussions, combined with plenty of tools download and experiments with windows I found out: Problem is caused by Microsoft update. OK but Steam is selling the produict as functional game whitch simply does not run. 
Cheap option is to create own preference text folder, copy and paste solution from official TW sites (https://forums.totalwar.com/discussion/160589/issues-when-trying-to-launch-rome-total-war-on-windows-10-workaround-provided) whitch makes your game run but in my case, on monitor with resolution over 2560x1440 / 160 HZ tis can be run only in window (with parameter "-ne" in steam launch parameter option, whitch causes to duplicate the mouse cursor on desktop so instead of acting with generals and unists you alltime finght with your screen desktop icons of other games and programms. On steam forums you can read that this problem persists over 4 years and they did not do a crap about it - making a simple script solving this, saving you sweat, panic and anger, should take few hours max. 
So Game is and was always FANTASTIC, and I ttotally DONT RECOMMEND BUYING IT in current state of affair.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I've been playing this game since it released and it still hasn't lost its luster!

Pros:
Rewarding campaigns
Very fun combat
Good Variety of units for most factions
VERY replayable
Auto-manage settlements makes managing taxes/buildings/armies a breeze
Basic game options allow for more realism or less realism in battle to help curate your experience

Cons:
AI can be stupid sometimes - both in campaign map and on the battlefield (just be careful of the quirks and you should be fine)
Campaigns tend to slow down after the first big expansion you accomplish since it can be difficult to get troops to the edges of your empire without ships or roads
Settlements can be tedious to manage (if you decide not to automanage)
Settlements are hard to control once the population is too big (expect revolts that you won't be able to avoid in the late game)

Conclusion:
A classic game worth a buy! I come back to this game regularly. What Creative Assembly was able to accomplish was way ahead of their time and in my opinion it beats Rome 2 Total War

title: Rome Total War
review: If you've never played a Total War game, this is the best place to start. Early game does a good job of explaining most of the basic mechanics and offers enough of a challenge without feeling unfair, evolving into a more complex and larger game as it progresses. Game-play consists of making turns on a board, the player and AI developing cities, building troops, sending spies and diplomats to neighboring cities, and initiating battles as they attempt to grasp control of the area, then those battles being played out (or auto-resolved if you choose) on a battlefield. This is where the game truly shines as you control hundreds of troops, either fighting in an open space, attacking a stronghold, or defending your own. The scale of battle here is awesome and evolving strategies as plans succeed and fail keep them tense from start to finish. Graphically, the game is starting to show it's age, but with everything maxed out easily on modern computers, the immersion and fun-factor isn't effected. Soundtrack is top notch. Only downside I've found in my time playing is that there is a lack of direct explanations for certain elements to the UI and the developing of cities. Overall, this is a must play for strategy fans interested in the series.

title: Rome Total War
review: Despite somewhat dated graphics and clunky mechanics ,  the original Rome: Total War is still a solid entry in the TW portfolio I'd go as far as it Almost as good as rome 2 in gameplay Its much more simple, and straight into it, But tthat means your able to have 8 hr campaign ,And achieve a victory ,Unlike in later total war titlles were its taken me 10-60 hrs to do one.,Sometimes simplicity is more enjoyable than Complex learning curves . There's just something fun about rising to the heights of power as one of the three main Roman branch families And heading north into Germany , France and one day The UK  and crushing everyone around you ,asbording their culture into your own, Hiring mercanries to bolster your army size, of local barbains,I must admit,The barbian invasion is my favorite dlc Of the two (Alexander and Barbarian invasion) And its set in fall of rome, Just like Attila:Total war , Is set in the ideticall period, with same factions and units, Atttila might as well Be Updated moderised version of barbarian Invasion. Wait for sale it usaullly goes on sale around £2.99, And worth picking up if you like History and indulging in Ancient warfare

title: Rome Total War
review: This is one of the best ageing game - ever. Whereas a lot of old games feel clunky or boring, RTW is still a fine  strategy game with a mix of real time battle and turn based strategy, without needing contrived stories or cut-scenes to fluff it up. It was a great game in 2004, and it's still today. Well done, Creative.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Still rocks. Play quasi-historically or make your own "What if...?" story. 
I really wish newer TW titles let you play the 'open' campaign style like you can in this one.

Resolutions up to 1920x1080 can be added with a simple .cfg line change (if they don't already appear in the menu), higher resolutions probably work fine but I haven't tested them personally. If it's 4:3/ 16:9/ 16:10 you're probably good.

GREAT music, super ambiance and general feel, models and textures are of course clunky by today's standard, but the whole visual sum of this game is so well put together that it's a good looking game to this day imo.
Enhancing with Nvidia/ Radeon AA/ AF/ etc helps.

A great way to spend an afternoon or evening. I will probably play this until it just doesn't work any more!

title: Rome Total War
review:
I have an illustrious gaming career. I have played, Frogger, Pacman, the original Doom, minesweeper, Mario the Legend of the Seven Stars, every Mario game in general, every zelda game, Warcraft II and III, Age of Empires, Total War Warhammer I and II. Machines, every Ratchet and Clank, every F-Zero, Metal Fatigue, Halo, Call of Duty, some of the sports games, Chess, Sim City, loads of indy games, Every Banjo Kazooie, Every GTO, Fully Modded Skyrim with 250 mods, BUT THIS IS MY FAVORITE GAME. The other Total Wars are good except for Rome II! Well, now that one is decent because of years continual support. What makes Rome Total War so good is the magical gaming recipe that floated down from the sky into the laps of the devs. Don't let the hours fool you i have about 1500 hours across all installs on computers from years past. 

If you want to play this game on a modern PC you need to do two small things. 
1. Watch this video https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8dGlog9mvKs and from the video description get the file and follow the instruction of the video(very easy) 

2. Go the "preferences" and change the resolution to your display size. probably 1920X1080. It will be lines to change. (very easy). 

3?? Profit!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Avoid like the plague! 

Horribly optimized for newer hardware, filled with performance issues, my pretty decent modern pc can not fast forward a 4.000 soldier battle with more than 10 fps when i can play games like rome 2 with full sized armies on 60 fps without drops.

From what i understand they released a patch for the steam version that made the game nearly unplayable on some newer systems and that was a few years ago or at least a couple of years, and they just don't give a shit about it.
Shit tier developers.
I can play the cd version of  the game with no lag at all, with 10k soldies battles but this shit on steam is trash.

DO NOT WASTE YOUR MONEY.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I played this back in high school when it came out and just purchased it again.

Man! It is an unspeakably good game. Of course it has its shortcomings like anything else but the graphics hold up well and the strategy side of it is very satisfying. When I was young I used to just build mass armies and swarm but now that I'm older I was a lot more thoughtful about how I went about things and I was happy to see that making smart decisions and outthinking your opponent really makes a huge difference.

10/10.

title: Rome Total War

title: Rome Total War
review:
I've been playing this game since 2nd grade, and I still play it (I'm 18 now.) The graphics haven't aged all to well, but in the gameplay has aged perfectly. There is no other Total War game I have ever played that made me feel I was commanding actual people. When I flank the enemy line and slam them with my cavalry, I can see the impact they make, and some people flying in the air. There's several different cultures. There's barbarians, carthaginians, egyptians, greeks, nomads, and romans. Each offers different gameplay, and you generally need to play differently and compensate for the different cultures. What really sets this game above the others is the modding community. Byfar my favorite mod is Europa Barbarorum, it is a historical and realistic overhaul. There's numerous other mods available; I've seen even seen a Starwars overhaul mod. The mod community is still alive, comparable to the Skyrim modding community. I've put about 2,000 hours into this game including steam, and I don't regret any of it. This game is extremely hard to put down. In my opinion is is the best Total War game ever made.

pros
1. you get the ingame console
2. diverse set of factions
3. immense replayability excluding mods
4. insane replayability including mods
5. active modding comunity
6. engine/physics system
7. graphics enhancing mods

cons
1. graphics aren't 10/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
It's an overall good strategy game, however, public order makes no sense. Whenever you move military units, it tends to piss everyone off, and when you make building that increase public order then the city revolts. There is no upside to gaining a large empire. But it is a fun game none the less and it's the first strategy game I ever played and I love it despite its flaws. 7/10 would recommend.
PS the camera in battles will piss you off.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Nothing more fun than calmly building up your empire one turn, then the next, having three of your cities besieged by your "allies," losing one due to it being undermanned, losing a 10-star general in the second due to bad decisions, and gambling it all on holding the point in the last and finding out that that's the best strategy. Until finally, you travel all across europe and recapture settlements and sell off your competition as slaves to your various cities.
10/10 do not trust germania ever again.

title: Rome Total War
review: Still the best in the series. Rome II is just eye-candy. Should've given more detail to historical matters in Rome II (like get rid of chariots for Egyptians & Seleucids, and make them actual post-Alexander phalanx armies).  So, Rome: TW and Barbarian Invasions the apex.

title: Rome Total War
review:
military and economic development leads to fine armies and battles can be paused for precision control over real time battles and realistic fighting.  Regular calvary tactics like flanking and charging from behind ranks to finish off engagement is the finest.  I play this game from everyone, Briton and Egypt are the easiest to play from even on the hardest level.  Carthage and Parthia are the toughest in my estimation.  Germany is fun and when you get Berserkers you won't want to build anything else.  They rock, only Spartan Hoplites under greeks can compete.
diplomats early and assassins throughout, diplomats can get all the trading rights you need early.
assassins are simply some aspect of the game that needs to be utilized, kill enough generals and you get master of assassins (its an awesome title that's enough) gives you bonus.
Generals hanging around in cities with libraries academies and universities gain all kinds of entourage members, mathematicians, doctors, artisans, traders (bonus to trade), legendary warriors (lowers recruiting charges) etc.
Fine game.  Every other game gets compared and the only ones close are panzer general and Shogun (shogun is awesome but Rome sorted out all the choppiness of battle and other movements)
Warcraft 3 is warcraft 3 and its unfair to compare, but , I don't know which I like better at the moment.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Your scouting army is ambushed in the middle of the desert by superior enemy forces. Instead of running, you decide to play out the battle to see, what units of the enemy has (that´s what scouts are for after all). Five minutes into the battle suddenly a short animation is played. A burning pig is trampled to death by elephants. Then comes a short message: "your general has fallen". Disturbed by the loss of General Piggy, your mercenaries are shaken and flee the battle.

10/10, best Total War in the series.

title: Rome Total War
review: This is tied with Medieval 2 for being the best Total War game. The graphics are a bit dated but they aren't bad by any means. If you can get past that, then this is where Total War's gameplay peaked. The RTS side of the game is fantastic and fluid, while the campaigns (the main campaign as well as Alexander and Barbarian Invasion) are very in-depth, immersive and sufficiently, although not perfectly, historical. As for the various other mechanics, all of them are fun and satisfying. There's enough complexity to keep the game interesting throughout the playthrough, but enough simplicity as to not overwhelm. Overall this is one of the best RTSs of all time and an amazing strategy game full of meaningful and interesting choices. 10/10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Steam says I've played this game for 72 hours. Steam Lies. 
I've owned Rome Total War since the game first came out about 16 years ago. It's one of my favorite of the entire Total War series. 
I haven't played Rome 2 yet, but frankly ever since Empire Total War the franchise seemed to go downhill. Too much paid for DLC to unlock factions and not allowing players to take control. I doubt I'll ever purchase Rome 2 unless it goes for sale for under $10. 

But this isn't about Rome 2, this is about the original Rome Total War. It's in depth strategy, balancing the whims of The People and The Senate, or about taking a tribe of so-called Barbarians to glory in beating down the gates of so-called civilized people. 
The graphics look like it takes 256 mb of RAM, which back in 2004 meant I had to upgrade my computer to run this game. But this game wasn't about the incredible graphics, (which for the time looked fantastic), but it's for the strategy and tactics. Plus being a bit of a history nerd, I enjoyed the historical notes of the units and other tidbits of history. 

Perhaps it is nostalgia, perhaps it is that I started playing Total War franchise in 2000 when the original Shogun TW came out, and I've owned and played most of the TW titles, usually buying them as soon as they were released (before I got older and realized if I just waited a couple months I'd save a lot of money). 

If you are wanting a great strategy game, you need to get Rome Total War and Medieval 2 Total War. (Medieval Total War was fun, but Medieval 2 added a lot of strategy, especially with troop movement mechanics).

I think one of the things that is not stated enough that I have seen is it is one of those games that you can just go back to a lot. I have never had a moment where I was not enjoying my time playing the game. I also would recommend trying online a bit more too. I was never the best at battles but this game always made it fun even if I lost. Anyways, this game is cheap and you have no reason not to try it and really get to see why the total war series is good.

title: Rome Total War
review: I played this back when it came out, before Steam was a big thing and everything was on Cd-Roms. I put about 5 years playing every day after school into this. This game is dated, the graphics do not hold up to current standards, and some could argue that the system it uses for AI is flawed. I get that, it's not the pinnacle of gaming. BUT, it is very fun. Custom battles give you unlimited options in terms of army building and unit control. The campaigns can be long or short, and the simplicity of it makes for a relaxing stroll through Rome, rather than a fast-paced stress-inducing nightmare. The DLC is still new to me as I only owned the base game as a kid, so I have nothing to say about it. If you enjoy RTS games and are annoyed by the shift they are taking, this nostalgic yet entertaining game is for you.

I've come back again.  Not so bad this time, but still...I find myself just relishing the details of settlements, alliance, murder, espionage etc.  Custom battles are all their own fun, as well.  The game really delivers on two different fronts and I appreciate the balance this game has with maximum enjoyment.

title: Rome Total War
review:
[h1] ROME TOTAL WAR REVIEW [/h1]

Where do I start? I've been playing this game on and off for as long as I can remenber, and all of my memories on this game have been truly fantastic and some of the greatest gaming memories that I have!  Rome total war is one of those games where you cant help but keep coming back too, maybe it is the mesmerising soundtrack, or perhaps the highly addictive week long campaigns; perhaps its the strategic element that it is drilled into the game, or perhaps. Perhaps its a mixture of everything...

[h1] Campaign [/h1]

The greatest thing in Rome 1 is by far the campaigns, you are plunged into a land of bloody conflict, a land of political intrigue, a land of inter-house dilemas, a land of ploys and plots, a land of *total war*
What is amaazing about this games campaign is the fact that the world is quite literraly your oyster, you can choose to invade anywhere at any time, kill anyone at any place, and wage war on any country for any personal reason. Many a times I have watched my empires form and my empires fall, there is no better feeling than slaughtering a rival faction that has wronged you in the past, or perhaps the feeling of re-conquering what was once your soverign territory, this game has mixed emotions. You actually feel a pang of sadness as you have created an empire through bloody strife and conflict as you remenber the hundreds of thousands of soldiers who died and laid down their lives for you to establish your empire. Or perhaps you wont feel this, maybe you wont have a huge militaristic empire, perhaps you will have a small but economically powerful kingdom filled with merchants and trades, or maybe you just want one or two small kingdoms and you just want to survive, after all. Total war is not for everyone...

[h1] BATTLES [/h1]

The maps in rome 1 are huge and give the player a great empty canvas of strategy at their disposal. The battles feel unique, and they feel like battles, you know that if you loose a certain battle then it will result in a crippling blow for your empire, perhaps your capital is under seige and if you loose then your faction leader dies thus morale is diminished to a minute fraction. Or perhaps you have sent out an expeditionary force to some far off land and have established a small but secure foothold which is under attack from a near unknown force. Each battle has a meaning, and each battle has its own ending. Perhaps your heroic soldiers will become 'men of the hour' birthing new heroes and generals for your faction. No units are over powered everything can counter something, so this game is balanced...

[h1] CONCLUSION [/h1]

This game truly is a master-peice of a game and i would recommend it to anyone who likes mass exterminating the populus. But unfortunatly it does not run on some pc's on windows 10, and the graphics are outdated and the frames are unfortunatly capped at what seems to be 30fps. If not for theise glithces/ graphical limitations then his game would be a solid 10/10. But unfortunatly I have to drop the final score down to a 9.5/10!

title: Rome Total War
review:
I absolutely love this game.
If it wasn't for Medieval 2 Total war, this would be my favorite Total War game ever. 

The graphics overall has a certain pop and saturation to it that makes it look really nice and vibrant, not only that but the game focuses more on an artstyle than realism, although I bet it looked realistic at the time. Theres so many mods that improve the game of sorts by making it historically accurate, and makes the units look more historically correct. But, theres a balance that games have to strike between realism and appearance with unit graphics, or realism and mechanics with gameplay. Nothing against the realistic mods, its good that they are there, because they are amazing in their own right. But, whenever I play a mod and look at the troops, i cant really get attached to them like I can in the original game. Again, nothing against the mods for that, its just that this game has such an iconic look that is only there through time. 
The graphics for this game is like a fine, old, red wine.

The gameplay, although having its flaws with pathing and AI at times, is still something that is really fun to play with. Maybe I would be more critical on the AI if it wasnt for the fact that they haven't really improved in almost two decades. Medieval 2 total war made good improvements, but afterwards things went downhill more than uphill. Its sad that this AI is representative for the time that this game came out. Because I can only imagine how perfect this AI could be if just given todays technology, and maybe more time to develop it. 
Outside of the AI, the fact that this is one of the only strategy games that has turn based civ managment and real time army strategy in one. I dont think theres anything like that other than Total War. Theres been a few games that has tried to do what this game has done for its series. But it never really got that click unlike what this game had. 

Although The Roman campaign is really the only super interesting campaign in the game, all the other factions, even the unplayable ones, are pretty fun to play as, just for the unit and building variety. Though, I wished there was more to them. Luckily mods are there for the rescue. Even though you could see that and be like "wow only one kind of unique campaign? Terrible game" you have to realize that this hasn't really changed afterwards. Some of the games afterwards has even had no unique campaigns in them. This doesn't really excuse Rome for just only the Roman campaign, I know, but like I said before, the other campaigns are still ones that are kind of fun to play as just for some variety.

The music in this game is absolutely phenomenal. To me this soundtrack beats out any other games soundtrack in this series of games. Theres some real pounding bangers that gets you hyped in battle, and theres some that are just genuinely really nice to listen to. I dont know the names of the songs, never really looked into them. But you know what song comes on when it plays. And the songs pull just the right emotions for the right moments. If you first hear that defeat music, it strikes you a bit. It hits ya different so to say. And for me at least, it invokes me to avenge my fallen bretheren.

Sadly this game seems to crash a few times and some people can have difficulties to start the game. But that happens with every aged game sadly.

I have went through a whole novel and I havent even went through all the parts in this game. 

Lets just leave it there and just buy the damned game, why are you here, buy. Buy it.

Basically, if you haven't played this game, give it a try.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is an excellent strategy game with a great (even though its old) mod seen. This game also being one of my favorites of all time since I started playing on launch day in 2004. And In my opinion this is still the best Total War game. With a fantastic music score and great strategic gameplay despite its age.

Unfortunately I cannot recommend it for Windows 10 users. The game has (of course) bad dev support. Most if not all of the original devs on this game no longer work at CA. Modern CA also has little to no interest in getting this game working on modern hardware with their focus being on creation and support of the modern titles. Which in my view this is  understandable, it's still a little disappointing. The game's lack of support has left the game in a state where its a real guess if your going to be able get up and running or not. There a lot of community fix's for it but these are not always a guarantee of solving an issue.  And many may never be fixed. 

If you're willing to put up put up with a lot of headache to get the game working, there a ton of fun to be had here. But if you're not, I would avoid it for now.

title: Rome Total War
review:
8 years after playing it for the first time, Rome: Total War remains my favorite Strategy game, period.  Multiplayer is sparsely populated in 2020, the pathfinding is awful, the AI runs a marathon around your walls in defensive sieges and loses 50 percent of their army without firing a shot.  I guess the AI isn't much worse then Rome II huh... 

On paper this game is terrible but I still love it.  My fascination with Classical Mediterranean history was spurred by my time investment in this game, and I spent many happy hours competing in multiplayer and conquering those pesky OP Egyptians. 11/10 would spam Oliphaunts any day.

Oh and the modding community is still fairly active for this game which is pretty cool.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Fantastic real-time strategy (RTS) game with a massive amount of playable value.  I have played hundreds of hours on different computer systems and am still  learning of new things I can do.  I have yet to try so many things because of how big this game is, and the instant-combats allow for really fast engagement that make you feel like a real army.

As a top-down game, where you don't control the individual characters, it can be frustrating at times watching your AI, and a few small bugs do not help.  Regardless, I have tried to get my friends to play me in this game because it is so good.  I might say do not buy this game unless you have time for the long run.  Even a preset instant-combat can take 30 minutes or more, and I have had many hour+ invasions...  There are AI auto-manage systems, though, so you definitely do not have to sit for hours.   I also recommend having a decent CPU/GPU because having thousands of units on screen is tough on your machine.  A poor CPU/GPU will run, but with low resolution and polygon count.

title: Rome Total War
review:
[h1]Grandiose & Stimulating / Recommended for all RTS & 4X Fans[/h1]

+ One of the more accessible entries in the Total War franchise
+ A good umber of historical factions to unlock
+ UI is intuitive & easy to acclimate to
+ Like other entries in the series, the game does an incredible job of blending both the necessity of city management & the thrill of real-time, tactical combat
+ Focuses on large-scale strategy & smaller-scale tactics in equal measure
+ Public order is a welcome mechanics that can keep an ambitious player in check
+ Household management adds a social layer to an already deliciously complex strategy game (perhaps not by the standards of the modern entries, but still very complex & gratifying, nonetheless)
+ Different units have their own, sensible, strengths & weaknesses
+ Scale of battles absolutely cannot be overstated
+ Factions enjoy many differences between them, making each playthrough feel fresh & unique to an extent
+ Runs beautifully on modern hardware with no real compatibility issues

- Dated visuals; although they were quite good at the time of release, they don't hold up quite as well to a modern audience
- Some of the Senate missions are borderline impossible to complete (if one is a sensible player)
- Enemy AI is often laughably at best
- Naval combat is automated only

[h1]LockeProposal's Big Day Out[/h1]

[url=https://steamcommunity.com/groups/bigdayout]Community Group[/url]
[url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/7611703/]Curator Page[/url]

title: Rome Total War
review: If you ever dreamed of riding on horseback through the Old World slaying barbarians and conquering neighboring cities with your unstoppable legions then this is the game for you.  I've slayed millions in my unending campaigns, I've been a ruler of Egypt, a General loved by the masses, holding gladiatorial games in my name because I'm filthy rich.  Yes, countless hours thinking of new strategies and new ways of back stabbing the Senate of Rome so I can place myself on the throne.  Rebels?  Enslaved.  Stand against my siege?  Exterminate the populace.  Ambush my legions?  Clear Victory.  An excellent strategy game, an old classic.

title: Rome Total War
review: Since I was a little girl, I have loved Rome: Total War. The dynamics and layers of the game are undeniably well-done. Battles are highly interactive, but not excessively. Although it is an older Total War game, it is one of my absolute favorites of the Total War series. The guidance from the Senate and from tips/advice allowed me to start playing this game at a very young age and still thoroughly enjoy myself (although I wouldn't recommend it to anyone younger than 12-13 years of age). As a noob when it comes to strategy games and this genre of gaming, of all the Total War games that I have played, this one definitely gives the most guidance and assistance (to noobs like me). Great, great, GREAT game!

title: Rome Total War
review: I like all of the TOTAL WAR series and can see an improvement in each one from SHOGUN onwards. ROME is best when not played by one of the Roman factions- which you can access if you've played the basic game to a certain point. I especially enjoyed being Carthage and using elephants in battle (even if they scare easily and run amock.). There comes a point however when it either gets too easy as your forces are supreme, or else it bogs down in endless rebellions, but the early game where you set up your empire is very fascinating stuff. I try to mix things up and try to create an empire using only a limited suite of units or use a power with disadvantages (Britain, Egypt etc have commanders in chariots which seem get the general killed at the first opportunity so avoid them).  It's now a pretty 'old' game compared to more modern ones, but still worth a go, and better than say the new WARCRAFT version which is frankly a bit silly.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Old but gold.
It's incredibly simple compared to the new games, obviously, but that's not a bad thing in this instance.
Even if the AI can be laughable, the game is still very enjoyable.
Your pre-battle general speeches are probably the best of the series, at least for the Roman factions.
The Greek, Barbarian, and Eastern ones aren't as strong, but that's not a major complaint.
Over all, if you want a older but solid strategy experience, this would be a good choice, especially if you're curious about the genre but aren't sure where to start.

title: Rome Total War
review:
===============================================================================
I N T R O 
===============================================================================

The year is 329 BC. Italy. Warring city-states vie for power and superiority over their neighbours. The Senate and People of Rome control The Latin states…but enemies surround them. The Republic stands at a crossroads in history… 

Bombasticus Maximus: Romans!  Senators!  Friends!  Latium is firmly under the rule of the Senate and People of Rome! The Latin people are now one! Not since noble Brutus drove out the last King, have we known such a glorious day. But now, my friends, in this hour of glory, we must be on our guard. To the south, treacherous Greeks and Samnites block our trade!Tarquinii groans beneath the tyrant’s heel!  That tyrant threatens Rome! Will we abandon Tarquinii? And now barbarians raid from the north. Burning and pillaging roman lands! Shall we let danger fester and grow? Or will we act as Romans? With courage and dignity. Remember. We are the Sons of Mars! As senate leader I call upon Tribunes Gaius Julius and Decius Brutus to smash the Gauls and relieve Tarquinii. All those in favour say I.

Senators: AVE! AVE! AVE! (...) Infamy! Shame! (...) No! NO! NO!(...) WAR! WAR! WAR! WAR! “I!” (Followed by cheering)

===============================================================================

===============================================================================

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is a really brilliant game that still looks and feels slick despite being over a decade old. The gameplay is immersive both on the level of individual battles and the overarching map of europe and I love all the historical detail. The main issue with it is the, in some cases, apparently stupid AI but honestly this isn't as bad as I've experienced in other games and its good enough to give a satisfying single player experience (if also a powerful illusion that you're a military genius). 
I've recently come back to what was a childhood game for me and can say it still impresses me and the top difficulty settings are well balanced.

title: Rome Total War
review: This game is not only a nostalgic game, but also one that stands the test of time. Once people look past the graphics, they will find and innovative, unique, complex, immersive, and entertaining game underneath. The battles and balancing are incredible (minus the hoplites which are overpowered as hell), and because of the game's age, anybody on any relatively modern device can run the game at the highest graphical rate. The game was massively innovative for being able to support so many three- dimensional models at the same time, as well as particles, arrows, effects, etc. Coming with this new ability came the chance for strategy in a video game never seen before or since outside of the total war franchise. This game is unique in its mix of gameplay and setting. There are not a large amount of games that take place in the Roman time period (which is a shame in it of itself), and very few which have the strategy and immersion of this game. Another charm of the game is how amazingly accessible, yet complex the game is. There are many intricacies to both combat and the campaign map, but these intricacies are easy and fun to learn over time, making winning a campaign extremely satisfying as you felt you progressed. Also, despite the aging graphics, the game is stupendously immersive, unlike any game I have ever seen before on any platform maybe discounting Skyrim. Overall, Rome Total War is an excellent video game accessible to almost anyone in this day and age, and it goes to show that crafting a beautiful game like this can cause the game to transcend time and limitations of graphical quality. If you enjoy any strategy games, love the Roman time period, are looking to get into the Total war franchise, or are just looking for a really cheap game to pass time on, then Rome Total War is the perfect game for you. Please don hesitate buying it, the game is criminally underpriced for its sheer quality, even if the pricing system is pretty much based exclusively on age of the game. JUST BUY IT, ITS SO GOOD!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Where the Total War series truly started. Whilst the previous two titles, namely Shogun and Medieval, were excellent in their own ways, it was Rome: Total War that would show what the series was truly capable of and even today continues to impress players.

Take on the mantle of the leadership of nineteen factions from across the Roman world, from the titular legions of Italy, to the fearsome woad-painted warriors of Britain and Germany, to the horse archers of the Parthian and Armenian empires. 

Pros:
+ Excellent variety of units, giving each faction a unique flavour and playstyle.
+ Great real-time battles (albeit lacking some of the later quality of life features).
+ Strategic campaign with a far superior Senate vs. People conflict than the second game.

Cons:
- Slightly outdated graphics (still impressive nonetheless but for those used to the modern titles it may be a bit of a shock).
- Diplomacy (as with all Total War games) is quite bugged with overly aggressive opponents and seemingly random decisions made by AI.

title: Rome Total War
review: The squalor mechanic is very annoying. Certainly I guess something like it should be in the game, but the actions that increase it don't really make sense - there is no universe in which building farms creates civil unrest, and having to massacre the inhabitants when you take over a city to avoid riots really takes away from the immersion and roleplaying aspect of the game. Otherwise, still a lot of fun and a really good game for what it is, so many years after its release. Will run on just about any modern machine. The only problem I have is that after a while it crashes to the desktop, probably because of my laptop overheating, so save frequently if you have an el cheapo laptop like mine.

title: Rome Total War
review: VERY fun and rewarding.   After winning as the three Roman factions . . . . you should play each of the "minor" factions.   One gripe, when you pay the Barbarian Invasion game there is an option to train / recruit a general.  You can, therefore have as many generals as you want.   I WISH there was such an option in the original Roman campaign.  When you expand, there are many cities with no general to rule it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I played this game on release and I have to say, it really does hold up well. 

In its day it was groundbreaking and really pushed the genre into the new era, now it provides a nice little niche away from the glamour of more modern TW titles. There are little things you will notice in the game that have not survived into the newer titles, things that really have no excuse to be left out as CA has gotten lazier and lazier in 'streamlining' the development of their games. 

You will be able to have unique individuals who accrue detailed traits as you rack up wins, losses or even just leave them to govern. I haven't played some of the most recent titles but this had the best character development out of the ones I've played. 

The campaign map is the classic TW version (arguably the best city building aspect before cities became small towns with intense building regulation requirements) but does suffer from a frustrating unit recruitment process if you're only used to multi-unit recruitment of later titles.

To unlock factions you must defeat them in the main campaign. I like this feature as you have to start as Rome, the easiest faction to play, so you essentially had a working tutorial that you could springboard off into other factions as you cleaved your way through them.  Somewhat redundant now though and if you can't wait to play your favorite faction you can simply edit some of the text files to unlock even some of the unplayable campaign factions. As a side note, the little tutorial battle they have you play was actually pretty fun in that it was modular; having a skirmish before the main battle which you don't really get elsewhere. 

The graphics are pretty but basic (to be expected). 

The AI isn't half bad for its age (and better than some of the later titles).  

It marks the start of CA's Golden Age and is hands down my favorite title. If you like ancient warfare, pick up this Rome Total War, not Rome II. 

My only criticism of this game is somewhat halfhearted; that is that there are a lot of historical inaccuracies (when I say a lot, I mean some factions are displaced by hundreds years) however that does not detract at all from the brilliant, if simple,  gameplay. If you do want historical accuracy, I cannot recommend Europa Barbarorum enough, it's an overhaul mod that introduces brand new factions, expands the map East and Southward and completely redoes all the existing factions to be historically accurate, all the while giving you reams of information about historical events, items and people with original voice overs, artwork and historical music... MUSIC! Just be sure to click 'show me more' on the adviser panel to enable the mod's full features.

title: Rome Total War
review:
A classic game that far surpassed its successor upon launch release.  Rome encapsulates the early growth of the Roman empire very well and is a must play entry for any Total War fan to play.  The greek phalanx and fire throwers were first class (and or fun) new units to the franchise.  Many, many hours spent trying to paint the map blue back in the day.

A cult classic that will live on through mods for years to come.  Shame it's not supported through steam..

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game transformed my view of History completely!

I was 16 when I bought this game; I was only interested in US History at the time. I was taking World History that year and saw this game on the History Channel and gave it a shot. I couldn't put it down once I downloaded it! I learned geography, (which is neglected in American schools); I learned ancient History. I spent hours just reading the building and unit cards.

This game was so advanced for it's time; and I'm glad it's on steam.

Give it a whirl if you love History and strategy.

title: Rome Total War
review:
They did everything better in this game than the two before. 
They cleared the map, made battles more "realistic" rather than arcadey Shogun and Medieval battles. 
Better mechanics and quality of life stuff. 
Agents actually make sense now.
I played this game I think from the day it came out (off steam). But only now after playing two first games did I realise why this one made the series so popular.
In my opinion this game is the best one to start with the series.
The problem is, the game has problems running on modern cpus. Bigger amount of arrows (especially flame arrows) starts to lag the game. Some time ago after a patch it didn't want do start and you had so manually kill its proccess and then restart it. And it all happens on win7.
Still, I highly recommend the game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
A great game. You may need to look up a tutorial to get it to run properly on Win7+, and you will DEFINITELY yell rude things at your monitor courtesy of this game's derpy pathfinding when commanding units, but it's all well worth the effort. Worth noting is I'm not a huge fan of the franchise. Got this game this year, and it's my favourite in the series, so don't think you can't enjoy this game unless you're a Total War connoisseur, because I'm definitely not. This is mainly because the game offers loads of freedom and variety in how you play-- indeed, the most fun campaigns are the ones I've played as the factions you *can't* play without editing a .ini file (play a game as the Rebels if you're looking for a challenge). That said, this freedom also makes the game somewhat easy to cheese. You can play honourably, or cheese till your heart's content, but trust me when I say that everything tastes better with cheese.

Oh, and before I leave, some cautionary advice: Beware the Dacians. They are completely, utterly, incorrigibly insane. They will hurl themselves like rabid dogs at the walls of Aquincum until the settlement is either theirs, or until every last Dacian man, woman, and child lies dead and bloody at the feet of your shell-shocked and mortified legionaries. It does not matter whether the godsforsaken place is hardly worth the dirt it's built on. They cannot be reasoned with. It'll be easier for everyone if you just let them have the settlement. You have been warned.

title: Rome Total War
review: I've played most of the total war series and this is still the best. Prime example of how better gfx and processor power doesn't necessarily mean better gaming. Beautifully designed with so many nice touches that sadly disappeared from the later games. Individuals within the units don't 'pair off' for the sake of some crappy animation but where they are positioned actually counts. Its not perfect, the ai get confused and it can be a bit unstable and crash so save regularly. But if you like the total war series and you have never played this it is worth the £8 just to see how it was a it's pinnacle. A classic.

Other than that, the game is wonderful! Great strategy game combined real time battle strategy. Absolutely love it. First campaigned as Brutii and then as Julii. The Egyptians are tough, but once you manage to eliminate them you feel like you can take on anyone else in the game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Before getting a digital copy I wore out three CDs of Rome Total War.  I had read about the game engine due to it's cross-over utility for the the new specialty history channels.  ( Before they removed all history basically ...  this was a need )  but in the way back when it's not like you expected a game to dazzle.  I had  Civilization for that.   The previous game which seemed unbeatable.  

The main thing, possibly the only thing I dislike is that in the early game  you really need your family members, don't have enough and several of the already born male children will eventually develop hooting.  One of them even kept under firm control and given every opportunity to balance that eventually winds up so depraved there is no safe place for him.   Yet like a lot of  RTW players I feel attached to the only characters you can truly know.  Eventually you can park  your family members in academies and they pick up enough positives that however depraved it's safe enough to use them.  The game guide kind of recommends killing them off which could be why I work so hard not to. 

The family makes for a nice thread through the many games you play. Oh weird the 'first father" is on a longevity streak.  Hmm sucks you moved all his cards to some young and sort of sucktastic upstart ...  Wow Portia had a baby at 62 .    You know which are programmed to have those traits which  you will be driven to rehabilitate.  The game hints making an extreme argument for the opposite. 

I like that despite playing way more hours than Steam suspects due to offline ...  that battles can still sometimes serve up something new.    The map is big enough the  possibilities vast enough that if I can see and move a mouse I will still be playing when I am 120 or so.   

I've played the older Total War Titles and a few of the ones that came after.  The rest seemed a departure from the series golden premise - Rome Total War is by far the best.  

I like a lot of games.  I'm always willing to try a game but if some odd deity said I could only play one game for the rest of my life this would be the game. 

As time has passed that no game has  passed it even if some have been temporary obsessions has made me wonder about my taste but I've spent enough time worrying about that so now I think it speaks to the game having every thing a great game has. 

Newer shinier games will have better graphics.  The units not just desynchronized but actually different but those are trivial things compared to the core premise and the game engine. 

Go ahead and play it.  It's so old it should be practically free .  You might want to clear your schedule . Stock up on grapes and wine and perhaps buy new sheets as toga's are hard to come by.  Go all in for the best game to be made so far.   That's such an extreme endorsement I expect flak and it's not like I don't hope a game that unseats Rome Total War will one day be developed .  

I have my doubts but it  could happen. 

The good news for people who have never played is as an ancient game it's practically free so give it a try.    If you miss the razzle dazzle that push your gaming rig to fire up all fans you can go back to games which may be more stunning  graphically and audio and have a familiar chaos to them but when you want to rest in solid game design you will be back.

title: Rome Total War
review: One of the best entry level strategy games out there.  If you ever want to play grand strategy games like Europa Universalis or Hearts of Iron 4, its best to start with games like risk, or Warzone.com, then work your way up to Total War games and Civilization Games, and theeeen try your hand at grand strategy, and this was by far one of my favorite games to do that.  It is basically Total War Medieval II by in a different time period and you actually get to choose your heir.  There's also a clear cut goal of the game, conquer the SPQR (or Rome).  The graphics obviously aren't the best, but this is a strategy game, who needs graphics? No total war game has good graphics, and that's so that they can hold bigger and bigger battles, which is far more important.

title: Rome Total War
review:
To me, the first Rome: TW is still the ultimate Total War game. For it's time, it was the best strategy game and was even used for historical TV shows like BBC's Time Commanders. It was an incredible upgrade from Shogun: TW and Medieval: TW as armies no longer needed to be dropped from region to region. This was the first game where you could choose your approach into enemy lands, or even march right through other nations to get to a town you wanted to conquer.

Medieval 2: TW was also amazing. Empire, Napoleon were very playable. Unfortunately, Rome 2, even though it improved the series in many ways was very confusing to me. To me, the first Rome: TW still has the best combat system, and other then feudal Japan, Ancient Rome and Greece are the best setting for a TW game.

Rome: TW also has some great mods to further extend the fun or to improve realism.

title: Rome Total War
review: There's not much to say about this classic that isn't already known. Rome is an addictive and engaging experience combining light grand strategy and unmatched real time strategy on the battlefield. For me, this is the best kind of strategy game. One that has you looking not at stats and hexagonal spaces, but at units of soldiers and at the terrain. When playing, you rarely if ever think of numbers. You're far too invested in commanding your army and outfoxing the enemy for that. The enemy AI is serviceable but at times (particularly as the defender in sieges) it can be downright idiotic, and all turning up the difficulty does is make the enemy morale higher. The AI shows it's age. That doesn't detract much from the experience for me, though, because the campaigns and the thrill of battle are as compelling now as they were then. The Steam version comes with the Alexander and Barbarian Invasion expansions. I haven't played the former but the latter is excellent, set in the downfall of the Roman empire and giving you countless new factions and units and having far more historical detail than the main game.

Well spent 700+ hours in my opinion, would definitely recommend.

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of my favorite games of all time. While it lacks the graphical look with the title being published in 2004 this game is simply the pinnacle of Total War games. It not only gives you that feeling of being a commander on the field but it also encourages the player to look up period the game is based on. 

This version has two separate games included which are Alexander and Barbarian Invasion they are supplemental and extensive to the base game adding even more bang for your buck.

Besides this game especially struck the right chords when it came to the battlefield. When I was just a kid my pop and I would be setting up an army on either side to knock down and pivot one another with toy cannons as our viably weapons. I love reliving those moments of my childhood as I make my soldiers the best that they can be. 

My advice is to have Germanic Berserkers on the Jordan River and stack the enemy units by ten fold and turn on the rage ability. Have fun. This is a classic that remains to grab my attention for many years. If you don't like the old look then please play Rome 2 both of these games are amazing at their own right, however, Rome 2 does limit army mobility in a slightly annoying fashion.

Enjoy

Rome: Total War doesn't need reviews to discuss it properly - it needs entire books.

As for Barbarian Invasion, it only ships with two historical battles, but the value of this expansion is in the overall improvements it makes to the core game, as well as the sheer challenge of the new single-player campaign. In many ways, Barbarian Invasion feels like a graduate course in Rome: Total War, and it'll appeal mainly to Rome fans looking for a fresh new challenge. Meanwhile, newcomers to Rome should familiarize themselves with the original game first, before tackling the barbarian horde.
