title: Rome Total War
review:
A little frustrated that my pc was not up to par to be able to play Rome II with high graphics (the game looks pretty terrible on low settings), I ended up getting Rome I during a sale and initially, I was reluctant to play it, thinking the graphics were worse than Medieval II and therefore only the gameplay would be similarly engaging. Boy was I wrong. For 2004, these were some really ground breaking graphics, especially being able to make thousands of units clash. While the city graphics are pretty basic and minecraft-ish (the white blocks of classical antiquity buildings look pretty low-poly), the environment graphics aren’t so bad (distant mountain ranges, the sea etc. look fine), and the unit graphics are actually pretty good, especially for the roman units where you can see intricate designs on their shields, chainmail, the bands of the lorica segmentata, helmet crests and so on. 

But before I begin, please note that this game runs best on DirectX 8 and therefore has problems running smoothly on Windows 10 (and DirectX 9, 10, 11 etc.) and therefore requires you to download and move a d3d8.dll file into your steamapps/common/rome folder so that you get a good framerate. This, however, renders flaming arrows and catapult projectiles invisible, and while there is an alternate solution out there that involves you installing some other third party program, I cannot find that thread anymore, all I remember is it saying that while it did not render those projectiles invisible, the framerate improvement was not as high as with the d3d8.dll fix which is why I stuck to this one. 

Ideally, you want to play this game at normal battle difficulty (subsequent total wars gave AI units only morale bonuses at higher difficulties, but in rome they get combat bonuses too to the point where your hastati end up fleeing from peasants on very hard, so stick to normal) and unit scale LARGE (80 men per unit) as this is the most historically accurate scale for roman cohorts at the time. One interesting game mechanic in ROME is that training units drains population from cities. Therefore, playing on HUGE unit scale (160 men per unit) would massively deplete cities and cripple population growth both for you and for the AI, making settlement development almost impossible. Play on too small a unit scale and you can do virtually nothing to stop city growth which can become a real problem during late game due to squalor and unrest.  

The aforementioned game mechanic also allows you to train peasants and send these to other provinces and disband them there to speed up population growth, which is needed to unlock more buildings for your cities.

Unlike Medieval II, provinces aren’t divided into two settlement types: cities and castles. Instead, it’s the same development tree for every province, but boy are there lots of different buildings to build. Even after investing 150 hours into this game, I can guarantee you that there still will be some buildings left to build even in your most populated settlement. Buildings are divided into several types: farming, sanitation, temple, market, docks (if there’s a coast), and three types of military buildings: barracks for infantry, ranges for archers and siege weapons, and stables for cavalry.

Rome Total War came out as early as 2004 and yet revolutionized the RTS genre with bouts of realism. For example, your geographical position on the campaign map will reflect how your battle map will look like, and from which direction you and your foe(s) will be deploying. Fighting a battle on Rhodos will not only see you next to a coastline (with a fleet of ships in the distance if there is a fleet near your position on the campaign map) but you will also be fighting in front of a backdrop featuring the Colossus of Rhodos.

This brings us to another interesting feature exclusive to Rome: Total war – the seven wonders of the world. Not only are they featured on the campaign map (and have models on the battle map) but they give unique bonuses to your faction if you capture the province they are in. Some yield powerful bonuses while others are only helpful in their immediate surroundings. The Pyramids at Giza help quell unrest in Egyptian provinces. The Lighthouse of Alexandria increases movement distance and survival of ships along the Egyptian coast. The hanging Gardens of Babylon increase your faming output, the Temple of Artemis at Ephesus reduces religious building costs, The Mausoleum of Halicarnassus reduces building time for high tier buildings, the Colossus of Rhodes increases sea trade revenue and so on.

What is unfortunate however, is that the game initially only allows you to play as one of three Roman factions and unlocks other factions only upon you defeating them. But to keep things interesting, instead of you playing as a single Roman faction, in Rome Total War you instead play as one of three different houses: the Julii (red), the Brutii (green) or the Scipii (blue). In addition to this, there is SPQR – the Roman Senate (purple) which controls the city of Rome and is allied to all three houses just like you are allied to the others. The Scipii are programmed to conquer Sicily and expand towards the north African coast while the Brutii fight in Greece and then eventually expand toward the north east. Your faction enjoys a certain level of standing with the senate and with the people. The more provinces you conquer, the more the common folk (plebeians) begin to shout your name from the rooftops. Meanwhile, fulfilling senate missions (even if this means declaring war on factions neutral to you) increases your standing with the senate and should this drop too low (by not doing what they ask you to), your faction leader will be forced to fall upon his sword and refusing that as well will set off the Roman civil war – the senate and the other two factions will consider you a traitor and declare war on you, but you cannot take Rome until you have a high enough standing with the people. So it is best to do what the senate says until mid to late game and from there on out – alea iacta est – march on Rome. The Roman Civil war is interesting in that Roman armies are the best equipped in the game, so they will put up a bigger fight compared to other factions. That being said, the others aren’t pushovers either, despite Rome being destined to rule: Greek phalanxes, Egyptian chariots, Parthian cataphracts, and Carthaginian elephants can ruin your day if you do not have the proper counters! And regarding Rome’s armies, the Hastati-Principes-Triarii line initially make up the infantry supported by Archers and Equites (cavalry) all the way until the Marian reforms (which trigger when you build your first Imperial Palace on the Italian Peninsula) from where on out you can start wielding professional legionaries that can form the testudo formation and are the best infantry in the game.

Until the Barbarian Invasion expansion night battles are not introduced and religion is only present in the form of temples conveying different bonuses – it is important to tear down temples and build your own ones because temples not compatible with your own culture cannot be improved when the conquered city grows to the next tier. And building the highest level temples in each city is paramount to keeping unrest at bay. Each faction has access to three different gods, each giving certain bonuses like improved harvests or better law (reducing corruption) or quirky retainers. Assassins and spies do not have action cinematics like in Medieval II but are still very straightforward to use and easy to train. Due to the high levels of gold income in Rome Total War, diplomats are some of the most powerful agents in this game, easily able to bribe enemy armies and even bring entire provinces under your control, as long as they are not heavily garrisoned or governed by enemy family members.

All in all, Rome TW is an EXCELLENT alternative to the GPU demanding Rome II.

I purchased this to my regret.  Sadly, it is completely unplayable - the mouse pointer doesn't work properly. It is impossible to point and click at things because the pointer either doesn't move at all, or jumps around avoiding the spot you are trying to click on, or goes to the edge of the screen entirely. In reply to a comment, my system is not too slow, it can play any game at high settings. The problem actually most likely is the opposite, something about the changes made between current  PC's and  when this game was made is causing the problem.  If I knew what it was, I would post it here so that somebody else having the same trouble can fix it too.

title: Rome Total War
review: it is a fantastic RTS. This game has aged only graphics and AI wise, but the multiplayer more than makes up for the PC's lac of competency. A great starter game for anyone considering getting into the Total War Franchise. The Campaign is very, very fun and addictive and has just the right amount of detail when it comes to managing your empire. It will run on any computer, which is always a plus. The modding community had a field day on this game, and there are countless great addons. The Multiplayer is very solid, although one wishes for a bit more variety when it comes to the siege battles, as all of the Roman and Greek cities are perfectly square, one layered, and linear attacks are the only possible mode of attack. IE the streets are the only available areas where troops can move inside the city, and there is only one surrounding wall, meaning that the defense is extremely one-dimensional. These cons could also be taken as pros, because as i said before, it is a fantastic starter game precisely because it is so linear and simple, yet the tactical route is definitely still a viable option. I would highly recommend this game. However, I warn you, you have to not care a whole lot about graphical quality considering the game's age.

title: Rome Total War

title: Rome Total War
review:
It's outdated and buggy but it is still an all time classic. I try to play it again every few years just to relive a happy period of my life again. Compared to Total War Rome 2, there's no real reason to come back to Rome: Total War. But if like me, when playing a series or watching a movie or reading a book you like to start at the very beginning, then Rome: Total War (the original Shogun and Medieval are too clunky for me) is a great place to start a Grand Total War Marathon :)

9/10 for an all time classic. You will enjoy the gameplay, the immersion, the graphics (yes it's 15 years old now but you must appreciate and respect that the graphics were revolutionary at the time of the game releasing) and the sound :)

title: Rome Total War
review:
A fun game, and one which has character and soul, something later total wars don't really have. 

My one criticism is a problem which has always existed in total war games and that is the AI campaign mechanics.  In order to make the game 'artificially' more difficult the AI receive all kinds of cheats and buffs, so for example they are completely unaffected by money. 
For example, you can blockade a faction's ports to block trade income, sabotage a town's infrastructure so it hardly makes any money or you can take all but one of their settlements, and although you can see that they have no money on the faction information scroll, they can still muster armies of 20 or so units.

This means that the only way of taking provinces and defeating factions is by defeating them in battle. You cannot starve them into submission or drain all their money until they submit, because they can ALWAYS respawn huge armies due to the AI buffs / cheats. You can therefore not play a small but tall empire as you can in CK2 for example.

It's a lazy way of making the game more difficult (instead of doing something like make the AI more aggressive / sneaky) . So you can't really execute grand strategies - the depth is in how you control your armies and where you send them, because they are the only viable way of winning the game

Having said that though, the game is still fun!

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is a good old masterpiece. 

I really enjoyed the game and it mechanics. The battles were amazing and it ran super smooth, rarely any crashes, awesome soldiers to soldiers combat and the ability to just conquer the whole world even if you finish the campaign. I went for conquering the whole world.

Bugs and crahses: There was one crash when loading the game but when I pressed it again it worked perfectly. Also when your in a loading menu a black flash appears everytime in my first playtime but not anymore.

The campaign: There only one campaign but it still really enjoyable to play. (You can also play as the barbrians when you conquer them)


The system and governership: It was quite hard to manage towns and cities as I had to take care of population size, public order, income and so on. But the most was my money will produce -211 gold, destryoing my profits. I eventually find to prevent it by constructing buildings that increase wealth and happiness. 

It was intresting to mention that you have three options of what to do with a conquered settlement. 
1. Extermination (loads of money)
2. Enslavement (Slaves and a bit of money)
3. Occupy,

Most of the players go to exteriminate or enslave settlement but im a more occupy person. Also it avoids getting into public order issues. By choseing option 1 or 2 you might gain some money in the short-term but long-term will be hard.


Anyways I recommand this game to anyone who likes strategy games and Total war fans.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is one of my favourite games of all time. Easily in my top 10, however, I'm having a very hard time recommending it at this point due to a few performance reasons.

Let me start off by saying the gameplay and overall feel of this game is amazing and I would highly recommend it if you can manage to fix the framerate and whatnot. If you do a simple google search of "Rome Total War performance fix" you will find that this game was originally intended to run on single core processors. You can set the affinity of the game to run on only one core, however in my case that didn't seem to help. I'm not sure if it's because I'm now running an AMD build or what, but recently the performance has dipped even lower making it really hard to micro manage your armies without resorting to lowering the amount of soldiers per unit and the graphics to the very minimum (which kinda sucks for a 10+ year old game.)

Supposedly part of the issue is because of the transition to Steam servers for multiplayer when Gamespy shut down.

Until a patch is hopefully released to make this game run better on modern hardware, or some modders figure out a way to make it run better, I would suggest sticking to Medieval 2 for the closest feel to a classic Total War game as you can get. I love this game so much.

title: Rome Total War
review:
ROMANES EUNT DOMUS?!

Rome: Total War is what you play when you want to tell the Romans to go home, or vice versa.


It's the third game in the Total War series, and the first to introduce the gameplay template it still uses today. Gone are the 2D battlefield models and Risk-style campaign map from the first two games, replaced with 3D models and a strategic map you can use to finely position units and armies. Gameplay revolves around managing your territory in a turn-based strategy mode, and moving armies around the map to fight opposing armies as well as capture or defend settlements in a real time tactics mode.

This particular entry is widely regarded as a classic, and with great value to boot. It can certainly suffice for people who can't afford or run the later games in the series. Unfortunately the game is optimized to run on only one CPU core, so newer computers might run into some trouble anyway. As this is still only the third game in the series, there are some things in later titles that are lacking in this one such as resolutions above 1600x1400. Something to keep in mind, at least.

The Gold Edition comes with the Barbarian Invasion expansion that takes place during the fall of the Roman Empire, adding new factions and some new features such as hordes & religion; well worth playing after the base game. There's also a [url=http://steamcommunity.com/id/trar/recommended/4770/]second expansion-slash-DLC[/url] available separately that lets you play as Alexander the Great, and it's required for some of the more popular mods to run.


The vanilla game is a good way to get the hang of things, but from the disorganized battle lines to the historical inaccuracy I wouldn't recommend playing for any extended period of time. To wit: the Greek city-states form one faction (just one) while Rome is divided into three families that each get their own faction. Egypt, meanwhile, looks like it walked out of a timewarp from 1000 BC instead of the Ptolemaic empire it was at the time of Rome's ascent.

There's a number of mods that overhaul the game to fix these issues and more, including (nominally) improved AI, which has always been a weakpoint of the TW series - with the exception of the first two games, which used Risk-style troop movement that's easier for AI to understand. Two of the most popular RTW mods include Rome Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum, the former being a general overhaul of the game and the latter being much more realism-focused to the point of near simulation.


I'd recommend this as an entry point into Total War for people on a budget. It's probably better than Rome II at any rate; even with the many improvements that game's had since its disastrous launch it's still a game about ancient warfare that uses an engine the developers intended for Napoleonic warfare.

title: Rome Total War
review: EDIT: I can now safely say this has been resolved on my end. This issue with it not starting has been cleared. Turns out for some reason one of the computer log files got corrupted (no idea how that happened) along with a few other files that got deleted. Also fixed that gamesUX issue and the game works fine. I put a solution on the discussion forums on steam if anyone has issues with it. Basically just do a system scan and it will (hopefully restore any files missing). This is if and only if the game will not even start let alone register on the systems task manager list. Hope this helps everyone, but it IS back up and running! As for the game itself, it's a great classic total war game. Sure, the graphics aren't great, but the music, the atmosphere it brings, along with the simplicity of the gameplay is what makes me keep coming back to it. It's a great game to start with (along with Medieval 2) If you're just getting into the total war franchise!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Let's be clear: I own Europa Universalis Rome and that is really a good game. 
But like many other Paradox games, EU:Rome is fairly complex and can be very frustrating.
Also, you don't have control over battles there.

I never played a Total War game before but I understand why people love the franchise.
Sometimes It's nice to play just casually while looking at massive battles on the screen.

Now, why did I buy the first Rome Total War if I like more grand-strategy games?
Because it's incredibly cheap now, it runs on everything and you can install a fantastic mod: Europa Barbarorum.
EB makes this game historically accurate, more engaging and harder.

I hope EB will work fine for me (I heard that people had a lot of trouble with crashes), because I can definitely see myself putting a fair amount of hours into Rome Total War.

title: Rome Total War
review:
So, where to start? This is the seminal point of the Total War franchise, kickstarting the series as we now know it. As with later entries in the series, the game allows you to choose one of three factions to start as; the Julii, the Scipii, and the Brutii. Now, for the most part, you won't find much variation here, with each one representing a different family that was a historic part of Roman history, and this can lead to viewing each army as essentially a copy-paste, with the differences being the colours (In order, red, blue, and green). That said, this might also be the biggest twist of the game. Each of those factions, plus the SPQR, representing Rome itself under Senatorial control in vivid purple, starts the game as allies, and this is a nigh unbreakable bond, at least until much later into the game.

As such, you get to spend a lot of the game securely taking over your desired portion of the world, at least until you finally get the message that you've exceeded the boundaries of good Roman virtue, as the Senate would have it, and can finally kickstart the late-game Roman civil war/bloodbath. Now, this can leave the idea of playing as any of the non-Roman factions as a little unappealing in comparison, given that you're lacking the safety net of having steadfast allies as a Roman player might, but this is Total War. If you wanted a nice easy game where you can try and manage it all easily, you'd be playing Age of Empires or Starcraft. (Just examples, not knocking them!)

In terms of graphics, obviously they're not on par with later games, but they are sufficient. A Roman legion in all its glory looks suitably impressive from afar, and even close-up they still hold a lot of the detail that could be demonstrated given the limitations of the engine and the times. Perhaps the biggest change for someone who's never played pre-Empire Total War is that obviously diplomats have to be recruited and sent out to do your bidding, and that naval combat is never seen on screen, resolved as a solely AI-worked calculation. Other than that, a lot of the staples we see, such as hiding units in tall grass, the exhaustion system, morale and even the limitations on ammunition for ranged units, it's all here.

TLDR: kind of a meandering review, but, just buy the game. It's well worth it, and if it's not, you can always try a refund.

title: Rome Total War
review: Great game. Definitely worth buying. Wish the developers would release a patch to help make it more compatible with newer technology. Better than Rome 2. It's easy to tell which units are yours and which are the enemies in a big melee. unlike later Total War titles. Characters are great too with traits that help define them and will change with what you do with them in battle and on the campaign map.

review:
A quick and simple review.
Q: Is the game fun?
A: Yes
Q: Is the game worth it?
A: Certainly.
Q: Is the game buggy?
A: Sure as hell is, but good for its time.
Q: Should I get this game?
A: If you don't mind the lower graphics, the game play in battles is glorious, while the sieges can be a bit buggy, they can be entertaining too. Each faction plays differently and can be very fun. 

Overall rating? 8/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War is one of the best titles in the early TW formula and the strategy genre in general.

The colourful cast of factions, the music and the atmosphere, more than make up for the aged graphics and gameplay when compared to newer titles. 

RTW is ideal for newer players of the franchise, as it trims down the fat and focuses on the "pure" strategy experience, even though it misses some quality of life improvements introduced later in the series. 

The battles play smoothly on almost every single PC at this age even though most  maps seem relatively barren. The units are still cool to look at though and the animations are charming and even fun.

The hisorical accuracy is pretty much on par with a history channel late night special but some would argue it's part of the fun and the charm of the game.

Finally the replayability va;ue is great, as each campaign can take from a few days to weeks or even months and there are lots of unique and fun factions to choose from, each with its own playstyle, strengths and problems. Of course, when adding mods to the mix, the replayability value is almost infinite.

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of if not considered the best total war games in the series, Rome total war set a very a high bar for the rest of the series, and honestly had some of the best mechanics in total war to date, and additionally doesn't feel like your giving an arm and a leg in DLC just to get the game to a functioning state

i will admit its definitely not perfect, the graphics while okay arent that great compared to future titles, the diplomacy ingame kinda sucks ass as NPC factions are kind of dumb in that they will betray you even if your best friends, and overall are kinda retarded       ((i mean this is total war in all games they are dumb)) 

I think that this game has some of the arguably best siege battles within the franchise, the higher leveled cities are absolute juggernaugts to take down and the games provide good and interesting ways of taking them down, such as catapults, Siege towers, Battering rams, ladders, sapper points. It allows for good overall ways of taking down your enemies

A nice feature as well is that you can build as much as you want within the cities, and can even go onto a map and visit the cities themselves and see all the cool and pretty buildings, while the graphics arent amazing they hold up very well too this day
Pros:
Solid siege battles
pretty good battle AI(not the greatest but not horrible))
Good empire management
Good lategame((atleast for Roman factions))

Cons: 
Diplomacy is dogshit((just get trade agreements and ignore the rest))
The other factions honestly arent that great and dont have good lategames 
can feel sluggish lategame((although this happens with every total war
AI is not that good at stuff other than fighting really
City management is a bit limited 

Overall I'd reccommend it to anyone wanting to enter the total war series, if its on sale then i highly suggest you buy it and expierence what one of the best total war games out there plays like

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is the classic game that made the Total War franchise what it is today. If you have not played it, there really is no reason not to at this point given the price it has now. 

With that being said, it is not a perfect game. As innovative as it was, many of the new systems introduced are just plain broken, usually in your favor. It is very easy to keep your economy booming and roll across the map. At higher difficulties the AI just cheats more, but once you've gotten that far you are probably able to outplay them anyway as they often do completely nonsensical things. Medieval 2 would take this game's basic skeleton and make something more cohesive, but it is also a more difficult game because of this. 

It is easy to have rose tinted glasses for this game because of nostalgia. However, all of its quirks make it one of the most fun Total War games. Later entries like Rome II, Shogun II, and Attila would certainly do well with making a better looking and more realistic simulation, but they are not near as enjoyable as Rome or Medieval 2 IMHO. If you want to get into Total War, this is a great place to start.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Least Bad of the Total War games.

1.  Combined with the Extended Greek MOD (XGM), RTW becomes greatly expanded & more playable.

2.  The next TW effort MTW II, continued the good looks, added Castles to their cities, but erased all game difficulty.  

3.  Non existent Diplomacy, as with all the TW efforts, there is no diplomacy (neither do the CIV, or the Paradox travesties).  If they border you, strong or weak, they will eventually ATTACK. 

Conclusion:

With XGM MOD, I enjoy flattening the Romans (as the Greeks) after uniting greece.

Also enjoy uniting Italy as the Romans.

XGM improves RTW a bit.  expands the map, adds a cultural dimension, and allows for some control/influence over the Diplomacy.

*If you wish controllable Battles, Cities - representing  Humans occupying the ancient world (no humans in subsequent TW efforts, only Forts), RTW, & MTW II, (& the pathetic RTW II - of which no more will be said here), were the last TWs to refer to the Human race, you must try RTW & MTW II.  Since, for the TW developers, war happens, happily in a world without inhabitants, as in a dream.

RTW was the best effort.  It had a bit of Tacky (some gamey difficulty).  Season it with XGM.

God Bless!

The third chapter of the series after Shogun and Medieval. One of the best strategy games, well after all, one of the best video games ever existed!!! The first of the series that marks a graphic turning point. 
It have an eternal re-playability and campaigns are very enjoyable, it require low hardware performance and presents a multiplayer where to challenge friends in direct battles.

The diversity of troops available is not immense and some times the borders of regions on map are a bit strange. The campaign and battle strategyes are really well done and it changes a lot if you are ruling with the Greeks rather than the Romans or Egyptians etc.
Along with Shogun 2, in my opinion, the best Total War. A step above Rome 2.

Who, like me, loves this game but is unable to install the old cd...here the solution.
If you find it under sale, it is a bit dated, I absolutely recommend it (I took it for 3,99$ I also saw it at 2$).

Rating: 8.5/10  It is still holding the comparison with other more recent games.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is a very big strategy game.

No, seriously. Imagine Macedon getting back the glory that it lost after the Alexander's death - you can do it here. And it will be epic. Oh, yes. In fact, if you decide to write an After Action Report based on your campaign, it has all the potential to be an epic. With epic battles and epic context to those battles. I kid you not.

That said, there are some cons. The game doesn't like Windows 10. It runs allright on my laptop, but it might not run at all on yours. The balance is off. The game regards chariots as the Mammonth tank. So, it's not uncommon to see the factions that have them be your mid-game opponents. The phalanxes are completely and utterly broken in the battle itself. If you use them correctly, you might find yourself unstoppable. There are also some QoL absent - you can't rearrage the unit order in your roster or see where you ranged units can shoot. But if you can handle it, the game will provide you with a good strategic action.

This has an impact on city growth, and strategies to keep the citizenry content.  I forget what I paid for this, but I'm sure I got my money's worth a few times over! (just look at my hours played!)

title: Rome Total War
review:
If your computer is new/usually good but you are getting bad fps, do this:

1. Run your Rome total war game
2. Wait until title screen then alt + tab out of the program
3. search up "task manager" on your computer
4. Once in manager, click on the details tab
5. Scroll down and find the Total War Rome.exe
6. Right click on the .exe and select "set affinity"
7. Just have your core 0 checked, press "ok" and then exit from task manager.
8. DO NOT RESTART GAME, REPEAT STEPS AGAIN IF SO
9. Go back into the game and your fps should improve at least a little bit (I was able to get another 10 - 15 fps)

title: Rome Total War
review:
First off, I love Rome: Total War. The amount of time I sank into this old classic in my childhood was phenomenal, and the game holds up even today. 

However, for whatever reason, this version on Steam has HORRENDOUS frame rate issues. For a game this old, this really shouldn't be a problem. In fact, I actually booted up an old computer of mine after seeing how bad this was and loaded a CD version (not the complete edition with Barbarian Invasion etc) and it ran a treat. Not a single problem. So what's happened?

As a result, I cannot recommend this particular version on Steam. Buy the CD on Amazon or something and play it that way, because this is still one of the best strategy games I've ever played.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is the sole reason why people have bought the games in the Total War series and been let down ever since and now it works on windows 10 ( sort of ). Owned this game 15 years ago, must of put thousands of hours into it and stumbled across it by chance today which became an instant purchase. This is still the Best Total war game of the series but considering the rest pretty much suck that's not saying a lot. This game has many factions which you don't have to spend more money to be able to play them. Each faction is pretty unique and plays differently, some have no archers what so ever, some have their archers on chariots, some have great spear men and some are useless. The main difference with this than any other is even the best player in the world can find a challenge unlike the rest which are just easy. The hardest faction to play is Partha, while it has some amazing troops they are locked away behind high level buildings, if you play on very hard good luck reaching them or lasting 20 turns for that matter. The graphics are not up to the standard of Warhammer but the graphics shouldn't be the reason you are playing these games. While the battle maps are lacking in some detail at least you can clearly see your troops which is far more important than a few more detailed leaves on a tree. The campaine map is large but not as big as Rome 2 or Attila in other words just right and you can easily find your armies, diplomats and spies. Unlike Warhammer every faction is involved and you will have to defeat everyone to win.
You might experience some problems with this very old game but I've only had one game crash in the 10 hours of playing. If you have never played this then what you waiting for it's far more enjoyable than the tripe CA have been mugging you off with the last 12 years and If you have played this before why you reading this ? you already know how good this game is, I'm so glad they released it again it will keep me entertained for a few more years

title: Rome Total War
review:
Although the graphics are a bit outdated this is the best Total War out there for sure.

The gameplay is similar to the Medieval TW series (when it was good: before the nonsensical skill tree and stuff they decided to implement). But more than that you can hold offices according to your popularity doing missions, so this was far nicer than Medieval ones.

As for the graphics don`t worry: you get used to them right on the second turn. Give it a go, you`ll find it to be amazing.

AND REMEMBER: it`s not because this is Rome TW1 that it means it is worse than Rome TW2, quite the contrary!! The second one has the new gameplay where they ruined the series. Do not change amazing strategy and gameplay just for the graphics.

title: Rome Total War
review:
No matter how advanced games and engines grow, every now and then, at least two or three times a year, I reload Rome 1 and find myself still enjoying a game that should be well passed its sell-by date. 

For sure there are many elements that are out of date. Its building and settlement management system was basic and primitive even when it first came out, compared to contemporary games of the time, and Medieval II refined it to a far better system. But there is just something visceral and heart pounding about the battles in Rome I that continuously draws me back. 

The music is iconic, the voice acting of the general's speeches are all worth listening to, and the variety of options in each campaign is still astounding. I don't know how many hours I've played this game since first release, and yet I can confidently say that no two campaigns have Ever been exactly the same.  

Unfortunately it hasn't aged well into modern OS, and lags and bugs can make some large scale battles a struggle to work through. It would be  a real pleasure if there was ever a re-mastered special edition at some point, because this game still has a lot to offer. 

An absolute classic, and in my opinion, the bar all other Total War games must reach if they are to grab my attention.

title: Rome Total War
review: After playing practically all the games in the Total War series, I find this one to be my favorite. While the graphics are dated the game play is still great. Total War titles after this got too heavy on micromanagement details. The only non-military characters you have to manage on this are Diplomats, Spys, and Assassins, and there is no mechanic where you must use religion/cultural influence on territory. Also, your generals get "perks" based on the way you use them. If, for instance, you fight the same faction multiple battles with a general, he is likely to a "perk" against that faction. All this goes on automatically, whereas newer Total War games has an experience system where the player selects "perks" of their general. While I can see why many like this, it is yet again an example of micromanagement of the newer Total War titles compared to this one. In short, this is a streamlined version of Total War where there is far less non-military management.

title: Rome Total War
review:
In my Opinion, Rome is perhaps the best strategy game. Employing simple yet engaging mechanics, complimented by stimulating music whether you are gazing at the campaign map overseeing your empire or in the heat of battle controlling one of your many created armies. For its time, the visuals are fantastic and the music even more so. Despite seeming simple, the game boasts deceptive challenges and fair difficulty ratings. You start off as Rome, choosing 1 of 3 houses of the triumvirates. In order to play other factions, you must first conquer them. To win, one must control over 250 City States and/or conquer Rome the capital of Italy (The 3 Roman Triumvirates have a different win condition, they must first win over the senate and the people of Rome to rule it via competition between the other two triumvirates.) 

Rome is a Turn based strategy game, but unlike most of the turn based strategy titles, Rome makes it so that each turn ensures healthy progression thanks to responsive AI that like you control their own military, agriculture and politics, engaging with both you and the other AI on the map. Plus you are consistently given Missions by the senate of your own faction, which if completed give very helpful rewards. Thus ensuring that there is no stagnation between turns and no cease of action on the field or on the map. 

There are a few problems posed by this game, first and foremost being that Rome is a very old game. Released in 2004 the game is now 15 years old, meaning it's multiplayer potential has faded into obscurity, unless you employ 3rd party software like GameRanger etc. Second issue with the game is that no matter what difficulty you put it on, there are certain factions that will naturally have the upper hand like Egypt and the Romans due to either their fixed position on the map and/or the resources they control when they start off. It is NOT impossible to face these factions on any difficulty, but there are some considerable rage moments on either the ocean or on land against said factions. Other than the reasons stated above there arent any other real issues with the game, it is very well made. 

Another BIG plus is that the game does its best to be historically accurate. From city state names and placement as well as faction names and placement and the resources they posses. Each set of factions have their own unique despots/leaders/wives/assassins/diplomats/scouts as well as land/water based army/navy units of who's profiles are historically accurate respectively. There is also an option to play historical battles that actually took place or if you want you may create custom battles at your own leisure, just remember to give yourself infinite Denarii so you can give yourself the best army ;). (Denarii = money)'

I have been playing Rome Total War far before it was available on steam and i have many thousands of hours played on both multiplayer and offline in the game. I HIGHLY reccommend this game to both strategy gamers and *coughs* plebs *coughs* non strategy gamers alike. It is a beautifully made game for its time and has aged very well considering the contemporary gaming scene. A worthy investment of time and money. 

Roma Victrix!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War.

This game is unremarkably historic as well as the genre-breaking game of the year 2004. In this spectacular yet old and buggy game, you get to partake in the affairs of the three families of Rome, which fight for power and for control of Rome.
The collection adds onto the popularity of this game by adding in the Barbaric Invasions expansion pack, which introduces the few yet new factions like the Franks, the Huns, and the Persians. It also adds a few custom units dedicated to each faction, along with new city styles and a few more specialized buildings and items.

The good things about this game/collection are:
- An expansive campaign.
- Unit varities.
- Factions have differences.
- A humongous map.
- RTS Influence.
- A still active gaming community.

The bad things about this game/collection are:
- Really out-dated in modern standards.
- Out-dated graphics.
- Quietly fading away in the public eye.

Nonetheless, I recommend the game and the collection because it's a great way to spend time, conquering others and fighting off the annoying Greek city-states and rebels as well. It's truely a big bang for your buck.

title: Rome Total War
review:
TLDR: Fantastic game but has its a fatal flaw in really bad combat AI.

I've gotten into the franchise recently and love it to death, this being my first TW game. The attention to detail in this game is absolutely phenomenal and genuinely impressive by todays standards. The only problem i have with this game is that the battles are just way, way too easy because of how bad the combat AI is. I played the tutorial then hopped into campaign on very hard for both difficulty settings and i just felt let down. The AI will just throw random units at you ahead of advancing its entire line, on top of that they almost never build long range missile troops or have good battalion composition in their divisions among generals. There's usually just a mess of infantry that the AI can't seem to control correctly and after several hours on the game it really broke my immersion. I found myself never actually building any archers, cavalry, or high-tier infantry units just so battles actually seemed fair and engaging to fight where i could try to manuever my units to gain advantages rather than have advantages generously tossed at me by the AI, even on the most difficult settings. I'm currently looking for a mod that overhauls the AI and makes it a bit smarter and will be looking into other newer TW games  to keep scratching this itch. 

That was a lot of criticism but i still love the game and im writing this review before hopping back into it, I just feel like it could be better, but for a $10 game made in 2004, holy shit is this game absolutely phenomenal. I'm hoping the more recent TW games have better AI that builds better armies and uses them better, or a modder has done that themselves for this game. 

8.5/10 for me.

What can I say about the greatest Empire Building game ever?

Online Battles that people still play daily. And all for under $10.00. Then, there is the expansion. It makes Rome:Total War feel like two games in one if you get it. Excellent game, Highly recommend for anyone who loves historic battle simulation.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Pros: 
[list] 
[*]Large scale battles. 
[*]Surprisingly faithful to historical accuracy. 
[*]Combat has a lot of depth, factoring in losses, morale, weapon types, formations, and terrain.
[/list]

Cons: 
[list]
[*]Even for its time, graphics are lacking.
[*]Far too much micromanagement, both in combat and in empire. Too many things to keep track of at once.
[*]Steep learning curve and unforgiving difficulty.
[*]Games are a complete slog, taking way too much time in order to play a single match.
[*]UI is dated and obtuse.
[/list]

This game is for the hardcore PC gamers, anyone else would not enjoy this game. I give this game a 6/10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Old game, but after trying quite a few in the series, I can't help but keep coming back to Rome: Total War. Medieval 2 and all historical Total War titles have their own areas in which they shine, but RTW uniquely has an interesting game map (despite the inaccuracy) with various factions and interesting power struggles to play through. Its battles are exciting and require some level of thought, though the AI has of course aged at this point. The game is simply captivating and draws one in to the historical period quite impressively for all the years it's had to dry out, and it stands the test of time remarkably well.
Can't forget about the incredible music, either. That's one of the biggest selling points for me.
Try it out, don't be scared away by its age. The graphics are hiding a much deeper and more immersive experience that follows your rise from senator to Imperator. And watch out for Egypt.

title: Rome Total War
review:
[h1]A wise man in times of peace prepares for war.[/h1]

My troops are encircled. The battle was not in my favour from the beginning - my general had sallied forth to besiege an enemy city, leaving two units of peasants, a nd a single unit each of Roman Hastati and Velite. So it was that barbarians amassed outside the walls, trapping the small frontier settlement. Weeks passed, and eventually the uncultured barbarians pushed against the walls. One unit of peasants held one breach in the wall against fanatical swordsmen, killing as many of them as they could before the peasant's morale broke and they fled back to the town square, where they managed to regroup. My Hastati and the other unit of Peasants, after killing as many as they could, retreated before the fanatical swordsmen could attack my flanks. The Velite fled down another series of side streets, leading the foolish barbarians away so that my Hastati could line up in the center of the street, protecting the town square from direct attack. The two peasant groups, now greatly reduced in number, stand alongside the Hastati, who had lost about ten men in the frenzied battle at the gate. Over a hundred, perhaps two hundred, barbarians marched down the main street while the other hundred chased after the Velite. 
The fight began once more in earnest, as the naked, fanatical warriors charged against Roman shield and steel. They were broken; routed, they fled out of the city. But more came - warbands of men armed with spears and shields, attacking Roman soldiers with vigour. 
The Velite were cornered, and fought to the death, brave Romans to the last. As they were being attacked, a unit of peasants was hurriedly ordered by the general to support them - this came to little, but the flanking action managed to surprise and kill a few more of the barbarian invaders than might have been killed by the unskilled melee fighters in the Velite regiment. The peasants fled back down the street to the town square. 
The Hastati and the other group of stout Roman peasantry fought valiantly, and broke group after group of barbarians against superior Roman steel and mettle. Soon, the hundreds of barbarians that had stood against the Hastati were fleeing from the city and tripping over the bodies of their fallen comrades, and, alas, a few Romans as well. 
Meanwhile, the band of cowardly barbarians that had encircled the Velite charged down the side street towards the town square. The peasants waited in the town square, only fifteen of them now, as the twenty-seven remaining Hastati turned, preparing to counter the charge. 

And they did - for a time. The fight raged on for some minutes, and it was just as the Hastati seemed to be gaining the upper hand that the warbands that they had broken before had returned - it appeared that their barbarian courage could only be gained by stabbing brave Romans in the back with their long spears! 
So the Hastati now, encircled by at least one hundred and fifty barbarians, stood back to back, forming a small circle. The general - a mere captain, hastily appointed by his compatriots due to the absence of the general, shouted encouragement to his soldiers, imploring them to hold fast. The peasants attacked the outer ring of the barbarians, and one group was completely wiped out. But, the barbarians were faltering, in spite of the amount of Romans that they had killed - they saw in the twelve men that remained true strength - they were true warriors. 
The Hastati, the brave twelve, pushed outwards, breaking the warbands, and striking a lucky blow against the enemy general - he lay with his dead brethren, right next to a fluttering Roman flag. 
As the barbarians fled the city, passing through the streets littered with barbarian and Roman bodies, twelve Hastati and two peasants looked out at the carnage that had been wreaked on the city streets that day; they were the only survivors. Romans, true and honorable. 

Some months later, the twelve Hastati were linked back up with their original general. They were taken to the capital of the barbarians, and it was there that they witnessed the fall of their 'empire'. Now, Rome had finally received it's revenge. 

Well, just in case you weren't paying attention - this game is one of the best strategy games ever made, with an easy-to-learn, hard to master attitude, hundreds of hours of gameplay, and countless tactical possibilities and awesome stories just like the one above. And just in case you are wondering about my hours - I played a lot of this game offline before Steam. 

My Personal Rating: [h1]Highly Recommended[/h1]

title: Rome Total War
review:
I got at least 100 hours out of this game back in the day. I still think it's much better than Rome II, which fell to overambition on the map side of things, is still incredibly buggy and laggy, whilst grossly neglected why people play Total War games - the battles.
This particular Total War game only gives the faintest lip service to any historical accuracy whatsoever, but the sheer cartoonishness of its cinematics, units ('head-hurlers', ancient Egyptian chariots, flaming pigs, naked fanatics etc.) and voiceovers gives the game its charm. If want any game to see thousands of Legions and Hoplites killing each other onscreen, this is still the best.

'Barbarian Invasion' (the free expansion in this) takes itself a bit more seriously. The Horde mechanics are definitely far less annoying than in Rome: ATILLA. Night Battles in particular are awesome. 
The only real thing Rome II and Atilla have over the original in gameplay terms was the inclusion on the Middle-East, this game arbitrarily cuts the map off at Armenia/Syria, meaning the Seleukids, Parthians and Sassanids usually die really early. 

There are however 2 *excellent* mods for the original Rome, namely Rome: Total Realism and Europa Barbarorum. Ironically the latter is the more 'die-hard' version for pedants, Total Realism staying closer to the original game.

tl; dr: A much more fun game to play than it's sequel, which poorly imitated Paradox-type Grand-Strategy games and just created a laggy, bugged out map with actual BATTLES as an afterthought.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Ok, reviewed this game 2ish years ago, now i'm re-reviewing it.

It's still actually one of my favourite games of all time. For it's time, without a doubt the best there was. But with teh changes that have been made to it with random patches here and there, and the increased difficulty of getting the game to actually work, I can't honestly recommend that anyone buy it from steam anymore.

Most people will spend a lot of time getting it to function and even then with difficulty. If you do manage to get past all of that, then you can probably with even more difficulty mod it and make it better still for you personal experience. However:

Many mods are broken and do not work an longer. Not sure how many have been fixed and reworked by mods.

Changes to the game in the last two years have made it a little boring and a bit of a wam-bam tahnk you mam experience battle wise. I haven't really been able to get in to it since they converted armour bonus' into actually hit points, as opposed to taking a percentage off of the enemy attack. Units break at half the speed in general, which does actually make it more difficult but the battles are soooo short now. There's no class to it. The campaign game itelf still has plenty of character which alllmost saves it. But alas, it does not quite.

If you have the disk version, stick to that, don't register it to steam or it'll likely ruin it for you.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I love this game, I really really do. I cannot thank this game enough for the times where outside problems didn't even matter anymore because the Romans were attacking or I had to deal with the betrayal of my Gaullic allies. I got this game originally in 2010 thru the CD box and it's only since the CD got too scratched I had to come to Steam, hence the low hours and it's helped me finish middle-school, procrastinate my way through highschool and now I'm juggling it with the rigors of a relationship, college, and working in the real world. Even with all of that I don't regret a single hour I've put in, the simplicity of wanting to be the undisputed emperor of Europe along with all the hilarity this game throws at me like losing a city because the attacking AI won't move into the town square since they like standing on my walls for 30 minutes much more make this game so addicting and easy to come back to.

I haven't even started to talk about the mods that some really creative people have dedicated themselves into making, want cooler spartans? done, want to make burning pigs fly on catapults? there's a mod for that, want a mod with even more authenticity and realism including barbarians having their dongers out? do I even have to tell you yes for you to know some guy out there spent time making pixelated penii? 

This and Medieval 2 are basically the two main Total War games I'm really limited to with my yucky computer with Empire barely playable (although I still have racked up 200 hours just bc I have some stubborn inclination to watch soldiers march into cannon fire) but the endless amount of fun I can have by sending spies with disease to all of Greece to watching enemy Roman soldiers go into testudo because the snowing was falling too hard on them seems like I'll be playing this game for years to come. I haven't played so many Total War games because I'm a broke college boy where the rent is too goddamn high and so this old 2010 computer is gonna have to do for a couple more years until I get to lose my social life and girlfriend and fail more classes because some Japanese clan or goblin stronghold thought they could betray me. But... I'm still proud to have found this game.

10/10 would exterminate all Gauls again since they poked some Roman grandfather's eyes out

A chief can regroup his escort in enemy territory, a nightmare for rearguard.... Although is irresistible for fans of this type of historical games: a guilty pleasure.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War was my first Total War game. Due to this game I fell in love with the rest of Total War series. Even though the game may be outdated, the gameplay is still great. Rome: Total War is a top class strategy game. One can control various nations during the rise (or fall, depends on which faction you play) of the Roman empire. I personally enjoyed the combination of city management and real time battles. I have spent countless hours (don't be misled be my current hours, I have played Rome: Total War long before I bought it on Steam) on Rome: Total War. Who wouldn't want to be like Caesar?
If you like strategy games, this is the game for you. The graphics may be outdated, but the gameplay is still solid. This game combines the features of a turn based strategy game with that of a real time strategy game. The grand campaign is situated in Europe, North Africa and Minor Asia and is played in the turn based mode whereas the battles are fought on a small map in real time.
In conclusion, I rate this game a 89,89/100.

Yes, I can be that specific.

With kind regards,
Your new Roman oppressor

title: Rome Total War
review:
During this great year of Battlefield V, Fallout 76 and other huge blockbuster releases - I find nothing more enjoyable than this to play at the end of the day with a cup of tea or hot chocolate.

This game has aged exceptionally well and bordelines on timeless. I find the AI and depth of this game the best of all Total Wars, and I find myself immersed every time I pick it up. 10/10

Pros:
- Immense depth of mechanics. Traits, choices, settlement trees, decisions that MATTER.
- Vast unit choices, physics and battle mechanics that I find better than newer Total Wars.
-  As difficult, easy - fast or long as you'd like. I recommend Hard campaign, Very Hard Battle difficulties.
- Replayability with factions abound.
- Units with COLLISION.

Cons:
- Newcomers will need patience to overcome the big ol' learning curve.
- Sometimes ambigious reasons for settlement dissent/unhappiness. 
- Limited graphics
- No naval battles.

If you've not played it - I really recommend!

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is a great game, from top to bottom.

Sure, it has its problems in terms of historical inaccuracies. And sure, you have a chance of crashing the game if you don't let the battle music end on the battle summary screen before clicking to return to the campaign map. But there is just so much fun to be had with this game. Expanding your empire and fighting the different factions is a blast. Those sure-defeats that turn into legendary, heroic victories for your faction hype the heck out of you. The sounds and music is just all too often perfect when sinking into the game.

And it's always fun to raze Carthage to the ground!

Rome: Total War is *still* my favorite Total War game. And every so often I come back to give it one more campaign playthrough.

9/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
I've been playing this game since about the time it came out. Turn-based strategy, realtime combat, and really fun. I think by this point most people get the gist of Total War games. The early game is very action-oriented, but as you advance it becomes a lot more thoughtful.

This game is just classic. Plenty of mods out there to overhaul the game if you so desire. Plenty of virtual genocide. (It yields more gold to slaughter entire towns... lol)

review: this game is great,  very fun, and the campaign also adds more strategy ont he map, and not just on the battlefield including rebellions and revolts in your cities, and the family tree allows you to have a chance to gain great generals, sieges are fun, but can be very costly to both armies. title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War combines a dymamic empire management system with great real time battles to deliver a very satisfying historical sandbox game that can be played over and over again and still be fun. The game also boasts great moddability, with several great overhaul mods that can enhance your experience even more. Unfortunately, the graphics and effects have become dated since the game's original release.

Overall, i'd say it's a great strategy game that is very easy to learn yet gives the player massive freedom in playstyle, for what it's worth you should probably buy it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
ROME TOTAL WAR is definantly in my top ten all time favorite games. i have had countless hours of fun battling carthage, all the different barbarian factions, the egyptians,and the greeks (not to mention parthia and two other power hungry roman families) in real time battles to the death. it's just so satisfying to smash into an enemy army and cause them to rout with a well timed cavalry charge or mow down advancing enemy units with archers and scorpions and that's only in singleplayer. i remember many times in multiplayer when me and a friend had massive battles against the AI (which is quite good if i do say so) like the time we wiped out four entire armies of upgraded peasants with war elephants or when we made a last stand against a barbarian horde as the romans or when i tried to screw over my friend in a custom battle and make him fight an army of incendiary pigs only to get screwed myself and end up having to deal with the incediary pigs rushing me instead of him (on the bright side at leaast my army had quite alot of bacon to eat after the battle) but yeah Rome Total War is an amazing game and barbarian invasion is pretty great too (personally i go with the Franks) another good thing about barbarian invasion is you are able to abandon your home city and just roam around with a giant army and lay waste to everyone and everything around you. (rome total war Alexander is fun as well)
i give Rome Total War, Rome Total War Alexander, and Rome Total War barbarian invasion a 10/10 8/10 and a 9/10 respectivly

title: Rome Total War
review:
Just wanted to say that I have played this game long ago. It was my first Total War game and it changed my view on RTS genre. Don`t want to sound like negative old fart, but "back then" it was the the most realistic strategy game i have played. 
I mean C&C was good too. I played RA1 on PS1, but TW Rome had formations, some micromanagement and you couldn`t sent "meat" to death. That would have been death sentence.
One unit type can be weak against most units, but against one specific unit type it can be strong. Aka "Each action has counter-action". 
When i tried to play it on Steam - It lagged. Not a big deal now that we have more advanced and modern Rome game. Many old games aren`t working well on modern systems.
If you haven`t played TW games before, you can try Rome 1 first. Old, yet simple enough. Good starting point for TW newcomers and RTS players,

title: Rome Total War
review: a legendary game.  our kids played this thousands of times and mastered it to the point of absurdity--but in doing so, they also learned ancient greek and roman history, geography and military history.  and for its day, it was by far the best and most advanced game every built and designed.  the campaign mode is excellent, the battle mode is excellent, and essentially, Medieval War II is based off of Rome Total War I in nearly every respect.  You can play the game out for yourselves, but essentially the huge question of the game is, why does Rome succeed, among the great powers of the three Hellenistic Kingdoms to the East, and Carthage to the West?  It's not intuitive that they would have been the successful power, and yet they were.  This game, more than any history book, proves why, if you just play the various factions through.

10/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
Considered by many to be the best Total War title, this game is good fun and still hosts many excellent user modifications. Personally, I consider Medieval 2 to have surpassed Rome, but there are mechanics that should be learnt from and adhered to here that have been missing in all Total War games since, most notably unit cohesion and behaviour (most notably no spreading out endemic to Medieval 2 or blobbing in Warscape games, and the automatic wheeling-and-charging maneuvres of cavalry rather than the disengage-and-order-again micromanagement in other Total War games).
However, I wouldn't reccomend purchasing this title as the modern Creative Assembly is a far cry from the past and prefers lazy reskins, broken mechanics and the historical revisionism of shoehorned political agendas over producing quality gameplay.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is probably the best Total War game ever made, and for good reason, since the only other Total War games that can stand up to the challenge is Medieval 2 and Shogun 2, both incredible titles on their own. But this game has more of the historical accuracy that Medieval 2 doesn't have while trumping down on Shogun with the fun of bringing glory to Rome!

The reason this game stood out amongst other games was the mix of turn based and real time strategy that has been done by only a few other games, and this is the only game that did it as well as it did. Combat is fluid, strategy is relevant, and the game actually manages to make me nervous when I am about to fight a battle on equal footing.

Strategy is important in this, becuase unlike many other games, spamming one unit will not win you battles. You need a well managed mix of units and sound tactics to win the day, and a good general helps as well...

And nothing feels as satisfying as bringing glory to rome.

10/10

title: Rome Total War
review: From the  Spartan Legends of Southern Greece to the Superstitious Druids of Briton to the Mysterious Parthians from the East, this game has it all! Choose your faction and build your empire from the ground up. Starting in 270 BC, The Romans are struggling to forge an empire that will last through the millenia. Beset on all sides by enemies: a rising power( thanks to the greeks) to the south known as Egypt, the Greeks themselves with their Spartans to the East, Barbarian tribes to the North, and beyond them the Seleucids(claiming to be decendants of Alexander himself) and we cant forget the Parthians with their powerful War Elephants: are all in the way of a United Roman empire. Your biggest enemy though comes from within... 2 Rival roman families also seek to forge the Roman empire in their own image... Choose what kind of warlord you wish to be! Do you exterminate their entire populace? Ensuring no insurrections or rebelions OR do you Enslave their people? Forcing entire cultures to build your monuments and cities? (You can also allow them to just integrate into your society; bolstering your own population but where's the fun in that?) The game play is fluid, the graphics spectacular and the battles are Legendary! Would recommend this game ten times over!

title: Rome Total War
review:
My favorite game ever!

Also a plus is that there are really good mods for this game: Lord of the rings total war, Europa Barbarorum, Extended Cultures, Roma Surrectum II, Rome Total Realism, fourth age total war, etc.

however some of them break some stuff or cause new bugs and I wouldn't recommend those to new players.

Vice versa vanilla has some bugs which are fixed in nearly all mods. Plus egypt isn't a hellenistic faction in the vanilla game which bugs me.

There is a unnoficial bug-fixer made by player1, however more recently ahowl11 has made a even more updated bug-fixer which fixes some bugs not fixed by player1 and turns egypt into a hellanistic faction. It's called ahowl11's vanilla enhancement mod and it's the only mod I know that doesn't add new bugs to the game.

http://www.twcenter.net/forums/showthread.php?787775-ahowl11-s-Vanilla-Enhancement-Mod-v2-Egyptian-Makeover

https://www.moddb.com/mods/ahowl11s-vanilla-enhancement-mod

Also many people who play rome total war nowadays run into issues like lag or aren't able to run the game due to compatibility issues with newer hardware and operation systems. However ths isn't the fault of the original devs because it ran good on all gaming PC's back in the day.

There are many helpful articles on the internet, but feel free to message me if you have difficulties working around your issues.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Well.....reviewing this game is hard. For it's time, it was without a doubt one of, if not the greatest, strategy games of all time. However, comparing it to newer Total Wars (except for ROME II, that is something else entirely) it lacks in several things, notably historical accuracy, diplomacy, and managing your government. 

For one, in historical accuracy, there are multiple nations (like Gaul, Spain, Greece, etc.) that are unified nations even though in real life they were a divided people, with seperate clans, city states, etc., but for some reason CA mashed a lot of city states and tribes together to form unified nations, which is completely inaccurate. Also, in Egypt is not Hellenistic at ALL. They still have traditional Egyptian paganism as their religion, and their units are traditional Egyptian ones, even though Egypt was now practically a Middle Eastern copy of Greece thanks to Alexander the Great. 

In diplomacy, there are very few options (some examples are trade rights, alliance, and map info), which lessens your interactions with other nations. The AI also struggles to properly conduct diplomacy.

Finally, there is governemnt. For Roman factions, the Republic government is somewhat accurately displayed, but in general, there really is no "government system" like in some later Total Wars, although there is a family tree that allows you to set the faction heir, adding a bit of spice to government. 

If we put those those things aside, though, you will find a true classic of a strategy game-and I'm pretty sure most people here would agree with me. In a time where graphics made people look like horrible mutants, the AI was as smart as your neighborhood stray dog, and strategy games lacked a lot of actual strategy, this game was revolutionary. The graphics, although inferior to today's games, probably looked really great to a lot of players back in 2004.  The jump from the previous Total War, Medieval, to Rome in terms of graphics was absoultely stunning. The AI (which, to be honest, is not much smarter than the neighborhood stray) is competent despite occasional errors. Diplomacy, while lacking in true immersion, adds a new level of strategy to the game despite its simplicity. The government system, while being very basic, also adds to the strategy of the game, as you scramble to find a sutiable heir for your glorious (or, more often than not, not-so-glorious) empire. 

Speaking of empires, there are 20 factions, with about half of them playable, half of them not playable. Technically, there is a 21st faction: the rebels. The rebels not only represent actual rebels, which I am perfectly okay with, but they also represent "minor factions" that CA left out of the game, which is kinda sloppy to me. However, all-in-all, the campaign is sound, if perhaps a tad disappointing to modern gamers. 

Now, on to battles. It is usually not possible to manage a nation without going to war occasionally, and this game certainly does not oppose that statement. You will end up in countless battles, usually with random weaklings who think they are better than you, but you will sometimes find yourself matched against a worthy foe. If it is a land battle, you can do one of three things: fight the battle out on a battle map, have the computer auto-resolve the battle, or retreat. For naval battles, you only really have the auto resolve option. For the battle map, you and everyone involved, regardless of whether they are on your side or not, will command various units that can be trained in cities if you have the proper buildings (in the campaign). You lead these soldiers to victory or defeat against the enemy. I personally believe CA did a great job with the battle mechanic of the game.

If you like Total War games, strategy games in general, video games in general, or if you like life, then buy this game. Even if you don't like life, still buy it. This is a true classic of a strategy game, and you would be a fool to pass on it if you are a fan of the genre.

Overall, 9/10.

Also, this game definitely deserves the "Test of Time" award. An absolute classic of the strategy genre.

title: Rome Total War
review: Rome 1 remains one of the Best Total War games simply because it avoids the feature bloat of the rest of the series. Rome set the conventions for the series going forward, but isn't overwhelming in the way that Rome 2 can be - with complicated systems that aren't quite explained well enough to make sense right out of the gate. title: Rome Total War
review:
My first impression playing this game was "I'm a little disappointed, it looks / feels a little old". But after one hour or so, I found this game to be as entertaining as people say. It deserves all the love it gets. The whole thing looks quite simple, battles are surprisingly fun and fast-paced, something you do not necessarily experience with other Total War games. So yes, it's an old Total War, definitely not the same generation as games like Shogun 2,more like an older / less refined Medieval 2, but it's a very enjoyable game. 

Also, you can enter console commands. Yeah yeah, I know. But still. Remember that time when you were crushed in a more recent Total War game and you ragequitted ? Sometimes cheats come in handy. 

Worth your pennies.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Often considered to be one of the best games in the Total War series. Rome is a game that has captured my heart and imagination since i first saw my friends played the game on his computer back in 2006. There is so much in the grand ambition of this game that far exceed most games back in 2004.

At the start of the game, you start out with the Roman faction. You have 3 major families to choose from; The Julii to the north, The Scipii to the south, and The Brutii to the southeast. rosterwise, there are no difference between all 3 families. Instead, each family is given different objectives by the senate to capture land for the roman republic. Your ultimate goal would be to gather enough strength and the support of the people to eventually overthrow the senate and become Emperor of Rome. After you complete the game, you will then be given the opportunity to play several other factions who are also vying for power in ancient Europe which spices up the gameplay with their different units and tactics.

Gameplaywise, the game is divided into 2 phases. The map phase has you in a turn based gameplay where you manage your empire to gain funds, act in diplomacy, look after your cities, and build up your army to expand and defend your territory. When a battle starts, the battle phase begins which follows an RTS formula. These are the true highlights of the game as you control armies up to thousands of troops on screen to defeat your opponents,

On the positives, this game aims to be grand scale in its endevours which for the most part succeeds. The feeling you get as you march your army of legionnares to conquer the Gauls or sacking Carthage is unmatch by any other game outside of the Total War series. Battles are often won with wit rather than force. Due to how the game's battle system that attempts to be more realistic with troop morale and the like, often times you can win or lose battles depending more on how you strategize and predict what your opponent will do next. Nothing is quite as exciting as being overwhelmed by number of your enemy soldiers only to outsmart them with a well place flank attack and gaining a heroic victory as a result. Rome succeeds at both giving the player the feeling of being a general and a conqueror that other strategy games don't really give. This is only exemplified by the excellent soundtrack composed by Jeff van Dyck which gives out a an ancient and haunting feel throughout the experience.

On to the negatives, one of the biggest issue that is incredibly infamous in the Total War series in general is the AI. Generally the AI can be competent but often times are rather stupid. Most fights can be easily won by just doing a flank attack and the AI will have no clue what to do. If you're looking for competent foes to fight then you're better off playing the multiplayer instead. The game has a glaring issue with its diplomacy system. The game is often unclear with what the other faction wants and they often come off as acting erratic rather than clever. Your allies may suddenly declare war on you for no reason and you're stuck with sudden attacks despite just a moment ago they proposed an alliance with you. Another weird hiccup is how the roster is designed. It's pretty clear that the Roman faction was given the most attention considering the name of the game, but other factions feel underdeveloped, severely in some more than others as a result. The game's factions are clearly unbalanced as a result and playing as them in the campaign can feel very frustrating especially if you play as one of the factions who are at war against Rome. Because the Roman faction is basically 4 factions with their own funds and AI, playing against them often feels more annoying than fun as you are severely overwhelmed by them if you don't act first. One minor issue i have is more towards historical accuracy. While the romans were given attention to reflect their historical design, the other factions caters more towards stereotypes that makes the whole thing feel cartoony instead. (The worst example of this is the Egyptians who despite at the time was more Greek than Egyptian as part of the legacy of Alexander the Great, CA opted to make them the stereotype egyptian from pre-Alexander time which makes no sense whatsoever).

Overall, Rome Total War is a game that is just incredible in what it accomplishes, while the game has plenty of blemishes that are more visible now than ever, it's not enough to diminish how much of an impact this game created. Follow that with the game had a very vibrant modding community in its hayday that iron out those issues and you have a game that i recommend for just about any strategy fan who are into ancient warfare with thousands of soldiers on screen battling each other.

title: Rome Total War
review:
In many ways, I view Rome Total War as the high point in the Total War Franchise.

Set in ancient, take control of one of many factions (Italian, Barbarian, Mid-Esteastern) and conquer the world!  It's a large game with the map covering Europe and parts of Asia and Africa, and a single game takes more than a small investment of time.

The core gameplay focuses on war and empire management. Battles allow for auto resolves, but the real charm and strength of Total War relies on taking to the field and commanding large numbers of troops in massive combat.  It controls great, even when the scale of the battles become epic, and the cieling for skil is incredibly high as real world strategies and tactics will get you far.  All the while, even less mechanically inclined players wont find it overly burdensome, even if they don't get all they can out of the game.  Finally, battles often feel unique as different fations play differently, the terrain drastically changes battles, and seiges on cities introduces its own mechanics.

The other side of Total War is the macro.  Players must build troops, build buildings, and manage finances.  While simple, I found a great ammount of enjoyment building my territories up.  While not in depth to any real degree, the over world system does require some finesse once you expand further and must deal with rebels.  I'm underselling this a degree, because the entire system is extremely enjoyable.

While I'm not up to date on the more decent Total War games, and despite its age, I would recommend Tota War Rome as a great entry point into the franchise.  It's a large, expansive, moderatly deep experience that you can get lost in for hours.

If you are a fan of the strategy genre and have't experienced Total War as of yet, give this game a try.

9/10
