title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War was a groundbreaking game back when it came out and provided opportunity for both strategic and tactical gameplay. The strategy came from building a world-dominating empire, one turn at a time, and sending your army out to subdue and absorb other lands in the name of Rome. The tactical component was satisfied by a n excellent battlefield simulation where you were the architect of a battle's victory, or defeat. This mixed-level gaming offered something for any strategy or war gaming fan and justly earned a place in gaming history and... Oh you can go and on. Rome doesn't need reviews to discuss it properly - it needs entire books.

Rome: Total War is one of my favorite games of all time and in a real way, Rome: Total War is the absolute exemplar of PC gaming. It's about what only PCs can really do: that is, everything, and everything at once. In an age of comfortable genre-games, the Total War series have always stood slightly aside from the main thrust of culture.

title: Rome Total War
review:
An absolute classic strategy game that I spent many hours playing back in the mid-2000s, which are not shown here. It combines RTS battles with a turned based style campaign, both of which are excellent. It is set in the 3rd to 1st centuries BC, which witnessed the rise of the Roman Empire. The graphics were amazing back in the day but have naturally dated over time, but are still aesthetically pleasing. The soundtrack is still as good as it was when the game was released however. A thoroughly enjoyable title all things considered.

A few words of warning however. This game is not terribly historically accurate. There are mods that aim to fix this but its worth bearing in mind if this is important to you. This does not affect gameplay.

title: Rome Total War
review: Wonderfully strategic. The game is a marvel especially for its decade. Made in 2004, it's basically an empire building game with wonderfully historically accurate land architecture (most of) the factions and units. There's no B.S. Microtransactions so the empire building is fun and also very in depth. Don't know what I mean? Well, you start off with a family. Julii, Brutii and Scipii are the choices. You start with a faction leader and a couple sons. Each family member acts as a general or official depending on where you send him. His experiences also shape his abilities. Let's say you constantly keep sending 'ol Decius out to conquer and battle enemies. Well his ability to command will rise and he will gain new traits such as confident commander. Your faction leader gets a trait called faction leader and you can also pick a son who will inherit this position. This son will get a trait called faction heir until he inherits the position as leader. You can also pay to have agents trained such as, the diplomat, and the assassin. The diplomat can talk to leaders, generals and other diplomats. He can help your faction work out deals with other factions and depending on his influence level, which is like command ability in that it decides on how well he can persuade and speak, be successful. These deals can be such as alliances, tribute, single payment, trade rights, giving territory, ceasefire in the case of a war, and many more. The assassin can well, assassinate. You can use him on enemy leaders and members and depending on their traits and skills will influence his ability to succeed. He can also infiltrate enemy camps to report their statistics to you and he can also wait inside for you to attack the camp and then open the gates for you. But if he gets caught he gets slaughtered. Also is the management ability and similar to command and influence, it decides how well this family member can manage a settlement town or city. If a settlement is poorly managed it can lead to peasant revolts and low taxes. This greatly reduces income. If you make war with another faction by attacking, you can attack each of their settlements strategically. The Gauls start north of the factions and I encourage you to start with them. Your family members can also gain office in the senate. Completing missions assigned by the senate greatly increases your chances of winning. You can also bribe factions to gain favor with them. Your also able to see how the people of Rome feel about you and how the Senate feels about you. This favor will quickly decline if you don't do the senate missions. I probably missed a lot but you get the gist of it. Oh and before O forget, you can train your own units of soldiers and make buildings in settlements to increase income and your army. Now onto the combat strategy section of the game. There are several ways to initiate combat. One is naval combat. Naval combat is basically just the computer seeing who has more ships between two sides. Whoever has more wins. There's no 3-d part of it and it's very short. Troop combat is where it gets really interesting. The first way to initiate combat is by attacking a settlement. Attacking will be violating the peace and will begin a war with whatever faction owns the settlement. You will then begin a siege.  You now have two choices. You can either wait out the siege or you can build siege upgrades, wait however many turns for them to finish building, and then attack. I forgot to mention the turns. It's not what your probably thinking. It basically that eventually your troops diplomats and such will stop moving on the map because time is passing. They will stop because their turn is over. When building anything it will take a certain amount of turns to finish. You can move to your next turn by clicking end turn. The factions will then do whatever they want to do sometimes meaning they send reinforcements or start wars. Each turn is half an in game year. Each family member starts at a certain age. Eventually after attaining a certain age they die. They can also die in battle. This is how the heir inherits the position. Anyways back to battle. So if you choose to attack with your now built siege weapons it zooms into a 3D view of the settlement. You will start outside of its walls (if it has them) and you can position your troops around a line around the settlement however you please before battle. After your done click begin battle. This starts the battle and you can now see the enemy troops unless they're hiding. We'll talk a little about that later. If you need to breach the walls then select your siege weapons, find a weak spot and attack. Beware of archer towers they will set wooden battering rams on fire. If you lose all siege weapons you lose. If you have an assassin inside he may be able to open the doors for you. It's all real time but you can speed up or pause the battle at your leisure. You can also make troops walk or run depending on the speed you want things. Keep in mind running will eventually tire them out. Weather can also effect troops. You can choose however many units you wish and click the location you want them. They will run or walk depending on what you select. Another way to start battle is attacking a general outside a settlement. This can also happen to you along with the previous to your settlements. Outside settlement battles are about the same minus the siege weapons and walls. It's just you, him, and the terrain. You can hide behind trees and surprise them or rush in. It's up to you. You can zoom in and out of the view closer or farther to the action as you see fit. I'm sure I missed a lot as this game is incredibly in depth but you get the idea. Try it. Your money will NOT be wasted.

[h1]Woth buying [b]FULL PRICE[/b][/h1]

Even with outdated graphics games feels like an absolute masterpiece- if you are Total War fan than this game is a must-have. It contains of 2 segments- [b]Turn-based grand campaign[/b] and a [b]Battle segment[/b] including land and siege battles. The game covers an era in ancient times and introduces simplistic economy, politics and warcraft. Battles are where it really shines- you are offered to use many, many various units ranging from Roman Legionnaries, Greek Phalanx up to Hannibal's Elephants. Additional DLC introduces [b]era of Alexander The Great[/b] and [b]late ancient times[/b] with new factions and barbarian tribes. This is how ROME II was supposed to be like...

title: Rome Total War
review:
If you're playing this game today for the first time you might not see how fantastic it was. I played it when it first released back in 2004 and it blew my mind. I had always been a fan of strategy games but before Rome: Total War I had only ever played strategy games such as Age of Empires 1 and 2, Rise of Nations, Cossacks - all great games with a special place in my gamer heart, but Rome was the first time I ever saw thousands of soldiers fighting on my screen at the same time, as opposed to those other games where you see as few as 30. Not only could you see thousands of soldiers fighting at the same time, you can actually zoom in very close. This just blew my mind. I never even dreamed this would be possible.

I used to sit at highschool and daydream about playing this game. I just wanted to get home and play it for another 10 hours. You choose your faction (Rome, Egypt, Greeks, whatever) and manage your growing empire. Build stuff in your cities, recruit armies, battle with other armies, decide the fate of enemy cities you conquer and so forth.

Music is PERFECT. Iconic really. I have the main menu theme for this game on my MP3 player. Graphics look old but what do you expect for a almost 15-year old game? I think my favourite thing of all in this game are the generals. Your generals are characters with traits and personalities. If one of your family members comes of age at 16-years old and you just leave him in a big rich city his whole life, he basically becomes a corrupt gambling lout. If you send them out to command armies and conquer enemies you can turn them into little Julius Caesars.

I recommend it, no problem. I still play it sometimes for the nostalgia. Some of the mods for this game are remarkable - my favourite is Europa Barbarorum (they also made Europa Barbarorum II for Medieval II: Total War). It's a very realistic modification for the game - changes almost everything because one thing that Rome: Total War was NOT was realistic.

100x better than that fraud of a game they call Total War: Rome 2. Rome 2 isn't fit to touch the hem on Rome 1's garments.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Overall a brilliant game. One of the best strategic games I've ever played.

Over the past 10 years or so I've played the first 3 Rome Total War games, Medieval Total War and the first Shogun Total War game.

The first game sets you in ancient Rome during the decline of the Greek "empire". You have multiple factions to choose from such as three Roman houses, the Britons, Germanic tribes, Gallic tribes, Greeks, various forms of Persians and many more. The main campaign usually gives you a set goal, such as hold 20 regions and take Rome. You'll have to build up your wealth, armies and infrastructure before taking on these goals as the diplomacies and technologies of the world advance. Playing as the Romans you will be given specific requests by the senate of Rome, asking you to use naval warfare on an enemy port or to take a city from the enemy, for example. The AI, both in battles and the campaign map, are really good! The only problem with the first RTW game is if you're playing as the Romans, eventually...no matter what, the Senate will turn on you. You can do all of their missions and so on, but once you reach too much power/wealth/land, they deem you an enemy of Rome and you have to fight all other houses (by which time, are usually the strongest adversaries) and take Rome itself.

In all three games you have historical battles, re-enactments of famous battles of their time periods. These are always good fun but not incredibly repeatable after your first victory or two.

In Alexander you play as the Macedonians conquering Asia and moving towards India. This game is different as it has a shorter time limit on achieving the goals. The game is more focused on constant combat rather than building up the infrastructure of an empire. It's still good fun if you're a fan of RTW but you can essentially do the same and more by just playing as the Greeks in the original game and heading east (while defending the west from the Romans too, of course).

The third (and my favourite) game is Barbarian Invasion. Barbarian Invasion takes place hundreds of years after the first game and focuses on the fall of the Roman Empire. There is no senate to appease. In the words of Palpatine, "I am the senate". The main reason I find this game to be the best is because of the barbarian horde system. The game is very similar to the original, with the factions being mostly just the descendants of the original factions. The Romans, instead of being 3 houses and the senate, are now two empires, the East (rich and probably the best of all due to superior infantry and cavalry) and the West (still the main bastion of Rome but clearly losing control). The horde system works with some factions from the start of the game but essentially it works like this. When a faction that can create a horde loses its final outpost, it will form a horde of around 3,000 troops. These will usually be strong infantry, archers and average-good cavalry. They will be able to march wherever they like, destroying or capturing anything in their way until they find a new land to settle in. Once the horde have taken 3 settlements, all remnants of it will dissapear (if you have 1,000 horde infantry in a city, they will dissapear). The horde system will continue to work until the faction has no family members/generals left. The horde system is always interesting as it leaves you having to be prepared for anything or nothing, which makes the game (in my opinion) the best in the series.

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of the best Total War games of all time - tied with Medieval II, in my humble opinion.

The game is of course, graphically old, but it's aged very well. The map, the interface and the campaign are very well done. There's a nice choice of countries - once you clear it as the Romans - and three playable Roman factions helps to bring across the feeling of the Civil War. Like the Catholic Church in Medieval II, the Senate will give you missions, and your actions will reflect your popularity with the Senate and the plebians. The fact that you play as a Roman family means you have to - to an extent - work within the confines and wishes of the Senate.

The entire Roman Empire - Europe, North African etc - is represented on the map. The ancient nations of the time - Gauls, Britions, Carthage, Greeks etc - are all in force. Each Roman family - Caesar, Scipio or Brutus - has an enemy tribe that must be defeated to win the game.

Well worth the money. 9/10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
While I'm not new to Total War, I have actually never played "Rome" until recently. A bit strange for me, since classical history is my jam.

Anyway, I'm "only" 15 hours in, but I can already say this has become my favourite strategy game. Ever.

It's supremely satisfying and addictive. I often find myself saying "just one more turn" and then finding myself saying it again, 12 turns later. And of course, nothing beats getting into a positively MASSIVE battle, with lots of factions joining the fray and watching the utter mayhem unfurl.

The best part is, both the strategic and tactical layers of the game are very simple and easy to pick up, but offer plenty of depth — it's exactly what a strategy game should be. It is deep without being needlessly complicated. Though I have not played them, the amount of modifications for this game is insane and most of them look great.

I do have some minor complaints, though. One is that naval "combat", if we can call it that, is limited to auto-resolve battles (that's not the bad part) which tend to become far too frequent and annoying once all hell has broken loose (that's the bad part). It gets such that when I try to move a ship just from Italy to Greece it's like being swarmed by bees only the bees are ships. Secondly, I'd say even the "short" campaign goes on for way too long. I would also say that most of the senate missions are largely inconsequential and not particularly interesting or challenging if you're playing as the Romans.

Lastly, I did only have one odd bug — occupying a settlement as the Julii crashed the game once.

Regardless, you'll have enough fun with the game even in its vanilla state. Even if you don't mod it, I fully recommend the Alexander campaign add-on as well!

title: Rome Total War
review:
[h1] Rome: Total War Review [/h1]

I am almost new to the TW saga and tried the good old RTW to get a feel of the series. So I don't have much comparison points.

TLDR: An excellent strategy and tactical game, hits a sweet spot between Civilization and Crusader Kings. The battles are real and the the management while a little less deep than CK still keeps you busy !

[b] Pros: [/b] [list]
[*]A lot of factions that play differently, I only completed Rome short campaign so far but I can get a feel of what other faction look like
[*]Well balanced game, events unfold, Rome triumph and you must take over the known world ! Win by force and bribes.
[*]A huge fan and modding community improving a lot the base game
[*]Awesome sound track, seriously
[*]Addicting as hell, one more turn....
[/list]
[b] Cons: [/b] [list]
[*]Hopeless AI who calls for a ceasefire and then attacks the next turn, unable to manage the empire development like a human would do. Victory is actually won in the first 10h of a game
[*]Lack of historical realism, especially for barbarian tribes (fixed with EB mod)
[*]Undeniable aging marks, doesnt fit to modern monitors
[/list]

title: Rome Total War
review: It's a good game, but whoever is in charge of releasing it on steam really needs to do better at making it compatible with newer computers. Constant performance issues and crashes on a high performance computer is unacceptable for a game that's been out as long as this one has. Something as simple as running the game in an emulator of the computer this game was meant to run on would fix a lot of these problems, but apparently no one cares about keeping the game up to date anymore, even though they're perfectly happy to take our money. If you have a computer from the early 2000's, then go ahead; otherwise, there are better, more modern options available.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I play House Julii and I will just say this. in my first game, the Gauls were a real nuisance with their constant attempts to take my land, constantly breaking a ceasefire and constantly demanding I give them ALL my territory in return for an empty threat which I usually laught at. I quickly wiped them out and then focused my attention towards the East and North as I now had control over the the majority of the West and my fellow Roman Allies holding the South. The Britania kingdom had suddenly declared war upon my house and I sent my best and finest troops in to halt their invasion. my men held them back as I sent out my diplomats to request help from my allies the Egyptians, the Dacians and Thracians in which only the Thracians came to my help as the Dacians and Egyptians didn't want to get involved. after a hard fought battle I had obtained a Ceasefire with the Britanians so I could focus on the advancment of my people and land fully rather than very little as most of my funds went to producing new and better soldiers to fight in the front lines.
I may not have finished my first game at the time making this review but I do say i'll be playing this for many years to come.
10/10 - Would slaughter the Gauls again for the shits and giggles.

title: Rome Total War
review:
>Be me, a 27 year old Greek King.
>I own a land called Thrace.
>Crazy place made up of a cross between Greek and Scythian.
>About 125-30 years ago, some Thracian King and his son decided to expand the nation.
>The son heads for Byzantium, while the King heads for Macedonia.
>All other generals head for Pontus.
>Byzantium falls quickly, Macedon is divided between the Spartans and Thracians.
>War against Pontus was bloody, and lasted longer than the King.
>His son leads a new campaign, he is victorious.
>Our lands remain in peace until my reign.
>Spent my early adult years partying hard.
>Realise that I'm the heir.
>Welp.painting
>Become King.
>Turn my reputation around in less than 2 years.
>Build up Thracian economy to outdo even Rome.
>Suddenly, some Greek envoy shows up at Byzantium (New Capital)
>Says "The Romans have taken all of our mainland cities, Sparta has burned, Rhodes is under siege, and Pergamum stands as our last free city."
>Uh oh.
>"Please, help us!"
>Say yes.
>Build up army, reorganize it too.
>Greek troops make up the center, mercenaries make up the wings, barbarians make up reserves.
>Round up generals.
>Begin campaign.
>Quickly take Illyria, crush Romans at Attica.
>Romans begin counter-strike at Thermon.
>Pyrhicc victory against the Romans.

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of the best games in the Total War series, I highly recommend buying this Rome instead of Rome II. The graphics seem bad BUT remember, this game was made in 2004 and graphics don't always matter, especially when the game itself is very fun, it's a turn-based game (on the campaign-map) and the battles are real time, even when armies meet eachother near some mountains, forest and wonders, you'll be able to see them on the battlefield. Empire building is fun too and you can roleplay during a battle/campaign (if you like that). When you don't feel like starting the roman empire, you can also defend it(Western Roman Empire), how? Well as you might know there is a DLC-like called Barbarian Invasion, now it's your time to fight for Christendom and/or Paganism, corruption and barbarian hordes who have learned how to (sometimes) out-combat the Romans. If you're interested in Alexander the Great you can buy the 'Alexander' edition where you need to defeat the Persian Empire in a given amount of turns. So if you like building the Roman Empire,  
make the Roman Empire great again (or conquer it) or conquer the Persians and you don't mind the graphics, I highly recommend you buying this game, it's definitely worth the small amount of money, and you'll (probalby) enjoy every single hour you put in this game!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Even though this game was made in 2004, don't let that fool you. I still find myself coming to this game on a annual basis. I probably sunk in over two thousand hours into this game. It's hilarious watching elephants steamroll a army; creepy too how a lot of soundbites from this game are found scattered across media.

10/10; a must have!

title: Rome Total War
review:
before the review i want to make clear that this review is not related to multiplayer nor its dlc's

This is rome total war, the game that makes a regular ordinary gamer into a military mastermind in classical warfare within about 50 or so hours by using THE BEST battle mechanics that you could ever imagine making battles rely less on who has a bigger and stronger stick but more on the skill of the person ordering the solder. does this mean that you can win aganst an entire roman army with a single peasant? no that would be stupid but you can win a fight using an army that has troops half as good while still being outnumbered if you know what you are doing.
now to pros and cons
pros: Amazing battle mechanics
fun seige battles for both the attacker and defender
all units have a purpose (Exept peasants who are pretty much useless)
great battle speaches (ik this sounds weird but it can actually help you plan what to do)
there is a counter to everything
encouragement for a diverse army
graphics even by todays standerds are very good
the feeling of controling huge armies to fight more huge armies
generals get traits baised on their situations (ex: if you have too much money in treasury generals will get corrupt and extravagant and if its too low they become cheap and more reluctant to spend money which can be both good and bad)
some traits become bad it they get too high (ex drinkers start at a good bonus but gradualy become worse as the general becomes more alchoholic)
ELEPHANTS
you are not just limited to playing as the romans you also can play as carthage, various barbarian factions, greeks, egypt, and more. 
combat looks and feels amazing
Huge amounts of small but important details (ex: culture penalties occor when occuping a settlement that is not your own and affects happiness depending on how different they are from your faction because you would not expect egyptians to be happy about being ruled by barbarians from germany)
Cons:
everyone sounds very similar
diplomacy is a bit of a joke
ai tends to be retarded
if you have windows 10 then it takes a lot of optimization and patients to get the game to work right
some units are a bit op
lots of micromanagment (this can be good or bad depending on who you ask)
not historically accurate
some factions are much more fun to play as than others

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is to turn-based strategy games what Age of Empires is to first generation RTS games... 

Rome: Total War is old, but still going strong.  It is a wonder of gameplay that the Total War franchise should continue to emulate.  It was a masterpiece then, and it still is a masterpiece today.  You need to play this game if you haven't yet, and are into turn-based strategy games.  Trust me, you'll thank me later.

Plus, it's nostalgic as hell. (10/10)

title: Rome Total War
review:
I legit would not be a PC gamer were it not for this game. I had never seen a game do what this game did and it was seriously epic and blew my teenage self away when I played it. I probably have close to 1000 hours in this game and I still have my goddam Rome Total War CD with the case and everything. I rebought it in Steam for the hell of it and cause I absolute loved this game and still do. It's definitely showing its age but even still, I find it absolutely rediculous that in some ways, the first Rome: Total War is STILL better than the second one a decade and some later... The battle mechanics in the tactical part of the game are the absolute pinnacle of the series and the campaign strategic part of the game had the family tree and dynamic traits for your leaders/generals that helped you connect with them and increased immersion. Only really minor and miniscule complaints is that cavalry are a bit too op in general and the Gauls a little bit underpowered but otherwise, this is the most balanced Total War battle mechanics wise Creative Assembly has made. Let alone the fact that the complaints above can be easily fixed due to mods... And thats another great thing about this game.. the moddability compared to the newer Warscape engine Total Wars is unparalled. Hell there was a Napoleonic Wars mod for this game... and even still, lets not get into the soundtrack which is amazing in of itself... Easily the greatest strategy game and probably my most favorite PC game of all time.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=B7kcau-Tx1A

title: Rome Total War
review:
Let me start by saying I owned this game on CD at first. and only bought it on sale a while ago. I started playing this game in 2005.
Pro's and Con's down below.

The total war™ franchise has been one great adventure for me. I own all the total war games and Rome: Total War™ Its the best one out of all the other total war™ games. The great element about this game is that you only pay for the base game! To unlock other factions to play, You got to conquer their faction and wipe them out. Almost all Major factions are playable. and alot of minor factions as well. My personal favorite faction is Egypt and Sparta. It offers an extramly fun time.

My Score:
Sound: 9/10    
The Game audio is great. Voice actors are awsome and the music is a masterpeace.

Graphics: 7/10 
This one is hard to do cause in todays standard of graphics its old school. but if you are like me and started 
playing with even older graphics its not that difficult to play with.

Gameplay: 10/10 Almost every faction offers a totaly diffrent playstyle from an easy one to a hard one. Also no factions are unlocked with DLC is all free. but like I said. you got to crush that faction into the dust first to unlock it (or edit the game files) Also the diffrent troop style's is great. Playing as rome you best way to fight is on open ground. but playing as a "barbarian" faction the best way to fight the romans is to ambush them. fight in the forest. hills. etc. 

Replay Value 10/10
Just that I started another playthrough of egypt and withing 10 turns my previes playthourh allies now declared war on me is great. the politics and all your actions can change every single action. also you can also loose a family member who is badass and cause of the loss of a great general your amry is weakend and is suddenly attacked by a strong enemy general who crushes a few city's untill you got another army to help out.

Pro's:
- Great political system although it could be better with mods :) 
- Great family tree system (even better then the attila one)
- Unlock factions by crushing them. You only start off with 3 roman factions.
- Great audio and great gameplay.
- Big battles that are badass
- Great sieges of city's
- Good world map
- Trading is actualy way better then other total war games
- The missions you get from your politcal party.
There is so much more I can put here. but you gotta find that out for youself

Con's
- Not the greatest AI. 
- Some small game breaking glitches.
- The controlls can be weird. I suggest editing them before you play.

Just that this is one of my favorite games I am willing to buy it for full 60 Euro price today.
But that its only so little money I suggest picking it up right away. I suggest you buy the collection casue the elexander DLC and the Barabarian invasian are also great!

The political system is refined and gives the player plenty of freedom to go about their objectives how they see fit. Unlike You-Know-What-Game that CA made the AI is good, although it certainly isn't perfect and you'll see plenty of off the wall stuff from yours and the enemy units. title: Rome Total War
review:
I first bought Rome Total War gold edition from my local Electronics Boutique store, in DVD format. Unfortunately, I played the game so much I broke the CD, which is why I had to buy the game off Steam. Luckily, they were having a sale on at the time so I got both Rome, Barbarian Invasion and Alexander as a package deal for less than $5. This is slightly less than I bought the original game, so it's all good.

Even in its vanilla state Rome is an awesome game and ties with Medieval II as my favorite Total War game of all. Gameplay is a mixture of turn based strategy at an administrative level, which switches to real time action during battles. As a younger player I found it hilarious to create an army full of thousands of war dogs and fight rebel peasants, shouting "cry havoc and unleash the dogs of WAAAAR!" as I did so. The actual goal of the game, however, is to become powerful enough to overthrow the Senate and conquer the entire map. Almost every faction you manage to completely defeat then becomes playable for later campaigns. My personal favorite faction was the Parthians - the first time I saw them was a real eye opener. Picture an army of feroicious desert bandits charging towards you, dressed in hot luminious pink.

There are a couple of pretty glaring historical inaccuricies in the game, the most obvious being Egypt. It's not Ptolemaic Egypt but Old Kingdom Egypt, which is out of date by a couple of centuries. A bigger problem comes in the fact that Steam is a bit quirky in loading the game. To access Barbarian Invasion, you have to run the game via the Steam Library, not by clicking the icon, which will only load the standard Rome. This becomes a major issue if you decide to run one of the many great mods out there, such as Ran no Jidai or FATW, because their icons won't work. To work around this, right click on Rome Total War in the steam library, then click on "set launch options". This will show a box where you can enter the command line necessary to load a mod. For example, for Fourth Age Total War, the command line is: 

 -mod:bi\fatw

This tells Rome to load the modification in the listed folder, so just alter it to whatever mod you have. Remember to load Barbarian Invasion via the Steam Library if the mod runs off BI, or you'll get an error!

title: Rome Total War
review:
My favorite Total War game and the game that actually got me into the series.
I love the roman period.
I have literally spent 1000's of hours on this game, probably completed the campaign more than 50 times, not including the 2 dlc's, that was well before steam. 
And apart from the graphics/resolution, a game spoiling bug (epic seige bug) and the quite boring building structure, compared to later games, this game is still my prefered TW game even over rome 2!

This is a great game to get if you are a TW fan and want to play on a low spec laptop.
It is not about the graphics like more modern TW games, for me it is the far more simpler strategy and building management that would make me suggest for people to buy this game.
The building structure was quite simple as was the diplomacy, army management etc.. essentially, when you know what you are doing, maintaining an attacking flow and constant faction progression is a much easier task than R2 for instance.
Perfect for playing when you don't exactly want to invest a whole amount of mental energy to a campaign, but want to succeed, and enjoy a great TW game..

title: Rome Total War
review:
First off, this is the second time I've bought this game so my hours don't reflect my total playtime.

This game may not be new (and may take a little time to get it working on Windows 10, see the community guide for help), but its by far my most played game. The campaign map is played turn based, where you move around your armies, manage your cities and recruit new troops. However, when you engage in combat, the armies fight in real time.

The turnbased part of the game is quite well done, with money being your biggest worry early on, and as you get that down pat, your public order breaking down as your empire exceeds its limits. All the while, your borders encroach on similarly powerful neighbours, keeping the game interesting till the very end.

The combat is where this game really shines though, especially on the highest unit settings. Watching a unit of 160 men marching in in formation as you order them is amazing. 20 of them? Even better. For when you're still learning the game, there are some options you can pick to make the inital learning experience easier, like switching off morale and fatigue, and giving your units infinite ammunition. Then, once you have them down pat, you can switch them on and suffer as your army loses the will to fight in a long battle.

Overall, taking into account its age, this game is easily a 8/10

title: Rome Total War
review: Bought this game along time ago around the time when it came out on CD and its still one of my favourite PC games. Its quite dated by todays standard and compared to the new total war games but it is still worth a try for a few £££ to play the first big total war game that got alot of people into the series.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Between the Original Rome: Total War and Medieval 2: Total War you will not find better gameplay mechanics, factions, attachment to generals/family members in any other Total War title.

These games are the golden age of Total War. Unless you do not care about gameplay and are a graphics junky, you don't even need the new games.

Pros: 
-Just best music of any Total War title
-One of the only games with diverse units for all factions (Much more than current titles)
-Heartfelt speeches from generals before each battle, which reflects their traits they have earned. Some are just hilarious.
-Nothing better than domesticating stinky barbarians in the name of Rome.

-Cheap when on sale is always great. You can own this piece of Total War history and all the DLC for like $10. That's great.
-Even playing as a stinky barbarian or Egyptian or any other non-Roman pleb you can still have fun and win.
-Noteable online community still plays, there aren't a ton of them but you can still find a game.
-AI is actually pretty smart, and will try to get your general, flank, target lightly armored units with archers etc.

Cons:
I don't see any cons in this game, just like you can't see the first letter of every pro I wrote for it.

title: Rome Total War
review: This game brings back a lot of memories for me. I remember my brothers playing this game while I watched them from behind their gaming chair. I remember when my brother put a herd of elephants versus 2000 peasants. I remember being able to destroy entire factions and take their cities. I remember being able to defend your cities with archers and destroy the enemy siege weapons before they breached your walls. I remember running my cavalry into the waiting spears of my enemies and feeling sad that my once thought invincible cavalry needed to be used more tactfully. This game is such an integrable part of my childhood and taught me what a good game was. I hope you enjoy it, too.

title: Rome Total War
review:
(Hundreds of hours played before purchase on Steam.)

Music 8/10
Gameplay 10/10
Voice Acting 9/10
Replayability 9/10
Video rendering and special effects 8/10
Sound effects 9/10
Story 6/10
Scaling of difficulty 9/10
Overall: 9/10

This game offers a wealth of freedom in strategy and tactics.  The game is played turn-based on the campaign (strategic) map, and pausable RTS on the battle map.  Difficulty is independently scalable for the strategic portion and for the tactical portion of the game.  

Terrain in the campaign map translates directly to terrain on the battle map; and terrain and weather can have dramatic effects on battle.  For instance, arrows fly farther if your archers are uphill of the enemy.  Bridges can be used as bottlenecks to block an enemy's crossing, while your archers decimate them.  Friendly fire is possible, and in many battles I have lost more men to my own archers than to the enemy.  Rain reduces archer effectiveness.  Open fields allow cavary to have more effective charges.  Uphill soldiers fight more effectively against their downhill opponents, Some troops gain a battle advantage in snow, and etc.

Music fades in and out nicely, and always seems appropriate for what is happening on the battlefield or the campaign map.  Voice acting of the advisors, and of the generals before the battles is well done, and often hilarious (there are some really funny audio "Easter eggs" in there).

It is possible to win battles against much bigger armies by exploiting the strengths and weaknesses of units.  Just one example: An enemy of infantry attacking your cavalry can be exhausted by using the superior stamina of the horses to evade the footmen for a time.  Attacking exhausted footmen usually results in a rout of the exhausted troops.

Replayability is high.  Different factions (most are playable after defeating them in a previous game) have different strengths, and playing them really is a different experience.  For instance, all the Roman factions are very well rounded and have an excellent infantry and tech tree.  Carthage has devastating elephant troops, but weak archers.  Other factions, like Partia, rely on heavy cavalry.  Gaul has a weak tech tree and economy (they are barbariaans, after all); but their troops can get big boosts from their religious system, their fierceness can induce morale penalties to their enemies, and they can field, by far, the best archers in the game.  Egypt has chariots, a well tounded military, and an excellent starting position on the map, allowing it to become an economic powerhouse without much opposition in the early game.  And the list of meaningful differences goes on...

title: Rome Total War
review: Honestly, this is for sure, the greatest Total War game ever created. Although people complain about graphics, it doesn't affect the game's playability, and I don't play games for graphics. This game does have optimization issues but that only shows up on the absolutely huge battles. Unlike the newer installments (ex rome 2) the combat works correctly (troops don't break formation to have a super epic 1v1 and then get stabbed in the back) The music is flawless and truly is the best for any Total War game. The Cinematic General speeches at the start of battles were a fantastic feature for getting you pumped that i'm sad they removed. Colo(u)rful units and banners add life to battles. Aswell as an interesting and in-depth campaign that allows you to choose 1 of 3 houses of Rome and conquer all of Europe, Northern Africa, And bits of the Middle East, once you have conquered your foes you will unlock many new factions to try and conquer everyone with. It is also possible to add AI players into multiplayer games unlike in Medieval 2 where for some reason that is not allowed. There were so many great mechanics in the first Rome that got removed in the later installments which is so dissapointing, however there is a lack of historic accuracy in a fair amount of things, but I absolutely love this game, 9/10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War was the first strategic game i played when I was young. It amazed me then, and it still amazes me today. Even if the graphics are old, but who cares about graphics..
The voiceacting of units, generals and the charming woman who guides you through your campaign are amazing compared to the one from Rome2. The units are well-balanced and you should really consider studying the advantages and vulnerabilities of every unit to correctly use it in combat-situations. Theres a relatively big map for you to conquer, with loads of diferent tribes and people you can fight or forge alliances with. And even if you like the actual battles more than the strategic manoeuvring on the campaignmap, you can have lots of fun setting up quick, custom or historical battles in either multi- or singleplayer.

If you are thinking about whether you should play Rome:Total War before playing Rome2 i have only one hint for you: Get Rome:Total War, play it and enjoy it, but if you expect the same from the second installation you should not waste your money, believe me... not even for the graphics (that aren't really the best anyway).
I still have only good memories of Rome: Total War.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is the sequel to the first Medieval: Total War, and despite the game's age it still holds up very well in my opinion. Just something you should take into consideration is that the game with the default configuration often does not launch on Windows 10, there are plenty of tutorials out there that can help you solve this problem. Now the PROS and CONS:

PROS:
+Awesome modding community; There are a lot of awesome mods out there for Rome: Total War, just be wary that the game doesn't have a Steam Workshop though, so you will have to download these mods from other websites.
+The game allows you full freedom over the faction you control, as one of the Roman factions you can choose to do the missions the Senate gives you, which will give you rewards such as troops or money, or ignore these completely (which would ofcourse hurt your standing with the Senate, that in the early game wouldn't be a good decision) and as one of the non-Roman factions you do not have an optional mission given at all (Unlike in Medieval: 2 Total War).
+Due to the freedom of the game, you can play a faction in a campaign multiple times without it becoming repetitive because you can choose to set different goals every campaign. (I have over 500+ hours played, still haven't gotten much into multiplayer yet that the game does still support and has people playing it).

CONS (Things to take into consideration):
-The game runs on 1 CPU core, so on modern systems the game wouldn't run as well.
-The pathfinding in cities can often be odd and sometimes requires micromanagement if you don't want your troops running into different directions, other than this the pathfinding is good however.

If you are considering getting Rome: Total War, get it!

title: Rome Total War
review:
[h1] Rome: Total War - The one that every Total War fan loves [/h1]

If you like strategy games, it should go without saying that you should have Rome: Total War by now. If not, buy it. It's a classic. It has turn-based campaign map where you control your military, economy and other important things while in battles the game turns into real-time strategy. Almost everything you have seen in later Total War games, it pretty much started here (mostly, it set basic standards for those games).

I don't want to write a long review, since there are a lot of things in this game. I thought that I should just mention, what I consider, the most important aspects here:

+ Almost every faction has different strengths and weaknesses and so on... pretty basic for a strategy game.
+ Average, but simple diplomacy, which does it's job well.
+ Basic city control, where you can manage you taxes, buildings and other things. It just works.
+ Most of the time battles go well depending on your skill, units (with varying experience and equipment) and generals....
+ Oh my..... Generals are the best. Their traits and skills dynamically improve depending on city buildings, battles, political power and other circumstances. WHY WAS THIS REMOVED IN TOTAL WARS AFTER MEDIEVAL 2??!!!!! And sometimes their traits can affect their battle speeches. Alcoholic/social drinker --> "the first one to kill gets my finest wine", boring speaker --> "hello, today we are here to do battle", mad --> "I ATE ALL OF THEIR BEES!!!"
+ Very good unit detail for a old game. Also, in general, graphics are passable and they don't bother much despite its age.
+ Nice music.
+ A surprising amount of small details here and there.

Neutral:
* Not entirely historically accurate. For example, Rome is split into four different factions, but it was needed to balance the game and make civil war possible at the time. Greek cities are one faction, apperently.

- Sometimes units disobey your orders for unknown reasons (this can be considered a positive, as it's unrealistic to assume that everyone follows orders perfectly).
- Unit formations are messy when you try to enter the city and move towards the target.
- Towers apperently have automatic turrets that shoot infinite arrows (this was fixed in Medieval 2).

I know, my review is pretty lazy, but I just wanted to mention this fantastic game incase someone somehow doesn't know or tried this game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
'i there. Let me tell you a story about a man, Total War:Rome and how it changed my life.


This man was an absolute hero. I loved him. Everything he did, I would obsess over. I soon got to the point of worshipping this man religiously and trying to get others into my cult. I spread the word about this man just like Ignatius Loyola spead the word about Reformed Catholicism. I created many large quizzes dedicated to him. Me and the rest of the 'cult' even had a gang sign dedicated to him. Why did I do all of this? The answer is simple. It's because he is cool.

Now, this man was quite fond of Ancient Roman history, as well as people like General Eisenhower (for those that don't know, General Eisenhower was the man who invented computers.) Of course, because of this, I and the other members of the 'cult' began to take a liking to Ancient Roman history too. How did we find out he loved Ancient Rome? We managed to take a look at his computer desktop and on there was a game known as Total War:Rome.


The man I have previously been talking about loved the game Total War:Rome. It is a strategy game, much like another of his favourite games, chess. He has spent hundreds of hours of his time playing Total War:Rome, so of course I had to follow in his footsteps. This game reminds me a lot of this man, and why shouldn't it? This man is one of the things that make my life worth living and some aspects of Total War:Rome are very similar to his ways. The battle instructure, Marcus is somewhat like the previously mentioned man and seeing lots of soldiers running around in battle really shows what a computer is capable of. General Eisenhower would be proud.

All in all, this game is a masterpiece. If you wish to join my 'cult', playing this game is a good way to understand our ways.

This game was made in 2004 and it's still amazing. There are a few limitations due to its advanced age of course. 1. The AI is poor at best, even on the higher difficulties. Most battles come down to flanking or a well timed charge. 2. The diplomacy is absolutely broken. As in " I know you've almost wiped me out but give me half your money or fear the retribution of my one remaining city and unit" or "You're armies are five times as large as mine. Better attack your one undefended city anyways". And finally 3. It can be a little repetitive after a while.
But the good parts: You can take over Europe, improve your cities and destroy your enemies building an empire from the ground up. You can play at the strategic level and at the tactical level and both are equally rewarding. I've sunk a ridiculous amount of hours into this game. Enjoy!

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is one of the early Total Wars, and lacks some of the graphics and action of the later titles in the series. That said, it remains my favorite Total War. It's far more tactical than the newer games (Warhammer, Attila, the nearly unmentionable Rome II), and offers a greater scale, both during battles and on the campaign map. Best yet, though, is the accomplishment you feel when you take full control of the known world. You start with two provences. You can end with Europe, Northern Africa, and the Middle East. You truely do come from humble begginings in this game. I can't possible recommend this game enough, especially for fans of the Total War series.

(A Qucik Note: I'm not just shooting my mouth off about a game I just purchased. I have only about ten hours on Steam, but I've played this game on disc for years.)

title: Rome Total War
review:
An amazing game.
Its my first entry into the Total War series and I will likely get either Medieval 2 soon.
To start off, I need to clarify I also play Civ 5 and which is what really brought me in to the strategy genre.
Rome total war is mostly about combat however managing settlements is also crucial- to get rid of rioting and general unhappiness you need to bring the occupied populus under roman influence by building buildings which specifically have Roman architecture and have arenas to generally distract people and minimise riots. A governor is part of your family line and multiple will be born and you can either make them fight along your side or place them in command of a city, generally decided by their traits.
Combat is amazing, and a strong point of why I like this game. Unlike Civ 5 or Hearts Of iron (The later of which I dont have much experience with sadly) it's not mostly diplomatical or economical revolving around a tech tree but based on strategy.
You can beat enemies with overwhelming numbers and little tact, but that will cause you to spend money retraining troops. Sitting back and smashing a weak army is amazingly fun and so is seiging a heavily guarded city with distractions, saps, ladders and towers (Hence I love capitals, because they are usually ten times more challenging to beat and more fun that a city with a small army and no walls).

8/10, sadly the graphics are a bit dated.

;
; RTW Unit Details spreadsheet-generated unit descriptions
;
 
;Data entries are as follows
; Type          The internal name of the unit. Note this not necessarily the same as the on screen name
; dictionary        The tag used to look up the on screen name
;
;Category and class define the rough type of the unit. They're used for setting some
;default attributes and for determining where units go in formation amongst other things
; category      infantry, cavalry, siege, handler, ship or non_combatant
; class         light, heavy, missile or spearmen
;
; voice_type        Used to determine the type of voice used by the unit
;
; soldier       Name of the soldier model to use (from descr_models_battle.txt)
;               followed by the number of ordinary soldiers in the unit
;               followed by the number of extras (pigs dogs, elephants, chariots artillery pieces etc attached to the unit)
;               followed by the collision mass of the men. 1.0 is normal. Only applies to infantry
; officer       Name of officer model. There may be up to 0-3 officer lines per unit
; ship          Type of ship used if applicable
; engine        Type of siege engine used by unit
; animal        The type of non ridden on animals used by the unit
; mount         Type of animal or vehicle ridden on
;
; mount_effect  Factors to add when in combat against enemy units that have the specified mounts
;               Up to three factors may be specified, which may be classes of mount, or specific types
;
; attributes    A miscellanious list of attributes and abilities the unit may have. Including
;               sea_faring = can board ships
;               hide_forest, hide_improved_forest, hide_long_grass, hide_anywhere   = defines where the unit can hide
;               can_sap = Can dig tunnels under walls
;               frighten_foot, frighten_mounted = Cause fear to certain nearby unit types
;               can_run_amok = Unit may go out of control when riders lose control of animals
;               general_unit = The unit can be used for a named character's bodyguard
;               cantabrian_circle = The unit has this special ability
;               no_custom = The unit may not be selected in custom battles
;               command = The unit carries a legionary eagle, and gives bonuses to nearby units
;               mercenary_unit = The unit is s mercenary unit available to all factions
;
; formation     soldier spacing (in metres) side to side, then front to back for close formation
;               followed by the same measurements in loose formation.
;               followed by the default number of ranks for the unit
;               followed by the formations possible for the unit. One or two of
;               square, horde, phalanx, testudo, or wedge
;
; stat_health   Hit points of man, followed by hit points of mount or attached animal (if applicable)
;               Ridden horses and camels do not have separate hit points
;
;Details of unit's primary weapon. If the unit has a missile weapon it must be the primary
; stat_pri      From left to right
;               attack factor
;               attack bonus factor if charging
;               missile type fired (no if not a missile weapon type)
;               range of missile
;               amount of missile ammunition per man
;               Weapon type = melee, thrown, missile, or siege_missile
;               Tech type = simple, other, blade, archery or siege
;               Damage type = piercing, blunt, slashing or fire. (I don't think this is used anymore)
;               Sound type when weapon hits = none, knife, mace, axe, sword, or spear
;               Min delay between attacks (in 1/10th of a second)
; stat_pri_attr
;               primary weapon attributes any or all of
;                   ap = armour piercing. Only counts half of target's armour
;                   bp = body piercing. Missile can pass through men and hit those behind
;                   spear = Used for long spears. Gives bonuses fighting cavalry, and penalties against infantry
;                   long_pike = Use very long pikes. Phalanx capable units only
;                   short_pike = Use shorter than normal spears. Phalanx capable units only
;                   prec = Missile weapon is only thrown just before charging into combat
;                   thrown = The missile type if thrown rather than fired
;                   launching = attack may throw target men into the air
;                   area = attack affects an area, not just one man
;
;Details of secondary weapons. If the unit rides on, or has attached animals or vehicles
;then the secondary weapon details refer to their attacks. If the unit has missile weapons
;the secondary weapon will be the one used for melee
;If the unit has a primary melee weapon, it may have a secondary side arm
; stat_sec      As per stat_pri     (a value of no means no secondary weapon)
; stat_sec_attr As per stat_pri_attr
;
; stat_pri_armour   Details of the man's defences
;                   armour factor
;                   defensive skill factor (not used when shot at)
;                   shield factor (only used for attacks from the front of left)
;                   sound type when hit = flesh, leather, or metal
;
; stat_sec_armour   Details of animal's or vehicle's defenses (note riden horses do not have a separate defence)
;                   As per stat_pri_armour, except that the shield entry is ommited
;
; stat_heat         Extra fatigue suffered by the unit in hot climates
;
; stat_ground       Combat modifiers on different ground types. From left to right
;                   scrub, sand, forest, snow
; stat_mental       The base morale level, followed by discipline and training
;                   discipline may be normal, low, disciplined or imperuous. Impetuous units may charge without orders
;                   training determines how tidy the unit's formation is
;
; stat_charge_distance Distance from the enemy that the unit will begin charging
; stat_fire_delay   Ectra delay over that imposed by animation, hetween volleys
;
; stat_food         No longer used
; stat_cost         Number of turns to build,
;                   Cost of unit to construct
;                   Cost of upkeep
;                   Cost of upgrading weapons
;                   Cost of upgrading armour
;                   Cost for custom battles
; stat_ownership    List of factions and cultures that may have this unit

title: Rome Total War
review:
Wow. I have like a hundred hours on this game and i still haven't written a review. Well, better late than never... (sorry for cliché)

This game is... mmmmwah! (immagine an italian chef being impressed) Its trait system for family members is great and quite realistic, all the campaigns are fun, and it lets you pretend like you are the ruler of your empire-soon-to-be. This let me imagine and theorise what the future would have been like (e.g. win as carthage, what would the world have been like today?) which is always a fun exercise. Also, the managing of cities and maintaining public order is both realistic and very deep. For example, don't make people happy = settlement revolts, turning to rebel hands.

The AI for this game is also surprisingly good, considering its era. The AI actually has the capability to fight back, or, like in many of my games, they all dogpile on you when you start to get good. That can become annoying, as over-expansion of one's empire can be disaterous at times.

The diplomacy for the game is also quite in depth, allowing you to form alliances, ask for ceasefires (if you are at war with someone), make trade agreements, exchange map information, and a few more that i have forgotten.

Finally,I'd like to commend The Creative Assembly for balancing all the factions so well. All the factions have their strengths and weaknesses, except maybe for the roman factions (although, those campaigns are quite boring. I suggest playing as Germania as soon as you unlock them, as they are a nice and diverse and fun). Even the unplayable factions are fun!

And so I conclude my reveiw. I would say like and subscribe, but this isn't a YouTube video. Goodbye.

title: Rome Total War
review: This is my first venture into the total war series. I played the Imperial campaign as House Julii. I started around 4pm one night and I immediately went to work against the Gauls. I moved into France and conquered it with pretty light resistance. I moved then to spain to finish off the Gaulic empire. I then went to work on the rest of the Iberian peninsula after a long and bloody campaign of death and carnage. I atleast masscred 3/4s of the population of Spain to deal with unrest. After this I waited. Built infrastructure, refined my army and commanders and moved 4 full armies of Princeps,Triarii,Archers and light cavarly, to the border of Germania poised to attack. However they sensed my imminent betrayal and made a suprise attack against my armies. This led me into a long 50 year stalemate with them, until the scythians from the west distracted them enought to where I pushed and took their capital with heavy losses. I masscred the population of Germania as well to settle unrest in the region. The Scythians not willing to give me any rest invaded and took many of the outlying cities of former Germania. I being sick of the fighting for the time being Charged them and crushed all resistance with my meager armies pushed them back. After a while of this I captured their capital and moved my capital to the former German capital to cause less unrest amoung my citizens. I then moved all my armies into place over the other houses borders of Greece and North Africe. Staged a coup against the Roman republic and crush any and all resistance making myself the emperor of the new empire.  Carpe Dium. I love this game and I'm going to check out the other Total War titles and purchase them, for anyone who wants a good strategy game, You've come to the right place.

However, I'm not all that great at writing so I'll leave it with a solid 1/10 IGN (not call of duty) but for a new fan of the game a 9.5/10 for running on my crappy laptop and having smooth solid gameplay that will cpativate you and keep you up into the early hours of morning.

title: Rome Total War
review: According to the tutorial all you need to know about how to manage a city is to build Shrines and Temples. So you'll be asking yourself why your income is different every turn and why it is lowering with thousands at a time. There is no help with this in the game itself, while it is the most important part of the game. It's a little bit of war, since you will not be able to make an army with negative income, and most of the time it's frustration, since there is no logical reason your income is that low. Most unclear strategy game I ever played.

title: Rome Total War
review: To say I loved every minute of Rome: Total War is a tremendous understatement. For my money, it's the ultimate strategy game. Not only does it effortlessly combine turn-based strategy with raucous real-time warmongering, but it delivers them in a package that is accessibe and easy to play.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Even in 2017 still great and up-to-par with Shogun 2.

Ive been playing like 10 hours offline (so my time wouldnt go over 2 hours so i could have more time to decide if i wanted to return game). So for for the past 10ish hours that has been unnecessary. Rome: Total war is an AMAZING GAME. I have 800 hours on Shogun 2 so I can compare the two. 

Shogun 2:
Better graphics
Everything else that comes with a newer game

Rome:
Higher detail in its content
More in-depth than Shogun 2
Graphics aren't as new (duh), but still nice and not a problem to me
No naval battles :(

Both are great TW games and I think equal to each other, but I love how Rome is more in-depth than Shogun 2.

I'm about 70 turns into Julii campaign and am killing Greeks and Gauls. Very fun.

PS I was totally given the idea to buy Rome by Historia Civilis's videos about Roman history on Youtube. Totally go watch those.

Steam should really put up warnings about games that are unplayable on modern systems.

EDIT:

After looking up more fixes, I found that the main problem with this game lies not with modern operating systems, but modern CPUs, mainly the Intel i-series. The problems pertaining to modern OS can be fixed, but if you have an Intel i-series CPU then be prepared for FPS problems, of which there are no fixes for now, due to an inherent problem in the game's engine.

Also, as someone in the comments pointed out, Steam did put up a warning for this on the store page. Although the warning was intended for MEDIEVAL II, it speaks about DirectX and GPU, and it's put in the very last bit of the description right under system requirements without any highlights whatsoever. A mostly irrelevant and bad way of warning people, but still a warning, however little it may be, so credit where it's due.

title: Rome Total War

At the feeling when you march on Rome and become ruler is something that will stay with you long after you've beaten the game. Lots of replay value with a handful of unique factions. title: Rome Total War
review:
An excellent game with a lot of content and epic battles.
You play in a map, you move troops and attack cities/armies, then you enter the battle map.
You use the cities to recruit troops. Each army unit has ~100 men, and an army has a maxmum of 20 units. 

The game covers the period from 270 BC to 14 AC

There are 8 factions to play.
Rome, divided in 3 familites: Julii, Brutii and Scipii. These factions are available to play at the beginning of the game.

The other factions need to be unlocked playing a campaign.
Gauls
Germania
Britons
Seleucid Empire
Greeks
Partian Empire
Cartage.

The Barbarian Invasion expansion covers the period 363 AC - 476 AC
All playable factions are available from the beginning.

Huns
Goths
Sarmatians
Vandals
Franks
Saxons
Sassanid Empire
Alamani
Easter Roman Empire
Western Roman Empire.

title: Rome Total War
review:
There was a time in which I would have described this as the best Total War game in the series. In fact, I would probably have gone as far as to say this is the best strategy game at that point in time. It has been a long time since this game's dominant reign and while it is still incredible fun I have grown out of it and no longer wish to play it.

Is the game not good enough? Of course not, it is great. Why did I grow out of it then? I put hundreds of hours into this amazing strategy title and just when I thought I was done I kept going after I found the mod communities online. I eventually grew to love Medieval 2 more because of the better natural balance between factions and other small reasons. Since then, I feel that Rome 2 (slightly modified) is a more enjoyable game overall and I have since replaced Rome from within my library by going to Rome 2 for my 3rd century BC strategy needs.

With all of that being said, this was a pivotal game in the strategy genre and is a classic to behold. This game deserves the respect and praise it has earned over the years and to anyone that hasn't played it, I think you should get it on sale and try it out. While it may be old, it is indeed gold.

Quick warning to TV users: If you play on a TV rather than a computer monitor, the executable for this game will somehow cause the TV to force 24p cinema mode and lock your frame rate to 24 FPS. This causes severe mouse lag and is annoying as all hell. To fix this, you can create a custom resolution such as 1904x1071 (which is 1920x1080 minus 16x9) and run the game that way. It looks every bit as good and allows the game to run at 60 FPS or higher.

title: Rome Total War
review:
[b]PROS:[/b]
+ huge campaign map
+ a LOT of various factions available to play
+ fun & tactical gameplay
+ interesting units
+ town upgrades & logistics
+ TONS of cool mods
+ ancient times atmosphere
+ Barbarian Invasion expansion included

[b]CONS:[/b]
- a bit outdated graphics
- wonky diplomacy system against AI
- the rebel armies appear too often
- weaker multiplayer

[b]Comment:[/b]
I finally bought this game here on Steam so I would have a digital copy of it as my discs are getting really old. This game is worth purchasing because it is a phenomenal RTS game and a must-have part of the Total War series. The graphics have aged but the game still looks decent and let us face it - the game has always been about gameplay first. Multiplayer is fun but the single-player campaign is what this game excels at. A huge map with three roman factions to choose from initially, later each defeated nation is unlocked as playable in the campaign. The gameplay is divided into 3 parts - cities management, sea battles and land battles. The last one is what this game is about and what makes it truly great. All the units, even siege engines, are nicely done and serve a purpose. The fighting is tactical and fair, although sometimes hard. But nothing beats the feeling of  a victory when you are outnumbered 4 to 1, or more! The AI has some problems but that can be forgiven in this case because it does not break the game at all. On top of all this are the mods, the lovely awesome mods. There are so many it would be hard to write all the good ones but MY personal favourites are Europa Babarorum, Lord of the Rings - Total War & Rome Total Realism. Seriously this game is worth your money if you like RTS games so I quite happily recommend it!
------------------------------------------------------------------
[b]If you liked this review you can find more on the [/b][url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/28638055-Subjective-Reviews-Corner/][u]Curator page[/u][/url][b] or in my [/b][url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/srcorner][u]Review Corner[/u][/url][b].[/b]

title: Rome Total War
review: Probably the best game out for its time of release, Great game music, Great campaign, great unit selection. The added bonus is that there are no DLCS, thats unless you didnt buy the gold edition. The best total war game and always will be. No multiplayer however but because the single player was good, it didn't matter. 10/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
Legit one of the best games of all time if you enjoy the time period, and definitely the best RTS of all time. The graphics and physics engines have become a little dated (2004-based) but if you enjoy the time period or game genre RTW is a must-play. You can choose between many different factions, each with their own unique play style and units, and recreate history or forge your own path. You can use diplomats, assassins and spies, fleets and massive armies.

Due to the (relative) simplicity of the coding there are mods aplenty from total conversions (think Lord of the Rings) to complete historical-accuracy rehauls, making Rome that much more replayable and unique.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I like the game - the terrain is interesting, the historical scenarios and campaign are intresting. 

The one thing I don't like is that you can speed up the game play pace but not slow it down and the actual pace is a bit faster than reality. I feel at some points a bit of an RTS like behaviour - the pressure of time that forces you to make rushed decisions and the fights sometimes devolve into charge/counter-charge. 

That might be less of an issue once you master unit grouping and keyboard commands. 

The keyboard commands aren't available at the in game screen which is a bit annoying so you'd better get a crib sheet.

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of the best if not the best Total War games ever! For all Total War fans this game is an absolute classic among all the total war games. Not only does this game bring back old memories, but it's also a game that you can put hundred's of hours into and not get bored of playing! This is a must play for any new or old total war fans as well as gamers that are into strategy based games!

Pros:
- Excellent game mechanics and UI
- Massive and large scale battles 
- Overall an excellent game as far as music, gameplay, and UIs

Cons:
- AI is and always has been a little a little dumb about strategic maneuvers
- Unit pathfinding when attacking cities with large armies can be a bit of a pain
- Some factions could use a little more unit varieties

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of the best Total War games today. I've played it a lot on non steam version. It was the first total war game I played and I love the turn based campaign map combined with real time battles. 

Compared to Rome 2 this is the better game for many reasons. 
- Senate and population opinion.
- More diversed factions, especially the eastern remnants of Alexander's realm.
- Family tree
- Troops obey imidiatly.
- Troops can use formations and tactis in proper ways. The testudo for example. In Rome 1 they present their shields on three of four sides, very effective. In Rome 2 they present their shield on one side, useless.

There are som things that Rome 2 does better. For example they don't have trees so high you van't zoom out from a forest and walls with the same problem.

title: Rome Total War
review:
It's a good place to start if you want to get into the series, as it is cheap and REALLY good. It's better than most of the recent medieval games, including Rome II. The only Total War game I could possibly reccomend more is Shogun II, which is only because it has 3 different eras. Definately a must buy if you like strategy from chess to Age of Empires. Does a lot of stuff that was the first of its kind and has very little to do with luck. If you dislike the battle aspect of Civ 5 or pretty much ANYTHING else, this is for you.

P.S. It's a kind of like Risk, except the battles have nothing to do with luck (Not counting naval battles).

title: Rome Total War
review:
For many Total War fans, and certainly for me, this is where it began. It still holds up today as a fantastically engaging and rich military strategy game, and has an easy and accessible feel to it that gets you hooked into campaigns that take many hours to complete. Still worth the purchase today, even though the graphics and some basic mechanics are starting to feel dated. With Mods, much of the games shortcomings can be patched and freshened up for new arrivals, but for the oldies even vanilla Rome Total War is a pleasure to dive into.

The aspect of Rome Total War that hooks fans, and that Creative Assembly really hasn't managed to re-create in many other releases in the series, is the role-playing element. You do get very attached to your characters in-game, and at times adapt your play style to the personality of the general you control: are you a brutal tyrant who destroys enemies mercilessly? Are you a strategic general who approaches conflicts with caution, or perhaps a political animal more suited to building a career as a governor close to the Eternal City? As your family grows you will understand that Valerius, son of Asinius, wants to avenge his father who was killed by the Carthaginians, or that the son of the good-for-nothing Gnaeus wants to prove his family can be great by conquering lands for the glory of Rome. This is part of the wonderful dynamic storytelling in the game, and something that is hard to find in other titles from the series.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I owned this game back in 2008. I was 10 at the time and I loved everything Roman.

I had no idea what the mechanics in the game were, since I didnt speak English.
Fast forward to winter of 2015. I bought the game on a steam sale. Now knowing English, I enjoyed the game even more than I did when I was a kid. From slaughtering Gauls to building up your own cities this game requires strategy, especially with higher difficulty settings.

Pros:
-Lots of different factions to play
-Very good battle system
-Great difficulty settings, you can make it really easy, and really hard for yourself if you wish.

Cons:
-Easily abusable battle mechanics, making the game easy even on the hardest difficulty
-Dumb AI, especially when they attack a settlement of yours
-Some historically inaccuracy

I recommend this game, it's very cheap and well worth it even if you play through it just once.
I wish that instead of Rome TW 2 we got a HD version of this, with the mechanics and AI fixed. You can't have it all though.

title: Rome Total War
review:
It runs well on my 64bit Win 10 Machine, I7, GTX980TI. Not a single crash or problem.

The game has aged well, I'd say. You can play in 16:9 and even on my 16:10 1920x1200 display it works well.

Can't say much about Barbarian Invasion. Havn't played that yet.

Regardless weather you played it back then and want to give it another spin or you just stumbled over it - It is one of the most fun strategy games to play and at this price a steal.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War is the best in the Total war series and even ranks amoug the top games of all time.  I consider it the second best RTS of all time, only following AOE2. Playing massive battle where you can go head first in frontline action is absolutly mesmorising. Anyone can play Rome Total War but it takes a pro to be good. You need to perfect tactics and have to know the ins and outs of each map. This game stands the test of time beaytifully, If your invading a citadel or recreating Thermopylae you are always having a great time because Rome total War, no mater how many times you have played it, always bring a new scenario to the table, something you didn't expect. I believe Rome Total War will always have a loyal fanbase that will constantly find new and improved tactics. Each map is masterfully constructed with amazing attention to detail, for example you can....

-invade towns, cities, and giant citidels
-recreate battles of the past on a massive scale
-Play multiplayer with friends (my favorite style)
-Make a battle of your own
-Quick play for a quick and fun battle
-the campaign (This is unplayed by many, I have never heard someone say, boy, i could go for some Rome Total War campaign)

These styles and many more is what makes Rome Total War so memorible and fun. If your playing with friends or, playing alone Rome Total War is always incredibly entertaining.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Decided to play as Germania
-Decided to start a war with Gaul
-Destroyed them every battle with my superior warbands
-Aliied with the Brtitish 
-Started bordering Rome and Britannica and Spain
-Rome declared war on me
-Got betrayed by the British
-Got attacked by the Julli
-Defended the city with just spear warbands outnumbered 1 to 6
-Three way war here we go... 
-Conquered the British
-Allied with the Greeks
-Destroyed the senate army with a few berserkers
-Almost destroyed the Brutii family
-Got betrayed by the Greeks...
-Won the first battle against Greeks
-Sieged a city filled with hoplites...
-Greeks decided to Rally
-Got tired from running up a hill
-Destroyed the army while rallying and entered the city without siege equipments chasing running troops
-Scythia declared war on me
-Dacia declared war on me
-Declare war on everyone
-Destroy their armies with berserkers and take their foreign women 
-Screw civilization
-Bribed a fellow Carthaginian 
-He becomes the Faction Leader
-Destroyed Carthage with him leading
-Conquered the remaining Romans, Carthaginians, and marched on destroying Egypt
-Take the world hundreds of years in the barbaric past
-Got a lot of bloodthirsty generals

This game is awesome... a must buy... Barbarian factions are a must play... Brute force beats discipline.
