title: Rome Total War
review:
It' is now worth saying no game is perfect, I will not call  this game perfect. but it is, perhaps, one of the greater gaming expirences. If you overlook the (now) outdated graphics, there is great gameplay, and the start of one of the most succesfull RTS (Real Tme Strategy) series ever. But enough positivity, lets look at what took this game down.
the graphics are sub-par and the models only have spikes as feet on anything but the highest graphic setting. The sound is compresses and the AI is braindead approximatley 60% of the time, leaving little room for grand strategy. The AI on campign denies fair diplomecy for no reason and commences wars for no reason. this game is fantastic but those are the three biggest flaws. Not to mention the crippiling bugs!
7/10

title: Rome Total War
review: To me this game and the first Medieval are the best Total War games. It's really enjoyable with lots of unique strong units. For example the Medieval 2 game often feels like "throw more of the same" or "throw a little better ones" till the end of the turns, which makes a repetitive gameplay. In Rome you may enjoy your level nine heavy horse archers with +5  to attack (as far as I remember temple + blacksmith bonus) that can sweep everything in front of them. And if you are tired of the vanila campaign, there are some really good mods like Total Realism which may cost you countless sleepless nights. Use on your own risk.

title: Rome Total War
review:
[h1]Rome: Total War is pretty cool, I guess. [/h1]

Back in the year 2000, a time when every music group went out of their way to look goofy, a little development studio named Creative Assembly decided to release a strategy game called "Shogun: Total War." 
The game mixed grand strategy and real time elements to create what was essentially a perfect formula of kingdom management and army control. The game was pretty successful, and two years later they released "Medieval: Total War" in 2002.  The game stepped away from the era of Feudal Japan and instead focused on Medieval Europe, hence the name. 
This game was also a success, and finally, two years later, Creative Assembly released what I personally believe to be their Magnum Opus. 

Rome: Total War was released in 2004, and that rhymes.

Set during a period when killing someone was a lot more difficult because you had to get in pleasant conversation distance of one another. Rome: Total War's campaign begins during the early days of the Roman Republic. Or "early", I guess. 
You play as a various number of factions, some being unlockable as you conquer them in game, each one has a unique quality to it that comes into play during the battles. 


Now, I'm going to admit, I spent way too much time playing this game, and I'm probably just going to gush on it. 

"But Dirk you World Champion Hugger." You start. "Steam says you only have 15 hours of total play time."

Well first, shut up, and second: Rome was one of the first PC games I actually bought myself after a long and backbreaking career in pig wrestling. I'm pretty sure I have almost, if not more than 1000 hours all together in this game. Though in those 1000 hours I haven't even played the Alexander expansion, but I heard that's good too. 

Campaign mode is broken into two segments, the campaign map where you control your entire empire, and the battle map where you command an army in combat. In the campaign map you build cities, train armies, make diplomatic agreements with other factions, and call Carthage stinky idiots for not releasing their hold on Sicily this instant. 
When diplomacy does break down, then it's time to get a little violent. Invading enemy territory involves you moving your armies around the campaign map like board game pieces, and having them attack enemy cities or armies. When the battle begins you zoom in to get a command eye view of the battle where you command each unit like a normal strategy game.

Something that Rome and a few other games had that newer games do not is a captain system where, if you don't have a general in an army, it would instead be commanded by a captain within the army. If the Captain can prove himelf in a climatic battle or over the course of a war, then there's a chance that that captain can be promoted to General and actually become a named character.

Generals themselves are fairly unique as well, each of them is named and can be improved or sabotaged independently. With every victory, the general can become a better commander and earn some traits, these traits can be positive or negative. For instant, a general may grow disgusted by war and have no taste for bloodshed, giving his army a morale penality. Or maybe he'll become better at army management and be able to move further each turn. Or maybe he'll just go crazy and talk about how his army will win because they have cooler hats. 

This and added into a pre-battle speech system where your general's speech can change depending on traits, gives the game a very neat little roleplaying element that helps give a narrative to your campaign. When your lords pass away they leave a history that will stick until the end of your campaign.

Commanding your armies in battle is a very easy affair. You can control on unit, or multiple units at once, prepare their formation before the battle, and listen your the general's speech before it all goes down. For 2004, this part of the game was groundbreaking, since it was uncommon to see so many 3D rendered units on screen at once. It still holds up, especially if you put the unit scale to max. 


[h1]But should you play Rome: Total War?[/h1]

Yeah, probably, at least if you're a Total War fan who somehow hasn't played the classics. It's considered one of the best games ever made by people who aren't as great as me, and I would consider it at least in my top 10, if not my top 5. 
There are some problems, enemy campaign AI get sometimes wig out, having things happen like nations ask for an alliance one turn and then declare war the very next, but there are mods that help fix this to an extent. The modding scene is pretty great as well, with Europa Barbarorum and Roma Surrectum coming to mind. 

I would give R:TW my golden seal of approval and say you should pick it up some way. It usually gets really cheap during sales as well. 

Rome: Total War gets 5 overly dramatic speeches out of 5. 

Bananas are curved because they grow towards the sun.

The curator: http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Dickbuttexperience#curation

Oh man, this review wasn't all that funny, was it?

title: Rome Total War
review: This is an incredible game that very closely captures the spirit of strategy games and the Roman Empire.  If you liked any of the newer games in the series, but want more TW goodness to explore, check this out.  Every faction feels incredibly unique, and not just because of starting positions and marginal stat differences.  The Romans play just like you'd expect them to, with powerful, disciplined infantry and sophisticated siege equipment, while the barbarian tribes get to play around with scare tactics and sheer numbers.  Carthage fields solid infantry and phalanxes that don't quite measure up to what the Romans get, but their elephants make up the difference easily.  The Greek states get basically ONLY phalanxes, forcing a very defensive approach to every battle.  The Parthians have such powerful mounted units that it's a legitimate consideration just to leave behind anyone without a horse.  Despite there not being any random generation on the start of a game, like in Civilization, I still feel like I've only scraped the surface on what this game offers, and I haven't played the Barbarian Invasion expansion at all.  Every faction feels fresh to play the first time, and it takes at least a full campaign to really master each specific style of combat.  I could go on about everything else I love about this game, but you can just look at any positive review for any strategy game and take the good points, and they probably apply to this game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is one of my favorite games, and, despite what my steam playtime may suggest, I have spent hundreds of hours playing the CD version. I cannot recommend the game highly enough.  The vanilla gameplay is excellent, and there is a wide range of mods that adds tremendously to that - Rome: Total Realism, Europa Barbarorum and others. 

So why the thumbs down? Because the steam version of this game is essentially unplayable on modern computers. My brand new desktop, which plays Total War: Warhammer on high settings at 60 fps, cannot manage large battles in this 13-year-old game at higher than ~30-35 fps. I've tried just about every fix for this that can be found online, from copying DX9 dlls to running in XP SP2 compatibility mode to running the game in borderless windowed mode at my full screen resolution. I've even turned all the settings down to low, and the problem still persists. The upshot is that this game is simply drastically unoptimized for modern hardware and operating systems. I'm at the point where I'm considering installing windows XP on a separate partition just to see if that will do any good, but I'm not holding out much hope. I understand that not everyone has this problem, but I've experienced it thus far on three modern computers, running windows 7 and windows 10. 

Anyone considering purchasing this should be aware of this problem.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Ignore the hours logged on Steam, I had this game way back when I had an Acer 7540G with a busted heat sink. Put countless hours into fowarding agressive Roman foreign policy!

Rome TW is still, in my humble opinion, one of the best TW games I've played. I Do enjoy Shogun 2 and Empire but maybe it was because it was my first TW, I dunno, Rome just has it for me. 

The three campaign factions are intersting and offer good variety in terms of where you start within the Italian peninsular and how that dictates your courses of action; Julii starting in the North where most players are likely to move to conquer west - Gaul - and move north into Germania and Britain. Then likely south into Spain. Fighting a very land dominated advance. 

Players who chose to lead the Brutii familiy will face primarily Greece and very sea based advances pushing east to Greek shores and pushing north into Dacia before the Julii get there. Claiming lands in Galatia (Turkey) and moving into Egypt and the Middle East. Facing the Greek hoplites is no easy task so good battle tactics are needed as these spearmen make short work of footsoldier and cavalry alike. 

Finally the Scipii family starting with lands in Capua south of Rome and a foothold in Sicily. Shrewd players will use the fact that their eastern and northern borders are rendered safe by other Roman, and therefore allied, forces to push hard west and south into Sardinia, Mauritania and Numidia where the Carthageans will put up a challenging resistance with their huge war elephants. Mixing naval and land based strategy.

Rome TW has it all as far as I'm concerned. It has a great campaign map system where each individual settlement can be managed in terms of build policies and taxes so that issues in a particlar place can be dealt with without affecting other settlements. Game progressions is well graduated and the tech trees are historically accruate (for the most part) and offer much reward for pushing your slice of the Roman empire to sucess. You'll need this as the culmination of the campaign is challengin Rome itself for power and facing down the mighty SPQR - though by this juncture you too will also be feilding the best troops your denari can buy. 

With a campaign map that stretches right across Europe and into the Middle East there are a myriad of options open to a player and this is something that makes Rome TW so good; no paythrough is the same unless you make it so. The factions are well thought out and the whole feeling of the game is done exceptionally well and for the most part is logical an intuitive. The only things lacking is the diplomacy from what I've encountered which is quite basic on most counts so it's hard to really 'reason' with the AI in order to advance less agressively. 

Depsite its age it stands a monument to strategy games and a lesson too, combining turn-based and real-time into one well proportioned package. It does show its age in the graphical fidelity of course but it is by no means bad and in this type of game is far less notceable of course. Some of the controls are a little counterintuitive in terms of controlling the camera in the battles but it's not something you won't get used to. 

If you love startegy games then Rome TW should be in your library. Its that simple. Veni vidi vici!!

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is one of the two total war games that I can with honesty recommend. This game has aged very well and continues to be one of the best total war games. 

This game has one great flaw which is the horrible AI. Slightly clunky controls and a slightly clunky camera can be forgiven but not the horrid AI which fails to even follow the most simple of instructions. Moving your unit through a gate can be impossible and the most common cause of losses is a result of terrible AI. Skirmishers that engage in melee combat despite being told to skirmish. Cavalry units charging when told to move a couple of paces to the side. Infantry unable to encircle the enemy without being constantly forced to move. Pathfinding and how the AI sometimes decides to fight losing battles makes the game greatly annoying.

Graphics are horrible and the game is rather difficult to get running properly. Crashing is common and bugs are not unheard of.

Even though the game has these flaws it truly shines when things work. Your troops have to be commanded and micromanaged in order to work properly. When formations clash against each other one might get pushed back or encircled if lucky. Small pockets of troops attempt to break the formation and morale can turn the tide of a battle. Good commanders can win against a massive enemy force if they know when and where to strike. Economy has to be managed and units are not all the same. Wars can vary in difficulty depending on player skill and enemy power but generally you'll have one or two battles that decide the outcome of the war. Constantly harrasing your beaten enemies to wittle down their numbers is vital in order to win. The player must learn how to fight different units on different soils as the terrain varies greatly. Missile units may work well against a wall of spears but when your enemy is on horse you might want some cavalry. Perhaps the terrain is too rough for cavalry formations to be effective and has to be compensated for!

If you decide to purchase this game then I recommend playing as one of the roman factions over and over again and then modding the game to access other factions to freshen up the game. 


Get this game? Unless you're squeamish about graphics its a must buy. I recommend this.

(go to discr_strat to add in factions)
 My Barbarian invasion story:
I started as the Burgundii and decided to become a pirate by building 200 boats and decided to form a horde. I send my King and his sons on the boats and set sail for a life as a pirate. First i raid Denmark then set sail and raided York. Raids the coasts of france, found the Roman Emperor in a costal town on the west coast of france, i then perceed to raid it and thus killing the emperor. I then raid the coast of spain, i then headed  to Morrocco but they decided to send reinforcements to the city i was raiding, therefore decided to go back to the ships and carry on too Carthage. The Romans, clearly not forgeting my regiced decided to send a huge reinforcement of ships and attacked killing the king and his borthers. But all  hope was not lost, by some meraculous chance (probably a glitch due to his two son maturing on board the ship while it was attacked) the king must have sent his 16 year old sons on a ship to escape the battle, and must have got ship recked off the coast of Mauritania and traveled to western Algeria. While travelling through the desert his name must have ment much in the area as hundreds of local mercenairies flocked to his side. He also gained great knowlage of philosophy and his brother converted to Christianity and became deeply interested in theology. After about a decade of travelling they converged on the wooden walled city in the middle of an oasis in the Sahara. The city contained the crown prince of the berbers and wasnt going to give it up easily, and thus he was defeated by the narrowest of margins, but  out of the some respect he let the two princes go so they decided to head east and found a small poor city in modern day Libya. The recent economic crisis had taken hold despite rapid modernisation they decided to leave. The Christian prince decided he wanted too go to the holy land to settle and free from Roman tyranny, his pagan brother agreed and they set sail for Jerusalem. they stopped off at crete which they promptly freed from the Romans and started to modernise a great fleet to get too Jerusalem, however when they set sail again they where intercepted by a roman fleet which won a narrow victory agianst him were he was then killed. Though the philospher princes had with no hair, word must have spread and a new Bergundii warlord, that had prevoiusly parted with the king when the king decided to become a pirate, had heard of the legendry philosphers and their wish, so he and the remnents of the Burgundii army attacked constaninople and used it to cross to Anatolia where they went down a coast route evading roman forces. from a secret path shown too them by a local spy they had managed to besige Jerusalem, they had won as the city wasnt properly gaurded and they managed to settle Jerusalem. After 6 mounths (1 turn) after the conquest of Jerusalem, the warlord had died of the plague and once agian with no heir the royality of the Burgundii had fallen. The end.

10/10 Somehow you can create awsome stories (from events and traits) when you form a horde on Barbarian Invasion.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I had played this game before picking it up on Steam and in the end I decided to do it through here as well, as I kinda miss it, I only had the base game, and it was stupidly cheap. As I usually do, I'm gonna start sharing what the game does wrong, then going up from there.

First and foremost, one of the worst parts of the game has to be the auto-battle option. You see, you'll be doing tons of big battles here, and if you feel like you don't need to oversee this one, you can just let the AI do it for you. However it seems the auto-battle AI is as brain-dead as Trump. I've lost quite a lot of battles because I had a ton of crap to fight and didn't wanna spend an hour doing them all properly. The last one being over 2k of my troops against 200 rebel peasants. F#CKING PEASANTS. AND MY TROOPS WERE HIGH TIER, WITH SIEGE UNITS AND EVERYTHING. HOW THE F#CK DID THAT HAPPEN!? It will make your playthroughs stupidly long, but I seriously advice you to not use that feature at all.

Second is something I'm still not a big fan of. At the start you only have three factions to choose, the three big families of rome (not counting the Senate). However there's a f#ckload of factions, to unlock them you must be the one taking their last area on the map. Why? Why not, for example, certain factions unlocking others at the end of a long game? This way you might unlock a few of them in one game, most likely the ones you don't really want, and will have to restart anew with a faction that's closest to the one you do like, putting yourself through with a faction you don't want. 

Lastly, I feel like archers are a bit too powerful at times. Sure, heavy troops can tank those arrows and horse units can just sprint to them and whoop their asses, but then we got archers on horses and the whole balance f#cks itself. Elephants are also somewhat powerful since the auto-balance system doesn't seem to understand what the f#ck they do and usually win insane battles.

That being said, this is a really cool strategy game that still stands strong after all these years that will give you hours and hours of fun for a really low price.

The thing I like the most, strangely enough, is the realism and history stuff on it. It's actually kinda fun to sometimes stop and read all of the stuff the game has to tell you about troops, buildings and such. If you actually don't know much about the roman times, you'll learn a lot in here.

The strategy itself is also really cool. It's not one of those "send all of your troops against them blindly" kind of games. The game is surprisingly deep and there's tons of cool tactics you can use to win even the most harsh fights.

The amount of factions is also impressive for the time the game came off. There's like f#cking 40 or so, from all of those there HAS to be at least ONE you like. 

Also, as dumb as it might sound, the dialogue from the captains before the fights are so well written, I can't help but to stop and listen to them constantly. Seriously, they had a blast with those.

Honestly, if you want Shogun 2 but you can't affort it, this is a really good alternative. On a sale it costs like 1 or 2€ and it's completely worth it. Though if you do have the money, I'd say give Shogun 2 a try instead.

TL;DR Edition: A classic that still stands strong by now. While Shogun 2 feels better, this one is way cheaper. If you enjoy hollywood-speeches, then it's already worth the purchase.

title: Rome Total War
review:
How to properly experience Rome Total War. 
Step one: Start a new game playing as the Romans, doesn't matter the family.
Step two: Decide how fast you want to get going by using cheats or not, usually depends onthe mood I'm in.
Step three: Create an unstoppable army, or two, or 20, depends how fast you want the world to tremble at your feet.
Step four: Send forth your armies into the lands of the barbarians, take their cities and sack them, burn them down, kill them all.
Step five: Once the barbarians have been eradicated completely from the map, head for Greece, the home of the intelects.
Step six: Send your armies to enslave the Greek peoples, beat them off their high horses and kill them slowly and painfully.
Step seven: Once Greece has been pacified sucsessfuly, wait till you have a plauge in one of your cities, you will soon see why.
Step eight: once you do have a plauge in one of your cities, get unimprtant agents like diplomats there, keep them for a bit, them send them to the south, in places like Memphis, Alexandria, or Carthage, large cities.
Step nine: watch as thousands die from your own little biological terrorist attack, take it in.
Step ten: Send your armies to finish off Carthage, Egypt and Numidia, enslave their peoples too, and make sure to kil the pharoh.
Congrats, Romam regit omnia, Imperitor.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I wanted this game when it first came out, but didn't have the hardware nor funds to do so.

Years later, I finally managed to acquire it, and I was not disappointed. To this day, this is still a decent game.

The game is half civilization builder, half tactical battle simulator.
You manage a faction, which includes cities and armies. Build up your cities for bonuses and to unlock better units. Guard your territory and expand it with your mighty armies.

I love the tactical battles in this game. There's been some moments where I wasn't sure if I could win, and only through superior tactics and maneuvering could I maintain some sort of victory. Also, there's been battles I've played perfectly, where I've taken out armies two or three times my size.

Don't get me wrong, the AI doesn't suck. If you try to just throw your troops at the enemy, you'll be in for a rude awakening. 

Also, be aware, this is not a short game (although there is alternate game modes if you're short on time and just need a quick fix). A campaign will take many hours to complete, spanning several days of gameplay.

Who should buy this game? People who like civilization games, sure, but more importantly, those who love tactical battles where the battle is won more by brain power than sheer might. Also, those interested in long campaigns... Rome wasn't built in a day, and it won't be conquered in one either.

Who shouldn't buy this game? RTS players who tend to just build up bases and overwhelm their opponents with sheer numbers. It is a possible way to play, but it wouldn't be an easy trip. Also, anyone who may just be a casual gamer should probably avoid this series.

Anyway, I also recommend an article linked on the Rome:Total War news page, about the best and worst Total War games. It was a good read, and help me to decide which Total War to buy next (I'm going to download it as soon as my monthly internet bill rolls over).

All in all, this may not be the *best* Total War game (idk, haven't played any others, yet), but it is very good in its own right, and its easy to see how it launched such a successful series of games. This one is definitely good, but I also recommend that you do a little research and see which Total War may be most to your liking before purchase, as they're all a little different (so I've read).

title: Rome Total War
review:
[Note that my hours on record are very inaccurate]

Rome: Total War is a superb game, and remains very fun to play even 12 years after release. It was the first of two Total War games to use this engine (called simply TW Engine 2 by Wikipedia), and while its successor had more complex strategic layers, more unit variety, and better tactical battlefields, it somehow lacked the charm of this one, in my opinion. Each faction plays very differently, having access to different unit types and requiring dramatically different strategies, which results in every playthrough feeling like its own epic story. Sure, the game has its inaccuracies, quirks and problems (save often; don't rely on alliances which you aren't paying for; and study your units in battle, as many of them require a little extra micromanagement than they should), but you'll forget about all that the first time one of your onagers takes out an enemy seige tower that was nearly ready to spew a hundred angry Macedonians onto your walls; or the first time an elephant runs amok through a pitched battle, tossing dozens of men aside or trampling them underfoot; or the first time your General's bodyguard makes a desperate final charge into the enemy's rear and actually turns the tide of battle.

To make this game even better, it has a large and dedicated fanbase, which has been producing mods of incredible scope and scale. Projects such as [i]Rome: Total Realism[/i] and [i]Europa Barbarorum[/i] can give you what feels like a whole new game at no cost. It should be noted, however, that most mods require game version 1.5, which is available only through the expansion game [i] Rome: Total War - Alexander [/i].

Overall, I would highly recommend this game. I dare say that it's one of the most memorable strategy games ever made.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Played as Julii:
Assassinated the Scipio-Heir and the rest of their family without consequences.

Played as Carthage:
Bribed the Julii, the Brutii and the Scipiones until I had a nice little army in all of Italy 
-> Conquer Rome and rewrite all the history books because Carthage has actually crushed the Roman Empire and not the other way around.

Played as Brutii:
Get annihilated by Greece's hoplite horde when attempting to Blitzkrieg the Grecian city states.

Played as The Roman Senate:
Built up a huge army, wanting to erase the Gauls -> Wanted to travel through Julii-territory -> Julii suddenly break the alliance with me -> both other Roman families also declare war on me -> my 10,000 men strong army gets absolutely annihilated by the newly formed coalition -> Faction S.P.Q.R is destroyed when Rome is captured by turn 35

10/10 Equal chances for every faction

title: Rome Total War
review:
So good that to this date mods are still being released for it. A pillar for the Total War series and the best Creative Assembly release for the Roman Era (better than Rome 2 in every way but the graphics).
 If you get this, like every other good TW title, make sure to try out some mods as they make the game infinitely replayable and will provide you with the best Rome 1 Total War moments. Mods like Rome Total Realism or Europa Barbarorum are two of my favorite. Mods help out in what the game lacks, which is historical accuracy. Some even improve the AI and even the outdated graphics.

 Unlike the most recent titles with the terrible battle animations, in Rome 1 if a soldier is surrounded by 5 enemy soldiers all of them will stab him untill his hitpoints reach 0 and he dies, instead of playing a battle animation with every single one of them while the others look and wait.

 Great Classic that aged well and is still enjoyable as hell - 9/10

title: Rome Total War
review: In my opinion, this is the best Total War title to date. There is a good selection of factions to choose from, and you can make all the factions in the game available to play by going into the game folder and moving a couple things around. There is good unit diversity, excellent combat, and the best music by far of all the Total War titles. City building is good, only problem compared to other Total War games is the naval combat, which is _only auto resolve_. Other than that, it is a masterpiece of a game. Others I'd recommend are Shogun II and Medieval II.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I had Rome Total War long before Steam, but was so disenchanted with Rome 2, I picked it up on sale. At the time of it's release, it was revolutionary. Now, many years later, it is still a worthy addition to any library of turn-based and real time strategy. 

This Total War Rome has a great real time battle engine. You can easily control any and all units and fight every battle on your terms. Crashing into an infanty until from behind with calvary remains fun to watch over a decade later. I won the short campaign on hard for both map and battles...but it wasn't difficult for a verteran of Total War games. 

The music is perfect, from the calm background of the world map to the adrenaline pumping battle music. The introductory movie/music still makes me smile, capturing some of the feeling of Total Awe I felt at the time of its release. 

8/10 Glad I visited old Rome again.

title: Rome Total War
review:
The best game in the total war series, have owned this game since 2007 (so alot more than 17.8 hours). The factions have a good amount of variety, Cavalry charges work (unlike Empire -> onwards), Melee combat works (no individual combat). This game is still up to date in my opinion. Got the best settlement progression and settlement choices but could need a bit more work on the campain diplomacy part and ai, Ofcourse, this won't be changed since its not live anymore but i'll probably be happy if there pops up a modification that fixes/enables this. 

This would probably be the best game in the total war series to start in if you're new to the genre since it has a very low learning curve and is pretty advanced in its simplicity if im honest. 

None of the negatives about Rome total war 2 apply to Rome total war 1, its quite the opposite. They removed what was good about rome 1 when they made rome 2, if you catch my drift. I had a friend who bought Rome 2... Not much to say, he refunded it withing 30 minutes. Time doesn't apply to this title, the graphics are actually pretty astonishing of its time, the gameplay is just golden, the music <3. Buy this game now.

title: Rome Total War
review:
My biggest 2 issues with this game:

Campaign: Holding large territories is virtually impossible due to unrest, I guess that is historically accurate (even on easy), but counter-intuitive to your objectives.

Battles: Unit and camera control are both a disaster. Why they decided against a traditional RTS camera (even though there is an RTS camera option in the game) is beyond me. Moving the mouse to the sides rotates the camera instead of scrolling the map...same goes for the arrow keys. Units themselves are hard to control and rarely do what you tell them to. Want your cavalry to attack a certain squad from behind? Well, first you have manually move them to avoid all other enemies in sight and then they may still attack the wrong enemy. Battles frequently look like masses of pixels trying to get to the enemy, but the game engine doesn't allow that.

A good example of how to do it right would be Dawn of War. Here units first engage in ranged combat, but when they are forced into melee they are actively looking for a direct opponent instead of creating 2 big masses of armies that patiently wait until the front line disintegrates. You can micro manage some of that, but honestly, it's really annoying and just lazy in my opinion.

Apart from that the game is actually pretty good if you're looking for Grand Strategy and the historic battles you can replay from the menu are fun and challenging, but also give you interesting info about what happened back then.

You can make alliances with other nations or declare war. In a campaing you rule from cities , where you can develop your own strategy of building and collecting taxes.              

The game is brilliant but it needs better graphic.

One of the 10 best PC games of all time; far better than Rome 2 TW overall.   Unit collisions, gameplay, factions, diplomacy, family, historical battles, modding, ... just to name a few. An excellent mod for the game is Darthmod 9.01.  There are many others excellent mods.


Added 9 months later:
Still the best overall TW game, followed by MTW2. If this game were updated with increased family, factions, diplomacy, and maybe most importantly not use that Warscape 2.5 engine (crap collisions no matter how they try to mask it in Sho2 & later games, even tho Sho2 has best use to date of that obsolete from day 1 lousy excuse of an engine), I would pay up to $100 for it. But not for a screwed up "reinvent the wheel" excuse of a game and gameplay like in RTW2.

title: Rome Total War
review:
[h1]Rome: Total War[/h1]
[u]Just another overly subjective personal opinion[/u] [i]FIRST DRAFT[/i]

Sadly I cannot offer anything that represents even a small fraction of an objective, highly professional review, thanks to the lack of my competence. What I got is only my subjective little opinion crafted by my experiences with this amazing game, which I see as a significant pillar and a spectacular peak, not only of the Total War series, but of the strategy genre as well.  

I started to play with the Total War series with the first Shogun: Total War back in the early 2000's. I still have the physical copy of that great game in my drawer, next to Medieval: Total War with the Viking Invasion Expansion, and Medieval II: Total War + Kingdoms. As a kid who played a lot with turn-based strategy games like the first 2 Civilization, and Heroes of Might and Magic 2-3 (yes, I am an old fart), i was fascinated by the system and the era Shogun could offer. I was captured by the whole notion of empire building and expansion, and while I respected the whole battle-simulation aspect (which I played for hours back then), I realized that I was much more impressed by the campaign map, with its diplomacy, economy system, constructions, army building, etc. After Shogun I played a lot with Medieval Total War, which became my favorite thanks to its theme, and then for some particular reason, i did not try out Rome. I was not really interested in the ancient era, and jumped right to Medieval II. It was overwhelmingly superior to the two games I played before, and for a short period of time, I thought that Medieval II brought these improvements into the series. But I was wrong. It was Rome.

I borrowed a physical copy of Rome: Total War in 2007 and realized how huge leap this game took from its predecessors in almost every aspect of the game. From the map which changed the whole one province = one army slot type to a more dynamic one with much more attention to positions and maneuverability, the engaging senate system with its authentic theme and quests, till the improved and much more detailed dynasty and family-tree building with an original ruler and general traits system, this game assembled a lot of great ideas, that not only gave it more soul and meat than the previous games, but it also made me identify with certain problem-solving and task performance situations much more effectively. 

I bought my own physical copy of Rome in the same year, but it did not live long. In 2009, after tons of gameplay hours, it gave up the good fight. 

After playing Rome, I went back to Medieval II, I bought Empire, and also Shogun 2, but I stopped trying out the latest entries of the series. I realized, that none of these games were able to eclipse the glory of Rome. Yes, they added new themes, some new mechanics, new graphics, changed some features, but the core mechanics are still those that was established in Rome Total War, and personally I only see them as bigger, brighter, louder echoes of the same old system, which still keeps its head up high. It may look ancient to some, but this well-crafted piece of gaming is not even close to become outdated.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I was looking for new strategy games, and I didn't find any that would match the simple, straight forward, but always replay-worthy quality of Rome:TW.

Of course, it is outdated now. Of course Rome II for instance has much nicer graphics. Of course, Rome:TW has its flaws.

What the newer games all lack is the concentrated energy of this old style game. They give you bling bling, but then they limit your playing experience because the devs want to shape the way you play a game, instead of presenting the player with opportunities.

I'll give you a - limited - example, just to show the main point, I could go into detail in many respects, but here's one that should show what I mean in principle. 

In Rome:TW, you could march an army without a general into hostile territory. Or you could scale walls with a single infantry unit - it's your choice (and your troops' funeral, perhaps). In Rome II, you are forced to recruit a general. You must replenish resources, even if you would like to get an advantage by sacrificing some units. You cannot win a game based on skill and creative tactics, but only by playing by the book. But the game will throw an achievement your way in exchange for freedom...

I miss old style games like some old software, that did exactly what it was supposed to do and nothing else.

Time to besiege Alexandria, brb

title: Rome Total War
review:
I played this game for years, and I remember the day I bought this game in a shop, and the first battles (battle at Carrhae, damn Horse archers!) and campaigns (Brutti and Julii, and that moment you unlocked more factions !!). It was really magical. Sadly the disk version is not working in windows 10, and on my older computer it really lags, so I bought it again, but now on steam, for a discount of 50%. On the plus side with Barbarian invasion.

This is, in my opinion, the best total war game. Some may say it is not really historical, as you have factions like "the Gauls" and "Germania", while in reality they were countless tribes. True, but I never minded it. I always made my own stories. And that is the magic I think. You should create your own stories, like a king that unites the Dacian tribes and invades Greece, etc. You shouldn't play this game just for gameplay. No. Because you want to create your own stories and love the era. 

Everything is great, well, almost everything then. The campaign is fun, the battles are. You want to play as every faction, try everything out, etc. However, the Romans ofcourse are the best. You have the Senate, missions for them etc. Eventually you will get a pop up saying that the people want you to invade Rome and be their leader, so you can have a civil war! 

The few downsides are maybe the squalor problem, which will be rampant in the mid to late game, and sometimes breaks the fun, or the sporadic fps killers on modern computers. But I think they are neglectable. There are also tons of mods, but I have never tried one, I like the vanilla version.

Great game, it is cheap nowadays (especcially during steam sales), plus you get Barbarian invasion, which moves the whole atmosphere to the end of the Roman Empire, and with religion, tribe migrations, etc. although I haven't tried it yet. 

STOP SCROLLING THROUGH THE REVIEWS, AND BUY IT ALREADY!!!

title: Rome Total War
review:
I've probably reinstalled this game every year since it came out. I actually enjoy it more than the editions that follow it. The soothing music and beautiful map keep me playing for hours. Much like Civilization games, it will make time fly and you'll always itch for one more turn. 

The attention to a lot of Roman history is engrossing and I very much like how you can choose to manage a battle on the field or let the computer figure out the odds. It's a good challenge and since it stays in basically the same era, unlike most other similar strategy games, it really immerses you in the world of the Roman Empire. 

Once you've completed a game as Rome, you can then play as any of the other factions, and this makes it infinitely replayable. Maybe you can rewrite history as Germania or Egypt or Dacia overthrow Rome?

title: Rome Total War
review:
My time playing this game.

-Starts as the Julii
-Makes a strong army
-Invades the north declares war on Gaul
-Gaul counter attacks but fails
-Pushes towards west but fails
-Gaul ambushes and destroy the main part of my army 
-Retreats quickly
-Gaul chases the army
-Army gets backup and pushes Gaul 
-Becomes ally with Briton to fight the Gauls
-Briton betrays me and attack with 1277 troops
-Backup arrives to retake Patavium from Arretium my capital
-Declares war on Briton and pushes them to Luvavum
-Macedon declares Thrace my ally
-Declare war on Macedon
-Attack Macedonian troops on the path to my city
-600 romans vs 450 macedons
-Macedon wins and damages my army very badly
-Backup arrives from Luvavum
-Im now fighting a war with 4 fronts
-West(Gauls) north and east(Britons) and Southeast(Macedon)
-Rebuild my grand army 
-Pushes Briton and Macedon
-Briton starts guerilla warfare against me
-Briton uses a strategy of hit and run which makes Macedon even stronger while I grow weaker
-House of Brutii sends help and attacks Macedon from the south and North
-Macedon cant fight me for now I have to rebuild my army quickly
-Battle of Aemona begins
-1000 Romans vs 600 Britons
-Reclaims the city
-Battle of Alessia begins
-1000 Romans vs 500 Britons and 300 Gauls
-I win the battle of Alessia making a Roman stronghold in France
-Rebels starts fighting me with Macedon
-Macedon,Rebels,Briton and Gauls are now fighting me at all sides but south
-Gaul now surrounds my Grand army 
-Grand army losing numbers every turn 
-Gaul does the same strategy as Briton, Guerilla warfare and hit n' run
-Army are now fighting at all sides except south
-Damage economy,morale,numbers going down and riots at Patavium
-Brutii and Scipii comes to help
-Ceasefire with Macedon(betray them later c;)

Im still not yet done with this game but its really fun
I rate it 10/10

title: Rome Total War

title: Rome Total War
review:
Hello my dear readers,

TL;DR: This review heavily recommends you playing this game.

Longer version:

I played this game a couple of hours. It's hella fun and even the game files are easily modified to get some more factions and whatnot. The graphics are a little bit shitty, but that's not the whole game, right?
So there are some things you think you need to worry about, but you actually don't need to:

1. You think it's hard.
It's very beginner friendly. Actually too beginner friendly. The advisor starts to annoy you after a couple of hours playtime.
2. Your computer can't run it.
C'mon, what is your PC? Wooden?
3. You might tilt after lost battles.
You can always use quicksave.

In the following I will elaborate a bit more about specific areas:

Graphics: Shit, just as I said. But as a consequence makes it playable for almost everyone. Taking the release date into consideration, I'll give it a solid 6/10 (w/out release date 3/10)

Gameplay: It's an open world strategy game. Except for when you play roman factions, no one gives a shit what you're doing. Every campain is unique, every move is new, every battle is nowhere near a duplicate. Even if you are playing the historic battles, there are multiple ways to beat them. I'd say 10/10, I can't name any flaws whatsoever.

Music: The music is a kind of dorian-pythagorean-archaic style, which fits the game. Personally I don't really like this kind of music, but if you are familiar with music notation, history of scales and history of music in general, then you appreciate the music more. During the battles, the music changes to a mix of contemporary styles and this archaic style. In my opinion it really fits the mood of the game all the time. I could give it a 10, but I personally don't like it that much, so I'll give it an 8/10.

Genre: This game and its ancestors have defined the real time strategy/round based strategy hybrid genre. RTW is maybe the most iconic game, because it is so popular amongst all sorts of players: casual to hardcore. Genres listed describe it perfectly: 10/10.

Now, to some extent, we must go and face the truth: This game has its flaws. It has transcended numbers in quantifying how many bugs this has. Nevertheless This game has always kept me awake at night and I still like it.

Overall (averages): 8.5/10


PS.: I only have 80 hours, because I bought it through steam after I bought the CD, but I lost it (you need to have it in your drive). I would've had over 400 hours, no exaggeration.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This was the game I always looked forward to play after getting back from school, I played it non-stop. I used to love this game so much, I used to watch the TV show Time Commanders just because the battle reenactments were done using Rome total war and recorded episodes on my parents' VHS player! Since this game I have bought almost all other TW titles afterwards, and despite the downfalls of DLC becoming more prominent, I have enjoyed each new TW installment more and more.

But the one TW game I have, and always will go back to, is this. I would say its aged modestly well, but graphics have never been important to me. The hardest campaign difficulty is brutal and I always seem to go bankrupt within 20 turns! But other than that, it is the classic TW game that stands out among the rest, its cheaper than ever, and remember when games had cheats? This one does! 

Definitely recommended, especially to those who are new to the total war series.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is probably one of the best games ever to me personally. It is one of those games that to this day, has aged well. There are signs of aging sure, but mostly due to issues with newer OS (Please fix Creative, thanks!). 

This game pits you as one of the three Ancient Roman families against the world, destined to conquer and divide and while only the three initial Roman families are avaliable at the start, if you completely conquer certain nations, you can unlock those too for the Grand Campaign.

What makes this game great is the amount of randomness and innate customazable characters that give this game personality. Through the family tree you will gain members and depending on how you use (or not) them, they can become crazy warmongers or glorious leaders, a depth Creative Assembly never truly tried to recreate after Medieval Total War 2. You will care (or hate) these characters as their personalities shine during their grand speeches before your army clashes with the enemy.

I recommend you this game, not for its combat and action, but for its personality and charm. Each grand campaign will likely be unique as different nations rise and fall and different characters are born into your family. If you haven't tried it and you love turn based/RTS strategies, don't miss this one out.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Around 2004 I got a demo disk in the mail from Maximum PC. Of course the first thing I did was install whatever games were on it. I tried to install and run Thief: Deadly Shadows first, but our videocard didn't support pixel shader 1.1 :(

One other game was on there, Rome Total War Demo which consisted of just one historical battle, Battle of the river Trebia (Hannibal at the gates).

I was hooked.

Watching your Cretan archers lay waste to Roman peltasts with fire arrows while your war elephants stampede through formations of legionnaires never gets old.

I've been playing Total War games since the first Shogun Total War. This is hands down the best one I've played. Even now, with hundreds of hours played outside of Steam, I still find new strategies, factions or units I want to try. 

The best thing The Creative Assembly could do is make Rome 3 just like this game, but with some updated graphics.

9/10 Mods are harder to install compared to Medieval II Total War.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Despite being over 10 years old, this for me is the definitive Total War title everyone should play. While not as polished of a spectacle as later Total War entries, including some baffling historical accuracy (Roman super assassins, the barbarian factions etc) it still has enough charm and a simplicity to it that allows for easy pick up at any time.  Combat is crunchy, the voice acting is cheesy and loveable, and the music is still glorious.

If you want a game that allows you to bring civilization to G*uls, this is the title for you.

title: Rome Total War
review:
In my opinion, this is still the best Total War game to date.

Rome's got good combat, decent unit roosters for different cultures, good siege mechanics & decent city "building/development". You can also build forts & watch towers on the strategic map.

Rome was made before the switch to the new engine, which means that each individual unit actually fight on an individual level, trying to hit enemies & block incoming attacks, instead of the crazy 1v1 kill-animation system. This have a major effect on how battles turn out & how they're conducted. If you got more units of similar skill & situation, they tend to do a fair bit better, instead of it just being a battle of attrition. Projectiles are fairly strong, but as far as I can tell, don't home-in on targets & ready, large shields greatly negate their effectiveness.

I should mention that the music is the best in this title by a land-slide, it's always fitting & it's always get's you in the right mood for the situation.

The one thing you may miss in this if you're used to the later titles is the naval combat, it's automated in Rome. Also, the graphics are very dated. Camera controls are janky & visual feedback is poor compared to later titles.

Compared to the other Total War titles, there's only 3 other games that even come close to being as good as this one: Shogun 2, Medieval 2 & Empire(after milions of patches). I haven't played enough Warhammer to tell how it hold's up yet, but it looks promising.

OBS!
You may get random crashes to desktop if you buy it through steam, unless you go to the main folder, select everything, put it in a new folder within the main folder & then check integrity of the game & let it re-download everything. The game should then not crash, probably, it worked for me (I use Windows 7).

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is a bad game that found itself with a good reputation. The epic 3D battles were so stunning that critics were willing to ignore some major flaws.

To call the AI stupid is an insult to the very concept of stupidity. It fights battles well enough, but simply cannot handle the campaign map, which means it rarely has any troops to bring to the battle. Even heavy doses of cheating cant help this guy. Wheatly would be better.

Diplomacy is an incredible pain in the neck. You cannot just summon a rival to a meeting; you must train a Diplomant, have him physically walk across the map; and then suggest a trade, which the AI will disagree to.

There is only one starting faction: Rome. To play as anyone else you must complete the campaign... which grows boring long before your even close to done.

If your looking to get into Total War (which is a very good idea) I would reccomomend Shogun 2, Attila, or Warhammer. If you want to see what the series is all about without breaking the bank, grab the original Shogun. It utilizes a Risk style map that makes life for the AI much, much better.

Whatever you choose, I hope you enjoy.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War is one of the best strategy games in history... The battles become massive and you feel like a real general when you send units in to fight a 1 on 3 battle and after 20 mins of back and forth, you actually win. Making you wanna take on the challenging story mode to put your general skills to the test. Or experiment with custom battles, by making 50 onagers go vs 900 peasants or have an actual set of battles and make a story out of it. with anything from siege battles to open field 12,000+ soldier WARS!!!!

Pros:
_____
-A real feeling of being a general!
-Easy to control armies (for the most part)
-Large battles that run well (because it is old)
-Intense last stand and to the tooth victory moments!
-Cool pre-battle speeches
-Challenging but fun story
-Many Armies to choose from (plus the dlc having its own armies)
-Nice looking Artillery and archer animations and projectiles

Cons:
_____
-Can be a resource hog with too many units on screen
-Frame rate drops when more than 10,000 units on the field
-Not that good of graphics
-Sometimes armies will run/flee for no reason
-Generals die too quickly

All around i give it an 8/10 when you can run it at its max and is a definite buy with it only being $10!!! it comes with a "Barbarian Invasion" DLC which gives you around 15 more armies and even more fun to have when in custom battles!

I highlly recommend to anyone that likes large battles or even war in general!!!!!!!!

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is a perfect classic of the Total War series. In short, you have the following:

1) a huge map.
2) massive armies.
3) unlimited options when it comes to planning out your campaign.

There is so much more I could mention that makes this game great, but I'd hate to write an entire novel about it. Just know that it sets a nice atmosphere and it's a great strategy game.

However, keep note of a few annoying things:

-Path finding for units can be very lousy sometimes, and there are some glitches routing as well. If a unit is defending the walls in a siege battle and they panic and route, they don't actually route for real. They just stand around idle all the time until someone kills them all off. 

-The AI, no matter how much of an effort you make, can be incredibly stupid at times. This is a trait common in all of the Total War games, but it shouldn't be too awful except for siege battles.

Otherwise, this game is definitely a classic of the TW series. The pros greatly outweigh the cons.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I love this game. That said, the tendency to crash before or after(which is much worse) battles, is fairly annoying. Wuhu! I just spectacularly annihilated an army, killing the king, taking the Capitol, winning the game...CRASH! At least when it has the decency to do it on the loading screen pre-battle you don't want to smash your computer.
 Would be nice to play all factions, but i hear there's a way to do that. Overall I like Seleucia or the Scipii best, Brutii next. Gauls have good shrines, too. If Seleucia could only make the Nike & Artemis shrines as well as their Hephaestus 1 they'd be invincible.

 Plus, I  LOVE all the cheats; never play without the money cheat or the fog 1. Making all the buildings at once also cuts down on excrutiating waiting for stuff to be built, wish I could get the troop cheats besides oliphaunt to work.(though the oliphaunts are cool) Yes , I'm a lazy control freak who'd play every game in god mode if possible, so I like as many cheats as I can get. I wish I could control all factions like on Medieval TW. Really, it's less like playing as king of an empire as the benevolent god that makes his chosen people totally wealthy & OP. My subjects are happy because they have low taxes & all the buildings in their city instantly built.(most of my governers have"the builder" in their name.) I don't feel even remotely bad for cheating because the game does it all the time. I've had enemy cites down to 25/30% loyalty & they wouldn't rebel: it jumps to 100 randomly(with 4 high lvl spies & a smashed temple in it,1unit). Meanwhile, your citii rebel at 70%, with a full garrison.

 My other favorite thing in the game is the assassinations. Nothing beats winning the game by whacking the enemy heirs & king. Plus it's cool getting"the killer" after your king's name. I've whacked many whole factions out of existence without ever going to war, with trade treaties the whole time.

 One thing I dislike about Barbarian Invasion is I can't use my sleazy go-to tactic of buying off the other 1/2 of the Empire's generals/troops/cities. "ooo a 5-star general w/ a full stack...sure would be fun to make him turn on his own cities & butcher the inhabitants thereof." I once bought Corinth off Macedonia as the Brutii to get the Zeus shrine. The senate wasn't pleased cuz it wasn't on their orders, but the people loved me. I bought a Gaul gen when I was Brutii, he sat in the capitol getting ancilliaries 'til he was 50 & I had an army for him, he then stomped all of Greece, took Halicarnassus, Rhodes, then Crete & finally Messina. He was 6 star, 9 when fighting in any situation. He became Praetor. I made him heir because he earned it, not to mention being way better than any of the family. Only the faction leader was his equivalent, but he'd fought as many battles & was Pontifex Maximus.

 What's the game like without all the cheats? Painfully slow & unplayable by my standards. Bankrupt & running a deficit within a couple of years, getting your butt whupped by ai that doesn't seem to be have a cashflow problem, they just contiunously build their cities & have huge army stacks everywhere.Mind you , I play on easy; I can't imagine what they think hard is. I've found many game devs equate easy with impossible. I think it means impossible to lose.(like when cheating heavily) I'm powerless enough in real life, when gaming, at least against ai, I want to be omnipotent. Losing's no fun, & I find it deeply satisfying to have no casualties in a battle where I annihilate the other army. I just want to crush my enemies, see them driven before me ,& hear the lamentation of the women, beacause that's what's best.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Hello, Lets get straight to the point, Rome: Total War is a RTS game, Althought when you look at it you say, "I think this is what my grandpa played." you are Wrong! RTW is one of the best strategy games out there, don't let its age and graphics trick you that this is a bad game. If you are new to Total War games this is a game to get you started. RTW take reletively low disk space (2-3 GB) and is amazing at almost every aspact it has. True you might say how is this different from Total War Rome II. This game is easy and you get a good idea on what TW games are based on. This is one of the oldest RTW's but I would call it one of the best. From units to strategies, this game is amazing at simulating a battle, physics are amazing and anything you do changes the world around you. So if you want to play as a roman and expand the wast territories of the SPQR, Become the supreme ruler of the Roman Empire or destroy the romans and erase them from history. This is a game for you.

Overall I would say I give this game 8/10 for being absolutely amazing. I really want to give it 9/10 but since it is old and Rome II or TW Attila is more modern, lets stick to 8/10

Hope this review was helpful, enjoy the game and take care!

title: Rome Total War
review:
WARNING FOR WINDOWS 10 USERS AND POSSIBLE OTHERS: The game got a post-Gamespy update that will cause the game to do all kinds of crazy display stuff and crash. What you need to do is turn off anti-aliasing by default by going into the game's installation folder, preferences folder, then preferences file and make sure AA_QUALITY says AA_QUALITY:AA_ OFF. This should let you launch the game. If you wish to turn on AA from there, you can do so in NVIDIA Control Panel or any other equivalent program, as turning it back on in the menus will cause it to crash again.

IF YOU GET REALLY BAD FRAMERATES AND LAGGY INPUT NO MATTER YOUR SPECS: Right-click the game in your library, click properties, then click Set Launch Options. In the text box, type the three characters "-ne" without the quotes and press okay. This should fix that problem for most people out there.

With that done, I'd like to say that although this game is a bit primitive compared to modern TW games, it still can be a very fun game.  

Pros:

-The Campaign map is very no frills compared to modern TW games. You can build any building in any city, public disorder is easy to maintain, and it just lacks feature bloat of later games. The game is all about the battles, something I'd wish would come back after games like Attila.

- The battles can look and play better than modern TW games in some ways. Losing units will actually be beaten back and enveloped by superior forces, soldiers will respond to orders at different times, and the engagements can have some real clash and weight to them. 

-There's actually strategy to the strategy map. I wasn't a huge fan of M2/Empire/Napoleon/Attila's maps because they tended to have lots of wide open plains, while Rome 1+2 and Shogun 2 had lots of limiting terrain features where you could create chokepoints and use terrain like mountains and rivers to your advantage.

Cons:

-Battles can be over a little too quickly. I kind of get whiplash at how fast I go from marching, to melee, to routing an enemy army.

-The flipside to things like independent unit movement is that response can be sluggish, sometimes often so bad that I can't tell if the game knows if I ordered them to do anything.

-Pathfinding can be garbage sometimes, especially in cities.

-You can still get cascade moments where your empire is powerful enough that you're just auto-resolving your way across large swaths of the map at some points.

Overall, I was surprised by how much I enjoyed the game despite not playing it since roughly around its launch. Once you get over some usability issues, there's a game here that's aged better than it has any right to.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is the third Total War game from England's Creative Assembly, and, to make a long story short, it's the best one yet. It was naturally expected to build on its illustrious predecessors, which featured epic-scale real-time battles and impressive attention to historical realism and detail. Shogun: Total War was a promising start for the series, while Medieval: Total War built on that promise to create an even more engrossing strategy game. With Rome: Total War, Creative Assembly takes the next step, and it's as much a revolutionary step as it is an evolutionary one, thanks to a beautiful new 3D graphics engine that makes the series' tactical battles--featuring thousands of soldiers--better than ever. The results are nothing short of spectacular, helping make Rome: Total War the very definition of an epic strategy game.


Where do you want to go today? The ancient world beckons, if you're brave enough to take it on.
As in the earlier Total War games, there are essentially two distinctly different types of gameplay in Rome. There's the overarching turn-based campaign in which you conquer cities and provinces, make improvements, and move armies around the map as you expand your empire, and then there are the real-time battles in which you use tactics and maneuvers to crush your enemy in combat. After the helpful and informative tutorial campaign, you can tackle the main imperial campaign. You play as one of three powerful Roman families--the Julii, the Bruti, or the Scipii--attempting to increase the size and glory of Rome and shore up your faction's power and influence. As all three factions are Roman, there's literally no difference between them in terms of units and building types, though they do have different responsibilities. The Julii must deal with the Gauls and Germania to the north in a difficult, landlocked campaign. The Bruti are required to deal with the remnants of the Greek city-states and expand the empire to the southeast. And the Scipii are tasked with subduing Carthage, Rome's great nemesis to the southwest.


At least, that's the principle goal of each faction. But there's a fourth, unplayable Roman faction, one that can influence your course during the campaign: the Roman senate. The senate will order you on missions, from blockading a hostile port or conquering a city (and perhaps exterminating the populace, depending on the level of enmity between Rome and the faction in question) to forging a trade deal or an alliance with a foreign faction. It's up to you whether you actually obey the order, as sometimes the senate will try to stretch you thin on purpose. If you carry the orders out successfully, you stand to gain a monetary reward, a useful new military unit, or influence in the senate. Failing to carry out missions earns the displeasure of the senate and affects your standing with that body. By and large, though, the senate missions help to focus the otherwise huge scope of the campaign--instead of being faced with the monolithic task of trying to conquer Europe, you can instead look forward to accomplishing a long series of short-term goals.

It's helpful to perform senate missions because they can affect an improved feature in Rome: Total War--families. Each of the three Roman factions is essentially one huge family, and your generals and governors are related to one another by birth, marriage, or adoption. These are the leaders of your faction, and they all have traits--strengths and weaknesses--that define their abilities. A strong general may have an excellent command rating, but his disdain for bureaucracy would make him a poor governor. Meanwhile, an otherwise strong governor may have a dislike of farming, which would affect the agricultural output in the province he's in. But if your family members are selected to hold important senate posts, they'll gain influence and abilities once out of office. This introduces a limited role-playing component in the game, as you actually care about trying to further the careers of your family members so they can serve you better.

In addition to traits, family members--not to mention your spies, assassins, and diplomats--can all attract retinues. These are the hangers-on who surround important people, such as advisors, mentors, bodyguards, lackeys, sycophants, and more. Each of these can affect your characters' abilities. For example, a wrestler can improve a character's influence (by being able to literally twist arms), as well as provide added protection against an assassination attempt. You can actually collect and trade retinue members among your family, so you can transfer them to where they're needed the most.


You'll draw your faction's leaders from the family tree. Make sure not to kill off your heirs in battle.
Families are also critical because only family members can serve as generals. You can assemble armies without a general, but they'll be poorly led and will likely fare badly in battle. But with a general, the army's fortune can change. A general with a high command ability is a powerful force in battle, as a well-led smaller force can defeat a poorly led larger force most of the time. On the other hand, the fact that generals are drawn from the ruling family can be dangerous, because you need to make sure there are future generations of leaders and generals. A disastrous battle can wipe out whole branches of the family tree, cutting down promising young sons before they can sire heirs. This can have a crippling effect later on in the campaign, when you find yourself short of qualified generals and governors with a huge empire to manage. It makes for an excellent incentive to try and preserve your generals, rather than treat them as easily replaceable fodder.

Thankfully, when you're short of governors, your cities will be taken over by the "automanager," which is represented by an appointed official who runs the city in your name. You can give the automanager certain priorities, such as to follow a military or financial policy, and it will go about constructing the building and units required. (You can also turn on the automanage functionality in cities that do have governors, if you don't want to micromanage at all.) The computer is generally good at doing what you tell it to do, and this should appeal to players who don't want to spend a lot of time on the campaign map. But if you're a fan of grand strategy and want to control every detail, you'll want to make sure you have plenty of family members at your disposal.

You can choose to autogenerate battle results or fight the battles personally. In most cases, it's easier and simpler to autogenerate the smaller fights.
You can choose to autogenerate battle results or fight the battles personally. In most cases, it's easier and simpler to autogenerate the smaller fights.
When you're not busy trying to crush your opponents, you can try to spy on, trade with, and subvert them. The diplomacy system has been completely overhauled since Medieval: Total War, and you now have a lot more options at your command. These include forming alliances, bullying your neighbors into becoming protectorates of Rome, and bargaining for trade rights. You can also dispatch spies and assassins to probe for weaknesses in enemy defenses, or to take out a key enemy general before a crucial battle. And in a nice twist, you can plant spies in your own cities, where they'll help keep unrest in check by acting as a secret police of sorts, rooting out the troublemakers.
 

I definitly recommend this game to people who enjoy a good, long, legendary campain.

title: Rome Total War
review:
As the renaissance was based on roman and greek ideals, I shall now write you a play that describes the greatest moment of rome and the stain of greek history
I call it, "Sparta's Folly"
[i]raise curtain, speaker comes on to stage center[/i]
Speaker: Twas decades before the birth of christ, the house of brutii had besieged the greek town of Thermon, angered, the spartan king had personally went there to break it, however the roman general in charge of the siege was not going to give up and planned to get the town and win favor of the senate.
[i]curtain closes, speaker exits, a roman general appears on horse, he is off the house of brutii looking out at the battlefield, another general comes on stage[/i]
General 2: The greek army lead by Kleomenes of Sparta are on the nearby pennisula, what are your orders?
General 1: we will besiege thermon again, once he comes into range we shall retreat and face off against his men on fairer ground
General 2: Fair sir?! there are almost 500 of them and only about 300 of us, we shall be fighting on less foul ground, but not fair!
General 1: if this works it shall be foul for the greeks
General 2: very well sir
[i]romans exit the stage,kleomenes of sparta and a hoplite appear on stage[/i]
hoplite: my liege, the romans have set out to take the city of thermon again, shall we engage?
Kleomenes: Yes, and this time we shall give chase when they flee.
hoplite: YES MY LIEGE
[i]hoplite exits[/i]
Kleomenes: This should show those romans not to invade our territory
[i]He exits aswell, enter the first general and an equites, both seem to have been running[/i]
equites:General, the enemy has tooken the lure
general 1: good then we shall show them our might, have your men ready, you'll be what decides this battle
equites:Yes general!
[i]He exits, and general 2 enters[/i]
General 2: we have the high ground but that won't help much in this battle, how do you plan to win this
General 1: you'll see when the time comes, you will also help in this battle, our spy has shown has the king has brought ranged units and peasants, you'll help keep them distracted while our hasati and velites take out their hoplites, then we'll take the kings head
hasati: Generals, enemies are coming this way!
General 1: Good, everyone in formation!
[i]speaker enters[/i]
speaker: The battle then began, while the king had been focused on the general and the main part of the army, the roman equites and the second generals guard quickily charged around the flanks, weakening the bulk of the greek army, outraged the king ordered his hoplites to hunt them down only for them to be lured away either far away from the battle or into the enemy lines where hasati and velite alike slauther them, finally the king had sent himself into the fray, only for his guard to be slain, injured he tried to flee, only to be chased down and slain by the same equites he was trying to hunt down. seeing their king dead on the ground the greek army was shattered, the romans did not end the battle and continued to hunt them down all the way thermon where they won with what men remained from that battle, this concludes our story of how the king of sparta foolishly threw himself into battle only for it to be his end.

so get this game, I worked hard on this play

title: Rome Total War
review:
A classic total war game, and the one that inrtoduced me to the series!
Pros:
-Visuals are great for its time/price
-Battle system still more realistic than 99% of games released on the market today
-Barbarian expansion adds a lot more fun playable factions
Cons:
-Glicthes can ruin certain battles, esp. seiges, and units can be bad at following simple orders
-Little differentiation between different roman families, or different barbarian tribes
-Campaign AI is wildly unpredictable, making diplomacy next to useless
Overall, great game with some bugs and problems that are to be expected given its age and price. A must have for startegy lovers.

title: Rome Total War
review:
You can conquer the world with many different factions, not just roman, but that's mostly for "historical fiction" and entertainment; playing as roman, you will play as one of three powerful patrician families, the Julii (main enemy: the gauls and germans), the Scipii (main enemy, the iberians and carthaginians) and the Brutii (main enemy: the hellenistic kingdoms and Parthia). If you get too powerful, you'll have to eventually face the envy and paranoia of the Senate, launching a relentless civil war that will threaten everything you have built at that point and will turn the Republic into your personal Empire, but that's the end of the game.
Or you can install a Total Realism mod, and just play as Rome itself (not patrician families), skipping the whole "civil war" part and conquering the WHOLE map with the colors of Rome. Your choice.

Anyway, the game is a mid-00's flawless RTS classic. Engaging grand campaign map and fun as hell RTS battles. Roma Invicta Est! And then there's the Barbarian Invasion expansion pack: same mechanics, but new factions (Dark Ages factions, huns, goths, vandals, saxons, franks, etc) and a new grand campaign map with the Western Empire (weak) and the Eastern Empire (decent) ruling everything, until you smash them with a barbaric horde, that is. Just as good as Rome.

Rome II and Attila are nothing more than decent remakes with better graphics, but the original Rome/BI is still fresh and fun.

title: Rome Total War
review: This Game is (together with 'M2TW') the best Total War Game of all time. There are't to much unnecessary functions like in Rome II. Also the Barbarian Invasion, what is actually the same story as 'Total War Atilla', is great an even better than Atilla.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game does so many things right!  

The Good:
Runs stable on low-spec systems and on newer OS, no problem.  I have yet to note a bug other than a single instance of pathfinding stupidity.
The tutorial and interface are both very easy to grasp.  This game is very deep, but also very approachable.
Family lines and member traits that give the game a slight RPG feel.  A coherent and interesting tech tree is present and units are well described.  The sprawling map with many factions vying for power promises an incredible amount of replayability.  Strategic and tactical levels of gameplay are both well polished.  Geography and financial management are constant considerations while playing this game.  Good implementation of spies, diplomats and assassins allows strategies that aren't entirely based on having the better army.  The AI is passable but that might be because it only has to simulate barbarians half the time.

The not good.
The AI consistently misses key opportunities both strategically and tactically.  At times the stupidity can ruin immersion.  Tactical naval combat is not present, all naval battles are auto-resolved.  Thankfully, naval action takes a back seat to the land action and I have yet to see a naval battle autoresolve in an unrealistically illogical fashion - it is pretty predictable.  There is no co-op campaign option or hotseat option.  Last, the graphics.  Even over a decade old, the graphics are still passable, but if you need a little more and eye-candy you to enjoy a game, look elsewhere.  Despite these modest negatives, for the price this game is worth a shot for anyone interested in strategy games and definitely one of the best "bang for buck" performers I've seen on Steam.

Summary: 
A classic.  I played Medieval II+Kingdoms prior to playing this.  Almost passed it up in fact because the gameplay is so similar to Medieval II and the graphics are older.  Believe it or not, I am enjoying this game's campaign more.  Perhaps it is the idea of Rome.  Perhaps it is the soundtrack.  Perhaps it is the pre-battle speeches that are missing from MedII+Kingdoms or the sense that Rome's units are more differentiated somehow.  In the Kingdoms expansion especially, it seemed like very little effort was put into making native american factions different from one another.  It is hard for me to put my finger on why, but this game has simply been more enjoyable.  If you want a decent engine that offers outstanding mods, MedII+Kingdoms is the way to go.  I highly recommend both, but "out of the box," I personally prefer Rome.  Score: 8.7/10
