title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War was the first game that I was ever obsessed with, being early in high school when it came out in 2004. I actually first saw the game engine on the History Channel’s show Decisive Battles, which used the game to depict the Battle of Cannae, among others.
The slaughter that can be witnessed and commanded on the RTS battlefield in this game came at a pivotal time, when Lord of the Rings rewrote the book on grand fantasy movies. You saw these huge battles on screen in movies, and now you could command them yourself.
From experience the central mechanics of a game obviously must grab you to hold interest, but I also believe that the little details can be just as important in showing the player how much the developers love their work. Those that struck me in this game were the hilarious descriptions and attributes of the generals, which adds flesh to the polygons you command. 
Here you could find that your general could be a bold Caesar, or an insane Caligula (literally one of the attributes can describe a character as painting his butt blue and running around the palace naked). These attributes can affect what your generals say in their speeches before a battle; I would always make insane generals my frontline commanders, just so I could hear them say ridiculous things before a battle. 
The game is fun, has plenty charm, and an epic soundtrack; still plenty of bugs, but they can be worked around. Try roleplaying your generals in battle, and your faction leader in the campaign map based upon their respective attributes.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Haven’t played this since it was sold on CD. Bought on steam for 3 dollars

Join 2v2 with friend

Friend wants to play as barbarians

I refuse; a true roman would join the legion

We play as rome v barbarians

He brings a balanced force including war machines and skirmishers

I bring a shit ton of legionary cohorts

I also point up a maxed out praetorian cohort; it costs more than 3 legionary cohorts

Is it cost effective? I assume not. Yolo, I bring it anyways

During deployment we start at opposite ends of our side

We accidentally start the battle early; we have not consolidated our forces

The barbarians deploy about 2/3 of their forces opposite me with a blocking force against my teammate

My unsupported legionnaires are being overrun by the barbarian hordes

My teammate is bulldozing through the blocking force opposing him and rushing to my aid

Can I survive long enough?

I decide to commit my reserve - the praetorians - to sacrifice their lives for time

PRAETORIANS, HOLD THE LINE AS LONG AS NECESSARY!

The praetorians are having none of this

They singlehandedly stabilize my line

By the end of the battle over 900 of my 1500 men will be dead. Many others will have retreated

Only 4 of 80 praetorians will die

The literal last act of the battle was the infantry praetorians chasing down a mounted barbarian warlord and chopping him up

I mouse over their status before the battle ends - they have been fighting about 2/3 of the battle, and charging up and down the field. Most of my other units are badly mauled, have low morale, and are exhausted

“eager, warmed up, motivated by presence of general”

ROMA VICTOR
 

10/10 would slaughter barbarians for the glory of rome again

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is possibly the best game in the entire Total War franchise. Beside the graphics, everything else in this game stands as good (probably better) as many strategy games released in later years. It has an excellent balance between action and strategy, and whether you want to kick some asses boldly just throwing every unit forward or  want to make complicated formations in order to disorient and surprise your enemy, entertainment and addiction will come double quick; when you realise, you will have spent more time in this game than in your love relationship, and if you don't have any, this is the perfect excuse to remain single. 
P.D. How not to love the incredible soundtrack? It fits any war movie you can think of perfectly. 

10/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War is perhaps the best of the Total War Series. What the newer Total Wars such as Empire and Shogun lack is unit variety. The advantage of Rome is that there are five main cultures, keeping the game much more interesting for much longer. The soundtrack is the best soundtrack ever in my opinion, and the fact that it rarely lags is a plus. While it lacks aspects of new total wars like multiplayer campaign, it makes up for it in quality and replayability.

I would rate this game 9/10. Theres just something indescribable about Rome Total War that differentiates it and puts it a tier higher from the other Total War games.

I've never had any bugs with this game.  Its a classic non rushed well built game like we rarely see anymore.  2nd favorite game of all time behind WOW before that game took a crap... Thank you Panda's and Garrisons. I digress, Rome is a Terrific Game i would recommend to anyone.

title: Rome Total War
review:
UPDATE: The game now runs old mods fine.  I admit I haven't tried multiplayer in them yet, but as far as I can tell the Steam version's now relatively stable.  Therefore I'm changing this to a positive review as it's really good even in single player.  Also, if a mod outright refuses to work properly on the Steam release, but has an alternate mode that works on the Alexander EXE, you can use that for maximum compatibility, as Alexander hasn't been updated to Steamworks and may very well run some older mods much better.

Original review below:

title: Rome Total War
review:
They may try, but they will never beat Rome: Total War.

Of course, the game is ageing, and with each new Total War iteration struggling to refine the gameplay it was always going to age somewhat badly. The soldiers which at the time seemed technological marvels now look blocky and cartoony, the campaign map looks less vibrant and more modular, the little portraits, banners and such all look unimpressive and much of the interface seems vaguely unresponsibe, low resolution and unattractive.

But they will never beat this game.

What was Rome Total War? Think of cars coming into a world of carts, think of chocolate coming into a world of porridge. People had dreamed of seeing the vast armies portrayed as 2D sprites in the original Shogun: Total War in glorious full 3D, and this game delivered in every way imaginable. The roman cities were sparkling, shining in the sun, the landscapes were the scale of the real world and the armies were, indeed, massive. The formations looked just as good as you always hoped they would, and things like charges had the very, excellent, feeling that we had all imagined.

Not only that, but the game was deep and [i]huge[/i], with hours upon hours of varied gameplay promised, with any faction we wiped out in one playthrough being available to control in the next campaign - something that Empire: Total War really should have allowed. The (strangely Australian) tutorial woman left [i]nothing[/i] to chance, and we never felt out of control, rushed, or under any pressure that was not a direct result of our own actions (all faults that would plague later titles in the series, in my eyes)

The characters were great - real world names popping up here and there, generals increasing in effectivness. Money flowed relatively easily if you were but a little thoughtful about it, and developing more advanced troops was intuitive and straightforward.

In short, this game got everything right. It has just the right mix of gameplay imposition and gamer imposition, input from both sources comign together to create a sandbox empire building experience that could suck you in and satisfied you for tens, hundreds of hours.

Amazing game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
It is a very good and very old game. I wish I had played it in my childhood years. However, the problems are not in the age, but the aesthetic. The gameplay and balance are very well (AI aside), but the culture and history is very bland. All the Gauls are simply shirtless men with green pants, and the Germans are just reskins of them but with red pants. 

In Barbarian Invasion, all the Germanic tribes are simply men in weird colored leather armor with leather helmets, and each tribe only distinguishable by their weirdly colored tunics and shields. 
I'd also like to add that all of the Germanic or "barbarian" lords and Kings are simply the Gaulish skins. 

That means the King of the Burgundians will have bright red hair, a golden Celtic helmet, and blue pictish face paint. 
If you're going to get this game, I suggest Europa Barbarorum (for vanilla) and Invasio Barbarorum (for babrarian invasion).

Personal opinion: overall rating 9.5/10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
The Roman town of Massilia is under assault from barbarians from Gaul. The Warlord Vindex had brought an army of nearly 3000 warriors, while the general Quintus held the town with 3 hastati with mercenary reinforcements on the way. Vindex began his attack on the town; his army moves up with battering rams to tear down the wooden walls and gate. Quintus and his men hold up near the town center, blocking the narrow streets that lead to it. The mercenary reinforcements have only just begun to arrive on the battlefield and continue to match towards the town. The walls and gate fall and the Gauls begin to flood the town, Vindex stays behind and watches from outside. The Gauls countue to pour into the town and a small group brakes off from the main army. The main army moves down the main road to the town center while the smaller group takes a different road. As the main army gets closer to the town center they are greeted with with volleys of pila fire that shred into the barbarians killing many. The Gauls with their massive army charge into the line of hastati and intense combat fallows. The two units of hastati fight bravely against the Gauls but their numbers are staggering and they slowly push the Romans back. At the same time the smaller army is attacking a seconded point on the road that is less defended but the Romans here are able to hold them. Quintus encourages his men to keep fighting before joining the battle himself to the keep the main army from advancing. As the Romans continue to hold the town center the mercenaries finally arrive to help and see Vindex just outside the walls. Before Vindex can even realize what is happening the mercenaries surround and attack him. Vindex and his body guard fight bravely but are all eventually cut down. The mercenaries quickly move into the town and cut off the Gauls from behind. The Gauls now confused and tired begin to panic and try to pull back but can't as the roads have been blocked. The Romans and mercenaries begin to slaughter the barbarians. When the day was out only 47 men were what remained of Vindex's army. Several months after the battle Quintus would join his father with a massive army to conquer all of Gaul. Quintus would go on to conquer the Iberian Peninsula and revive the title "The Great". As for the mercenaries, they disbanded and settled in Massilia. Years latter their descendants  would help form the very backbone of the legion and lead Rome to further glory.

10/10 Would win against overwhelming odds again.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Still my favourite of all the multitudinous Total War games. Having played the Total War series since CA first came out with Shogun, I have to say Rome was the one that really turned me into a Total War fan through and through. The factions all have their own unique personalities - Rome's heavy focus on infantry; Egypt's swift chariots and devastating archers; the powerful hoplite infantry of the Greek states or the freewheeling Parthian horse archers. The game itself is easy enough for a rank beginner to learn the basics, but challenging enough for even the most grizzled of Total War veterans to take a beating. And even the strongest of factions, when stomping across the map, can suddenly find their full-stack armies reduced to nothing by a well-placed ambush, the point of an assassin's blade, or the treacherous bribes of a high-ranking diplomat...

Overall, Rome Total War immerses you in the Mediterranean world of the last few centuries BCE, lets you take charge of many of antiquity's most celebrated nations, and conquer the known world through a combination of sly negotiation, swift backstabbing and - most importantly - the iron-shod feet of your mighty legions. And that's just the campaign map.

Rome Total War, as all the games in the series are, is a game of two halves. The campaign map is probably the more in-depth and fascinating part of it for me, but there are also the impeccably tuned real-time battles. Your units face off against those of your enemies using a fairly basic rock-paper-scissors arrangement: infantry fight cavalry; cavalry crush archers; archers blitz infantry. Upsetting the balance somewhat are the fearsome Egyptian chariot archers with the speed of cavalry and an even longer range than foot archers; the same can be said of Parthian horse archers, while the Roman legionaries can Testudo in the classical formation, protecting them from archers. The battles are well balanced, enough so that you can pull a victory out of your own personal Thermopylae one turn, while the next your vastly numerically superior army can be utterly crushed by a much smaller force with superior weapons. (Pro tip: don't take a 3000-man-strong army of cavalry into a fight with 200 Spartan hoplites...)

Rome Total War does have some technical issues on Windows 7 and later. These can be worked around with certain resolution tweaks and a launch option, although it's unfortunate that these issues persist despite many other older games being updated for Steam and newer OSes. I have yet to notice any of the old Crash to Desktop issues RTW used to have, but I'd like to see a compatibility update at some point.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Where to begin....

I first purchased Rome over a decade ago... so the 500+ hours stated on here is vastly inaccurate. Which is a good indication as to what I think of the game. This review is to the point:

The simple yet satisfying game mechanics are what keeps you coming back. The options of other factions, and the different unit available within each, means you will have hours of fun mastering the pros and cons depending on who you go. Armoured Elephant units or the Pharaohs Bowmen units are my personal favs.

If you are a fan of recently released Total War games, give this a try and find out where it all really began for the franchise.

title: Rome Total War
review:
ROME TOTAL WAR AND ROME BARBARIAN INVASION ARE NOT THE SAME THING!!!

That being said. RTW is one of the best strategy games ever. I loved it for many reasons. Large armies, good, fun battles, espionage aspect, and finally at some point all there is left is other big civs that you have to fight. It makes for a great time. 

I would like to add that i am a big total war fan. I know how to run the economy, use agents, win battles, plainly, I know how to manage my faction.

Now we come to BARBARIAN INVASION. 
This is a great game in its own right. Personally I do not consider it an expansion because it is so different. It is similar but not the same as vanilla rome. Different time period factions, units, but also a different play style is needed. It was not designed as a conquer the world type like vanilla Rome was.

Keep in mind that I know how to play total war. My opinion is not that it is bad, it's just that it is not for me. Vanilla Rome had a long campaign setting for 50 provinces need for victory. In B.I. most have an 18 province requirement.

The odds are stacked against you. It is not too hard to beat I just found that it was too much a chore to enjoy. I play games for fun which is different for everyone. I tried many factions. My last on was the Saxons. I tried to see it through thinking that once I got enough cities I could have those big armies  I wanted. I had 10 provinces. I clawed my way up to this point. I still could not......

get a lot of money,
get massive armies, 
stop having to gruel my way through the campaign.

In short BI is a good game with a good challenge. I m just saying if you like vanilla Rome then I suggest you get  Barbarian Invasion demo before making your decision.

I vote  a very big yes to this game. Play it and decide for yourself. Just some things I thought you should now

title: Rome Total War
review:
I have little prior experience with RTS and Strategy games in the vein of Total War, but I'm already hooked. Rome: Total War promises a long-lasting and extremely deep and entertaining experience for anyone dedicated enough to learn. I am a little over halfway through my first campaign and plan on trying out the other factions and "quick" campaigns once I have finished conquering the eastern side of the world. 

Pros:
+ Deep strategy on both the world map for management and battle map for real-time combat
+ Nearly infinite replayability - you'll get your money's worth
+ Setting is great (Who doesn't love Rome?)
+ Crushing Greek sieges back-to-back while outnumbered 4-1 is an awesome feeling

Cons:
- Burden of knowledge is huge. Expect to be confused if you're new to the genre, but stick with it
- Consequently, the tutorial is also very long. Be prepared to set aside an hour or so to get through it
- Can sometimes be difficult to find information on the game's mechanics (e.g. "How does the culture penalty work?")
- I have had a few instances where the game will crash after I end a turn. Disabling the AI via console commands (disable_ai and run_ai) fixes this temporarily, but it means the armies on the map do not move or attack, taking all the fun out of the game. 

Altogether a very solid purchase, good entry title into strategy games. Would definitely recommend.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I hadn't played any Total War games until I bought this one. After downloading and running it I went through a tutorial that taught me how to push buttons, and then I began the campaign. I started as the great Roman house of Julli, and began my great campaign. 
After pushing north to the alps, driving out the Gauls, I made peace with the nearby empires. The Gauls had been raiding me on occasion, and I had always beaten them back. Things seemed to be going well, until I asked to buy a city the Gauls owned. Now, of course, I offered a fair price. It was an incredible price, in fact, but they denied it. I offered again, with even more money and goods, and again they denied. This was the last straw. How DARE they deny me?! Don't they know who WON all those wars? I then decided that I had had enough of these ancient Frenchmen who dared to think they are equal to us great Romans. I not only wanted to teach them a lesson; I wanted them gone. So thus, the Great Gaul Genocide began.
It was a truly incredible campaign. Several new armies were raised. All traces of Gaul in the east were annihilated first, and a great push into the west began. Whenever I captured a city I was given the option to either occupy it as it was, enslave half the people and disperse them among my empire, or slaughter 3/4 of the people in the settlement. Naturally, I chose the latter. My goal was elimination. Death to all those barbarians who dared to have national pride. 
I pushed into the Gaul empire, taking city after city. The enemy had a bigger empire, perhaps, but mine was far stronger. Our great Roman soldiers killed all in their path. Despite a stumbling point where one Gaul army managed to defeat mine and save their city, two new armies took its place. The massive campaign wore on until, at last, the final Gaul stronghold fell. The people were slaughtered, and nothing remained of the once great empire. 
 I had kept a running body count as the genocide wore on. The final results were:
Gaul Soldiers killed: 3,659
Gaul Civilians killed: 33,689
Total Barbarian Gauls killed (citizens and soldiers): 37,339
Brave Roman soldiers lost: 1,258
Final body count: 38,597 people dead. 

It was only after the genocide was over that I realized I'd forgotten why I was mad at them in the first place. 
Hmm...it was something about a city...

10/10 would genocide again.

title: Rome Total War
review: So last night....I stayed up until midnight, preparing to attack Rome, three full stack armies, two of them coming from the North, full of Urban Cohorts and the most elite troops I could get. One coming from the sea to the west, a fodder army of lesser troops. The turn before I plan on attack, SPQR denounces mine and the other three houses. Instant Civil War, four or five of my settlements beseiged by the other two houses, but I press on. First, my fodder army lands, 2-3k of my troops against two full stacks of SPQR elite troops, some 5-6k. I manage 681 kills to their complete annihlation of my army. SPQR forces have HUGE buffs. But it works, one of their armies is too far away from their capital to provide back up, so I lay siege. As soon as my towers are built, I assault the city. Walls so large they fill the entire screen, my onagers unable to penetrate them. The SPQR has less than a thousand men garrisoned in the city, but my reinforcements are delayed, they may not make it to the battle. With the enemies army marching at us from the other side of the city I quickly charge the walls. Sending my top units up the towers, I lose a thousand men, just trying to take the walls that less than four hundred defended. I rush a company of men to the other gate, to prevent enemy reinforcements from entering the city, they get there just in time. Now they must use my siege towers, I turn my onagers against them, destroying my own siege towers. But I haven't the ammo, one remains. With my battered and half killed army, I march to the city center, leaving only one unit back to defend the walls, along with my archers positioned along the enemy's approach. Half of my forces retreat from the city center as soon as combat ensues. The other half fighting bravely, but slowly losing. The enemy army reaching my tower, and then, reinforcements, my own. Finally arrived, striking the enemy in the back as they try to clamber up their own walls. I send the calvary and some infantry around to the side gate, attacking the city center from behind. I lose near on a thousand more men fighting the contingent of several hundred in the center, but I take it. Now I must hold it. With the enemy army at my back, attacking the walls my men so valiantly took. My second army charging at them, forcing them up against the walls, ballista's and arrows raining down on them. They begin to break, but so do my men. The might of the SPQR is undeniable, their armor thicker, weapons sharper. Sending the calvary out of the side gate, hitting them in their flank, finally the break. And the city is mine. The SPQR is destroyed, but the war has just begun, now the house Julii must reign supreme over the other two houses, they must be dealt with and swiftly. And with the Britons to my north, I know my victory of Rome will be a spec in comparison to the battles that I must fight to be declared ruler of the Roman Empire, and the world!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is a great game. You know this game came out in 2004 and twelve years later this game managed to heavily impress me. From the small part of diplomatic relations to the absolute massive battle scenes, the game just immediately sucked me in. Now the Total War games had never really been a big thing to me up until this moment so I was just a bit dubious about how much this game would appeal to me, but I am a history buff and I was trying to find a way to spend the summer so I picked it up during the sale. What I found was an actually really good game that managed to combine the turn base parts with the real time strategy. 

The game as said is split into two types of strategy. The first part is map screen. From here you manage your settlements and your armies. You can upgrade your towns and recruit new units. From here you can also send out your diplomats to other factions in order to institute trade agreements and forge alliances for wars. The diplomats have actually quite a bit that they can discuss with the other factions. You can make demands such has making them hand over a territory or you can create a trade agreement that can help your income or just allow them military access to other parts of the world. Another thing that impressed me is that they can reject your offer and make counter offers. This really does feel like an actual negotiation rather than just a basic “I declare peace or war thing.” One thing I’m going to say though is that there is a severe problem with the lack of anything to really during peace time. In the end though the map screen is fantastic turn based strategy. 

Now as for the actual battle screens it is one the greatest parts of the game. The sieges and the battles are just so massive that it is impossible to be swept away by it. The fights aren’t too complicated. It doesn’t take long to figure the strengths and weaknesses and of each unit. Just know when to charge and how to flank the enemy and that’s rather easy to pick up. What makes it really work though is just the basic ability to pause the game and figure out your positions and where each unit should go. This takes a lot the panicking and stress out of other strategies that usually takes me out of most strategy games. The units are widely varied and it is rather cool to see the progress of your units to much more powerful troops.

In the end what really sells the game is just the absolute scale it has. The game just feels massive and every advancement you do makes you feel more powerful. Some might say that the effects don’t look good and to those people I say they need to shut it. The game looked amazing back in the day and still looks line today. I don’t care if we can’t see every pimple on the soldiers they look fine. As for the multiplayer I don’t know what it’s like. I am not interested in it, but if you are then check it out. Rome: Total War is a game that everyone should check out if you are interested in history or if you think you might be interested in the game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
They say rome wasn't built in one day, but that certainly depends on how much you play this game, and with a game like this, you can easily get stuck in front of your computer for hours. I've heard some good and some bad things about the sequel to this game, Rome II, so i figured i might try and review this one instead.

I realize there's alot of TBS games kinda similar to this out there, but by some miracle i found my way through all those rip-offs and half bad ones, and found my way to this. Anyways, let's get to it

Now even though this game might not have the best graphics, it's a good quality game, the game runs very smooth on even the worst of computers, I experienced a surprisingly few number of glitches and flaws. Also this game variates a lot more than you’d think, the terrain and weather and basically all the nature, and even soldiers surrounding the battlefield has an effect on the battle itself, and it manages to create a somewhat realistic atmosphere.

You start of by choosing between a rich number of factions to play as, and each faction has their own abilities, starting points, diplomatic and offensive advantages, and of course they all are different difficulties. Now when you start you can also choose different campaign lengths and modes, but the ultimate goal, is to conquer the world. Even after you’ve reached your goal, and have gotten the “You Beat The Game!” message, there’s a lot to do.

Now the game doesn’t have many tracks to get you humming along, in fact it has a couple of tracks running in the background, and some music to set the mood for a fight, but that’s in the rough it, and that’s one of the things letting this game a bit down in my opinion.

To sum up, this game has a great costumization ability, and is good for a replay, or even two (to all the rome fanatics xD) not the best graphics or music but all in all, I give this an 7/10

title: Rome Total War
review: Don't even think about it; this title is a definite buy.  This was my first RTS, although it is a mix of RTS or Turn-Based, the battles that take place are RTS.  This is my first Total war game ever, so I might not know everything about the franchise, but what i've experienced in the time i've played is amazing.  The graphics are definitely not going to blow you away in todays standards, but back when this was released was very impressive, in my gameplay there was about 2,000 people on the battlefield at once.  Don't get me wrong this game is not perfect, but is pretty close. For example, your troops get stuck way too many times. Also your troops run scared even though you may outnumber them 8:1 and you are dominating them. Those minor errors do not in fact damage the game in any way.  I do have one major problem since this game came out so long ago, my Nvidia can't automatically optimize it for me so it goes kind of slow for me, but maybe that is just me. Bought this on the Sega/Total War sale 10/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
I've logged over 200 hours on R:TW off Steam over the past few years, and it's one of my favorite Total War titles to date. Great micromanagement, great immersion, and caters to many playstyles.

Extremely well thought-out and put together and with a very approachable learning curve, ROME puts you in the shoes of the head of a Roman Great House. Take on the Barbarians in the North as the Julii, wage war with the Greeks in the east as the Brutii, or dominate the deserts of Africa as the Scipii. As you expand a facet of the great Roman Republic, you eventually must take on your neighboring Romans as time passes. With either popular support within the Senate or with the Plebs, or by whitlling down your alliance with the other Houes, civil war breaks out and you can take Rome itself for yourself, and crush your past Roman allies. After completing a campaign as a Roman house, you unlock a new package of factions to play, all quite a bit more difficult than your Roman campaign.

In the expansion Barbarian Invasion, you face a lot more challenges this go around, the Roman Empire is suffering, plagued with Rebels on each side, and taking on enemies on all side. You can choose to repair Rome to it's former glory as the Western/Eastern Empire, or watch Rome crumble as a barbarian faction. From the Saxons in the North, to the Hunnic horde in the east, you have the same template ROME provided, but add hordes, changed regions, religious conversion and new units/buildings.

tl;dr Play this game

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is the best Total War in the franchise even better than Total War: Rome II. There's just so something awesome bout these factions that really make you feel you are the one who is controling everything and dominating all. The armies itself are very unique giving each faction their own individual units that make the game feel so much more refreshing when you're wanting to play another campaign because you have the chance to experience the different units.

The gamplay itself is very strategic where you see your men in their formations and positions ready to attack or defend. You may be outnumbered but if you stick to formations, strategic planning you can win which I very like that you need to use your brain to win.

The game has the best soundtrack in any Total war game, it fits the battles perfectly and makes it epic too. The Generals speech are very cool to hear aswel while you hear your soldiers cheering. Finally the utscenes are really entertaining to watch as well just seeing if your spy or assassn failed/succeeded the mission. 

Now when I say this game is better than Rome 2 I don't mean it but I do. Rome 2 has probably the most stupidest AI ever and the most content removed from. I won't go into detail because I am not reviewing the game (Also I don't have it on steam).

Rome Total War wasn't opening here, i don't know why, well... I discovered a way to make it happen. Use the window mode configuration "-ne" . This should work. Don't need put any kind of compatibility .

Right-click on the game title under the Library in Steam and select Properties.
Under the General tab click the Set launch options... button.
Enter the launch options you wish to apply (just write "-ne" without ") and click OK.
Close the game's Properties window and launch the game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Suprisingly, the ai is very smart for being such an old game.

Started as the Julii and went into battle against some barbarians in northern italy near the mountains.

The enemy barbarians put up their shields in a defensive stance as my soldiers approached which was a surprising mechanic.

Told my soldiers to charge at the enemy but somehow things went horribly wrong and my army started routing.

The enemy warriors then lowered their shields, charged, and slaughtered my army.

The AI is incredibly smart which makes me wonder how CA went from this to the lazily put together games of today.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is a genre defining game. Even all these years later I still love it and play it. If you haven't tried the Total Wat series, I can't recommend it enough.

Sure, the game is not perfect (graphics are a bit aged, AI isn't the sharpest tool in the shed, doesn't have the depth of its successors), but I will always love it. There are many other exceptional Total War games, but this one has a special place in my heart.

For those of you unfamiliar with the franchise, Total War games have a unique blend of turn based and real time strategy. You manage your empire and cities on the cmapaign map and then fight your battles on the battle map. 

This game is in my lifetime top 10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Not only a classic of the genre, but also the best of the total war series imo. This game beats every other title out there in terms of a combined turn-based/rts historical game (especially with mods, which virtually increases the game length by hundreds--possibly thousands--of hours. 

Graphics: They're okay for its time (about a 6-7/10), but it may feel outdated for some newer gamers. Try some mods, and it'll feel more new. With that being said, about 7/10 with the mods in mind.

Gameplay: Very smooth, responsive battle animations. If you can control your cavalry well, you can handle any opponent with proper flanking and timed troop engagement. The turn-based aspect may seem somewhat outdated, but there are mods that will bring the diplomacy among other parts of the game to unrivaled levels. 10/10

I'm not going to comment on anything else, since I think this game is all gameplay with some visuals to create immersion. There is a grand and truly epic feel to the campaign, so anyone with some interest in history would enjoy it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I am the House of Julii.

I am to the North of Italy. I am part of the Glorious Roman Republic, sharing with three other factions; the blue Scorpios (I think) who have decided to take a couple of islands and then the big parts of Africa. The green Brutii, who decided that looking ridiculous would best show the Greeks what's what. And I, wearing fantastically imperial red, who was tasked with sorting out the dirty Gauls.

I quickly began a conquest that would put the Black Templars to shame, sending out army after army, conquering town after town. They tried to resist, but my men were worth two of theirs, and my men outnumbered their three to one. As we came, we took most of them slaves, built up my core towns, built as many temples to convince more people to shag as possible, and continued on our merry murdering way.

Occasionally, the Guals or Brittony or Germans would manage to scrape together an entire army of 2000 people. These were the battles I, and my family, were born for. We smashed together, blood and sword and sinew, as my Velites threw their spears overhead, and cavalry quickly hit them from behind. Few enemies died facing us in the north, many ran and most died with sword wounds in their backs rather than face us.

We tried peace once, and we paid the price with roman lives. When they begged for our mercy, they found only our gladius. We heard the lamentations of their women as they were taken back to mighty Arretium, our capital city. And how it had grown; on the back of slaves and the glory of our men, we raised great arenas and temples to show our glory! We raised great barracks to train our men! We grew the greatest of men to enforce our will! And the north of Europe was stained red with blood; the map of Europe was stained red with our flags.

We found that land ran out quickly; Europa gave way before our bloodlust did, and we turned to look back. We were disgusted with what we saw. Corruption. Weakness. Our supposed equals made peace with the savages, our supposed superiors hide behind the walls of Rome. They whispered of treachery, but we knew weakness and corruption when we saw it. The spineless Scorpios had no trouble gaining the favour of the Senate; spending more time on their knees in glorious Rome than sword in hand over Carthage. The Brutii failed to live up to their brutish name; content with a paltry pile of sand, growing fat and lazy as we had grown lean and numerous in both flesh and glory.

We recalled our armies to home, to the swell of the crowds. They chanted our name, and spat at the mentions of the Senate. All had been united under our banner; did not the Celts and Gauls and Germans and Thrycians alike not bend the knee to the glorious Romans, all beneath the bloody red banner of the Julii? Mars had made his favour clear; he doesn't favour cowards, and Jupiter didn't let the weak rule. We built temples in His Name, and spread his name further than even the diplomats know. All that was left was to follow the glory given to us, under the gaze of the gods and cheers of the people, we marched the final path.

All roads lead to Rome.

-Buys Game

-I GOT 2 CITIES AND 2 GENERALS YAY
-Sees text: "Taking Syracuse will up your standing with the Roman Senate."
-Moves armies around a bit

-I AM NOW A SEASONED TOTAL WAR WARRIOR
-Ends turn
-Sieges Syracuse with my biggest army (240 men)
-Ends turn
-Fights 520 dudes with my army
-Kills 430 of them, loses my entire army AND my general dies
-Roman Senate, House of Julii, and House of Brutii declare war on the Greek Cities
-Ragequits
-Repeats


10/10 would siege Syracuse again

review:
he game that launch the Total War series towards heights that it could've never dreamed of. This game is a turn-based strategy game where you take command the various factions during the Roman Era as you command, build, govern and attack Rome's enemies.

The battle system unlike the system you will see in the modern day versions of the game is really simplistic. Sort of like an almost modern update of Imperial Glory. Now of course, the usual complaint would be "OMG the game is too hard" or "OMG the online players are wrecking me" Luckily the game has an in-depth tutorial plus you have all the time in the world as this game offers various combat both historical and custom made as you polish your skills in battle. And also being a leader of Rome.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I definetly loved this game. It was revolutionary at the time and is still considered one of the best total wars to date. It is mostly balanced and when it's not it's usually just the overpricing of certain units. The community is full of skilled players which is a pro and a con. Many players may struggle to get into the game because of that fact, but if you practice enough and look up some strategy guides then you can rek face. I felt that no army was super under-powered or super over-powered and that anyone could be good with any faction. 

Now I'm going to talk a bit more about the cons. One of my major cons is that some factions do not get that many units. In campaign this may be OK but in multiplayer it can make some factions harder to play as. Next con is, well it's old. I'm not complaining about graphics, I'm more complaining about limitations. Battles above five thousand are laggy and hard to play. Also the campaign is hard if you don't look up even one strategy guide. It's confusing and sometimes you feel like you don't know what to do. They give you some tips that aren't neccessarily helpful. I remember having to restart the game as the brutii often because it's that hard. You can end up having built up a large debt. And my final complaint is diplomacy. Oh god the diplomacy. The diplomacy is awful. I remember gaul asking me for trade rights, me accepting, and then they attack me. Also, I have a friend who was attacking the last city of dacia. Dacia had a ton of money and he had accept or we will attack, in exchange for ten thousand denarii. Dacia refused and got obliterated. Stingy bastards. Also, Gaul in my most recent Brutii playthrough said "give us 500 denarii or we will attack" and I just gave it to them. Keep in mind that the julii is currently making them their bitch. Then I was like, "Hey, want map information? Just give us 10,000 denarii." Gaul counter offered with "Give us 550 denarii every turn for two turns or we'll attack." and I was like "Fuck you!" and then Gaul went to go threaten the rest of rome. Bare in mind that they haven't attacked yet.

My final score is 9/10 for the game. It struggles a bit, but for the time it was made it was amazing.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Oh wow.  Performance is really bad.  I mean BAD.  My main machine has a FX8320 @ 4.6GHz and an overclocked HD7850.  Can't run the game at more than 30fps no matter what settings I lower or turn off.  Tried it on a secondary machine with a stock Phenom 9650 and a R7 260X and the same deal.  I clearly remember being able to play this game a little after it came out with an Opteron 165 and a X1950XT at full settings with no fps problems.  
At first I imagined it was a driver issue, but then I decided to dig out my old original RTW CDs, and after jumping several hoops to get it installed, sure enough, I was able to play the game at max settings with my fps numbers in the high 50s on average.  WUT?
Whatever.  I got it on sale and for convenience (my old CDs are scratched already).  As it is the game is painful to play.  I then read the negative Steam reviews after the fact.  I highly recommend the game, just not this version.

title: Rome Total War
review:
My Steam account will say I've only got about 10-15 hours on this game, but in truth I've been playing this for much longer, since 2007 in fact, whereas I installed Steam on my new laptop earlier this year.
In total I've probably got 800-900+ hours on this game, maybe even 1000+, it's hard to calculate because I've been playing it so long and have spent many long sessions on this game.
Suffice it to say, I think my opinion on the game is worth something.

This game is without a doubt one of the best games I've ever played, ever, in my nearly 21-year life.
I've played a multitude of games on different platforms from the first 3 Spyro games on PlayStation 1 as a kid, to GTA San Andreas on the PlayStation 2, to Halo 3 on the Xbox 360, to Red Dead Redemption on the same system, etc. All games I'd consider to be absolutely classics and some of the best games made, and I'm sure many of you would too.
Rome: Total War, in my opinion, owns a place in that list of games.

Most people reading this review, I feel, will be those who have already had the pleasure of playing this game, and just want to see the good words that others have been speaking of it. This game is old enough and iconic enough in the PC gaming community that I dare say most PC gamers worth their salt will have played it.
Well you won't be disappointed by me, because this game is one of the most iconic PC games to have ever been made, if you ask me.
It has its imperfections, as do all games.
The poor campaign and combat AI
The now dated graphics (not even worth mentioning anyway)
The, erm... the.... God, what else is an imperfection of this wonderful game?

For those of you who have genuinely never played this before, and are wondering if it's worth it, note that this game is 11 years old, as of the writing of this review. That's old.
Be kind to it for its dated graphics and game mechanics.
Trust me, if you can get past that, you'll be in for one wild ride, and one amazing game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is the most highly acclaimed game in the Total War series. Upon it's launch, it was apparent that the Total War series had something different to offer to fans of Turn Based Grand Strategy games. In time, it would become known as one of, if not, the best Total War games ever made. You might ask yourself why out of all the newer Total War games is Rome the best? Well, there's several simple reasons.

Pros:
- Simple design, as it is one of the first TW games
- Large, sprawling cities to battle in, but not too detailed so as to distract the player.
- The single best Soundtrack you will find in any TW game.
- Large map, but not on a ludacris scale such as Rome II.
- Great choice of factions
- Campaign and battle map look beautiful
- This game can be played smoothly at its highest settings on any modern computer
- Massive replay value

Cons:
- [post suggestions in the comment area]

Overall:
Rome is a nice and simple, beautifully crafted game. It is what CA was praised for in the Total War series. Rome II is way more technical with a great deal more to learn Honestly, the inlons about this game. Just as I have, almost all major and indie critics have given this game a 9/10, 95%, 4.5/5, etc. This was also given "14th Greatest Game of All Time" apparently and I do think it deserves it.

10/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is a classic!

Sadly when you buy the Gold Edition on steam, you don't get the Alexander DLC.

The Barbarian Invasion has one problem, chosen archers have bleeped up graphics. 
If you want an even better experience, I would suggest learning how to modify the descr_strat files to play as every faction. Nothing beats the satisfaction of invading Gaul as the Franks.

For the normal campaign, it is a challenge to get used to, but it is entertaining to form the Roman Empire through a bloody civil war in late game for control of all the Empire. Carthage is the best challenge because it is fun... fun to get kicked out of Sicily while invading Iberia.

My rating for this classic RTS would be a close 10/10, in reality 9.7/10.
Barbarian Invasion would get a solid 9/10
Alexander would be 8/10 ( I rated this because I had the DLC before I got Steam )

title: Rome Total War
review:
I came, I saw, I conquered. Those words mean a lot in this game. When i saw this game in my local MVC shop before it closed down nearly 11 years ago. I wasn't sure if i would enjoy it. I loved games which involve empire building and controlling large armies on the battlefield like the good old AOE series. Although this game doesn't lead on the same path as AOE, it brings a lot more entertainment with empire building and controlling vast armies on battle map. This game, like a few others are the types of games that i could play for ages. They are my golden games to which i will never sell or never forget. Each faction has a strength or weakness, but it also depends on which units and buildings you create. It is up to you and you alone to survive. Its not a simple hit and run game where you can do anything you want and get away with it. Each choice, move and final act you make will to a certain point have an impact on your empire and your armies. You will never know who will betray you, attack you or ask for an alliance. The battlefields are more or less the same, once the battle begins, its fate, skill and intelligence that helps you win and leads you to world domination. 

Although the game will have its moments be it bugs, crashes or simple copy and paste. If you ever play the game on the hardest difficulty, the feeling of victory after an hour+ long battle is beyond satisfying. The battle music is perfect, the power and awesomeness before battle and the clash between your army and the computer AI is just as good. Many factions do have the same units and it can be rather annoying when facing the Roman's, but it can also be a wonderful challenge, but again, that all depends on the choices you make because one wrong more and that's it, everything could come to an end.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game was a classic, yet if you do not already own it, it is now more trouble than it is worth.  As someone who has put many hours into this game (owning it on CD long before I bought it again for steam) I have to say its many bugs combined with its age mean it no longer the game it once was.

You may boot it up and find yourself enjoying it, only to discover any one of many game breaking bugs.  These bugs are older than many small children and most have no known solution.  I myself have had trouble with CTDs upon ending my turn, graphical glitches, freezes deep into epic battles and others.  The one that sent me over the edge involved a bug where you can not attack your enemies but they can attack you.  It happens after a special event late in the game and there is no remedy.

While this game is a classic and was great in its time, it has not kept up with software advancements and I assume the problems will only pile up over time.  Unless your an anthropologist interested in old relics, don't bother with this game any longer.  I say this as a fan, rest in peace old friend.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Hi there, friend! I just happened to be in the neighbourhood and was *really* interested in your area.

What's that? My 5000 troops making you nervous? Who said anything about them being troops? They're just my friends, ready to welcome you into the neighbourhood.

Say what, why don't we sign an alliance to get things started. We can share trade rights, map information, lots of stuff I'm sure you don't really care about. Tell you what - anyone bothers you, just let me know. I'll bring my friends around again. Deal? 

What's that? You're worried about me breaking our arrangement? Why would I ever do such a thing? I mean, look at you, fledgling settlement and all. Just sign and accept, k? We're new BFFs!

/unsheaths dagger

10/10 would meet 'n' greet, betray, pillage and murder you again

PROS:
Realistic campaign sees you requiring real micromanaging of settlements into cities, taking into account real-life issues such as corruption, squalor, plague, etc.
You learn about Roman history and troops REALLY fast and what they're good for.
You realize real quick how placing swordsmen in front of cavalry makes for a really bad ending. 
Light cavalry suck...
Hiring mercenaries has its pros and cons
Slow, patient micromanaging can result in a solid economic empire and allow you to crush anyone in your path
You want to play while watching simultaneously Gladiator for some reason..
Moddable
You can spent easily 100hrs and not be done with the game
You get easily engrossed in crushing the AI and then get a warm fuzzy feeling realizing that there are OTHER TOTAL WAR GAMES WAITING TO BE PLAYED!!!

CONS:
I'm experiencing stupid lag on the campaign map while I zoom across the map despite having a beast machine (980 GTX, 5820 i7, 16 gigs of RAM)
The game isn't really optimized apparently for multi-core CPUs
You will eventually forget to go outside, much less leave the room

If you have an experienced assassin, he migh have this descriptor to accompany his experience level; 'the man is as cunning as a sackful of hungry weasels'

4/5

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of the older Total War games, this classic is still fun to play. An enjoyable blend of RTS and turn-based strategy. You start out as one of three Roman families, and proceed to conquer the known world. The world map is turn-based. On your turn you can march your armies, train more soldiers, hire mercenaries, and send out your agents to do your bidding. You can have your diplomats trade and ally with other nations, send spies to find their weaknesses, or send assassins to remove their generals and kings (or do all three!). When your army encounters an enemy army or beseiges a city, you can fight in real-time. Soldiers move in squadrons across the battlefield, flanking and being flanked in turn, breaking when morale is low, or staying to fight when the general rallies them. As you defeat nations, they are unlocked for you to play. Parthia, Britannia, and Carthage are three of them. 

There are several issues with the game. Diplomacy can be rather frustrating, with enemies refusing to make peace, or demanding you become a protectorate when you are crushing them into the dust. Anachronisms abound (the entire Egyptian roster, for example). Graphics are dated, though the map view is still pretty.

 Overall, though, the game is fun, and longevity is added through mods. Some like Europa Barbarorum overhaul all the races, removing anachronisms; others like Lord of the Rings change the game from the Mediterranean to Middle-earth. In the end, if you have not played it, or you enjoy history and can't get Rome II Total War to run on your computer, this is a good classic to have.

title: Rome Total War
review:
When Rome: Total War first came out, I remember ordering it off Amazon and being so disappointed when it didn't turn up in it's little box on the scheduled date. Having played both Shogun and Medieval Total War, the originals, I was chomping at the bit to see what this next generation of strategy was going to be like.  This time you wouldn't move armies like a chess piece. This time they'd move like proper people across a living map. Betterx than that... the armies would actually seem to have three dimensions and not the old paper cut-out effect of the previous games. 

Over the next year and long before Steam existed, I probably clocked in some disgusting triple digit number of hours in gameplay. It was beautiful to look at, ground-breaking in every way and completely sucked in my life. Everything that I wanted from a classical strategy game was right there. And it still is.

Some time later Medieval 2 came out, which once again I diligently spent too much of my time playing. Now we have Rome 2 and Attila. Are the later games (with patches) better? In my opinion: strategy map yes, battles no. It all really boils down to the person and their attitude towards graphics. 

The other day I downloaded Rome 1 due to a nostalgic hangover, and have spent even more of my time ruining the afternoon of various Gaulish villages. I would never say 'don't download Rome 2' because it's also great fun, but Rome 1 is solid entertainment throughout.  

If you haven't experienced Rome 1 and are a fan of the TW series, or even a newcomer looking for a strategy game... I strongly suggest you give it a chance. 

Watch out for Elephants.

title: Rome Total War
review: The pure nostalgia i feel every time i play this game, (and dont let the 13 hrs fool you, i have played this game on disk since 2007) is just so awesome. The best of the series definatly. Best UI, best soundtrack, best features, and this is one of the main factors, best SOUNDTRACK!! The song "Forever" that plays in the credits is enough to get you off which wouldnt be weird if the song wasnt so SAD. Just awesome. 100%

title: Rome Total War
review:
*WARNING : LONG (But detailed) REVIEW

Where to start with Rome Total War? This game is like Sid Meier’s Civilization but more focused on , as the title would suggest , Total War. So, enough beating around the bush.

Pros

This game is absolute genius. Its historically accurate , apart from the part when you , the player , take 100 percent of the area near Rome. The game notifies you when something like a flood or the Pompeii eruption occurs around the same time (I have no clue if Pompeii makes an appearance in the game. I've never gotten far enough). Another great part are the wars. There are , I believe , 3 types of fighting : Army to Army , Army to Town or City , and Fleet to Fleet. Army to Army is a standard type of fighting. Two armies on opposite sides of a field where there will be a fight to the death. This is challenging for me due to all the open space but to others it may be easier. Army to Town or City is where an army is trying to take a town or city by either maintaining a successful siege , starving the enemies inside, or forcefully invading by making Siege Towers , Ladders , Rams , and / or other breaching equipment. Either way , If successful , the army and their faction will then take and rule the captured city. Technically this is a con but , Fleet to Fleet is just borderline impossible , at least for me. In this type of battle, two fleets fight each other on the unrelenting sea. This can be especially dangerous if your ship attacked is a transport ship carrying YOUR ABSOLUTE BEST TROOPS. If this transport ship loses the battle , every man aboard will die. However , there is a fantastic feeling when you successfully take down an army , general , town , or even 1 of 20 factions. 

Cons

This game is anything but perfect. For starters , the battle screen. Before each battle , a screen pops up describing the soon starting skirmish along with 3 buttons : Flee and Retreat , Auto Resolve Battle , or Go to Battle Screen and fight the enemy yourself. Tip : Pick Auto Resolve. Fleeing is for Benito Mussolini and good luck trying to figure out the Battle Screen controls. The camera is awful. If you want to move the camera right there is a chance that you could end up looking at the ground. Along with that , you cant simply tell your archers to fire on an enemy. There's this whole process of moving them into position and it's just not worth it. Using a faulty controller to play Mortal Kombat while making a space station in Kerbal Space Program with your toes is easier than taking on an army. Its hard to explain but don't fight in the battles. Another con is the fact that the game goes through almost phases. One minute you have more generals than any other faction with more gold than Scrooge McDuck and another you are losing towns to rebels because of dying Governors without enough cash to fight back , let alone buy half a particle of dirt. This second phase is the main reason I can't get a single faction. The game gives you about 255 years to conquer all factions but even Alexander the Great couldn't win.

Summary

Challenge - 8/10
Replayability - 8/10
Battles - 6/10
Price - Rome Total War - Worth It
           Rome Total War Collection - Yes if Previous Fan
           Rome Total War Master Collection - Nope
           Rome Total War Grand Master Collection - Not even if you are Bill Gates

Verdict - Buy

title: Rome Total War
review:
I bought this then-cutting-edge game back when it was released in 2004. I'd seen it advertised some months before that on a TV series that used its engine wherein two teams competed against each other to win an historical battle. That whetted my appetite enormously. When I bought it, I not only spent countless hours playing but also played its add-ons (Barbarian Invasion and Alexander).
To me Rome: Total War was the best of the Total War series - a balance between the old 2D strategy of Medieval: Total War and the increasingly eye-candy iterations that came thereafter (though I think Medieval 2: Total War was also very good).
Add to this the fact that Rome has more mods than any other in that series (and with more diversity of setting/theme) and you have a game that is highly replayable. I still dip into it after 11 years of owning it! Rome forums still remain populated after all this time, and mods are still being developed for it. That speaks volumes.
I've had the pleasure of being a RTW modder myself which has only added to the great joy this game has brought. Give it a go. You won't regret it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
5 Hours in:
After playing this game for a few hours, I really enjoy it. As someone who really enjoyed Sid Meier's Civilization V, the campaign is really enjoyable. The combat system with the open landscapes works beutifully and feels like a real battle. Definately get this game if you liked Civ V or enjoy a good strategy game.

15 Hours in:
Just beat 7 Armies of Gauls with my one army of Selucid warriors. [proof http://imgur.com/aznIG1d] I fucking love this game.

30 Hours in:
The campagin is even more fun now that I've put a few hours into it. The different factions with different units make things much more interesting and the Senate's missions really help drive objectives. The campaign really flows and feels like a living civilization. I found myself so deeply involved with this game that 2 hours passed within what felt like 20 minutes.

title: Rome Total War
review:
RTW has an epic feel.

As of today, this game is nearly eleven years old.  So, the battle graphics are not as crisp as newer titles, the historicity of some units is sketchy (or just made up), and it seems that multiplayer is not smooth in Steam.  Fortunately, none of these mean a thing to me.  The heart of the game is in the grand strategy and the personal narrative.

With over a hundred regions in which to play, the strategic game is where RTW shines. You need to plan where you will expand and where you will defend... and then be ready to adapt when the AI does not do what you expect. You may be the pawn of the Senate and serve at their beck and call.  You might try to expand against the weak.  You can follow the trade routes to gain riches through conquest.  You will find yourself occupying regions merely to stymie your enemies (and your allies). Or you might work your way towards all seven Wonders to reap their benefits.

The twenty factions all fall into one of the major religio/cultural groupings. Some conquered peoples will not like your religion, but a few might. Some conquered peoples will happily accept you as overlord because you share the same cultural values... and the Spanish clans just don't like anyone. Some factions have great infantry, some have cavalry, and some do many things well.  Yet, you can usually find mercenaries (disgruntled locals, rival tribes, or thugs) who might fill the holes in your army.

Yes, most negative reviews harp on about the lag in multiplayer and the poor graphics in battles.  If you need gratuitous violence or managing pixels in a free for all, then watch Mad Max: Fury Road or play League of Legends. If you want to make decisions that will impact your dominion fifty turns down the road, then this game can give it to you.  What kind of temples will you build in each region... or should you let the people keep their native religion?  Will a town become a recruiting station or a cash cow?  When you conquer a region, you'll have to decide to either just incorporate it into your lands as is, relocating half the people by enslaving them, or just slaughtering most of the inhabitants and stealing their goods.... and you'll find yourself using each throughout the campaign, because one size does not fit all.

And guess what?  I don't fight the battles.  If I did, I'd never finish a campaign.  I hit the auto calculation button every time.  Why?  Well... there are a number of positions which you will fulfill in a game.  Benevolent multi-generational spirit guiding your family, governor of a province, Commander in Chief, general of an army, and captain of a unit. Playing all of these breaks the narrative for me... I play the macro game, i.e. the big picture.  I plot and scheme, I build cities, and recruit armies.  Then I send them out into the field.  How they do is up to them.  If they win... great! I must be a genius.  If they lose... nuts. Back to the drawing board.

Two friends of mine, let's call them Doc and Bro, played RTW like this... Doc played the campaign map, i.e. he decided what units were built and where the battles were fought, but Bro fought all the battles.  Doc was the CinC and Bro was the General.  They played two campaigns in three years, but they remember both as epic stories of their teamwork.

In addition to the war... campaign strategy, building armies, transportation of armies, theatres of conflict, fog of war, etc... you'll have to deal with natural disasters, (In one game, a young woman of my family married a promising young fellow, but he died a year later in an earthquake.), piracy, rebellions, brigands, bribery attempts upon your armies, old age, death in battle, adoptions, plagues (stupid unwashed barbarians), and assassination. (In one game, the youngest son of my German leader was sent to subdue Gaul and Hispania. This gave him a command of 10.  I marched him and his elite German veterans across the Alps to conquer Rome... but the Romans assassinated him.  With my hordes leaderless, the Romans proceeded to sieze Gaul and invade Germania.) All of these additional factors help create a unique narrative for each game.

Oh, and when you play as a Roman faction, you'll need to keep an eye upon the Senate... how they view you, how the plebs (the masses) view you, Senatorial missions, and the official Senatorial stance with every other faction. For instance, you may have a great trade agreement with the Egyptians and a low standing with the Senate, but the Sentate demands that you attack Egypt... attacking Egypt will hurt your income considerably, but offending the Senate may cause them to label you as a rebel... what will you do?

Certain events always happen... Aetna erupts and the plague breaks out in Macedonia, but certain other events happen only when certain triggers occur (the Marian reforms), while others, such as floods, are random.  But the big event for Roman players is the Civil War.  At some point the plebs will want you to deal with the Senate and/or at some point the Senate will either have enough of you or become paranoid of your growing power that they'll demand the head of your family to commit suicide.  If you agree, they'll do it every turn until your family ceases to exist.  If you're not ready for war, then you can comply with the Senate for a few years (and prune your family tree of bad apples in the process), but at some point you'll have to stand up to the Senate... at which point you go to war with all other Romans.  Talk about raising your anxiety.... sheesh!

All of your characters really flesh out the narrative... the story of your family.  Spies, diplomats, assassins, admirals, generals, and governors all have character traits that make them who they are.  Some will be drunkards, perverts, and ne'er do wells, while some will be loyal, moral, and cunning.  They'll also tend to generate a following of hangers on, freeloaders, men of honor, mistresses, etc...  For instance, a son might come of age in your family with a command of 3... a natural born general... but on his way to the frontier to defeat the Dacians, his inner circle grows to include a Drunken Uncle and an Actor and they decrease his command ability by 3... Ouch!  He's now a zero...

In the first two Total War games, Shogun and Medieval, you had family members, but not nearly as many as Rome.  So to help you manage them (and for the sheer fun of telling a story), RTW includes a family tree.

The game's not perfect.  The legendary/semi-mythological units can be frustrating and the Egyptians were certainly not using chariots in the second century BC. Naval combat results can make you scratch your head.  Negative income numbers on the campaign map are definitely misleading. There is always the point at which you know you've won even though you may only be forty to seventy percent of the way to the finish... but that's true of a lot of games.

There may be other games out there that have made improvements to the grand strategy game, but I've always found this one to be fun to return to.

title: Rome Total War
review:
The game is awesome, even with graphics which are rather old. However, like many users, after a while the game started having issues for me, like random and not so random crashes. If you read up on the many solutions people proposed on many places on the web, some may or may not work for you. I tried and tried, until I finally figured out that IN MY CASE there was a conflict between the game and the sound HARDWARE --- I switched in the audio options of the game to SOFTWARE emulation and that stopped the crashes. 

I will recommend it, but be aware that because the game is older than most recent computer hardware, it may or may not work properly for every user. It is difficult to diagnose a priori for everyone what the issue may be, if there ever is one for you, but with that caveat I will say I fully recommend it, but just be aware of the technical issues it has had for many users for quite a few years already, and diagnozing it may take a while for you if you ever have a problem --- MOST users seem to not have NONE, though. 

(If a whiz at programming were to rewrite some of the software it would certainly take care of any problems, but since the game is old, Sega doesn't seem to be interested in doing so --- so it's up to the user community to come up with a solution)

title: Rome Total War
review:
My first Total War game. I purchased it a couple of years ago after watching gameplay on YouTube, I first saw how amazing  and fun it looked to control these huge armies and to be able command them to charge into their bloody deaths while women were throwing severed heads at the enemy. After, I learnt about the campaign mode, it is simple: build an empire and take over the world (pretty much all of europe and a bit of the middle east). This simple campaign type/mode is the best part about the game and all Total War games in my opinion. After playing the game it was just, or even more epic from the footage I witnessed on YouTube and was everything I expected.

I'm not hugely a strategy game fan boy, but that hasn't stopped me from placing Rome Total War in my top 5 games of all time (I have played a lot of games haha)! Definitely recommened.


Well, I hoped you found my first ever review helpful haha, I wrote it as I am rather bored :)

title: Rome Total War
review:
Now superceded but a great game in it's own right - I immensely enjoyed playing the long  campaigns of all 3 familys in this game.    Each one plays a litttle differently to maintain your interest - and because of their location will have different strengths and weakness's.  Should you buy it? - Yes if you like action oriented strategy and tactics and or historical warfare.

I like it enough to have bought it in boxes and from 2 different companies digitally as well. And it runs fine on most modern computer systems so you shouldn't need to break the bank on new hardware either.

Of late (July 2015)  I have noticed a move back to this game from Rome II - with some saying they have dumbed the AI and gameplay down in the new one in favour of better graphics.  

Ive put in 622 hours on it on steam.

title: Rome Total War
review:
If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:
1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie 

Directions:
1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War

The game that launch the Total War series towards heights that it could've never dreamed of. This game is a turn-based strategy game where you take command the various factions during the Roman Era as you command, build, govern and attack Rome's enemies.

The battle system unlike the system you will see in the modern day versions of the game is really simplistic. Sort of like an almost modern update of Imperial Glory. Now of course, the usual complaint would be "OMG the game is too hard" or "OMG the online players are wrecking me" Luckily the game has an in-depth tutorial plus you have all the time in the world as this game offers various combat both historical and custom made as you polish your skills in battle. And also being a leader of Rome.

The advisor system is really helpful as they give advice towards the player. DO NOT turn it off if your new. Keep that option for advisor input set to "High". Plus the User Interface for manging your territory and what not is simplistic as well.

Now bewarn, save often. Some of the daily tasks that the senate assigns you don't really give you concrete directions. For some of them it's a simple click of the "zoom in towards target location" while others it's "Find this city" and your just like "Um okay...WHERE?!" some of these tasks are important as it may further your position in the Roman government.

If you still want a simplistic Total War game this is for you.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Don't let my game time put you off, I assure you I have owned the disk version from very early on. I only bought the steam version to play online as I couldn't do it otherwise.

This Game. By far, in my opinion, the best strategy game out there. TODAY. 
The economic system in campaign is simple enough so you can stay on top of it all but complicated enough so you face challenges to keep your armed forces financially. After play ROME 2 recently I have to say that I believe the economic system in this is better. 

Actually, this game does stand up to its successor (ROME 2). The AI for one don't spam one unit constantly, they provide challenges to you as well as actually being fun to play against. The battles are great and a regular computer will be able to handle it with ease. Each faction has a wide and fairly balanced selection of Units.

This game is simply a masterclass. Way before its time, (if you excuse the graphics at times, althought they are not wholly poor). If you do not own this game, you are a fool. It is a must for all strategy game players.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Nothing beats a classic, and Rome: Total War is a classic.  I'm sure there were games that predated it (the original Medieval Total War, right?), but Rome is probably a solid place to start.

For the time it came out and its place so early in the franchise, you can't fault it much.  It has all the staples that would appear in the other installations in the franchise, and the balance of story, graphics, and controls make it a fun experience that isn't terribly hard to learn.

Anyone who is a fan of tactical games, strategy games, historical games, or even just enjoys playing God for a tiny nation of soldiers should enjoy this game.

title: Rome Total War
review: For 5-10$ this game is fantastic. The combat system is great with a variety of infantry, calvary, and ranged units. There's a number of factions to choose from which provides good replayability. A solid playthrough is quite the committment so it's easy to sink hours into this game. City management is decent with factors including unrest, economy, and population. However, from cities are good while others are bad. There's no fixing certain cities and they're doomed to be financially awful so it can be frustrating. The diplomacy is the least exciting and extensive part of the game. The selling point of the game is absolutely the combat. Crush the rivaling factions alone with fun and intense battles. The diplomacy allows no true alliances and depending on what faction you play you can be surrounded by enemies and have to fight a steep uphill battle. All the factions are fun but some have a pretty solid advantage. The barbarian factions are more limited on technological buildings and  troops such as onagers, scorpions, and even stone walls. It's slightly made up for by the fact that the troops they do get can be outright more interesting. Like headhurlers who throw severed heads at enemies to lower moral or axe wielding berserkers who fight to the bitter end in a bloodthirsty rage. Once again you can see the emphasize on the combat. Despite the shortcomings in diplomacy the game is super fun and there's a large mod selection too. So go build your big badass army and conquer. Veni, Vedi, Veci motherfuckers.

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of my favorite Total War games. I used to play this all of the time, back when it was on CD. It provides a ton situations to deal with: politics, diplomacy, family, war, financing, and strategy. Your empire's development is slow to start, but soon after you empire expands diplomacy and senate appeasing is important. Then you have to worry about your new neighbors to the north who also want your land. However, the Senate wants another territory on the opposite side of the empire to be taken. So you have to balance your troops, as you can only afford so much. While that is going on your citizens are upset at the tax rate and need to be subdued.
This game is complex and a great starting game for the Total War series. As it has many ways to play and I still to this day can be entertained, even with the graphics not being as shiny as Rome: Total War 2.

title: Rome Total War
review: This game started my passion for Total War games, and remains my favorite.  My logged hours does no justice to the actual time I've spent on this game.
