title: Rome Total War
review:
This game WAS my childhood.  It was easily the best game of 2004.  It is better than its sequel, rome II, in a variety of ways, including:
- better soundtrack
- no limits on what factions you can play
- armies outside of cities do not need a general to function (but have certain penalties when lacking)
- easier army movement, especially in disengaging
The game's strategy is simple enough to learn in an hour, and complicated enough to spend months mastering multiplayer play.  I believe that it is the best game that the Creative Assembly has ever released.

title: Rome Total War
review: One of my personal favorites games. I love how it has a turn-based board-style overworld, and then some cool real-time strategy simulation battles of epic scale. It's just a really fun game and my personal favorite RTS game. Fun as a fusion of both turn based and real time in an interesting combination.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is my favourite Total War game.
-The gameplay has potential to be challenging on the higher difficulties (note that the higher difficulties just give the AIs bonuses, but it does make the game harder)
-It's fun to beat the AI in a battle you shouldn't have been able to win (the AI's tactics are usually poor)
-The graphics run well (much faster than later releases)
-You can easily mod the game (or even modify the data files to make certain unit types invincible)
-When playing Roman factions, the generals give context sensitive speeches which reflect their character and past victories/defeats

title: Rome Total War
review:
One of the greatest games of all times- who doesn't want to conquer the world using Pigs you can set on fire? This game, is without a doubt, one of the greatest things total war invented, the variety of nations and paths you can take leaves you almost unable to stop. Try to conquer the known world, killing the gauls, the britons, the spaniards... etc, but we can't forget the parthians and their amazing pyjama warriors ;p Once you tire the singleplayer (normally after you have dominated the world at least a dozen times) you can try your hand at defeating other players on the multiplayer. I spent so many hours of my life dragging my friends with their laptops to my house to play all v all on this game... It was essentually who was the most devious or subtle one of us who won, always a challenge to be more cunning than the next. I found the best way to success was to use troops that blended into the map... so though they could be seen, they were'nt always acknowledged by my opponents... 
Though I may not have many hours in this game on steam, it was through the disk that I played a good thousand of hours on...

title: Rome Total War
review:
This was my childhood. This is why I gat into gaming. I have thousands and thousands of hours on my old disc - the old kind of discs that came with a map of the game's world, building chains and a good manual without it being the "collector's edition. I played the game before a knew English and was therefore unable to understand the mecanics of the Grand Campaing; I simply played custom battle for years until I was old enough to start my first conquests. 

The game is not a gem, it's a marble - for that is the single foundation of Roman Empires you will create in this game! It is filled with deep tactics, tons of features (no streamlining here), and loads of historic knowlegde in the unit and building cards. Unlock all faction by destroying them in the campaings, create tons of strategies for your different armies, but most of all - install mods from the third most dedicated modding community in gaming (try Barbarorum or Surrectum).

Buy it, play it, and remember: The man who rules Rome, rules the world; and one day YOU WILL BE EMPEROR!!!

title: Rome Total War
review:
A classic. One of the best pc games of all time.

If you've ever dreamed of being an ancient general like Caesar or Hannibal, or conquering the ancient world as the romans did, this is the game for you !

The game's main campaign is set during the rule of the late Roman Republic and early Roman Empire with the player assuming control of one of three leading Roman families. Other factions are playable once they have been unlocked. Gameplay consists of real-time tactical battles framed within a turn-based strategic campaign.  On the large strategic scale, players spend each turn managing diplomacy, developing infrastructure, moving armies, and managing the population's growth and public order. On the smaller scale, real-time battles against enemy armies take place with the player commanding forces that can contain thousands of individual soldiers.

The game is also featured in tv series about ancient battles - Decisive Battles and Time Commanders

Some other roman themed games : Caesar 3, Qvadriga, Grand Ages: Rome,  Europa Universalis: Rome..

title: Rome Total War
review:
Excellent game.  I can't wait to delve into the other Total War games.  I'm having lots of fun playing as different factions.  Carthage is especially fun to play.  You may want to look into the mod that allows you to play any nation; I enjoy playing as the Numidians. 

No balance issues other than the roman factions and Egypt being a bit overpowered, but if you are a true strategy gamer, you'll figure a way around that.  I simply ally with Egypt for example when playing Carthage, and having a lone Numidian territory in Libya between our two nations ensures Eqypt never goes hostile.  Taking out the Scippii romans early means no real competition in the western Mediterranean, and so on.  Strategy.  It's what this game is about.

title: Rome Total War
review:
The best Total War in my opinion and the only one I've finished so far. It is easy to see why this is considered the most influencial of all Total War games published. The battles are fantastic to play, the game is challenging to play, if you play certain factions, and fun to see a faction that was wiped out by the Roman imperilaists in our history, to suddenly lick Carthaginian sandal in your game. Another good feature in this game is how each faction has their own unique apperances and even how they fight and what units they can have, even if they are a bit copy and paste. 

If there are any flaws in this game, it is these; stupid stacked armies (several generals with up to 30 or more units), overpowered factions and historical inaccuracy.  The stupid stacked armies are a constant menace, especially  if you invade Rome, so be ready for that. Another one is overpowerded factions. The one in particullar is Egypt. If you play as the Seleucid Empire against them, good fucking luck! Historical inaccuracy is another flaw, but only minor compared to the latter two.

Overall, the game is fantastic and a good place to start if you're new to Total War and want to see how the Total War franchise became more famous!

+Wide range of units with different specs, spread over 10 good playable factions
+ELEPHANTS MOWING OVER PEOPLE

title: Rome Total War
review:
I'm gonna say exactly what others said about this game - forget R2; just buy this game.
The vanilla game provides an excellent strategy experience in battles - Units aren't breaking formations often during combat, unit skins and combat animations look neat and special unit abilities such as the testudo or phalanx actually count for something in this game; although the AI may sometimes not always use the I part correctly, the combat is still enjoyable. 
The campaign is also very good - the map is sunny and very neatly designed, which makes the campaign even better. 
While the game is somewhat historically accurate, there is one thing in this game that makes it a little bit of a letdown - the roman factions are very, very overpowered; they have strong units as the base of their army, plsu after the marian reforms they get legionaries which are probably the strongest units in the game. 
That's where the mods come in. There is a very large variety of mods to choose from for this game, and they make the experience even better. 
All in all - this game is very, very good, and in my opinion it even rivals Medieval II as the best Total War game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Nothing like the book by Caeser Wilhelm but that's not necessarily a bad thing. The tale differed in such a way that people who already read the book were still captivated by the genius story and excellent voice acting this game brings to the table. I will never forget these brilliantly quotable lines such as, "Imperator!" and "Yes Imperator?".
The gameplay however, is where this game lets itself down. The mechanics and graphics are a clear rip off of Don't Starve. In fact, you could be mistaken for thinking this is just a cheap Don't Starve DLC at some points in the game. This is an unavoidable stain upon the franchise that cannot be removed nomatter how much Ariel or Vanish you use.
In conclusion: I believe Rome: Total Waves to be the greatest and latest surfing simulator and gets the BAFTA for best elephant graphics 1887. Thankyou.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War is a very good game for anyone who likes grand strategy. As a fan of History myself, this game is even more epic to control the Roman Empire and crush Carthage or be overrun by barbarians. It is very accurate to the period, and offers plenty of hours of good fun. Many times I found myself losing track of time in the middle of a campaign. This game also has plenty of support for mods, ranging from Middle Earth to more realism. 

However, the game does have its' flaws. It's very old, and will be a pain from time to time. Also the controls can be a bit troublesome, such as selecting units and arranging them, to trying to execute complex maneuvers. The auto battle function is completely broken, and because of that, so is the naval combat. 

I find that at times managing a giant Roman empire can be a pain, and so the function to be able to play as the other civilizations was a welcome suprise. Once you conquer one, you can play as them in another campaign, and it is fun to try and assualt Roman cities as the barbarians. 

The modding community is so healthy, if you purchase the game and find that you don't enjoy it, there is a good chance that there will be a mod that makes it all better for you. 
Hopefully this review helped you make a desicision, but at such a cheap price, you should check it out if it interests you at all!

As you progress in the game the cursor will start jumping uncontrollably and in most of the larger battles you will eventually think twice about changing the speed setting, because you may be unable to change it back.

TL;DR Good game that performs poorly

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is rome total war, but it doesn't feel like it at all.

Battles arent as smooth as I remember with the regular boxed edition. Unit pathfinding is non-exsistant at times, however I'm not so sure if that is down to me using the "Huge" unit size setting. Siege battles are almost unplayable as units never follow my instructions. For example, telling my auxilia to enter a city gates and form a line while the rest of my army enters, they never just run straight in. They have to run to a certain point(all of them one by one) turn around, and walk into the city gates and not as one unit either, more like dribs and drabs.

Plus, when your unit of 161 roman cavalry with three bronze chevrons, shield and sword have a hard time taking down a single unit of slingers....there is something wrong there, the same also goes for most other infantry.

Hastati, two silver shevrons, bronze shield and sword should form a very ridged centre, take casualties like nobodys buisness.

The game is there, diplomacy is the same, campagin tactics are the same, some battles are the same. If this is your first time playing RTW, this version won't dissapoint you. If you have played this version before, don't get the steam version. Dig out an old boxed copy and save the hassle of banging your head against a wall when you notice half your unit decides it knows a shortcut to the part of the city you told it to go to.

title: Rome Total War
review:
A bit dated now, but it still has the best feel of all the total war games due mainly to the music and sound. 

The epic feel of defending against a siege attack, rushing your tired men to and from weak points, again the music brings real tension in the battles, elation in victory and almost tears when your once certain victory is snatched from you in the last minutes. 

Its one of those games that will give you great memories. You will actually feel fear when you see a full stack of gaullish celts appear from a mountain pass on the main map, not knowing what there intentions are and hoping they dont come your way. 

This game also enables you to play the excellent Europa Barborum mod for the history pedants.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Basically Rome: Total War was my first game to the Total War series. Recommended by my schoolmate and I'm really grateful that he introduced it to me. I'm proud to say that I'm still playing this game even though it's more than 10 years old. Owning later Total War games like Rome II and Shogun 2 couldn't convince me enough to stop playing this valuable "veteran". As I mentioned, this game is more than 10 years old. So do not expect much on the graphics.

In the campaign, you'll start as Rome divided into 3 different families. You'll unlock other playable factions as you progress. Without being said, Rome is by far the strongest that campaign will look easy. Want more challenges? Try the barbarian tribes (Gaul, Britannia or Germanic). Other non-playable factions like Macedon, Pontus, Thrace, Armenia should be made playable by default to add more fun to the campaign mode. But that can be resolved by modding. For sharing, my 3 most favoured factions for the campaign mode are (1) Rome, (2) Seleucid Empire, (3) Carthage.

Diplomacy is rather 'useless' in the later part of the campaign. AI (especially those factions you're at war with) will reject any diplomatic proposal. But hey, this game is all about using your sword and thrust it into the face of the enemy! Let the sword or arrows do the talking instead. It's all about "I came, I saw, I conquered".

If you don't have a background to Total War series, try this out. It's a perfect start. Oh, and I really love those cinematic starts of the campaign as well as those historical battles.

10/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
I recently repurchased the game on steam. This would be the third time i have bought the game. twice on disc (the early version and the later version) and i have to say it is by far the BEST GAME I HAVE EVER PLAYED. If you are thinking should I? DONT. Just buy it now. If you liek RTS but Civilazation just isnt quite action enough for you than this is the ticket. Get this game and love yourself. 

I have somewhere in the 2,000 hour range in this game. I have played it since it came out and i never had a gripe about anything in the game. I never once felt bored. Never once felt the AI was garbage on the campaign map or in a battle either, which worries me since people have those gripes with the latest installments of the series and it leaves me wondering if they tried ot reinvent the wheel and failed or if i have poor standards :/. The Barbarian Invasion "dlc" is a complete game in its self. I dont even want to call it DLC. Barbarian Invasion is its own installment in my mind. Not to mention all the mods avaiable for this title. I reccomend the LOTR mod for this (although it might be for TWM2 and im completely mistaken). BUt anyways folks, set your unit size to huge and go to work on the barbarians of the north, or set out as the remnants of Alexander the Great to reconcour his lost Empire.

title: Rome Total War
review: This is by far my absolute favorite historically based grand strategy/RTS game ever made. Rome: Total War is an absolute must have for fans of games like Civilization and Command & Conquer. Rome: Total War is one of the rare games that does what it is meant to do, perfectly. It has no problem letting you feel the triumph of Caesar himself as he conquered Gaul, or the rage of Hannibal as he sacked Rome to avenge his father. For any fan of turn-based games or real time strategies, Rome: Total War is a must have for any serious PC gamer.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Developer: The Creative Assembly   Publisher: Activision   Release Date: 22.09.200

Played On: (Various but most recently)
Nvidia GTX 760
AMD FX 6300 3.5Ghz
8GB RAM

(Upto several hundred hours to complete depending on faction, difficulty level and campaign length chosen).

Where to start with Rome Total War? First released back in September 2004 the game recently reached it's tenth anniversary. I've played it on and off since release and the recent anniversary prompted me to go back and play through it again. It's a game that mostly stands up to the test of time for me and well worth playing today. I didn't play the Barbarian Invasion expansion included in the Steam edition as it's quite a distinct entity that should be reviewed in it's own right.

Like all games in the Total War series there are two elements; the campaign map where you manage your empire, build cities, recruit units, move armies etc and the battle map, where you fight battles in real time. This gives the game some great depth and whilst you can auto-resolve battles this can be a bit hit and miss and you'll want to fight them yourself to get the best results. The Imperial Campaign is the main game mode where you can choose from a number of different factions and play through either a short or long campaign with prescribed victory conditions and different difficulty settings. There is a decent tutorial to ease you into things and plenty of advice is available throughout both with the optionn to turn it off for veterans.

The Imperial Campaign is backed up by being able to fight custom battles where you choose the map, faction etc and Historical Battles which recreate a number of famous battles of the era such as Hannibal's invasion of Italy and the Battle of the Teutoberg Forest. You can also play online against other players but this wasn't something I did.

The main campaign has a good deal of depth and each of the factions has different styles, units, cities and starting points which offer a wide variety of challenge. Playing as the Romans is the initial starting point and they are divided into three factions which compete against other and have some additional mechanics to account for including the Senate of Rome, the Marius Reforms and some other suprises which I won't spoil. Rome also generally has the strongest units and buildings which can make things somewhat straightforward for an experienced player. However a lot of the late game units of other factions more than match them and playing the campaign as Eygpt, Carthage, the Britons or others is very enjoyable.

The mechanics of the campaign map are very broad and offer a wide variety of tactical options to pursue; bribery, assassination and spreading plagues amongst them. I played through on the very hard settings which I'd reccomend any veteran Total War player to do and the campaign offered a good challenge with interesting scenarios and incidents along the way. Whilst my progress was steady I wasn't able to steamroll the AI into the ground within a few turns. I did play as Eygpt who are one of the easier non Roman factions to play but still a challenge later in the game.

The battle map is probably the slightly weaker side of the game and whilst some battles, particularly sieges, can be a bit difficult or frustrating, most are straightforward affairs if you have assembled a balanced army and have a relatively comprehensive grasp of the tactics to use. However the various factions armies all have different strengths or weaknesses and there isn't the rock, paper, scissors situation you see in some games. The Roman armies have the strongest armies as a general rule of thumb but other factions e.g. Eygpt, Germania have some very good units too and what works with one may not work at all with another.

I've not mentioned performance or graphics at all as the game is ten years old and there generally shouldn't be any issues nor will it look fantastic.

I'd also take a moment to mention the additional content available online from Europa Barborum and a couple of other sites. These add a huge amount to the game and are well worth a look if you want to take things further after playing the main game.

Overall I'd definetely reccomend playing this if your a fan of the Total War series and I also feel its a good starting point for the series as whole. Those interested in the era itself will certainly find it enjoyable.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is the first Total War I picked up and it instantly got me hooked on the series. Now, I can't really compare this to other games of its time because I started playing TW about 3 years ago, but I will say this: This is still one of the best TW games in the series. They just nailed so many things correctly, and the fact that after so many years it is still so fun to go back and pick up where I left off, is a huge plus. 
Graphically it can't compare to the new ones, but it did so many other things so well, it doesn't even matter. Diplomacy with the old diplomat agent system is a pain when compared to the newer TW; Combat is still so satisfying (when u rain a thousand flaming arrows on a horde of barbarians); The campaign map still feels expansive; The biggest plus is the games massive variety in playable factions and unique units/traits. Even by today's TW standards it is impressive.

ONE HUGE CON FOR THE STEAM VERSION:
There is a problem where in the campaign map you will have massive amounts of lag, but this can be fixed (ranging from easy to infuriatingly hard solutions). I think this is due to optimization bugs or something for the most part.

Still recommend 9.5/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
As the user-defined tags suggest this is a historical strategy game.  The overworld campaign is a turn-based grand strategy- sort of a simplified Civilization.  The battles are mostly real time, with a toggle for 2x or 3x, so I guess it could be argued there is a 4x element to the battle.

The campaign takes a long time to finish, but it is good training if you want to play multiplayer.  There are some troops that don't seem to be very good relative to their costs-  I'm thinking the Arcanii (why only 16????????!!!!!!!!!!), but for the most part the game seems pretty balanced.

The biggest downside for me was the fact that this game crashes every 4th or 5th battle, and I hear I am not the only person who has this problem.  The public order system can also be wonky- I lost a settlement to a gladiator revolt, then recaptured it and two turns later there was another gladiator revolt with the exact same amount of gladiators. 

Overall, I would strongly reccomend this game if you like the idea of massive battles, tactical thinking, or time consuming strategic considerations.  I know I loved it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
It only says 57 hours but trust me, I have had a lot more on it on an old CD version I lost. If you want to try Total War, or you just have a crappy computer, this is a good game for you. The battles are still impressive after all these years and seiges are amazing despite the dated graphics. Not only that, but this game is dirt cheap, and it is easily worth a 30 dollar price tag comparing it to some other titles these days. It does havew flaws in not being 100% accurate, but that is a minimal part of this otherwise great game. 

All in All it's a great buy, a must have for a Total War Fan and an excellent way for newbies to dip their feet in before getting to the newer (and occasionally buggy) Rome 2. Would also reccomend buying the Barbarian Invasion espansion, which is almost like a new game in some aspects.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game...
Despite its historical inaccuracies (more than likely set so to have a more balanced game), its a fun game. Its a game about taking the helm of the culture of your choice, then leading it to conquer all others (or a specific faction in some short campaigns). What more can I say about a "Total War" game?

Despite its HUGE LACK of any decent diplomacy, classical Rome never saw fit to just let its rivals get away with anything. It's a game that wants you to take lands, demolish the barbaric religions, and build your own. 

What more can I say? Other than "If you dont like it, mod it." and "I killed (absurd number of) peasants with (tiny number) of (elite troops)." 

Seriously, if you don't like what is in the game, you can look up how to change it.
Armoured Elephants ARE overpowered. Chariots and War Elephants aren't.

Greek Cites shouldn't exist, Sparta should. Spain didn't exist, nor should it be unified, Why does Numidia hold Siwa? 

OBLIGITORY "OUT OF TEN" SCORE: 9/10. 

I need to find a mod that makes diplomacy better...

title: Rome Total War
review: This game hits right on the target for RTS games. It has a turn based campaign in which you create massive armies and manage settlements. Then when two armies collide (whether that be an seige or field battle) the real fun begins you can play battles with thousands of soldiers slugging it out. The different factions have huge differences in which you have to play. Romans have superb heavy infantry which can tackle most other infantry but lack cavalry. The Greeks have phalanx that buckle down enemy infantry so your cavalry can finish the job. And the barbarian have cool unique units like the druids and fanatics. This game is very polished and is better than all the other games in the series and i have played all but the first two (rome 2 is on my other account). Me and my friend love playing battles (even though he spams phants and  sacred band). I would recommend this game to anyone who plays RTS!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is a Grand Strategy game that will peak your interest in Roman Culture and the politics of the Roman Empire. I began to watch Rome Documentaries, read historical accounts and see what lead to the eventual decline and annihilation of the Empire. In the beginning of Rome: Total War you have a choice of which house to represent Rome.  Julii, Brutii,or Scipii. When your orders come in from the senate you are eager to do the biding to further this penisula into an empire. As you progress you are rewarded though the senate with influence in the political wheel. WIth family members and a vested interest in the outcomes of each town with what family member to lead it. Which is easy to determine through the very easy to learn UI. Now the Graphics are dated however its brushed aside as you gain fame and conquest through lower Europe. 
There are many reviews and great aclaim for this Total War Masterpiece. Problems did arise with my own gameplay but they are not with the game persay. You have to forget the world in which we know and put yourself in the culture and politics of the era. This alone will start to forge your understanding of what these men and women endured daily. Military  victories and winning against 3-1 odds are awesome. Learning battlefield strategy is learned quickly as there is a vast amount of information in game you can utilize to win the day. But its not all about conquering your enemies abroad but at home. In game you will start to to see beyond the game into why each house is not only doing the Senates will also to further the house they represent. 
I would also recommend all the DLC as it increases the immersion of the era and offers many more hours of gameplay. 
Also there are Historical Battles to play. And if your like me and study the battle before you play it, your immersion will be 10 fold when you may know the outcome however when it really has happened...exciting.
I recommend this title its well worth it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
My name is Alexandru,This being said, I should mention the two things I cannot stand about Rome total war, These matches usually consist of one of two types of user: users who are friends with one another or users who are so terrible at the game that they are incapable of killing anyone above low level.
I play games for XP. Working towards a higher level is always my first priority. Because of this, I am always seeking this way I garner the most XP I can in the least amount of time. I've always been one to cut, especially when it means I can reach an objective in less time than using an inefficient method. 
For the few of you who read all of this, good job. It must have been a lot of work reading all that text. I commend you for your perseverance. Don't be hesitant Rome total war is a great game but for 18+ yrs old.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Empire building strategy game where you conquer provinces and conduct battles. Lead your family/nation to greatness. You control what key structures are built in your cities and what units to produce. Units that have been in combat will gain experience and get better morale and combat effectiveness. You have family members, who are your generals and administrators. They help the general effectiveness of your armies or city efficiency and gain traits based on what happens to them throughout their lives. You can also use diplomats and assassins to deal with your enemies and allies. 

Turn based strategy for the overall city production and troop movement. When armies meet, you can have the game calculate the battle automatically or you can control all your troops in a RTS battlefield.

Of the Total War games I've played (Rome, Medieval 2), I like this one better.

title: Rome Total War
review: I have sunk over 200 hours of my life into this game, and guess what? Every last one was enjoyable. RTW is my favorite title by Creative Assembly, and my favorite real time strategy game as a direct result. The main thing most people sink hours into is the Imperial Campaign, which can last an upwards of 20 hours per campaign if drawn out. Your goal is simple, conquer 50 territories in the known world, and of course, Rome. The most focus in this mode has obviously been given to the Romans, as they have unique mechanics in the campaign, such as the ever hostile senate, the Civil War, the reforms of Gaius Marius, and so on. This isnt to say the other possible factions are any less far to play, far from it in fact. Playing as Carthage, you have access to mighty war elephants, the Greeks get their Spartans, the Germanians get Bezerkers, everyone has a unique element that mixes up gameplay in a way that forces you to adapt different strategy for each campaign. The AI for battles can either be brilliant, or mind numbingly awful, depending upon the difficulty you set it to. However if you want a real challenge, you are going to have to take your skills online. Despite being a very old title, there still is a good chunk of people playing this online. Most of them are experienced veterans, so dont be too upset if they wipe the floor with you the first couple of battles. The nostalgia runs deep in this game, and for those of you who have never played a Total War game, its probably the best game you can start with. It was GOTY worthy when it came out back then, and compared to RTW2, its a gem every collector should have in their library.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Such an amazing game. Playing this after TW:Empires and TW: Shogun 2 just reminds me that the AI has taken a huge dive in terms of difficulty. I decided to play it again after TW:E crashed for the third time that day and started as the Julii Romans. A few exciting battles in against the Gauls and I ran into a Briton army. That's when I remembered why I loved this game. They charged my Hastati with chariots and sent me into an almost full blown route until my archers set them straight. It was only then that I realized it had been ages since I'd even come close to losing a battle in any of the other TW games. 

TLDR: This is a classic, and they still have yet to out do themselves.

title: Rome Total War
review:
DOWNLOAD EUROPA BARBARORUM MOD

Vanilla RTW is a very good game for its time. It spits in the face of history in most cases, it is not well balanced in many cases (for instance, Roman calvary are better in 9/10 situations than similarly priced Roman infantry), but it's still worth playing.

NOW ITS MODS

Its mods are amazing. The Europa Barbarorum mod (google it) is absolutely phenomenal. There are also two excellent LOTR mods set in different eras. 

DOWNLOAD EUROPA BARBARORUM. It is one of the best mods I have ever played. It has a tremendous focus on historical accuracy and was painstakingly researched. It's the sort of mod that should of gotten the developers a full time development studio, it just reeks of quality. 

You will get 60+ hours into EB and then give up because, well, the enemy combat AI just can't keep up, and that apparently is an issue that is hardwired in and can not be improved significantly through moding. But it's a SWEET 60 hours with beautiful music, visuals, and a history lesson to boot.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I was the romano british, and most of europe was under my grasp. I had forged a strong alliance with the east and west roman empires, and most of the hordes had crumbled beneath my combined arms tactics. My graal knights ruled the world, and history was as it should be. Then the eastern roman empire decided I was making too much trade on londinum and landed there en masse, the same turn that the huns came out of hiding. The western roman empire, confused on what to do declared war on everything that breathed. Civilization crumbled again, and I will now have to spend another sixty hours piecing everything back together again.

The game is a great strategy game, and the campaigns are fun (The modded ones are good fun as well) but for the love of god find a campaign AI upgrade.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War, the game that launched a series. Okay, so there actually was a Medieval and Shogun: Total War before it, but Rome is the one that introduced the concepts its successors have built upon. While the graphics are a bit dated, and historical accuracy wasn't as rigorous as later titles, this game is quite fun, and can end up being a bit of a time-sink.

Two side notes: One, I first became interested in the game based on a fun History Channel series called Decisive Battles. The game engine from Rome was used to show the battles in the series. Second, while my time of use may seem low, that is a bit deceiving. First, I had played the game before finding out it was on Steam. And the other reason is I have many games that I tend to use when I cannot get on-line. And that time doesn't always sinc up.

title: Rome Total War
review:
In 2005, aside from Morrowind there couldn't have been a better game for my to pour hours of my life into. I had just finished a fairly shallow, but interesting intro Roman History course, and I was home for the summer, jobless. My campaigns and expeditions really drew me in, especially the focus on individual characters. Watching as a 16 year old noble started an insane mercenary fueled campaign and grew into a competent commander and ruler was immensely satisfying.

The systems in the game all fit together well and provide a fun, if not entirely historically accurate grand strategy game. 

10 war elephants out of ten for me.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Even 12 years after its release, Rome: Total War continues to have a surprisingly large online community, outsizing those of more modern TW games such as Empire. My brother and I still have regular matches; he's the only one who's ever beaten me, and even now we're on par.

Rome is a fantastic game. Its controls are easy to master, the campaign map and in-game menus are well-organised and easy to manage. A wide variety of factions and units mean you can fight using any strategy you like, and the higher difficulties provide a genuine challenge for even the most seasoned players. If you haven't quite got the hang of the real-time 3D battle map (which is gorgeous for its time), you can practice in a Custom Battle or automatically resolve a conflict in the campaign map. If you're only playing for a short period of time and want to make campaign progress, this acts as a good time-saver. However, losses in an auto-resolved battle tend to be higher than in one you manage yourself; as such, I would recommend using the manual battle map.

All in all, Rome provides an incredible gaming experience, and I still enjoy it more than a decade after its release. While it may have been outshone by more modern TW games, Rome as a standalone game has aged well, is still fun to play and is now REALLY cheap in the Steam Store.

Just watch out for those pesky Corner Spartans online.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is by far, my favorite game. Hands down, no competition. It is old, but I've yet to see any other strategy game come close to this. The graphics are decent, considering its age. The gameplay is complex enough to not be bored and just steamroll through everything, yet simple enough to actually know how to use every feature this game has to offer. 

The game is basically you controlling a faction during the time of the Roman Republic, and trying to become the best nation. Diplomacy is simple and allies will betray you constantly, unless you would just completely dominate them (and even then, they still might attack you!) The AI is pretty simple to defeat, their entire strategy seems to be just throwing all of their units at you and seeing who wins. 

The challenges come when you get into the Roman Civil War. This is an in-game event where the 4 roman factions fight each other for control of Rome. Up until this point, you've just been steamrolling through barbarians with your heavy legionnaires. Once the Civil War starts, you're fighting 3 other roman factions (2 of which have just as much land as you if not more, each) and they have the same troops as you. If you're not playing a roman faction then this will never happen, but it's called ROME total war for a reason. 

If you're into strategy games, buy this game. Even if you're not, you should at least give it a try. The controls might be difficult to use at first, but the tutorial is very helpful. You will probably lose your first few campaigns, but once you get the hang of the game it will be so much fun.

review:
After few hours of gameplay I will definitly recommand it to you.

The game innovates in differents parts if not  it's graphic engine (but sega...you know). The gameplay is very dynamic offering you multiple ways to be able to play with your very own strategy and I especially enjoyed the sea fights even do I consider that they should have pushed it further. 
Even if you play the campaign mode in easy, it will still ask you to stay vigilant about risks of rebellion in your very own town and keep your countryside safe with legions camps and don't waste your money.
The campaign is very long ,I haven't finished it yet and been playing for 3 hours and I haven't conquered any land yet.
The AI is really challenging and even in easy you have to pay attention on your troops managment.

The only negative part and the main default of the game is that I have already encoutered several nasty crashes while playing, I don't know if it's due to the core of the game being inadapted for windows 8 computers or the Steam client.

Regardless the graphics and crashes it's a great game and it's worth the 4 euros I've payed, if you're looking for a strategy game with plenty of actions and historic go for it with blind eyes.

title: Rome Total War
review:
For me, this has to be the definitive Total War Game.

Rome Total War is in many ways a much better game than those that followed it. The combat and mechanics are fairly straightforward, while not being overly simplified and the campaign managment is streamlined and not overly burdensome (completely unlike RTW2.)

While not perfect in all ways, it is fairly easy to mod things yourself, in order to change things around a bit. Want to give barbarian tribes paved roads and stone walls? Easy to do and takes less than five minutes. 

Roman units and hoplites are a bit OP and the IA can be a bit stupid at times, but all in all, the game provides many hours of enjoyable play, while the combat animations are far more realistic and weighty than those using the more recent Total War Engine. 

In the ten year since its release, I'd have easily played well in excess of 1000 hours on this game and after briefly grappling with the disaster that is still RTW2 (even after the Emperor Edition), I can see myself enjoying this gem for many years to come.

title: Rome Total War
review:
For me Rome: Total War is still as addicting and fun to play as the first times I played it (that must be over 7 years ago now).
Even after all these years I can still spend hours on it without getting bored. The combination of turn based strategy on the campaign map and real time strategy during the battles gives you a lot of freedom and allows you to be creative while reaching your campaign goal.
Although, once you've figured out the AI's flaws you can beat the game at the hardest difficulty fairly "easy" (I can understand this might be a turn down for some people) but it will still take a lot of time to do so, especially the full campaign games.
Sound and music quality is good. Graphics are obviously outdated for this day and age, but that does not bother me. I think the most important fact is that this game withstood the test of time. After 10 years it still is a popular game! And that is proof of its quality!

title: Rome Total War
review: BEST GAME EVER, played it since I obtained the cd version. Never dissapointed me. If you do get it you´ll never regret it. Or you could also get RTW II as it has been fixed, regardless both are good buys. For RTW though id recommend getting really any mod with it to expand the campaign as its kinda yeah, but hell it was "the first" TW game that really sold. This game is just sheer badassness all the way, when you carve your way through either the Macedonian phalanx, the Raving Gauls, and the Carthaginian Elpehants, which hilariously can turn on their own allies, its funny. Not only are there amazing battles, but also you have to think and actually manage your cities, its not just a blitzkreig, since you need to move governors (if you want to control the settlement intself) and much more other stuff. Like taking don shrines of other religions, making that town your religion etc. The first time I played the campaign, I Literally took over Gaul as the Julii in lightning speed. But my economy got raped, so i had to use cheats to dig me out, which was kind of a pussy thing to do, but then I learned. If you wanna play something else than vanilla I would also recommend Rome Toal Realism VII, as it is also pretty epic. Not only are there a kabagillion cities, but there are also some other factions. Now back to the game, the multiplayer is also quite solid, it has never crashed on me or bugged out (except when my peers had shiz interent). But I would assume you would come here to either play the campaign, or download a mod for it as its multiplayer, is generally dead, unless you have someone to play with. Yet it still lives on, since this game is such a f@cking masterpiece. So im just giving this 10/10, because its so freaking awesome. Now itd be cool if maybe in the future when computers are more powerful, make a RTW with cohorts that actually have 400 men! and have a 4000 men legion with auxiliaries and all, it generally feels (for me) that when you have a 240 men first cohort just doensent feel geniuine.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Though aged now, the original R:TW was a fun and genre-establishing product of its' time. What I haven't done 'til recent times was try any mods for it.  If you're a true fan of ancient history/ancient warfare, I would highly suggest the Europa Barbarorum (1.2) mod, which adds incredibly depth of historical accuracy, and a myriad of changes to the way the game works and unit/texture differences. It builds upon the old structure and enhances it to the extent that the vanilla/original game appears cartoonish and amateurish in comparison. 

For anyone who has wondered time and again why for instance our ancient Romans seem to be popularly portrayed extensively in a modern UK english accent, (for some bizarre reason), you'll be happy to hear true latin, ancient greek and celtic languages. Units are also elaborately detailed, and given large, informative descriptions. It's part history-lesson, part classic R:TW experience.

It is also an extremely entertaining challenge to seasoned veterans of the TW series like myself.

title: Rome Total War
review: Rome Total War is simply a masterpiece. The feeling of ordering a calvary charge into a large mass of Gaulish warriors and creating a all out slaughter, is in a word, astonishing. The whole system of this game is fantastic. Yes, the graphics are a little dated, but it is totally worth every cent.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Let's start with a confession. When Rome Total War was released I didn't buy it, didn't play it. Turn based sounded boring, I wanted real-time because that was cool. So when did I first play it? After Rome 2 was announced, I wanted to play with the ancient world but release was still months away. Then the release was utter garbage. Thus I turned to Rome Total War.

So lets start with the TL;DR part.
Good: The feel of combat. It's not fast, a bit to slow but formations collide. 
Good: Size, this game is huge. Large amount of provinces as well as factions. Improvement over Shogun 2, stuck in Japan.
Good: Atmosphere, Senate missions as Rome, three seperate factions. Lots of different other factions too.
Good: Mods, mods, mods. There some excellent mods out there for this game.

Bad: Graphics, the graphics sure aged. Then again it's an old 3D game, they rarely age well.
Bad: AI, AI isn't the smartest. The game is easily gamed, then again newer Total War's still are.
Bad: Egypt. Egypt was greek at the time, not pharaohs, well not styled like the rulers of old. Just graphics but I'll mention it anyway.
Bad: Resolution, no real widescreen support and no 1080p at all. Highest I can get is 1600x1400.

So should I still get it? Well it's different for sure. I got into it after I played Medieval 2, Empire, Shogun 2 and Fall of the Samurai. I could make the journey back and was pleasantly suprised. On the other hand my main gaming PC wasn't very available at the time and I played mostly on a laptop. So older games was something I was stuck with either way.

Give it a shot if you like ancient history, a slower strategy game and long battles. If you like historical accuraccy give Europa Barborium a spin. From a pure gameplay perspective it has an overwhelming amount of units, recruitment, moving and battles take ages but it's sure authentic.

This is a great game, it has aged but not to much. It's deep but not to deep and I'm sort of sad the path Total War games have been taken lately. Still we can go back to this and I recommend you do that.

title: Rome Total War
review: The first Total War game that I played, and probably the best in my opinion. A fairly sharp learning curve for those unfamiliar, but incredibly satisfying once one is comfortable with the gameplay. The RTS elements are, in my opinion, flawless. The game is divided up into a campaign map that is turn based, which involves running the economy and moving armies, and the battles, which are what happens when an army meets another army or a city. Every battle that you choose to participate in (you can auto-resolve if you want, generally in the case of overwhelming odds) is epic. So you routed the enemy army? Well, unless your cavalry chased down and killed them all, they won't disappear from the map. Chokepoint defended by a hoplite phalanx? Good luck getting through that wall. The graphics are dated, but that doesn't matter to me and shouldn't matter to you; this game stands well enough on its other merits.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total War A great game despite it's age.

Graphics 4 of 10

It's a really old game and the first total war game with 3D units instead of animated 2D sprites so you can't expect much in the way of graphics. and what you expect is what you get.

Learning curve (the lower the number the less learning curve there is) 5 of 10

The tutorials are good and the game is fairly simple to get into. This game has some learning curve for those who have never played any other RTSes but for those who have played other RTSes before they will have no problem getting into this game's controls.

Gameplay (on the battlefield) 7.5 of 10

Pros.

+Siege battles are very fun and challenging without being too hard.
+Land battles are Fun and tactical without being too hard.
+The AI is very good for a game of this age and can keep up with human opponents.

Cons

-some units are a bit over-powered such as elephants.
-some units are completely worthless unless under very specific circumstances such as the incendiary pigs that are only effective against elephants and have a tendency to kill more of your own people then the enemy’s that are killed due to the attack.and they do the same thing that a barrage of fire arrows from your archers could do.

Overall the land battles are very fun to play and are even better if you can find a human opponent to play with (CA recently migrated this game to steam due to the gamespy shutdown.)

Gameplay (Grand campaign) 4.5 of 10

Pros. 
+can be very fun when everything works well in tandem.

Cons
-Very dated
-It is nigh imposable to keep your budget in check when at war.
-diplomacy is clunky
-auto-resolving battles tends to end with your army losing a battle that anyone could win when controlling the units themselves.

Overall the campaign is good at times and really bad at others.

Overall 7 of 10.

Rome Total War is a game of two qualities; on one hand the battles are great and fun to command, on the other side the campaign is clunky, and not all that great at all. The good does outweigh the bad however. I completely recommend this game as custom and historical battles circumvent the horrid campaign and go to what is great about Rome Total War the combat.

title: Rome Total War

title: Rome Total War
review: You may be wondering I have not recomendded total war.  Well the reason for that is quite simple.  If i had just recomended it, then my review would have been lost among a sea of other reviews that also recomend it.  Hopefully someone somewhere will actually see this because its in a much smaller pool.  Anyway Rome total war is an excellent game, tatics while rather straightforward most of the time are realistic and you need to have a basic understanding of strategy to beat the AI on anything above easy.  Every faction has different unit compositions to use so your tatics will have to change on subsequent playthroughs.  Basically Rome Total war has a stunning amount of depth and historical accuracy put into it.  While the graphics don't hold up a decade later, the gameplay is superior to even the sequel Rome TW 2 which came out several months ago.  This game is worth the full price even today, and if your looking to get into total war, or getting your friends into total war, this is a great starting point or gift respectively.  To give you some basic tatics, rome's usual goal is to when not facing phalanxes just mash your infantry into the enemy, as your infantry are essentially the greatest in the world.  While there is more to it then that namely using light infantry to hold your flanks whilst heavy infantry splits the enemy down the center, using your cavaly to take out enemy seige weapons or to flank a phalanx, thats all there is to it.  When playing as greece your goal is to not get flanked, as you have the most powerful phalanxes in the world and will almost never lose if you don't get flanked.  Carthages goal is to use elephants and support cavalry to literaly blow holes in the enemy line and crush enemy morale, whilst your infantry pin the enemies center or flanks in place, depending on the lay of the land.  If your parthia you want to make the enemy chase you and use hit and run tactics as you have the best cavalry in the world, and the greatest horse archers to ever live.  and so on.  Basically buy this fucking game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
10\10 (Life changing)
While my steam play is only about 10 hours, I used to play this game back when you would goto the store to buy a computer game (or the fifth grade). That being said, I've easily put hundreds of hours into this game over the years.
This game was the first of the total wars I've played and stands second to maybe the newer versions of total war games. 
Smooth interactions on the campain and battle maps make navigation and stratgy easy. The A.I. can be easy at times but ramp up the difficulty and you may find yourself in a tricky spot during your campain. The game offers many different factions with a big yet easy to follow diplomacy setting and notifications to allow you to build up your own faction. 
Today the Mulitplayer is acomplishable but unless you have a freind that plays you probably wont find another player.
The steam version is up to date as you would expect and is a great  and cheap way to break anyone into the total war experience without beating an older PC to death with the high demands of shogun 2 (awesome game as well) and Rome 2 (which was dissapointing). 
RECOMMNEDED.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Only because for some reason it's ridiculously unstable, I got 100 turns into a campaign and it seems to CTD no matter how many saves I go back. It's still infinitely better than anything CA has released since medieval 2, and for a fraction of the price
Combat in this game is fast paced and fun, with many varied units and every faction having a unique feel. The battle AI is what you'd expect from a 10 year old game - having said that, it's better than many new entries in terms of self preservation and repositioning. 
The campaign takes some understanding of its intricacies (particularly cultural unrest and squalor), but once understood becomes easily manageable, and allows you to better array and deploy forces as you see fit
Once you beat the game (which can take a few days) you'll also have access to almost all of the other factions in the game (without a £3 entry fee, unlike more recent releases) which provides tonnes of replay value
Get this game, but maybe not on steam - my hard copy from 10 years ago works fine and doesn't corrupt my saves, so I can only assume it's a problem with the steam release

Also with the modding community for even more options, you have no excuse not to get this classic of a game. The only complaint I would have is the fact that you have to play through as a Roman faction first before you unlock the rest of the playable factions.

title: Rome Total War
review: Just bought it yesterday and have clocked about 22.9 hours and am about to clock a few more before bed.  This is my first (but defintely not last) total war game.  Breaking enemy lines and chasing down fleeing enemies is rewarding and unlike any other game I've ever played.  Even just marching to meet the enemy anticipating the upcoming battle is enjoyable.  The music and the sounds are amazing.  The graphics of units engaging are amazing for the number of units on screen at one time.  I will admit that after I had captured Spain, the battles were getting kind of vanilla (distract with infantry, flank with cavalry), but when I went to different lands, the enemies had different units that challanged me in ways that I had to adjust my tactics.  One of my favorite moments was getting surrounded by two armies whose combined total manpower was more than my army.  I went into the battle thinking that I was going to get slaughtered, but the two armies were separated by a large distance, so I pushed my army to close the distance and engage the smaller army before the larger army could come up behind me.  There was an urgency to break the smaller army and get my units turned around and in position to engage the larger army (which btw was still larger than my army).  I was able to win but just barely.  The game is filled with these types of moments.  I bought this game during a sale, but recommend this game at full price.  If I had known about this game when it first came out, I would have recommended it at full retail.

title: Rome Total War
review: I highly recommend this game! It's perfect for people who have computers that can't run newer games. The moment I played this I fell in love with it and I've already spent half a day on it when I bought it a day ago. Absolutly incredible! It has such intense battles, such intense campaign, such intense multiplayer that you forget how bad the graphics are because they're old and you just can't stop playing. I havn't even given any time for Rome: Total War Alexandra download yet! It's also great because when you are creating your armies, it tells you when you go overboard on the army and warns you that it may cause some lag and crashes. You can create such big armies that you don't give a flying f*** about your people or the taxes! The only bad thing is that it's quite hard to understand and get used to at first, even with the Prologue that teaches you what to do. But you'll get the hang of it in the end. Plus, it still has an active community after all of these years. I'm a beginner to this and I can barley say it's buggy. Except from that odd battle when your general takes out 80 fleeing men by himself. BUY THIS GAME!!!! It's worth it!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Easily the best RTS game of its era, it might have aged a bit, but it is a cheap way of having some relatively realistic RTS fun.
Some of the mechanics might be outdated, the graphics might not be the best and some units not realistic, but the unique to the Total War series battle and campaign system easily make up for it. 
Many historically famous and important factions to choose from, including 3 roman factions, the Germanic Confederation, Macedon etc.
Good (although not very sensitive/complete) diplomacy options will give you the chance to regulate the fate of the (then known) world with other means than just endless battles. 
I rate this game with 7/10 only because since then btter games have been released, especially from the same series.

title: Rome Total War
review:
While Rome: Total War is a masterpiece by all standards. It is clearly lacking in challanges for the factions I most like to play. Due to it being Rome: Total War I prefer to play the Italian factions. However the problem with this is when you don't nerf yourself and play on normal the AI is about as good on the battlefield as a toddler smashing the keyboard would be at this game ... It isn't; this is shown further by ridicules battles you can have... In example facing the greeks I've repeatedly destroyed 500 + Armies whilist only losing 90-100 men. That's asinine really. So while I can't praise it enough for its ambition and how fun the game is so far the game also doesn't present a challange to me - and I am a new comer to the series. Well that's not neccaserily true I played a lot of Medieval. But I am far from an expert so it should be that easy.

In almost every other area the game shines. Squalar is a ridicules problem that never goes away even with the appropiate buildings so that was a fuck tard move by CA and Sega. Other than those two issues the game is amazingly fun too bad it isn't better in the series main selling point however..

title: Rome Total War
review: It's the 5th turn in a row that a full stack of Egyptian troops has besieged me in North Africa. After 4 successive sieges without being able to retrain a single unit, the garrison is looking a little f*****. The battle begins, in true defensive siege fashion, every unit is on a chokepoint just next to the centre, i skip the part where the enemy ai knocks down my walls and spends 10mins getting his troops in the city. The panicky advisor screams 'The Walls are down!' ...jeez, calm down mate, it's not over yet. A couple thousand infantry and just under 100 chariots (god, you learn to hate those things) come barreling down the main 'road' towards my town centre, 5mins of carefully stacking my units just right pay off here, most of the chariots bounce off my block of 500 or so legionaries, but, wtf is this!?!?! there is one unit just sat on my town square, they oblige my worst fear and abruptly charge into my neatly packed lines, facing the other direction. What unfolds is a tense fight to the death where i am powerless to help my troops as they are mown down by the chariots, followed closely by infanty, a tense meat grinder, both armies simply melting away in moments...utntil one heroic legionary standard bearer decides to stab the enemy commander in the face, despite hiom being on a chariot. This superhuman feat results in a mass rout...my infantry is too tired to consider a pursuit. I end the battle. The world map loads up, 5 armies down, 8 more to go. Declaring war of Egypt was a terrible idea... (This hasn't beein much of a review, but it simply shows the beautiful anecdotal content this game creates, despite being made in 2004, it still easily holds up to modern gamin, i considered it a benchmark for Rome 2, and found Rome 2 to be lacking...again, proving that this game was insanely ahead of it's time. Would utterly reccommend, one campaign will easily sustain you for 50-100 hours. Enjoy!

title: Rome Total War
review:
I was never a strategy gamer.  I always played Call of Duty, Medal of Honor, God of War, and so on and was reluctant to ever play a strategy game.  The few games that I did play which were strategy were Halo Wars and Endwar and both were not my cup of tea.  The execution and view of them were not of my taste.  It was games like this that deterred me from the strategy genre for many years, until my sophomore year of high school.  I was watching a History video in class about Spartacus' rebellion and recognized footage used in the documentary that was obviously lifted from a game.  I knew for some reason that it had to be Rome: Total War.  I don't know what it was, but I just felt the impetus to buy it.  As luck would have it, it was on sale for a dollar on Steam (with Alexander included).  I came into it thinking it would just offer the same as any other strategy game.  Was I ever wrong.
   I have an exceptional ability to tell whether a game is good or not and my misjudgement of Rome was rather monumental.  Unlike many strategy games which are either turn based or real time, Rome: Total War was a mixture of both. There is a campagin map which is turn based-driven where the player can move armies, spies, assassins, diplomats, and ships.  There are a number of cities which are capitals to regions that the player can come to control by conquering the city.  There is a little depth with the utilization of resources for income for the faction the player controls.  Players can also spy on other factions' settlements, take part in diplomacy with either leaders or other diplomats, assassinate individuals, or blockade ports to cities.  The campaign map is far from static between turns.  
   Nevertheless, the charm of Rome is not the campaign map but the battle map.  This is by far the best part of any total war game for me.  I am glad that I played Rome: Total War before any other strategy game because I would have missed out on the dynamic battles which the player get to partake in.  There are basically three flavors of battle:  siege, field, and ambush.  Battles range from besieging cities to fighting in other locals on the campaign map.  If an army is position in a forest, it has the ability to ambush an army.  This is a game changer for it could result in a force of fewer soldiers to defeat a whole legion of the Roman Empire.  The normal battles in the diverse terrains of Rome: Total War are a spectacle to be witnesses.  The player has the ability to either decimate an enemy army or survive the onslaught and exxecute a brilliant last stand.  Fans of ancient warfare and 300 will most definitely enjoy Rome in this regard.  Sieges offer a different style of play.  Siege operate both on the campaign and battle maps.  The player can create multiple siege weapons and assault the city he or she besieges after blockading the city for a number of turns.  Having units scaling the walls of a city or busting through a gate is satisfying.  The most enjoyable part of battles (and from one source I read it seems to be a valid claim) is when two battle lines collide.  The player feels the impact and the game is made just that much better for witnessing such a spectacle.
   As with any game there are a few weak points.  For example, naval battles are nonexistent and the player can only approach each naval confrontation with a auto-resolve action.  It really takes away from the game.  Also, the game is not historically accurate to any extent.  Various historical events, save for the Marian reforms and various natural disasters, have no real effect on gameplay.  Also, the AI of other factions is not the greatest.  You'll partake in many battles where you'll be wondering if the AI was really trying or not.  Also, there is the issue that two factions, the Britons and Egyptians, are just overpowering and end up conquering half of the map by mid-game.  It does provide a challenge but it is really annoyting when they eliminate most other factions before you get to meet them; i. e. Parthia.  As a matter of fact, the only time I got to fight the Parthians was when I was playing as the Seleucids.  Another big failing of the game is the monopoly on unit advancement and power that Roman Factions have.  There are basically four Roman factions.  This means that no matter how you play the game, by the latest turns, the whole world will be ruled by Romans.  Again, this takes away the ability of the player to fight a diverse multitude of enemy types.  Exacerbating the issue is the Marian reforms effect on the Roman faction.  It basically turns all of the units into damage sponges.  This would have been okay if other factions were able to advance in such a faction but that isn't the case.  The most sad case is Gaul.  Gaul can get most of its highest level units before the Marian reforms take place.  However, that is only because it has fewer unit choices than the Roman, Carthage, and Seleucid factions.  I understand that it may have been made this way to bolster faction diversity but nevertheless it breaks gameplay for Gaul.
  Now with all these problems considered, I now bring to light the most exciting part about Rome: Total War: the mods.  There are so many good mods out there.  Note, these go well beyond a few stat changes and skins for units.  There are overhauls, historical mods, fantasy mods, etc.  Among the most prominent are Europa Barbarorum (a history buff's mod), Roma Surrectum (a Roman buff's mod), Fourth Age: Total War (a Tolken buff's mod), and Terrae Expugnandae (a truly interesting mod).  There is even a Napoleonic era mod with actual units that use rifles.  The modding community is similar to that of Skyrim in that mods are available at many hubs dedicated to mods.  The ability to use mods in Rome just makes that dollar purchase that more worth it.
   Rome: Total War is one of those quintessential games that needs to be played by everyone that has a PC.  It encompasses many aspects of strategy games and does not fail to deliever on the ancient Mediterranean theme.  You'll scream yells of excitement and aggravation as you play it.  The replayability is astronomical, especially with the use of mods.  I currently have a total of 544 hours of gameplay logged by Steam.  However, I've see numbers as high as 1000.  If you buy this game, I guarantee that you won't regret it.  The show that Rome puts on is worth the price of admission.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Ah, Rome. I never played it at launch or for years after the fact, but it was always on my friends computer. Which he was of course one of those little wank-jobs that always showed off his shit but never shared it.
	
No, about 2012 was really the first time I got to play R:TW, my first TW title being Medieval 2. 

Nowadays, people often say just get EB or any of the number of great mods. However, we're talking about Rome here, the base game as presented on Steam.

First off, with this purchase you get both Rome 1 (which follows Roman history from before the first Punic War to the early Imperial age) and the expansion Barbarian Invasion (which follows, of course, the invasions of barbarian tribes during the decline of the Roman empire). You don't receive the expansion Alexander (the campaigns of Alexander the Great) but of all the Rome expansions- Alexander is often regarded as the poorest by both critics and fans.

Rome 1 provides all the basics of a TW title. A campaign map where you conquer a part of the world. A skirmish game-mode where you fight the AI in a battle of choice. And Multiplayer (Now patched for steamworks as of 2014). Barbarian Invasion supplies the same package.

Within the Campaign Map you choose one of three Roman Families at first. This is where I start to have some gripes with Rome. For one, you have to conquer the other factions to unlock them in the grand campaign. Two, even if you just edit the .ini files to unlock them, the campaign is heavily focused on Rome. They get the most units, the most mechanics, the most events, and the most progression. While it's perfectly possible to enjoy playing the underpowered Gauls, I find these other factions to be relatively abandoned by CA. Some factions feel relatively the same, such as the Gauls and Germans, with only minor unit variations to give some feel to them.  Also of note is that some factions are simply over-powered beyond conceivable belief. Units such as Rome's Urban Cohorts are just horrifying when placed against the AI. This can make Rome somewhat of a snooze-fest once the Marius Reforms activates and you start to get the best of the Roman crop. Other factions such as Gaul have laughably garbage infantry for the most part. While some argue historical accuracy, I find it harms the game balance and the ultimate enjoyment available. But a discussion on Rome's balance is way beyond the scope of this review, suffice it to say, Rome is unbalanced- but it rarely matters in single player.

If however you only care for Rome, then RTW is for you. Each of the three families starts with an 'obvious' foe and paths of expansion. The Senate functions as a uniting force, rewarding you for following orders, showing disapproval when you fail. The whole game is built around your family as you grow both your empire and your influence. The game provides some great role-play as you follow the Senate's orders, checking to see if the masses or the patricians prefer you. As you progress, so will your power- inevitably enraging the Senate. It's moments like these where the campaign starts to shine. While I won't spoiler where that ultimately leads to, it justifies the slow start to the Imperial campaign.

Speaking of the campaigning, the conquest of towns is fought on the battle map. Here you command your army, including your general if he's there, and engage the enemy. This is where the meat of the game is, and here where Total War makes its name. The battles are some of the fastest in the series, with units moving rapidly and viciously. Veteran units can stomp multiple newbie corps single-handedly. A single cavalry charge can lead to a rapid route. All this occurs to the excellent soundtrack of Jeff van Dyck and combat mechanics that (mostly) stand the test of time.

I have a gripes here when compared to the later Total War games. For one, field battles (where units meet with no city or the like nearby) are unfortunately not too common in the later stages of the Campaign. This is due to the AI choosing the hide in cities. Due to this, you get to meet the siege battles of Rome- which are terrible. I'm not going to dance around this issue, siege battles are awful. The path finding of your units is all sorts of agony, and it only gets worse if you fight civilized nations that have large, built-up cities. You can have entire units enter into embarrassing formations where a handful of men are trying to take down a hoplite wall. It's funny, but it's hell. Siege battles can be ignored due to the great auto-resolve system Rome has, which can be used for field battles too.

Unfortunately, I have issues with unit path-finding in general. Cavalry especially is very cumbersome compared to later titles. You will just have to get used with Cav occasionally ignoring your orders and charging head-long into spear-walls instead of between that wide-gap in the line. Also, units randomly charging other units instead of the ones you ordered them to is also common- this includes cav. It makes the control feel archaic, and from what I've researched it just seems to be a bug with the formations. It's annoying and often makes me just go towards Medieval 2 and download a Rome mod (EB2, I'm forever hyped). It isn't game-breaking since the AI is just...

Meet CA's AI, from Rome to Rome 2 you're going to be playing with him. He's mentally insane, tuned seemingly for players that have no clue about formation tactics. The moment you figure out strategy, is the moment you realize that the AI is helplessly innocent, inept, incapable of learning, a terrible judge in terrain choice, a terrible flanker, and perhaps suicidal to boot. He's come in many different flavors- but really only modders seem capable of making him remotely competent. Increasing the difficulty will not make him smarter, only gives him a boost in unit stats. For a newbie, he's a good first opponent for casual player, but he won't teach you anything.

What is not a flaw of the series is its presentation. Rome's simplistic art direction may have aged polygonal graphics but it still holds up relatively well, appearing distinguished and fluid despite being a game from 2004. It's a standard that's been kept by just about every title. The music, which I've only mentioned once, is some of the best in the series, bringing a lot of those aged graphics to life with broad stroke of tunes. Even the voice-acting has some charm, in the hammy sense.

But we're not done, BI rounds out our package by being fucking painful. It's a campaign for barbarian lovers giving great variety to the barbars while still making Rome a fun faction. Notably a bit more balanced in the campaign the Western Rome campaign is one of the hardest challenges in TW history. It's meant only for series vets, even then it's infamous for the horror it gives. My personal opinion of it is that it's hard in the arbitrary sense, with unrest and religion stacking the deck on you. The AI isn't any smart notably (can land units by sea if the stars align). Most of the difficulty comes from rebellions, but the various barbarian tribes declaring war on you adds some fun. This campaign is historically inaccurate in it's portrayal of what troubled Rome. This is mostly due to the engine being incapable of modeling certain things. Historical inaccuracy is just a common thing in TW as it is- but I'm someone capable of ignoring this in favor of fun. BI besides the difficulty, is a neat addition to Rome and where I say barbarian lovers should go in lieu of the RTW.

Still, RTW offers a great package for TW newbs. Introducing you to the series with a game that still holds up, with great modding potential. For the gripes I have, RTW is still a great game. If you have to choose a TW, go with an era that interests you most. All of them have pros and cons. Between Rome 1 and 2? You get a complete product with R1 that is fully patched and 'done'. No dlcs, no patches ruining your mods, same era.

title: Rome Total War
review:
As a newcomer to the Total War series, I must express just how enthralled I am by the gameplay of Rome: Total War. It is an impressive strategy game that lets you live out those dreams of amassing a large army. Now these armies can be massive, carrying at least 1,200 soldiers, and don't even get me started on the reinforcements. However, it's not just a mere 'pick up and play' sort of game. This is a game that requires thinking, as a turnbased strategy game. You start off with a faction in the imperial campaign, where you are then given a large map of Europe that is populated with other factions of that time, such as the Greek, Egyptians, Gauls, Spanish, and many more. 

It is up to you to conquer Europe and extinquish all other factions from the competition. You can also choose to become allies with a few of these factions, if you want. The diplomacy feature in this game provides heaps of options, from trade rights with other factions, to extortion, or you can tell other factions to attack your rivals.

Each faction has its own economy, but I won't get into that. Admittedly, I'm not very good at this part. This requires constructing certain buildings to improve income, such as shrines to Jupiter or crops. You can choose to have each settlement have its own taxation. But set it too low, and your citizens may revolt and start an uprising. This is a game that requires lots of patience, and your experience should not be rushed. But there is no joy greater than conquering that final Spanish settlement, sending hundreds of infantry troops to slaughter them, while your archers lie back, and bring fire to the various buildings until finally, you have wiped their existence from the face of the Earth.

Overall, Rome: Total War is a thrilling experience that you'll find yourself investing many many hours in. Oh, did I also mention that you can play historical battles that took place in real life? Or if that sounds too boring, you can create your own custom matches.
