title: Rome Total War
review: Great Game

title: Rome Total War
review:
I spend a majority of my strategy gaming with two games: Rome: Total War and Civilization V (I have maybe 250+ hours offline in RTW). Why do I mention this? Because I have to say that while Civ V is a better game (though not by much), I have never found a game more masterfully put together than Rome: Total War. You might be the nicest person ever, but by the end of a campaign you might as well be ranked as the world's #1 sociopath, for you will be driven to crush every rebellion and consolidate the world under the mighty grip of your imperium. The aesthetic, feel, music, all for the glory of arguably the greatest empire ever created is emulated to absolute perfection.

And that's 10 YEARS after the game has been released. The most epic, enthralling, massive strategy game you'll ever get your hands on.

Only issues involve possible compatibility problems. Other than that, you're paying $10 for hundreds of hours of triumphant conquest. An absolute must buy.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is on my Top 5 Games of All Time List.

Let's start with the presentation. This Games graphics are out dated, but the attention to detail and polish are abundant. Nothing was more satisfying then watching my cavalry charge send individual men flying. The world map is kind of bland, but you have a pretty good idea of what the terrain is. All of the cities are (or were) real cities, and many you may already know of. This game is a very well researched game. There are many historical troop types and landmarks. I can't even imagine how much time was put in to making this game as historically accurate as possible.
Overall, this is a well-presented game.

Now let's look at gameplay. This games battle system is hands down the best I have seen in any RTS ever. The attention to detail is astounding. Certain troops counter others, this is in other games. However, different formations and tactics can turn the tables on your so-called counters. You can be a regular Cesar if you play your cards right. The AI is not the sharpest tool in the shed, especially when it comes to troop movement. I have missed a table-turning oppurtunity in many a battle due to a units slow response or incorrect followthrough of an order. It could be said that this makes the game more realistic, but that doesn't make it any less frustrating. The game can be played in single or multiplayer player mode. Single player has three functions: Campaign, Custom battles, and Historical battles. The Campaign can be played as one of the three Roman factions at first and later other factions. Not every faction can be played as-at least not in th vanilla-which is a shame as many unique factions were left out. The campaign takes place over a world map as you and the other factions take turns building and managing an empire. The campaign is extremely immersive. Players personalities are reflected in how they play the game. I can be impatient, but I also am a procrastinator. As a result, I would impatiently blitz one enemy, then stand around repelling the attacks of another. The goals of the game are dependent on what type of campaign tou chose. A short one has small goals while a long one has large. Overall the campaign is the best part of the game. The custom battle option is fun for experimenting with new tactics or just goofing around. It is not something you will spend a ton of time on though. The Historical battles are just that, battles from history. They put you in the shoes of real ancient commanders in battles that actually took place. They're fun, but not very replayable. The multiplayer is the second best function of the game. It allows you to play online in battles with other players. The type of battles vary, from sieges to free-for-alls. There are even some historical battles exclusive to multiplayer. Overall, the multiplayer is great for when you want a change of pace.

Over all, this game has a good presentation, pays attention to detail, and is highly immersive, the best ten bucks you'll ever spend. 9.5/10

title: Rome Total War
review: Rome: Total War is an excellent real-time strategy game. However, the most recent string of updates has caused countless problems for me and other players. The most recent update I downloaded has made the game unplayable. I cannot launch the game. I am a big Total War fan but the fact that these simple, not game-changing updates to an old, fantastic game break Rome: Total War for me makes me question what the developers are trying to achieve. I recommend buying this game in the future only when these constant updates stop.

title: Rome Total War
review:
There is no doubt that if you are looking for how to make a strategy game, this is THE bar! The combat is fluid and has a realistic feel to it; don't be fooled by the simple animations, all the unit interacts with the other unit by ganging up on members and dodging and blocking. The variety of tactics is also to be admired, each faction has to be taken on differently and the rewards of a very long campaign include some very unique and interesting units.

Sadly, as with most TW games the AI is lacking in challenge. With that said, you must check out the multiplayer! This game is a decade old and the servers are still very well populated; and let me toell you... there is nothing more awesome than an EIGHT FACTION FREE FOR ALL!

I implore you! Do not judge this game by its graphics and age, if you are a fan of RTS; for THIS is the KING OF ALL RTS GAMES!

title: Rome Total War
review:
For an old game, it's pretty well made and executed. Definitely worth 10 bucks.

I used to watch a lot of Rome Total War let's plays and I got pretty excited when I was able to download this from steam. The game starts you out playing as one of the three Roman factions, all of their intros distinct and unique. As I started the campaign I had a mixed sense of awe and fear. My first playthrough as the Brutii I enjoyed ravaging the cities of Macedon, Thrace and Greece. I did play on easy but there were some battles along the way that had suprised me and kept me emotionally invested in my campaign forth to the east. I remember countering the Phalanx heavy armies of Greece, Thrace, and Macedon, with skirmishers, artillery and archers whittling them down as they marched toward me. The same tactic worked for every battle with me always taking the hill. However I remember being annihilated by being caught in-between reinforcements and the main Macedonian army. I won, I lost, and I would never make the same mistake again.

After deciding to raise the stakes (Hard/Hard) and playing as a much less civilized faction (Germania) I found myself squished in-between the armies of Gaul, Britannia, and Dacia. I began my campaign reuniting the german people and invading what is now France and Britain and then proceeding into the territory that is known today as Austria. My empire was huge, to the west were the Spanish and to the east were the Scythians, and to the south were the Romans. With the Spanish and the Scythians at peace with me and Dacia all but scattered across the lands, I began my march into the Alps and into Rome itself.

For the Romans, it seemed too late, battle after battle I left their Hestati and Principe armies defeated and scattered, their war machines burnt to the ground and their cities pillaged and burned. They could not stop the hordes of horsemen nor the cries of the beserkers, Rome was crumbling. However, I faced as much more devastating enemy as I conquered their cities, holding them. There were constant rebellions and with the Romans building navies and giant army stacks at sea (and then landing in my territory) I had a rough time with them. When the Romans took a city, I couldn't take it back, simply because their walls were too strong to hold at siege. The Julii and the Scipii were battling the Numidians and the Carthaginians to the south, and then using the wealth from those campaigns to take back their homes. The Brutii were marching entire armies of Urban Cohorts, Legionaries, and the Praetorian Guard at my doorstep. Soon, my economy collapsed and I had begun to fear the threat of being overrun. I could take Rome, but could I hold it? After countless battles I eliminated the Julii and both the Brutii and Scipii were on the run. My armies all had silver/gold chevrons weapons and armor (upgrades) after such battles, so I was able to defeat many of their experienced warriors.

Then I decided to download Darthmod for Rome....

Every battle against the Romans was different than before and it had me running scared. I fought smaller army stacks and although I would outnumber them my men would leave the battle completely depleted. I couldn't auto-resolve otherwise I would end up losing and with the Egyptians, Pontus, Thracians, and the Spanish barbarians marching toward my gates I had one hell of a time. All in all, I had more fun than any other game I've played. The mods bring me back, and the battles are fantastic. Rome: Total War is certainly worth the money.

Trying to get to the bottom of it (complete game reinstall, verified files, updating drivers, scoured forums, contacted customer support, etc.) So far nothing has fixed it and customer support SEGA has yet to respond to my email.

 I highly recommend this game so long as the problems I have experienced with it are isolated to my set up. If it is a more systemic problem (which judging by the forums it is, many people having my exact error or a variation of it)  then I wouldn't recommend buying it until there is a stable build.

title: Rome Total War
review: I really love this game. I played Medieval II: Total War first and that was an amazing game in itself. If you like strategy games this is the game for you. Large battles where you command thousands of units. A huge world map for conquest. You may play as Rome or as the other factions: Gaul, Germania, Carthage, Macedonia, Parthia, Egypt, etc. If you are a history buff this game will appeal to you, and you may learn some new things yourself. Learning curve is steep though, and you probably won't be successful on your first go. Besides battling your enemies you have to deal with the Senate of Rome. You also have to manage an economy. This is my favorite game of the Total War series.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome's Legacy wasn’t built in a day, and the game that bears its namesake was not free from this either. Unlike the empire, however, Rome the game's glory was ripped from it in a single moment---Rome 2's release. 

For nearly a decade, we the true lovers of Rome awaited its fable return, and begged the gods of the Creative assembly to return to us our legions! After the wonderful gift of Shogun 2 we thought certainly that this would be given to us, and that it would be glorious. Now that all the other classics had been given sequels the greatest of them all certainly was overdue for a revisit. Rome 2 was not a Total War, but a Total Joke... Unless you count the design choices conflicting with your desire to enjoy pillaging all of Antiquity-- But that was about as much a war as the British fighting the Zulu; the Zulu being your enjoyment.

This prompted me to return to the original. Was it hard to put aside my Nostalgia to write this review? I would have to say nostalgia had no place in my experience with this game. For as many hours as I put in it all those years ago I can't say I had a plethora of memories to go on. Once I conquered Europe as the Saxons, and once I pitted Carthage against Egypt and both full stack armies were obliterated in an epic stalemate. These were my two favorite memories going into the game.
I started up Rome and went for the Expansion "Barbarian Invasion" first. I picked the faction I always played as back in the day and took on the Vandal horde. We marched south into the Baltics and settled in present day Croatia area. Eventually the ERE decided I wasn't fit to exist and attempted a Reconquista. A fifty-year war ensued where we engaged the enemy professional armies with our militia. Suffering through the great losses of our people we pushed south taking Thessalonica and Achaea. The war finally came to a close after the third Siege of Constantinople took the city, and destroyed the ERE's last European Legion, and subjugated the most powerful city in the world during this point in history.

The fledgling Vandal Kingdom of the Baltics established and independence now secure I reset the clock (And the game) to play the Vanilla. 
I decided to go a different route than I did when I was younger. Instead of picking Carthagians, or Scipii; I picked the Brutii. It took me a total of 6 minutes to realize what I just did. I was playing the Roman faction that was tasked to take the same exact lands as my Vandal kingdom had taken in the Expansion. I was essentially building the same ERE I would invade centuries later as the Vandals.  

As I am still in the middle of my conquest of the Greek-Macedonian Alliance, I can’t really say that I curb-stomped them... In fact Athens remains defiant and un-siegeable from a practical standpoint. While the Greek armies of Athens  send every one of my Legions home completely rekt, the Macedonians force our defending armies to either remain garrisoned, or all-together abandon settlements to defend more critical points against the armies of the sons of Alexander at our gates.... Eh, at least the Senate likes me.

So obviously I enjoy the game. I knew that before I even re-bought it on steam the other day. Despite being a decade old the game gets a ten for just the enjoyment. But I'm so confident in this game I am going to take it the extra mile and rate it like it was released a month ago, and compare it directly to Rome 2.
Pros-

-Competent AI
So the AI will not be winning any genius competitions, but put Rome’s AI up against Rome 2's AI and it will mop the floor with Rome II's pretty-boy face. Not only does this apply to the battles but the Campaign AI will actually give the player legitimate trouble.

-Soundtrack
Good, solid, mood setting music that changes based on the situation.  This music will get you PUMPED, and you'll remember these tracks for a lifetime. The track number is a little lacking in quantity, but quality is perfect. Medieval 2 might be the only one that can beat it.

Units-
The Roman factions all have the same units just painted different colors, but the Foreign factions are all unique to some extent. And don't think any faction is left out. Each one has their own death machines. Carthage has elephants, Egypt and Britain have Chariots, Greeks and Macedonians have Hoplites-- All of which will thoroughly ruin your day with brutal efficiency. The Barbarian Expansion scores a little lower on this to me, But the expansion still gets clearance on this issue

Religion-(Barbarian Invasion only)
This is a very simple religion system where the player can convert to a new religion at any point. Ironically the people will convert much, much faster than the player's own royal family. In short it's simple, but works.

Engine- This Engine was designed for this type of game; Rome II's was designed for EMPIRE's Ranged based combat. Though the clashes can be anti-climactic at times; you'll never get the ridiculous mosh pit of Shogun 2 and Rome 2. 
Animations are also nothing to write home about, but they function, and don't jump around for kill animations.

General Speeches-
Yes. THIS IS HOW YOU DO GENERAL SPEECHES PEOPLE.
Cons- 
Graphics- Graphics are dated, but it's a decade old; Since I said I was Rating this as if it was last month I can't not count this.

..... ummm.... come on that can't be it...

Diplomacy- All total war games fail here, it functions but the AI can act a fool on a regular basis. the only TW game with decent diplomacy is probably Shogun 2.
Seriously there’s not much to find wrong with this game. If you like Grand-Strategy and/or RTS this game is the one for you. Is it my favorite Total War game? Um, no I can't say it's my favorite, but it is the original champion. It didn't earn that honor form being a PoS. It was the first one I played back a decade ago, and it echoes a long forgotten day that CA had more pride, love, and passion for this title. Back then it was their baby, and it shows.
for $9.99 Rome and the expansion is an investment any lover of strategy will not regret.

If it was released last month:

Modern Day Score- 7/10

Overall and timeframes aside:
Final Verdict- 8/10 

When all is said and done Rome has aged moderatley well. While it does show it's age; the old man it more than capable of holding it's own and even going toe-to-toe with modern titles. It is the Jack of all trades, but a master of none. It is and forever will be one of my favorites.

title: Rome Total War
review: This game is really fun and I enjoy it a lot. I have not yet played any of the other total war games. Though so far the bar is set really high and I am hoping that the other games are at least close to the same calibre as Rome Total War. I honestly think that the graphics are decent and I love all the variety of different types of units with their own characteristics. I like how they made this game more realistic giving the soldiers attitudes and making them get tired. This really shows the effort Total War put into it. I have not yet had any problems and I would recommend this to anyone.

title: Rome Total War
review:
A great strategy game outlining the military and political stresses across the known world during the rise of the roman empire. Play as Rome, Carthage or any of the other major contenders for dominance over the mediterranean in this great installment in the total war series.

Barbarian Invasion, the expansion included in the gold edition, details the demise of the Roman empire through the invasion of various playable barbarian factions. The expansion includes a revised religion system, new units and scenarios. Although not as fun to play (or historically accurate) as the base game it is a nice, and highly playable addition.

Awesome turn-based grand strategy and RTS battles, as well as the low cost and ability to run on almost any computer makes this great for anyone who likes strategy games.

title: Rome Total War
review:
i had two problems running this game on windows 8.1 64 bit (first: game doesn't launch, only a black screen and then returns to desktop; second: problem "Failed to find Steam"). I finally managed to resolve both, so in case some of you have the same problems, here i post the solutions. I tried many solutions i found on internet:


-copied the Steam.dll file from C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam
-deleted the ClientRegistry.blob file from C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam (Make sure you are not logged on Steam when doing this).
-tried every possible compatibility mode, but not working
-tried disabling steam community in game from game properties on steam
-tried the solution down here.
     1: Right-click on "Computer" (in XP it was called "My Computer") and click on Properties.

    2: in Vista / 7, on the left click on "Advanced System Settings". On XP, Google search for how to change your system path, because I can't quite remember where things were in XP.

    3: In the Advanced tab, you'll see a button for "Environment Variables". Click it.

    4: In the upper section of that new window, you should see something like "User Variables for [your username]". Scroll through to find the one called "PATH".

    5: Highlight the entry for "PATH" and click "Edit...".

    6: You'll get a too-small text box that has a field on the top for "Variable Name" and a field under it for "Variable Value". Put your cursor into the "Variable Value" field and hit the [End] key so you know you're not inserting text in the middle of another entry. If you push the right arrow key it should not scroll.

    7: Add a semicolon [;] to separate your new entry from the others. This is the key to the right of the 'L' key, without      pressing Shift. Correct -> ; Incorrect -> :

    8: Paste in the path to Steam, which for me on a default-install Windows 7 64 system is: C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam

    9: Press OK, and re-launch Steam so that it gets the new environment variables. (It might work without re-launching, but hey why not.)

    10: Run the game normally!

-finally, i changed the default setting for the use of integrated or dedicated video card, to integrated (mine is Intel HD4000).




After all this passages and a system reboot, now the game starts. I don't know exactly if only one or more together of the above solutions was the key, but i know that if you do all of that, the game will start. Try one after another.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Probably the best entry in the Total War series, Rome is where for many it all began. It would be difficult to overstate the hours of time that this game will eat up, as you conquer Europe as one of the three Roman factions or rewrite history by creating a sprawling and prosperous barbarian state from the Balkans to the Iberian peninsula. 

It's still a remarkably pretty game, and although the unit geometry is a bit angular when zoomed in it holds its own in creating an attractive world, with none of the over-sharpness that is plaguing the later games in the Total War series. There are frustrations though, especially with large unit sizes causing major pathfinding errors in siege battles.

If you somehow haven't played it yet then it's a must-buy. Cross that Rubicon and you won't regret it.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is one of the best grand strategy games ever made. While light on diplomacy, this game focuses heavily on the latter two words of the title: Total War.

Starting out in 270 BC, you take the helm of one of the patrician families of Rome: the Julii, the Scipii, or the Brutii. While functionally the same, each one has you expanding the empire in a different direction, against different enemies. You must serve the Senate and People of Rome (the SPQR) during your campaigns if you are ever to realise your true final goal: domination of the other Roman families, and the siezure of Rome itself. After completing a campaign as one of the families of Rome, you unlock several new factions to play as, each with their own unique units, religious buildings, locations and much more.

The Good:
+Turn-based campaign map and real time battles keep the tempo just right. You'll never get bored or be bombarded with too much action.
+Very diverse factions, but the Romans typically are the best to start with, due to their favorable situation. More veteran players will like the other factions for their increased challenge.
+Challenging campaign that forces you to think about what you are doing, and hopefully not make decisions you'll regret.
+Graphics have aged well for a decade old game, and it runs very well on modern systems. Only very underpowered machines will struggle with this game.
+Music is intense and epic, and gives the battles a sense of awe when they are large enough.
+Battles are fun and can be very challenging. Don't be surprised if the AI outsmarts you sometimes!

The Bad:
-AI is not always very good. It does not handle sieges very well, and naval warfare is usually trivial as they rarely keep sizeable fleets. Also, weak factions will attack you (often the most powerful faction in the game) for seemingly no reason, and enemies on the brink of destruction will make outrageous demands to you, while your armies are at their doorstep.
-Diplomacy is very limited. You can make very limited demands and offers, make alliances and trade rights, but that's about it.
-Feed back from the game's building and condition descriptions are very poor, giving the player almost no feed back.

The Iffy Stuff (stuff that some people will like, others won't):
=The game is VERY long. Even a short campaign will run you a few hours, and you'll need to set aside a few days to do a long one. However, this means this cheap game will provide TONS of entertainment.
=The game is quite old, so some will scorn its simplicity, but others will like it.


Conclusion:
Rome: Total War is still one of the games that truly defines strategy, and its impact is still being felt today. A must buy for strategy enthusiasts and new comers alike.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Never bothered with Total War games. Then I decided to pick up a copy of Rome 2 to see why everyone was getting massive hard ons about it. I thought that was great and all but I wanted to try the other games.

MY GOD! THIS IS WHAT I'VE BEEN MISSING OUT ON!? Sure the graphics and animations are 10 years old but the game itself has so much to offer. It even has my favourite period of history: West and East Roman Empires, this is much more challenging, complex, and tactical than Rome 2, even its soundtrack is better. This requries actual skill to succeed, you really need to think of the consquences of your actions and its effects on your empire.

Despite its age, Rome has easily become my second favourite RTS (Wargame comes first) I know I will be playing this more than Rome 2. I still can't get over the fact that I didn't get this eariler, I have a lot of catching up to do on the other Total War titles.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Where do I begin? The soothing music is soothing, the epic battles are epic. The Syrians are the Syrians, sadly Scotia does not feature.
I recommend to start as the Julii, the Gauls are a relatively easy opponent, and they fly the well-known Roman Red colour. The Brutii are fun, but you're up against tougher opposition, in the form of Pontus...Feckin' Pontus... But, the Scipii, in my opinion are the hardest. Lemme explain: Your main enemy is Carthage, they have War Elephants, you'll also be mainly situated in the North African desert, Arid climate does not help trade or pop growth.

Anyway, 10/10 Game, one of my favorites, i may even prefer it over Med II Total War.

      From the very beginning you can tell that this game is going to take you on a journey. You pick a faction that piques your interest, and set out to conquer the known world. Everything about this game is fun and rewarding and I quite simply could not reccomend it more. If you like strategy games or anything like lord of the rings then pick this game up. I cant really say why i have taken to this game so much given that im no purist and will freely admit that all the sequals (ever) are superior in literaly every single way but there is something about the simplistic charm and familiarity that attracts me so. 

If you do not own this game then you are an computer criminal who belongs in game-jail. Every number above 10 out of 10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I came, I saw, I conquered!

Played it since my teen years, bought and played it again. Choose a Roman family, rise in status, fight barbarians, and seize power in Rome herself. Or you could be a barbarian heathen. Easily one of my favorite games in the series and one of the best RTS games of all time. 

The only problem perhaps is the autoresolve battle AI seems to leave a lot to be desired. However; if you wanted a turn based game I recommend The Republic of Rome Tabletop game (playable by your lonesome but better with friends you aren't afraid to lose) or your favorite Civilization. The Historical inaccuracy of certain aspects is also fairly blatant but it is forgiven due to the game being more about cinematic sword and sandal warfare than a rough simulation of historical events for that I recommend something by Paradox Interactive.

The game's strenghts lie in it's great battle system and it's fascinating overworld of intrigue. If you want a hardcore tactics game it can be that but there is also an arcade mode for people who just want to watch the sword fights but do not wish to get heavily involved in tactical movement.

This is a game I could recommend for anyone with even a passing interest in this period in history. The phoenicians are waiting to meet you on the field of battle.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is what its title advertises, the Roman Empire (and the other factions that existed during that period) and the vast, complex and often overwhelming task of leading your chosen faction to greatness. The game is a unique blend of turn-based strategy and real time tactics that Creative Assembly has turned into an ever flourishing series that has earned its praise many times over.

You control everything from what buildings to construct in your cities, to which factions you want to conduct business with. That's the turn-based part. Where the "real time tactics" come in is when you fight a battle, commanding your units in real time, as you might have guessed.

As far as combat is concerned, it's solid to say the least. You have a great amount of control over your units, even being able to tell them where to move siege towers. However, there are, of course, flaws. It's always frustrating to have your soldiers attack enemies that you didn't send them after, especially when those enemies just happen to be the very thing that can chop your precious soldiers to bits.

The diplomacy also suffers a bit, since the AI tends to reject even the most reasonable offers, no matter how much they would profit from them, unless you have a diplomat with a high influence stat, which is gained through successful negotiations. This creates a vicious cycle of useless diplomats, leaving you to solve all matters with the sword, rather than the pen.

Over all, this game, however old, is still a gem and well worth your time.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Possibly the best TW game on the market. It may just be me viewing it through nostalgia-tinted lenses, but this game definitelly surpassed the competition in my book.

Pros:
- Good unit variety, building variety, and so on.
- Far more colorful and vibrant than later entries.
- Good variety of civilizations.
- Decent dificulty curve.
- Replayable to almost infinity due to variety of strategems and civilizations.
- Decent modding community and re-works through dedicated websites.

Cons:
- Realism slightly lacking.
- Some balance issues in multiplayer (barbarians lack morale, phalanx beats any other unit one-on-one etc.).
- Poor diplomacy.
- Community has partially moved on to Medieval II and later, meaning less mods and reworks to add replayability that    otherwise.
- Graphics slightly dated.

In short, the game has much to reccomend it. The main complaint I find is that the game hasn't aged well compared to others, that the graphics are out of date etc. While some have a point, the old graphics have a certain charm and don't detract from the gameplay one bit. In fact, I take that as a point in their favor as it means that older systems can run the game without frying from the effort.
Buy it. You won't regret it one bit.

In the meantime you will easily lose yourself in this game and develop a real taste for the series in general.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is a game that more or less started my addiction to gaming on a computer. I tried this game at a friends house many years ago as a kid and to this day I still find myself loving every minute of it. The graphics are superb for the time period and my childhood mind was in awe at how thousands of individual soldiers could not only be seen walking among their units, but you can even see each soldier FIGHT on their own! I have seen some issues with the AI following commands (they will head for a completely new target even though their initial target isn't destroyed), but I have yet to completely lose a match because of such incidents.

Overall, this game is possibly the best strategy game I have ever played. You can never go wrong with a classic like this for a mere $10. I would go so far to say that you don't really need anyother game from the series!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Creative Assembly's early work was a little too "new wave" for my taste. But when Rome came out in '04 I think they really came into their own. Commercially and artistically. The whole game has a clear and crisp gameplay and a new sheen of consummate professionalism that really gives it a big boost. It's been compared to Civilization, but i think Rome has a far more epic, grand scale type of campaign.
In '05 Creative Assembly released Barbarian Invasion, their most accomplished expansion. I think it's their undisputed masterpiece. Most people probably don't play all the nations. But they should, because it's not just a historical digest of the era, it's also a personal statement about the developers themselves!

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War is the oldest Total War game available on Steam, and can be considered the basis of the rest of the games which followed (although I would totally rebuy Medieval: Total War if they ever added that). In previous games, the overlying board played like a giant Risk board, where you moved armied from province to province, instead of having the entire campaign map laid out and moving your armies to specific locations. This was a DRAMATIC shift for the series, and one which really helped to establish it at something unique from other strategy games.

Like all Total War games that followed, you move your armies around the map to strategic locations in your turn, then the rest of the other players' turns elapse. At any point where two armies meet and fight, the option to autoresolve or fight on a tactical campaign map is provided, which is where the real-time portion of the game takes place.

Rome is also the first game in the series where the armies were polygonal as opposed to sprites, which was a RIDICULOUS feat for graphics at the time. It's still relatively streamlined compared to modern Total War games, but it still stands up to this day. It's an excellent, excellent game, and well worth playing even now, a decade after its release. While I don't personally hold it up as the best example of the series, I know many people who do and I cannot fault their opinions - this is a damn fine game.

title: Rome Total War
review: Ahhh rome... what a game, truly one of the best RTS pc games ever made, well for its time yes but now its 2014 and creative assembly have come along way. Rome 2, shogun 2 ,empire theres quite a few so if you bought rome now would it still be fun to play? the answer is yes, while the graphics suffer because of its age gameplay never dies and theres still an active community who play this game online. Rome feels like it has what it needs to be a fun game while rome 2 on the other hand feels like rome 1 but with aload of junk piled on top, rome is simplistic, fun to play and will have you hooked for hours even days. In its time i would of given it a much higher rating but as theres newer games like shogun 2 that gives you pretty much everything you would want in a RTS the score will be lower but this is still a gem and as a pc gamer you owe it to yourself to check out this game, Overall 8/10

title: Rome Total War
review: Amazing strategy-battle game. This turn based game forces the player to look ahead, and see potential threats of enemy invasion, keep an income steady and positive, train and maintain troops inside and outside of your city, as well as external relations with other countries. Juggling all of that, as well as the ability to command and control every movement of every unit of troops your army makes. This game allows the player alot of control, forcing them to learn how to use it to think ahead to control Rome!

I will most definitely be trying out TW: Rome II at some point in the future(I own it but haven't played it), but until then this will be my favorite Rome-conquering game.

My score: 8/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
When I first bought this when it was first released (back in them ol' pre-Steam days), I was ultimately underwhelmed by it. Then I played it again, and grew to like it more. I lost the CD's, but found it on Steam and got it to try playing it again. After a while, I uninstalled it. Now, at least twice in the past few years, I've thought about the game, reinstalled it, played it for a day or two, then uninstalled it again. Why? Because, really, in the end, I'm underwhelmed.

RTW CAN be a fun game. I've done multiplayer against friends, and enjoyed it immensely. I like the various units available. With the Roman factions, I like playing the various quests to win approval in the Senate and among the populace. I wouldn't call it the worst game in existence.

So why, then, am I still underwhelmed?

First, there are some serious problems with this game's battle mechanics. You will have to literally micromanage your units, and like 1-year old children you won't be able to leave them alone for a while, because if you do they will do amazingly stupid things. For example, I had a cavalry unit chase after some routing archers, went to another spot of the battlefield, then when I went back to the cavalry unit, I saw they had decided it would be an awesome idea to charge headlong into a line of spears, and were suffering tremendous casualties. This doesn't even cover that sometimes you could give individual units specific orders, and they'll just ignore you. Then there are some SERIOUS pathfinding issues. Units will take the most random routes to go from point A to point B, even when there shouldn't be an issue. The biggest example of this I can think of was one time when I was besieging a city, and was charging my men (who were not routing) down the main road in the city - apparently, "go charge at the enemy right in front of you" translated into "turn around and head back outside of the city."

Second, the campaign map part of the game will be annoying. Diplomacy is virtually USELESS. You could set up alliances with all your neighbors, get trade deals, and generally be peaceful...and then suddenly, for absolutely NO DISCERNABLE REASON, all your neighbors will, one by one, declare war on you. OK, fine, this game is called Total WAR, maybe that can be forgiven. However, none of your opponents will EVER accept a peace deal, even if you've destroyed all their armies in several embarrassing battles, and have taken all their cities except their capitol. You could offer them the best peace deal ever that would ensure their survival, and they would still say, "Nope! Fight to the end!" On top of this, naval battles are just annoying: while they automatically auto-resolve all naval battles, they rarely involve the complete destruction of one side. You could have a fleet of 300 sailors up against a fleet of 13 sailors, and it would still end with the enemy getting away somehow. Aside from blockading fleets, I end up just not caring about navy battles.

There are also some issues and bugs that I've noticed in the Steam version of RTW that I didn't see in the original RTW or its expansion. One of the biggest issues is that reinforcements seem to ALWAYS be delayed. Originally it was sporadic enough that it helped make the battles random and unpredictable...now, I no longer expect the reinforcements to come, because the minute I get into battle I get a notification that the reinforcements - either for me or the enemy - have been delayed.

In the end, RTW is just not an enjoyable entry into the TW series. After a certain point of wondering why a one-city nation decided it would be wise to launch an attack against my empire, or after the fifth time I've suffered casualties because my men are wandering around the battlefield like wet hens and ignoring what I told them to do, I lose all interest in playing it, and uninstall it. If you want to play a Total War game, I would go look elsewhere.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is the number one game in my library. For over a year, it was the only game other than Spore and the contents of the Orange Box. Five years later, I still go back to it every now and then. I've had many a 14-hour marathon day playing Rome Total War, quite often back to back. I'm pretty sure I got a chance to play as every civilization before I switched computers and lost my progress. I've even gone through the Barbarian Invasion campaign a few times. Honestly, if I'd never bought Civ V, I'd have well over 1,000 hours racked up by now.
This is strategy at its purest. Not only do you have the strategy of "How do I move around my armies and generals and funds to best maintain and expand my empire?" you also have the battles themselves. Many games do only one or the other, and those games can go hang. I'm not going to go into detail about the games mechanics and why they're good or bad; instead, I'm going to regale you with but a few of the ridiculous stories that have come out of my 800+ hours.
*My British faction leader, supported by two other armies, slaughters a quarter of the entire Brutii force over ten years, littering Poland with heroic victories. He eventually meets his end, known as "the Legendary," defending a town against a Roman force three times his size. Succesfully.
*An elite squad of Berserkers sacrifice themselves on the walls of Rome itself, eliminating two entire legionary cohorts and flanking the wall's other defenders.
*Four hoplite units hold Sparta against a full-size Roman army, earning a 100:1 k:d ratio.
*My prize Egyptian army meets a humiliating defeat at the hands of Ponitc troops, navigates around the army, and marches straight into a Pontic city.
*A Roman town is betrayed by Spain's finest, throws them off every year for three years until reinforcements can come in and ravage Spain's western coast.
*A Carthaginian gambit to take Rome early fails miserably; a generation later, we're back with five armies that now include line-ravaging Armored Elephants.
*Betraying Rome by landing an army next to her city - as well as every other non-Brutii city on the peninsula, and bloackading every Roman port east of Palma.
*Falling in love with my faction heir, as he's my only general who can fight at night. He later on earns three bonus command stars at night, and sacks Constantine by the light of the moon.
It's a glorious game, one with an infinite supply of stories. Go make your own.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I just got done writing a review for TW: Rome 2 and realised my whole review could've been summed into the words "Go play Rome 1 instead."

This game, where to even begin? I played an ungodly amount of this game back in the day and when I returned to it, it still felt brilliant as ever. Get some mods off TW: Centre and this game feels fresh and exciting every single time you play it. The graphics look a bit block up close but you'll be at a bird's eye view most of the time so it's of no matter. The unit differences are great. The intra and interfactional politics are ever relevant and fun to play with. The political system allows amazing freedom and flexibility in your diplomatic relations. The deployment of troops makes sense. The strength of weapons and missles make sense. The AI doesn't ever feel overpowered. Seriously, get this game and get a mod like Total Realism.

For 10$ you will not get a better RTS game out there honestly. If you need a number, this game gets a 10/10, 5 stars, 100% whatever just do yourself a favour and get this. If TW: Rome 2 left a bad taste in your mouth, this game will fix it by causing endless orgasms.

title: Rome Total War
review:
I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a strategy game.
The spectacular graphics and extensive detail behind each character and race.
Whether you choose to play as a Roman or a Gaul, each family member has their own traits and differences, so every new playthrough has it's own new experiences.
The battles are utterly amazing, whether you're flanking your enemy with cavalry, using your archers to hold off twice your men, or bringing reinforcements that either you or an AI can control.
Then there's the diplomatic side to it, you can put a spy in an enemy city in the hopes that when the time comes, they manage to open the gates for your men. Or, sending an assassin to kill an enemy captain, maybe send your diplomat to win over the enemy?
However you choose to play the game, it's up to you. But it is definetely worth the price tag! 8/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
My very first Total War game and it really hooked me.  One of my favorite things to do early game was just to create an entire army of peasants.  You haven't seen hell until you see over 3000 peasants trying to get through a gate all at once.  It was glorious and it made trained soldiers flee in terror just because of the sheer size of my host.  Unfortunately that tactic only works in the early game but it's fun to watch. I would build huge walls and watch as my archers tore apart the incoming troops.

I would read about the buildings and units that I built and their historical context and I ended up learning a lot about it. I would deal with the "senate". I would master trade. It was all a surreal experience. I played this game so much that I scored a 100 on my europe geography test without any other use of materials. In short, buy this.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game was great 9 years ago and it is still great today. The campaign is very in-depth and it keeps you wanting to take just one more settlement before you save and quit. There's something very rewarding about building your measly little armies up from scratch and over time watching them become the dominant powerhouses that steamroll everything in their path.

 The diplomacy can be frustrating at times and the Senate will piss you off. Always wanting you to blockade this port and take that city within X amount of moves. Then when you ask them for some help they're like, "Um, no." That's ok - when you're strong enough you can take them out too and run things how you like.

 Overall, it is by far one of the best RTS games ever and if you have that craving for war tactics like I do, this is the one for you.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome Total war is a rare breed. A realistic RTS game without the chaos of real life interfering with it. Historically, this game is fairly accurate, and the Roman fighting style lends itself to more user friendly battles. And here is where the game is such a drastic improvement on the previouse titles in the series.

Organised Chaos
Whether it is by phalanx or testeudo, the battles are a lot more organised than its predecessors. Battles are based on your ability to organise, coordinate and react to the adversity, more than the troops at your disposal. Gone are the morale sapping archers on the hill top and heavy cavalry charge from Medieval TW2 - Rome brings you a more balanced feel to the battle, even if it is elephants vs peasants.

Macro, not micro management
What I like most about Rome (and where they seem to have strayed from the path in more recent releases) is that these are strategy simulations, not population management games. The management evironment is simple and straight forward, the interface is both familiar and intuititve while still giving you the ability to go into more detail if those damn peasants insist on revolting every turn.

Rome is a great game to either pick up and play or delve into in for days on end. Rest assured there is a battle around every corner, usually where you least suspect it.

Even with CA's recent release of Rome 2, it still does not compare to the level of pure effort put into Rome 1. Rome 2 is horedously buggy, overpriced, naval combat is a plus, but only makes the game more tedious, just as it did in Napoleon and Empire, and simply uses new age graphics to lure players. No game should be judged by graphics, onl by gameplay mechanics, sound, community, and execution. Anyone who says "DONT GUY THIS GAME OUTDATED GRAPHICZ SUX BUY SHOGUN OR ROME 2" is inceccantly butthurt about losing 60 Dollars to the shitpile that is Rome 2.

Buy this before you play ANY other Total War game.

title: Rome Total War
review:
With the failure of the recent Rome title, this game certaintly deserves another go. The game is set during ancient Europe, where the many factions of the time wage war for dominance. Many of these you can play, even so more with mods. The game does focus on the Romans however, and you can choose one of three families to play as to dominate your enemies and eventually become emperor of Rome by overthrowing the other families. The actual warfare itself requires tactical thinking, unlike other "strategy" games where you can mass-produce units and zerg the enemy, you must actually think about the positioning of your units as well as their strengths and weaknesses. Outside of actual combat, the game takes place on a map screen,similar to a Civ game, there you manage troop recruitment, finances, manage settlements, build forts and send out dimplomats to make allies or trade. The game will also appeal to fans of managment sims, as you must manage every aspect of your settlements such as repairs, construction, defense, population, happyness ,trade and religion. On the field of combat you really must tap into your inner general. Using the terrain to your advantage can be a deciding factor against a larger ammount of opponents, funneling the enemy over a bridge will reduce their effectivness, allowing you to take on a smaller ammount at a time. All the units MUST be managed properly or they will be slaughtered, so charging your cavalry headfirst into a spear wall is a big no-no. Morale is a crucial factor of the game which gauges your troops willingness to fight, and if broken can be disasterous and cause MASSIVE routs. Things like exaustion, casualties, murderous hounds, and a lacking commander (and much more) can all effect your troops morale. The last great feature is the family member system, that allows you to play historical(or not) figures and level up traits that help(or hinder) morale, combat strength, city managment and more. So that lame 1 star general your sending up against that guy who has been wrecking everything probably should retreat. 

Overall, I love this game. Easily my favorite RTS game of all time and I HIGHLY suggest picking this up if you want a real strategy experience that will test your abilities to lead men in battle. My only complaint is the game doesnt explain much of the real important mechanics, so I suggest reading guides/watching videos. But other then that I give it a solid 9/10.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Shogun 1 may have been the first of the Total War series, but Rome was the real "breakout" entry in the franchise. Pretty much every TW game since can trace its core roots to this game. The map style where you have cities/strongholds that control a "province", and only by besieging and conquering that place can you can control of a region. Otherwise your armies march around the map and fight wherever they end up meeting. If you have played a TW game before, but not this one, what you will find in this game will all seem very familiar to you, with a few features missing here and there (Naval Battles are autoresolved, for example)

So how is the game now? Well, it's still what it is a decade ago, and the Rome of a decade ago was one of the best games of that time. Getting over the obvious things like graphics and perhaps a few gameplay annoyances that more recent games have improved on, you can easily enjoy this one. Since Rome II is out, I suppose few people will look into this one. Then again, Rome II is apparently a bug-filled mess, so those who want to fight it out in this time period can look at this game instead. You could very well be happy with what is here and play with this until Rome II eventually gets itself fixed up. 

There is a chance you can run into some bugs, but those should either be easy to resolve or not be totally game-ruining.

Enjoy! :3

title: Rome Total War
review:
If you like the Total War games, but have shied away from thsi one because it seems so old, you are doing yourself a disservice. This is still the best game in the series and one of the greatest strategy games of all times.

You start by leading one third of a trimvirate in power in Rome. The Senate will give you missions that lead your faction in one direction and while you are free to ignore the Senate missions, it will lower your standing with the Senate and result in fewer of your generals and statesmen getting Senatorial positions.

Eventually when you get strong enough, the Senate will get suspicious and start asking you to have your leader commit suicide. If you accept things will be OK, but the Senate will start making the same request more and mroe frequently. Denying them causes a civil war between all the factions in a major throwdown for control of Rome.

Wether you play as one of the several legions of the Roman empire, or as the barbaric hordes of Britannia, Germania or the Gaul, there is something to tickle every strategists tastebuds. 

The campaign is just fantastic, and considering how old this installment is, the graphics are commendable to say the least! After god knows how many years of playing this game on and off i still find it one of the best strategy games i've ever played, and it has some pretty cool mods too, so you can carry on even after you've completed all the campaigns, but if you HAVE actually managed that, then i don't know what else you can be doing with your life... 

8/10

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome. Today the most remembered and influential civilization EVER. A small italian state took 500 years to become an ancient nuclear superpower. They were not particularily strong, academic or friendly, Instead they would sit on their back all day and eat, read, take baths, etc. They wanted to show the world how to live. And they did this through a latin-invented word: dicipline. A small, relativley scrawny Roman Legionary would find himself a shoulder's distance away from thousands of clones of his, all with a crapton of armor and a gargantuan shield. Using precise formations, fighting manners, and commands the average Roman could fight beyond his own power. In Rome: Total war you can really get a feel for how this works, fighting in the Campaign to make your own Rome, or other nation or testing your skills in the Multiplayer against real people. Fight as all of the great powers of the time; Rome, Macedon, Gaul, Germania, Brittania, Carthage, Seleucia, Parthia, Egypt, Scythia, and many more against eachother. This truly is the best strategy game ever. And then there is the soundtrack. This game gives you a sense of succes or bitter defeat, and the campaign is unforgiving as real life. If you lost a battle on your frontier, suddenly that army may punch right into your homeland. And it would be you who lost that battle

Go from politician to Emperor. Tribune to Legate. Kingdom, to Empire. Novice, to a near God. Que Usque Roma Ibis, frandulatum?

title: Rome Total War
review:
Although the game is over a decade in age...

With a community of players that age from 14 to 30+, RTW has been one of the most well crafted RTS games to ever grace the gaming community. It has been exposed to some incredible modding, expansions, and tournaments for all sorts of Ancient Warfare Strategists, as well as history enthusiasts, and with its addictive battle-sequences (no matter how outdated), the game has achieved in many people's books the top echelon of strategic gaming.

If you have any sort of fun constructing a nation, but always wanted to try your hand at on-the-field battle command, this is truly the game you should've first tried. The feel and UI make the game relatable and easy to handle by so many different ethnicities/cultures, there's no wonder really as to why this particular game is the most successful of the Total War franchise.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Even today, Rome: Total War takes the cake as the best Total War title. If nothing else sells you, it is important to note that this game almost NEVER crashes. For those of you new to the Total War series, Total War games love to crash, ruining your hours of hard, strategic work and luck.

Rome is extremely well balanced. Territory development, troop training, technology advances, political maneuvers, unit types...it all works together to make a deep, strategic game with no room to blame broken mechanics.

You pick a house of Rome and start conquering things. Many of the problems that the Roman Empire faced are now obstacles for you to crush. You can spend hours getting sucked into this world and attempting to achieve perfection. Each hour is worth it. Learn lessons, get defeated, try again. The true spirit of combat.

Napoleon and Empire were so similar I can't even review them separately.

title: Rome Total War
review:
New to this version of the Total War. I started by playing Empire: Total War. This is a step back in graphics, but you really see where the game comes from. Great mechanics and battles. You play as one of the great Roman families just before the republic fell and became an empire. You do what you want or you follow the senators, either way there is fun to be had. Great game, and the new version that just came out looks even better. 

Basically, you take over cities, manage them by building temples, and food stores, military training and government buildings, then you defend them and grow an empire until you become emperor of the fallen republic. fun game, just like Empire: Total War. Great if you have an older computer (or one not for gaming) and want to play somethign that doesn't use much resources.

review:

The good:

title: Rome Total War
review:
This is perhaps my favorite game that has ever been made. It contains excellent strategy level gameplay along with great tactical level battles. I really cannot recommend this game enough for anyone who enjoys strategy games or even someone who doesn't play games, but enjoys history as the experience is quite immersive. In addition, the game is incredibly moddable and there are a multitude of mods out there (with perhaps the best Roman-era mods being Europa Barbarorum and Roma Surrectum). I cannot state enough how much mods help this game as there is a very dedicated community out there that has developed this game to peak performance; if you don't have mods for this game, you are missing out (though a few campaigns on vanilla is extremely fun).

Highlights
A very broad unit roster (hundreds of units) that allows for diverse and fun battles
A decent AI considering the scope of the game (try adding a formations mod such as Darthmod formations)
MODS (like really, get them)
A family tree system that lets you groom your generals to become leaders of your empire and creates a deeply immersive environment.
A fantastic battle RTS system that is in a category all its own when it comes to RTS games.

title: Rome Total War

title: Rome Total War
review: This is still my favourite of all the Total War games. Simple to pick up, difficult to master and complete with multiple ways of going about the business of creating an empire and slaughtering thousands. The ability to unlock some of the nations you conquer adds to the replayability of the title which I still play from time to time years after its release. A real gem.

title: Rome Total War
review: As the first Total War game I've played, the place of the Rome: Total War in my heart is very special. Vanilla RTW and Barbarian Invasion are great but after all those years (7 actually) the game continues to live with the huge modding community. From Europa Barbarorum to Invasio Barbarorum there are countless mods to play and re-live or create what-if scenarios. I'm not sure what will be the next Total War game, but I am pretty sure RTW will still have its' own hardcore fan base. It is even still possible to find multiplayer matches in the multiplayer mode and since the game isn't new, the players are mature most of the time if not all the time. I'm enjoying my Invasio Barbarorum modification, which takes place through the end of the Western Roman Empire and it's like I am playing a new game. Modders have creatad a new game from the scratch and this is true for most mods out there. A must game for every Ancient history lovers and strategy fans (I don't mean Starcraft players)

title: Rome Total War
review:
Rome: Total War. One of my all-time favorite games. Taking place in the late Roman Republic, you assume control of one of three Roman families vying for power. Depending on which family you select, the Senate will usually direct you against one of three adversaries - the Greeks, the Gauls, or the Carthaginians. The beautiful thing about Total War, however, is you can simply ignore the Senators and go on a campaign of your own... Egyptians? Invade them! Is the Senate demanding you join in on the war against the Macedon, but you'd rather become allies? Go for it! Just make sure you keep a home guard, because Civil War is a constant threat!

It has been almost ten years since Rome's release. It hasn't aged terribly bad - the AI is somewhat atrocious, the graphics are dated, but the game is still genuinely satisfying. At the price Rome goes for during Steam's seasonal sales, there's really no excuse NOT to give this game a try. If nothing else, it is a taste of nostalgia before these types of games became more like movies and less like free-for-all sandboxes!

title: Rome Total War
review:
I know that Rome Total War 2 is out, and that a lot of people like it. If you haven't played the original Rome Total War, then you should. It's excellent, and one of the best strategy games around. It was good enough that they had to made a sequel for it.

Choose from any of the factions from around the world at the time of the Roman Empire, and command a host of different troop types, employing various tactics to beat your enemies. The game features both turn-based strategy and real-time strategy.

A steal when it's on sale.

title: Rome Total War
review: Rome has still its own personality among Total War series: its still nice to play it after the next ones of the series. Its main problem in my opinion is these powerful units with more than one "life point" like general units for example that make it unrealistic for this part and tough to counter. Another problem is the use of gamespy for multi battles, that sometimes show an error when you try to join a hosted game. Else the game in multi give to host more settings to manage than in next games since Empire, giving more the ability to have the battle the host wish without using rules among players, even if these rules are still used in some case, like clan war belt (cwb) rules.

title: Rome Total War
review:
This game is a must have for the strategist, or history nut. Take control of ancient empires, the Romans, Greeks, Macedonians, Gauls, Germanics, each with a hugely different playstyle.

There's a massive campaign, custom battles online; you can take control of historical battles and turn the tide, for example, one of the battles where the Romans were defeated by Hannibal, you can figure out a way to lead the Romans to victory, set right what went wrong, but the game only gives you control at a crucial point, where the Romans are about to be defeated, it's like figuring out chess problems, where you're given a scenario and you're about to be checkmated, but have to find a way to prevent it and still win. It's a really interesting view on ancient warfare, nothing before has given us such an interactive take on it.

My biggest gripe with this game is that the campaign is single player only. It would have been incredible if you could play it online with people. Multiplayer only has custom battles, where you just assemble your own army and fight on a chosen battlefield. Those can however, lead to glorious, to-the-core strategic battles. Check out PrinceOfMacedon's videos if you want a piece of that.

Even once the next RTW comes out, there'll be people going back to this one. It's a beloved game, and now, you can love it too.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Ah, Rome Total War. I've spent a good 7,000 hours into this game over the years. It may be one of the earlier Total War Games but its still very fun. The only issue I have with this game, is in campaign. You see, your cities expand, and the larger they get the more you need to build buildings to expand them. But, when it hits max level, it keeps expanding. Thus, making the city rebel from you because of the fact they can't stop making babies.

But don't get me wrong, I love this game to death. This game is worth every cent. 9/10

title: Rome Total War
review: Rome: Total War is a brilliant RTS, taking your from running your own Empire to the very battlefield itself. The game offers a unique campaign expierence that make hours of time fly by like minutes. Not only does it give a wide array of troops and tactics, but it does the same for the political aspect. You can opt to keep control of your Empire, create peace treaties, start wars, assassinate targets and spy on cities all in the comfort of your chair. Despite being dated, this game still delivers years after it's release.

title: Rome Total War
review: Rome has to be THE Total War game that brought an already successful series into the world of 3D and installment that pretty much defined the series as we know it today. Taking this into account it comes as no surprise that it's still one of the fan favorites thanks to its modding scene still going strong and incredible replayability. There are only two weak points I can think of: AI that would be expanded upon in every subsequent game and artistic freedom when it comes to historical accuracy. A definite recommendation, if for no other reason than to see the origin of modern TW games.

review:
This game needs to be renamed Calvalry Killing Machine 2012. They depict those who ride atop a horse in this game as an unkillable demigod with the power of a thousand suns at their disposal, when they charge into some poor unknowing enemy unit they simply dissapear in a shower of pink mist, leaving on Hiroshima style shadows imprinted on the ground. Don't ever build any foot units or archers, even if you need to scale a wall with ladders or a siege tower, just let the horses run up it (trust me they can if you give them enough hay). 
An amazing horse-based game, would not reccommend playing if you are a pig however.

title: Rome Total War
review: I milked easily 100+ hours out of this beast. One of the best and most addictive RTS ever made. Is no easy walk in the beginning since you really have to manage EVERYTHING from diplomatic relations to army salaries (yeah 200 years BC) but once you get the hold of it there is nothing else stopping you from conquering the world (or europe and north africa in this case) apart from 2000+ men armies, huge stone walls with boiling oil and 20 battalions of archers blocking the sun with their arrows coming at you. YES, it is that much fun! (and I'm not even counting Barbarian Invasion here!)

title: Rome Total War
review: This is one of the best stratagy games that I have ever played. That includes Starcraft 1& 2, Civilization, Age of Empires, and Star Wars Empire at War. In this game your goal is to rule all of the Roman Empire including Rome itself. In order to accomplish this you must expand your factions power base and do missions for the senate to increase your popularity with the Plebians (Peasant people). In the end you attempte to take on the other 2 Roman factions and the Senate itself in an allout quest for the Empire!

title: Rome Total War
review: There are probably hundreds of recommendations for Rome Total War, but I decided to write one as well. Rome Total War by far is one of the best strategy games to ever break into the market. Though the graphics are a little outdated, considering it first came out in 2004, the gameplay, unit selection, campaign, and my personal favorite, Multiplayer are outstanding. One of the best, if not the best game in the Total War series. I would recommend this to anyone who is a lover of Ancient Warfare, Ancient history, military history, and real time strategy games. Even if you dont' like any of those topics, play it anyway, because through this game one may sprout an interest in one of many subjects relating to this games history.

title: Rome Total War
review:
You may struggle to win your battles at first, but when you get used to using the different strategies and when you understand how morale works, it isn't too hard. Winning battles in this game is very satisfying, especially when starting with a disadvantage. Diplomats, spies and assassins can make the war a lot easier, as well as having a good economy and good leaders.

When you finally take over the world, you can mess around with the custom and historical battles. Or you can continue the campaign until you control every region on the map. Either way, there is plenty of content in this game to keep you busy.

title: Rome Total War
review: I haven't played much Shogun 2, but compared to the rest of the series, this is my favorite TW game.  Everything seems to be in balance.  Take your favorite nation available and proceed to conquer the ancient world.  The strategic part of the game is not as skin deep as some would have you believe.  You need to be careful with your economy and the morale of the people to survive much.  The battles are much fun toplay, even though there are a couple of points where you can (but you shouldn't) abuse AI glitches.  The use of special characters is not as annoying as in the Medieval series, where it becomes an annoyance more than fun part of the game.  Great game and eagerly await for a sequel/remake of it some time in the future.

title: Rome Total War
review: Rome: Total War is one of the best Total War games to date, and never gets old. Before I bought this Steam, I played this game for weeks and even after winning the campaign mode, I continued playing it in hopes that I would conquer the entire world with my Roman House. If you want the true Roman experience, look no further than this game. The combat is intense, the soundtrack is amazing, the AI diplomacy isn't as bugging as Empire or Shogun: Total War, and conquering your enemies is fanastic. I HIGHLY recommend this and a must for strategy fans.

title: Rome Total War
review:
Looking for the best RTS game money can buy? then look no further. Rome: Total War is by far one of the greatest games in Total War history with the best balanced gameplay in any Total War game.

You run an empire of choice, first you must unlock other factions as this game is focused on Rome so you are only able to choose from them at first. Beat the main game and you unlock a smattering of factions. Then you can also hack the game files and unlock every other non-playable factions and of course play as them. Great fun.

This game is many years old but the graphics stand the test of time, still pleasing to the eye as well as the first fully 3D Total War game.

The game can range from been easy, to a total nightmare of course that also depends on the players skills. 

Something negative is really, the Rome factions on the higher diffculties are amazingly tough, but they are also overpowerd to play as. Overall amazing game easily a 9.8/10 :) - Dean
